<div class="word-content">
<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></b><b><span
style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>GLOSSARY
OF COMMUNICATION-RELATED TERMS</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-top:0in;text-align:center'><b><span style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-top:0in;text-align:center'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Virgil Warren, PhD</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-top:0in;text-align:center'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-top:0in;text-align:center'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The Glossary of Communication-Related
Terms describes terms and expressions used with language structure, usage, and
writing. It highlights biblical and theological studies, hence, the numerous references
to Greek, Latin, English, Hebrew, and Aramaic. Usages beyond these languages
exist, of course, but they do not usually appear in these entries. This subject
has fuzzy edges because language itself bleeds across into contentinto the surrounding
that it is used to talk about; besides, truth itself is holistic. Language,
oral and written, involves linguistics, hermeneutics; specific languages like English,
Greek, Latin, and Hebrew and their grammars; some issues in New and Old
Testament textual criticism; rhetoric, and writing. With such a breadth of
interest, the material presented stretches at times in the direction of an
encyclopedia.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Words preceded by an asterisk (*) are given
a main listing elsewhere in the glossary in perhaps greater detail, usually in a
main alphabetical heading. (<sup>+</sup>) indicates a word to click on that
will bring up fuller treatments of subjects like zero endings, clauses, and
conditional sentences in Greek or in Latin. <b>VW </b>Words preceded by
asterisks could have a panel open up when they are clicked on, a panel showing
the full treatment and also the same pop-ups as would appear when clicked on
from other documents in the total system.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Where applicable, word meanings include a
comment in contrast to. Ideas are clearest when seen in contrast to their
parallel alternatives. For that reason, we have so entered them here. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Alphabetized entries that are part of a
set have the other members of that set noted beneath them in parentheses. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Derivational origin and the word picture
in a term should be given perhaps at the end of the entry as in many
dictionaries</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Need to indicate part of speech for each
type of usage</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Entries are not capitalized unless they
are proper nouns or proper adjectives.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Entries within entries are entered
alphabetically </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> See further </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>is
the link to more specific application of a general entry, a way of trying to
avoid duplication. Another, more frequently used, device for avoiding undue
duplication is a pop-up for long entries that apply in more than one place. The
procedure is to give a few examples of the point involved and then enter the
pop-up panel (designated <b>[insert panel]</b>) that a person can click on in
each of the entries to get the full list of relevant items.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Use (1), (2), (3) for different sets of
application of words</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>The glossary contains the following subtopics:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> figures of speech (litotes, metaphor,
simile, zeugma, metonymy, trope)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> textual criticism, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> hermeneutics</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> linguistics</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> types of literature (poetry, prose)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> pronunciation, spelling, writing</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>The Glossary contains also the following per-entry
items where applicable: derivational entries, part of speech, in a set with,
duplicate pop-ups that apply to more than one entry,</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Under a potentially huge entry, subsets
can be indicated See __ or*__ . In large entries like case or clauses, the
attempt is made to indixcate characteristic of the matter at the level of the over-all
term with *__ in the comments. The specifics of each case or each clause are
then given alphabetically under the clause name. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Notations about Greek, Latin, Hebrew,
though worded in present tense, do not necessarily describe modern Greek and
modern Hebrew. Notations about Greek distinguish classical from Hellenistic
where they differ, preference being given to the language as it exists in
biblical studies. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> On words that have many current English
usages, only those that are related to communication are included in this
glossary.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>abbreviate/abbreviation: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>used
in writing to shorten a word by using (1) some of its initial letters followed
by a period: ave., st., Abbreviations may also be (2) a collection of
prominent sounds plus period<u>blvd</u>. for boulevard; fnt. for footnote; EGD
for <u>e</u>sophago<u>g</u>astro<u>d</u>uodenoscopy. In a set of words, the abbreviation
may choose initial letters without a period, as in <u>aka</u> for as known
as. The presence or absence of periods after each letter or after the whole
set varies from type to type by custom of usage. All caps for acronyms commonly
do not use periods within or after: NATO, North Atlantic Treaty Organization; EMAW,
Every Man a Wildcat (a KSU slogan).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> An older, less common, form of abbreviating
(3) puts the first and last letters together with a line above them: </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
theta + sigma for <u>theos</u>, the Greek word for God/god. Medical
terminology sometimes uses a superscript line for abbreviations: <i>pc</i> with
a line above it for <u>post cibum</u>, after a meal, after eating, taken with
food; also<i> c</i> for <i>cum </i>(with); <i>pp </i>for <i>post prandial </i>(after
a meal);<i> s</i> for <i>sine </i>(without). First and last letters also are
used in <i>ca</i>. (<i>circa</i>, about).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (4) Plural abbreviations sometimes use a doubled
letter: c. = copy, cc = copies; f. = and the following verse, ff. = the
following verses; ms. = manuscript, mss. = manuscripts; p. = page, pp. </span><span
lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>=
pages; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>PS = post script(um), PPS = a second post
script; v. = verse, vv. = verses; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(in a set with
*acronym, *acrostic, *backronym, *short)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (4) An occasional abbreviation uses a
slash with prominent letters of a word: <i>w/</i> for <i>with</i>; <i>w/o</i>
for <i>without</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>abecedary: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a
listing of the letters of an alphabet</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>abecedarian</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
one who studies or teaches alphabets; by extension, one who is just learning
the a,b,cs of something.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ablative case: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a
grammatical case that implies separation. Ablative appears in Latin after
prepositions implying location or separation. Latin also uses it instead of the
accusative after some verbs that imply separation: examples. In Latin there is
an <u>ablative of attendant circumstance</u> with <u>cum</u> clauses Wh 310</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>and an ablative of <u>degree of difference</u> wh 333.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Ablative case is not identified separately
in the Greek five-case system, but it is in the eight-case analysis. Ablative
value gets split up between the genitive and dative cases in the simpler
analysis.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ablative absolute</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Latin uses an *<u>ablative absolute</u> construction, which consists of the
subject in the ablative case with the verb idea covered by an ablative
participle in the same number and gender as the ablative subject. (in a set
with *genitive absolute, *nominative absolute, accusative absolute, dative
absolute)<b> </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ablative of *degree of difference</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the amount of difference between two things in regard to time, space, weight, <i>etc</i>.
and most of the time involving a *comparative degree adjective or adverb: He
is six years older. Latin puts six years in the ablative case with no
accompanying preposition; the idiom would come into English most nearly as, He
is older <i>by six years</i>. Greek follows the same pattern, using the dative
case. *Degree of difference calls for no special construction in English. Instead
it is covered by an adverb-adjective combination or by using <u>by</u> plus the
measurement: He was six years older; he is older <i>by six years</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *dative of degree of
difference, *degree of difference)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ablative of manner</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Latin, a noun in the ablative preceded often, but not necessarily, by <i>cum</i>;
if the object of <i>cum</i> has a modifier, the <i>cum</i> may be omitted. Even
in this circumstance, however, the author can keep the <i>cum</i> to make clear
that <u>manner</u> is meant rather than <u>means</u>. The means construction
does not have <i>cum</i> ahead of the ablative noun.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>absolute constructions: (1) </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Absolute
constructions are absolute in that they have no grammatical tie to the main
clause. Absolute clauses can replace *adverbial clauses. The condition for
using such a construction is that the subject of this dependent element does
not appear in the main clauseor at least not appear as subject of the main
clause.  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> There is a reason for limiting the
condition of usage to cases where the subject of the dependent element does not
appear in the main clause. If the subject did appear in the main clause, then
it would not need to be re-expressed in the dependent portion of the sentence;
the participle, put in the correct number-gender-case, would connect to the
proper actor in the main clause. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> That said, I want to explain the
problem. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) a verb, adjective, or pronoun that
does not have its normal accompanying words, as in the case of an
unexpressed/implied direct object of a *transitive verb, an adjective without
its accompanying/implied noun, or a pronoun whose noun referent is not given.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *ablative absolute ([Lat.];
*genitive absolute [Gr], *accusative absolute [Gr], *dative absolute [Gr],
*nominative absolute [Eng.]) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>absolute time</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the tense of a verb form viewed from the standpoint of a sentences speaker in
contrast to the time of a dependent verb form relative to the main verb in a
sentence. Another term for *sequence of tense.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *relative time, sequence of
tenses)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>accent</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: emphasis or
stress on a syllable or word; longer English words may have a secondary accent
as well.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English accent rules. Words ending in
tion are accented on the preceding syllable. Two-syllable suffixes are usually
accented on the preceding connecting vowel: thermmeter. But -itis words are
always accented on the *penult; -plasty words carry accent as far toward the
beginning as possible: st</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>matoplasty; -pxy gets penult accent.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Greek accent rules</u>: Accents in
Greek are really tone marks, with acute being a rise tone, grave being a fall
tone, and circumflex being a rise-fall tone. Since these accents are actually
tone marks, they are always written over the <u>vowels</u> of a Greek syllablein
contrast to being written after/above the <u>last letter</u> or before the
first letter of a syllable as in English dictionaries. Accents are considered
part of a words spelling, and so are indicated in typical writingat least in
modern reproductions of ancient documents. On *diphthongs, the accent appears above
the second vowel. On the front of all Greek words, there were also *breathing
marks. If an accent and breathing mark appear together, the breathing mark
precedes the acute or grave and is written under a circumflex. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Fundamental to the placement of Greek
accents is vowel length. The long vowels are eta (</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
and omega (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>); the short ones are
epsilon (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>) and omicron (</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>);
alpha (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>), iota (</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>),
and upsilon (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>) can be long or short
depending on the word. All diphthongs are always long except final -</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
and -</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> outside the *optative (and in the
one word <i>oikoi</i> in classical Greek).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Acute accent in Greek was a rise tone
that could appear on any of the last three syllables. Acute accent could
sustain accent for three syllables, and so could appear on any of the last
three syllables pending further considerations. It could appear on the *antepenult
only if the *ultima (last syllable) contained a short vowel and did not end in
a double consonant; it could appear on the *penult (next-to-last syllable) only
if the conditions for a circumflex were not present, circumflex taking
precedence. It could occur on the *ultima only if punctuation or an *enclitic followed.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Grave accent was a fall tone that appeared
in Greek words only on the last syllable and only if there were words
immediately following that were not enclitics. Grave accent could sustain
accent for only one syllable.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Circumflex accent was a rise-fall tone in
Greek that could appear only on long vowels and only on the last two syllables.
Circumflex accent could sustain accent for two syllables, and so could appear
on either of the last two syllables, pending further considerations. For
circumflex to appear on the next-to-last syllable, the last syllable had to be
short and not end in a double consonant. For circumflex to appear on the last
syllable, the syllable had to be long. Since acute (and grave) could also
appear on the ultima, the circumflex could appear on genitive and dative, but
not on nominative or accusative unless a vowel contraction had called for a
circumflex there (see below under contract rules).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Thus, the length of the ultima was the main
determining factor for <u>Greek</u> accenting patterns</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-top:0in;text-align:center'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Add diagram of accent rules?</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Accents in Greek were either *persistent accents
or *recessive accents. They were persistent on nouns and adjectives generally
and recessive on finite verbs. Persistent meant that the accent stayed on the
same syllable (as counted from the beginning) throughout its inflection unless
the rules for accent placement caused it to move. Strictly speaking, counted
from the beginning is a refinement of the rule because some words picked up a
syllable on the end after passing from the *dictionary form. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> There were some exceptions to the
persistent-recessive generalizations. The <u>ma</u> nouns of the third
declension were recessive in the nominative and then persistent thereafter. Monosyllable
nouns of the third declension picked up another syllable outside the nominative
singular, and formed a pattern with acutes on the last syllable of genitives
and datives and acutes on first syllable of nominatives, accusatives (and
vocatives). Nouns of the first and second declension that have accented ultimas
bear a circumflex on the genitive and dative singular and plural and bear an
acute (to grave shift) on nominative, accusative, and vocative.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Finite verbs (and most *infinitives and
*participles) had *recessive accents, meaning that the accents moved as much as
three syllables toward the front of the wordas far as the length of the ultima
would allow. Many infinitives and participles used recessive accents as well,
but some were distinctiveas the second aorist active infinite, which bore a
circumflex on the ultima (-</span><u><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>);
the perfect active infinitive, which bore an accent on the *penult (-</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>);
or the aorist passive infinitive, which bore a *circumflex on the *penult (-</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>).
Since infinitives and participles are kinds of adjectives and nouns, departures
from the recessive accent rule on some of those forms does not really stand at
odds with the basic generality.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Baritone</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Baroxitone </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Accent could not precede *augment, a
feature occasioned by prepositions prefixed to verbs: </span><u><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></u><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
but </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>. Indeed, most of the time, an accent
does not move back onto the prepositional prefix regardless of augment. Exceptions
include </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In instances of vowel contraction, accents
are first figured on the uncontracted form. If basic accent rules put an acute
on the contract vowel, the resulting contraction bears a circumflex. In the
other contract situations, the accent is retained accordingly after
contraction.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Enclitics are words pronounced with the
preceding word. As a result, if they can, they throw their accent away; if they
cannot thrown it away, they throw it back onto the ultima of the preceding
word; if they cannot thrown it back, they keep it. The accent they throw back
is an acute, regardless of what the accent would have been on the theoretical
form. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Basic to figuring out how enclitic
accenting works is the ability of each kind of accent to sustain accent. An
acute can sustain for three syllables; a circumflex for two; a grave for one.
If the accent on the preceding word can sustain through the enclitic, the
enclitic has no accent. If the preceding accent cannot sustain accent that far,
then the enclitics accent can throw back an acute onto the ultima unless doing
so puts acutes on successive syllables, in which case, the accent stays on the
enclitic. If an enclitic appears first in its clause, it keeps its accent (since
there is no preceding word to receive it). One exception to the enclitic accent
rule is the practice in editions of the Greek Bible of allowing a previous
ultima circumflex to sustain accent through a two-syllable enclitic (Acts <b>5</b>:39).
Normally the ability of that circumflex to sustain accent would carry it
through only the first syllable of the subsequent enclitic.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The enclitic </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>becomes
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(first syllable accent) if it is first in the sentence, if it signifies
existence or possibility (<i>vs</i>. being a linking verb), or if it follows <i>ei</i>,
<i>ouk</i>, <i>kai</i>, <i>touto</i>, or <i>hoos</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The New Testament enclitics are </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/<i>mou</i>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/<i>moi,
</i></span><i><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></i><i><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/me </span></i><i><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/sou,
</span></i><i><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></i><i><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/soi, </span></i><i><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/se;
</span></i><i><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></i><i><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span></i><i><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>//tis/ti;
</span></i><i><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></i><i><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/pote, </span></i><i><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/pou,
</span></i><i><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></i><i><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/poo, </span></i><i><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/poos;
</span></i><i><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></i><i><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/ge, </span></i><i><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/te</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>;
all the present indicative forms of the verb <i>to be</i> except second
singular (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/<i>ei</i>); and the
present indicative forms of </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/<i>pheesi</i>
(all of them?).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Proclitics have no accent of their own; they
are pronounced with the following word. They can have an accent only if they
appear last in their clause (that is, before punctuation) or if an enclitic
follows. If a proclitic is followed by an *enclitic, encliltic rules take
precedence; a proclitic can receive an accent from an enclitic, but not vice
versa. If two or more proclitics appear together, none of them bears an accent.
New Testmanet Greek proclitics are <i>eis, en, ek/ex (preps.), ho/hee/hoi/hai </i>(the
nom. mas &amp; fem sg art)<i>, ou/louk/ouch </i>(neg.),<i> ei hoos </i>(conjs.).
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Latin accent rules</u>: The penult of a
word with three or more syllables drew the accent if it contained a long vowel
or led into the next syllable with two or more consonantsincluding the double
consonant <u>x</u>. Otherwise, accent went back to the antepenult if there was
one.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Thus, the length of the penult was the main
determining factor for <u>Latin</u> accent patterns.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Hebrew accent rules</u>: Hebrew words bear
primary accents only on the last two syllables with accenting most frequently
on the last syllable. Segholate nounsthose with a seghol (short e) in the
penultcarry an accent on the penult. Verbs with pronominal suffixes likewise
have penult accents, and nouns with possessive pronominal suffixes have
penultimate accents in most situationsexcept for the heavy endings of
masculine and feminine second and third person plural. This same last pattern
occurred with inseparable prepositions that carried pronominal suffixes.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Disjunctive accents (WG 251) in the pointed
text of the Hebrew Bible indicate separation or pause. *Conjunctive accents indicate
continuation and unity (phrasing) between words.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>accentuated verse</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>acceptance speech</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an elected or selected candidates traditional public response to being chosen
for an office of important position. (in a set with *concession speech)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>accidence: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>the
structural<b> *</b>inflection of words short of alterations that would change
the *part of speech or create *cognates; hence, changes relative to number,
gender, and case (*nouns and *adjectives); *person, *number, *tense, *voice,
*mood, and *aspect (verbs). The kinds of changes that take place within a
words complete *paradigm. Contrasts with *vocabulary, *syntax, and *word
building. A subdivision of morphology. (in a set with *morphology, *morpheme.
*paradigm, *synopsis)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>accusative case: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>*Accusative
case is the terminology used in Greek and Latin for the objective function.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>Same as the objective case in English-language
terminology, the case that is used after all *prepositions and *transitive
verbs. English, however, analyzes as direct objects words in Greek that involve
relationship (follow, hepomai, akol</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>utheo)
 </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *nominative case, *genitive
case, *dative case, *instrumental case, *locative case, *ablative case,
*vocative case)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>account</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a record of a
real event. Account implies the actuality of the event in contrast to *story</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>accusative absolute</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a rather rare Greek construction in the New Testament that uses an accusative-noun
plus *participle as the *absolute construction. It occurs in Acts <b>26</b>:3;
Rom <b>8</b>:3; 1 Cor <b>16</b>:6; Eph<b> 1</b>:18.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>accusative case:</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Accusative
case equals objective case in English terminology. Accusative is used for (1) *direct
objects of most verbs, (2) *objects of all prepositions in English and many
Latin and Greek prepositions, especially those implying destination; as (3) subjects
of *infinitives (= English, Greek, Latin), (4) on time words to indicate
duration of time, and on space words to indicate extent of distance. In its use
to indicate extent of time or space in English, Greek, or Latin no accompanying
preposition is needed: He walked (for) four miles; he walked (for) four
hours. Accusative case applies as well to (5) a *retained object, that is, the
noun left over when an indirect object becomes the subject of the passive
transform: She gave the poor dog <u>a bone</u>; the equivalent passive
transform is The poor dog was given <u>a bone </u>[RO] (See also *accusative
absolute, adverbial accusative, *double accusative). Accusative case applies to
(6) an objective (OC) as in They elected him <u>president</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>accusative of extent of time</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek and Latin the accusative case on a time word indicates extent of time.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>accusative of extent of space</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek the accusative case on a distance term indicates the extent of
distance.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>accusative pendens</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a hanging construction that double-references the direct object in the main
clause: What the Fates bringwe will endure it with a calm mind. WH 215 #11.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>acknowledgements</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a listing of people or companies whose assistance the author appreciates in
producing a published work</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>acronym: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a
sequence of letters formed by the first letter of a series of words such as the
name of an organization. Acronyms are written in all caps without spaces: FEMA.
The government and the military have many such acronyms for identities within
the system. OSHA stands for <u>O</u>ccupational <u>S</u>afety and <u>H</u>ealth
<u>A</u>dministration. UNUS NAUTA is a helpful acronym for remembering the
group of nine Latin adjectives that decline irregularly with ius in all three
genders of the genitive singular, i in all three genders of the dative
singular, and may show ud in the neuter nominative singular. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *abbreviation, *acrostic, *backronym,
*short, *stand for) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>acrostic</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a sequence in
which the first part of each element begins with a successive letter of a word,
name, motto, or the alphabet. Songs like <u>M-O-T-H-E-</u>R and <u>C-H-R-I=S-T-M-A-S</u>
illustrate the idea. Cp. Ps <b>119</b>, other OT examples</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>act</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a major division of a
play, one level above scene </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>acts</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a chronicle of a
person or related group of persons. In the New Testament, <i>Acts of the
Apostles</i> is the second volume in Lukes two-volume work on the origins of
Christianity. The second document (<i>Acts/Praxes</i>) became a *genre copied
by sub-apostolic writers as in the case of <i>The Acts of Paul and Thecla</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>action verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb that refers to action in contrast to one that equates or indicates
identity.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>active verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:<b>
</b>a verb that shows action; a verb in the active voice</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>active voice</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the kind of verb where the subject does the acting in the verb. Contrasts with
a verb whose subject receives the action (passive voice) and with a
*state-of-being verb (a to be verb), which does not deal with action at all
but with linking/identification. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *middle voice, *passive
voice; *fientive verb; *stative verb; *state-of-being verb = *equative verb =
*copulative verb = *linking verb = *to be verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>actual result</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the result that in fact came from the action in the main verb. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *tendential result)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>acute accent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a mark slanting up to the right ( </span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>). It occurs on
some English words to show that a final <i>e</i> is a separate syllable and
that in any position the <i>e</i> has an <i>ay</i> sound as in <i>day: attach,
blas, caf, clich, communiqu, consomm, crudits, distingu, enceint, entre,
expos, fianc, fiance, habitu, ne, outr, pass, risqu, touch; adlie </i>(penguins)<i>,dtente,
clat, lan, prcis. </i>Two acutes appear on <i>rsum, protg, dcollet,
dclass.</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek spelling, an acute indicates a
rise tone, which could appear on any of the last three syllables of a word,
conditions permitting. For a full layout of Greek accent rules, see *accent. The
same symbol can mark a long vowel (Czech), an accented vowel (Spanish), or a
vowel that is close or tense (French). WB </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *grave accent, *circumflex
accent; *diacritical marks)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ad feminam</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
appealing to an irrelevant personal consideration when talking about women
webster. Same as *ad hominem but in a circumstance that deals with a woman.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ad hominem argument</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
An argument to the man plays on consistency with what the other man has previously
said in an argument and does so in a way that supports the respondents position;
a kind of consistency argument. Appealing to some personal consideration when
speaking rather than to reason or logic (Webster) Lk <b>19</b>:22-23, I will
judge you out of your own mouth (Parable of the Pounds; cp. Parable of the
Talents, Mt <b>25</b>:26-27)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ad lib</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (cp. *extemporary,
*off-the-cuff) short for ad libitum</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ad verbum</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
word for word, verbatim [Latin: to the word]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>adage</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In a set with
*proverb, *maxim, saying*)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>address</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) to speak to
an audience in a deliberate way. (2) to speak to a person using a formal name. (3)
As a noun, <i>address</i> can be used as a more general term alongside *speech
, *sermon, and the like. (in a set with *sermon, *speech)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>adenoidal</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having the sound of someone who has enlarged adenoids</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>adjective</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word that modifies a substantivea noun; a word in Latin and Greek that is
tied to a noun by sharing its number, gender, and case. Since English does not
*decline its adjectives, placement determines the fact that a word is in fact
an adjective. Adjective slots are before nouns and on the other side of linking
verbs and modify the subject. An adjective that appears immediately after a
*direct object is called an *objective complement: The experience left her <u>sad</u>.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English adjectives and nouns, for the most
part, are not declined for number, gender, case. That fact has set up the
possibility of putting what are normally nouns in slots that are used for
adjectives: That piece of guitar music takes lots of practice. Linguistically
<i>guitar</i> serves as an adjective even though it is thought of basically as
a noun. Such a use of nouns can actually be double or tripled: The
double-glass living room picture window is six feet by three and a half. The
growing tendency to use nouns this way creates an air of greater
sophistication in communication.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Adjectives in Latin and Greek have endings
that identify them by number, gender, and case. These three factors have to
*agree with the noun they modify so the hearer/reader can know they are in fact
modifying that noun.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew adjectives are tied to nouns by
appearing after them and by sharing the article with articular nouns. In
classical Hebrew, adjectives were not plentiful; so that role was compensated
for by putting a noun in the construct, followed by another noun that covered
the idea an adjective would have carried: a man-of God = a godly man. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *attributive adjective, *attributive
position [Gr], *predicate adjective, *predicate position [Gr], reflexive-possessive
adjectives, *substantive adjective, *interrogative adjective, *possessive
adjective, *comparison of adjectives)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>adjectival clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a clause that modifies a noun in the same way that an adjective does. Most
relative clauses are adjectival as are Latins relative clauses and *relative
clauses of characteristic.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>adjective complement</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a modifier that immediately follows a direct object: Drink your milk; it will
make you <u>strong</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>adverb</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a word that can
modify a verb, adjective, or another adverb. In English sentence structure, the
place before the subject is adverbial and so can the place be before the verb.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Associated
with adverbs are time, means, manner, cause, condition, concession, attendant
circumstance, aspect, purpose, result, accompaniment, location; that is, they
are associated with what characterizes action. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Adverbs often have no recurrent endings
and usually have endings distinctive from other parts of speech. Frequently adverbs
of manner are derived from adjectives. English adds <i>ly</i> to <u>adjectives</u>
to make corresponding adverbs of this sort: quick &lt; quickly, <i>etc.</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Not all -<u>ly</u> words, however, are (always)
adverbs: <i>bodily, brotherly</i>, <i>churchly</i>, <i>comely</i>, <i>costly</i>,
<i>courtly</i>, <i>cowardly<sup>1</sup></i><sup> </sup>(lion)<i>, creaturely</i>,
<i>daily</i>, <i>dastardly </i>(deed)<i>, </i>(<i>daughterly), earthly</i>, <i>easterly,
elderly, fatherly</i>, <i>friendly</i>, <i>gamely</i>, <i>gangly</i>, <i>ghostly</i>,
<i>godly</i>, <i>grandfatherly</i>, <i>grandmotherly, gravelly</i>, <i>heavenly</i>,
<i>homely</i>, <i>hourly</i>, <i>husbandly, kingly</i> [crown], <i>leisurely, lively</i>,
<i>lonely</i>, <i>lordly, lovely, maidenly, manly</i>, <i>matronly (air), miserly,
monthly, motherly</i>, <i>neighborly, nightly</i>, <i>northerly, orderly, portly</i>,
<i>priestly,</i> <i>princely</i>, <i>quarterly</i>, <i>queenly</i> [pose], <i>saintly</i>,
<i>scholarly, shapely, sickly</i>, <i>sisterly</i>, <i>southerly, stately</i>, <i>unearthly,
ungodly unseemly</i>, <i>unsightly</i>, <i>unworldly</i>, <i>weekly</i>, <i>westerly,
wifely), wizardly, </i>(womanly), <i>worldly, yearly</i>. Most adjectival ly words
are based on <u>nouns</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Some ly words can be adjective or adverb:
<i>cowardly, daily</i>, <i>early</i>, <i>hourly, monthly</i>, <i>only</i>, <i>quarterly</i>,
<i>weekly</i>, <i>yearly</i>. Many of this type are time words.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In fine, -ly makes nouns into adjectives
and adjectives into adverbs.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek, adverbs of manner can be the
same as the accusative neuter <u>singular</u> of the corresponding adjective in
comparative degree and the accusative neuter <u>plural</u> of the superlative
degree. In the positive degree especially, Greek often uses an adjectives or
participles neuter genitive plural neuter with <i>oon</i> changed to <i>oos</i>.
Neuter accusative singular of the positive-degree adjective is also used for
the adverb. The dative case form can be adopted as a form for adverbs as well: 
(Mt <b>1</b>:19). Greek sometimes uses adjectives in places where English
expects adverbs:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin often forms *positive degree adverbs
from corresponding adjectives by dropping the #/g/c ending of first-second
declension adjectives and replacing it with : bon-us &lt;ben-, pulcher &lt;
pulchr; tarde &lt; tardus, male &lt; malus. The adjective *superlative ending
<i>issim-us</i> does the same thing, becoming <i>issim</i>. Positive-degree
adjectives of the third declension can become adverbs by adding <i>iter</i> to
the base: <i>grav-is &lt; grav-iter</i>. (If the base ends with <i>nt</i>,
only <i>er</i> is added: <i>sapiens &gt; sapienter</i>.) Third-declension
comparative adjectives can be turned into comparative adverbs by re-using the
neuter accusative singular: gravius &lt; gravius.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>adverbial accusative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In classical Greek, a word or phrase in the accusative that is not a direct
object of the verb may have an adverbial value (C &amp; Shafer, 142)  I want
to go <u>home</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>adverbial clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a clause that connects conceptually with, or modifies, the main verb. English introductory
adverbial clauses are examples because the slot before the main subject is an
adverbial one. Other examples are *adverbial clauses, *adversative clauses,
*causal clauses, *circumstantial clauses, *conditional clauses, *concessive
clauses, *fear clauses, *proviso clauses, *purpose clauses, *result clauses,
*temporal clauses.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>adverbial conjunction</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word that serves both to connect main clauses in a compound sentence and to modify
the verbal sense of the sentence. Also *adverbial connective or *transitional
expression.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>adverbial connective</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an alternate term for <u>adverbial conjunction</u>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>adverbial noun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a noun or adjective-noun combination modifying an adjective: <u>six inches</u>
taller; He went <u>home</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>adversative clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another term for *concessive clause</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>advice/advise: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a
directive based in the <u>nature of things</u> rather than in the <u>authority
of the essential author</u>. As a result, it may be a general guideline rather
than an absolute requirement or prohibition. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *commandment, *proverb) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>affectionate term</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
An expression indicating a feeling of closeness. In English there are <i>Bab(y)</i>,<i>
Babe, Bud(dy)</i>,<i> Hon(ey)</i>,<i> Honey bunch, Sug(ar)</i>, <i>Suger Pie,
Sweets, Sweetie Pie, </i>Same as *endearment term.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>affix: </span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>an addition to a
word that adjusts its meaning as to number, tense, person (in a set with
*prefix, *infix, *suffix, *epenthesis, *morpheme) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>afterthought</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an expression attached to the end of a sentence: so to speak. An afterthought
may be a longer statement at the end of a persons main presentation. Gregg 17</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>agency</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: An agent is a
person that causes something to happen. Agency contrasts with *means in that
the latter is the instrument by which the former brings about the result. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) Agency can be expressed by the <u>subject
of an active verb</u>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) Agency can be expressed by the <u>object
of a preposition</u> in a passive verb construction. In English, <u>by</u>
fulfills that role: The book was written <u>by</u> my wife. In Latin, <u>ab</u>
+ the ablative case does the same thing (*ablative of agent). In Greek, <u>hypo</u>
+ the genitive is the most common construction although <u>apo</u> + genitive
also appears in the New Testament (Acts <b>4</b>:36). Especially under the
influence of Hebrew idiom, <u>dia</u> + genitive occurs with persons for agency
(as well as with things for *means). In so doing, it parallels the Hebrew idiom
<u>min</u> + noun<b>.????? </b>In the King James translation, the <u>hypo</u> +
genitive construction is translated <u>of</u> + accusative, a rather unnatural
phrase in modern English: <b>EXAMPLE</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) Agency in Latin is covered by a <u>dative-case</u>
noun (*dative of agent) when used with the passive periphrastic construction (*gerundive).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (4) Agency is also expressed by <u>suffixes</u>
in English (<u>-er</u>), Latin (<u>tor</u>), and Greek (<u>-tes</u>). In
English <u>ist</u> can be reserved for a specialist, as in a medical field. Such
a thing happens particularly if there can be an <u>er<b> </b></u>and <u>ist</u>
in the same area of work: radiographer <i>vs.</i> radiologist.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Agency is often limited to personal agency
(especially in Latin, George Washington), which then contrasts with means for
impersonal instrument (hatchet): The cherry tree was cut down <i>by George
Washington</i> <u>with a hatchet</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>agenda</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a list of items
to be addressed, especially in a committee meeting </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>agglutinative/agglutination</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the formation of words from morphemes that retain their original forms and
meanings when combination. An agglutinative language that splices *morphemes, together
with little or no change in the process. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *inflectional language, *incorporative
language, *isolating language)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>agreement</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Agreement, or *concord, shows that words belong together. Agreement and
*government are the two kinds of inflectional indicators for relationship
between words. Government causes another word to take a required form;
agreement makes two forms alike. As to agreement, there is concord (1) between adjective
and noun, shown by shared number, gender, and case. There is also concord (2)
between subject and verb in person and number (and gender in Hebrew second- and
third-person verbs). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Adjective-noun.</u> In general, English
does not show (1) adjective-noun agreement , or <u>concord</u>, by using inflection,
or form, to connect them. Instead, it uses position, or <u>distribution</u>;
certain slots in certain formats indicate that a word is an adjective and that it
connects with (*modifies) a certain noun in each format: (a) immediately before
the noun (*attributive adjective): the <u>red</u> boat, a <u>red</u> boat; she
has given <u>serious</u> effort to preparing this report. (b) on the other side
of a *linking verb (*predicate adjective): the boat is <u>red</u>; a cow is <u>four-legged</u>;
money is <u>precious</u>. (c) as a *subject complement: The bird sat there <u>fat</u>
and <u>sassy</u>. (d) as an objective complement: Traveling eight hundred miles
made us <u>tired</u>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English demonstratives afford the one
exception to the rule that English does not inflect adjectives: <i>this/these
