boat/boats, that/those boat/boats</i>. The alteration of forms with possessive
adjectives [<i>my/mine, our/ours, your/yours, his, her/hers, its, their/theirs</i>]
is not a matter of agreement, but distribution: the first in each pair is an
*attribute adjective (<i>my book</i>) while the second is a predicate adjective
(<i>The book is <u>mine</u></i>). <b>Older English usage</b> is used as of word
meaningin this case number and/or gender reference.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Subject-verb.</u> Agreement between (2)
English subject and verb is shown again by position/distribution for the most
part. Modern English verbs have lost person-number endings except for third
person singular present indicative active: -<i>s</i>, as in He work<i><u>s</u></i>.
Older English personal endings are commonly found today only in the King James
Bible (and other old translations) and in Shakespeare: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  </span><span lang=FR
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>1sg
-- 1 pl --</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>  <b>2sg <u>est</u></b> 2pl
--</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>  </span><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>3sg
<u>eth</u></span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> 3pl --</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>The verb to be has retained special inflection in
the present and past indicative. Personal pronouns have special inflection as
well; so it makes sense to think about *concord in the limited circumstance of
pronoun subjects and this main linking verb: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  I am we
are </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  you are (thou art) you
are (ye are) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  he/she/it is they
are</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>   I was we
were</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  you were (thou wert) you
were (ye were)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  he/she/it was (wast) they
were</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Cases of *<u>hendiadys</u> in the subject
position normally carry singular verbs: The <u>God and Father</u> of our Lord
Jesus Christ <u>is</u> a God of love (cp. 1 Th <b>1</b>:3).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In linking-verb sentences, the subject,
not the predicate noun, determines the number and person in the verb: Books
are my security blanket; the distance is seven miles. The perfect and
imperfect <u>tenses</u> in Hebrew are really completed and uncompleted <u>action</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin, Greek, and English, a plural
*word used as a word has a singular verb and singular modifier: <i>This </i><u>foolish
ones</u><i> </i>describe<i><u>s</u></i> the monkeys.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A compound singular subject carries a
plural verb: <i>Jim and Alecia</i> <u>were</u> married Thursday.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Since not all words ending in <i>s</i> are
plural, we say, Linguistics <u>is</u> a fascinating study.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Collective nouns in American English take
singular verbs: The <i>committee</i> <u>is</u> meeting now.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek has formal indicators for adjective-noun
and subject-verb agreement. (1) Adjective-noun agreement calls for shared *number,
*gender, *case. Number is singular or plural (or *dual in classical Greek
poetry). Gender is masculine, feminine, or neuter. Greek, in the *five-case
analysis/system, has nominative, genitive, dative, accusative, and vocative. (*Eight-case
analysis/system identifies nominative, genitive, dative, instrumental,
locative, ablative, accusative, and vocative.) Since adjectives and nouns each
use more than one ending set for their own number-gender-case indicators,
agreement does not necessarily mean that the letters of the endings will be the
same as the modified noun; it means, rather, that the number-gender-case
agreement, however indicated by either the adjective or the noun, will exist
even if the two use different spellings for it. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Since all nouns have grammatical gender, a
problem arises if two nouns of different genders are modified by the same
adjective. In that case, since the adjective cannot have both genders at once, it
takes the gender of the nearest noun. (An alternative solution may be to invoke
the principle that masculine takes precedence.) A similar problem comes up if
one adjective modifies two nouns of difference number. Again, the adjective
takes the number of the nearest noun.  This later situation appears in
Acts <b>5</b>:21: The high priest, coming, (mas/sg/ptc) and the-ones with him
assembled the Sanhedrin. Cp. Latin: <i>your great vaults and treachery</i>: <i>magna
vitia</i> (acc/neut/pl) <i>insidiasque</i> (acc/f/pl) <i>tuas</i> (acc/f/pl).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Some Greek adjectives cover the masculine
and feminine gender with the same form and use a separate form for the neuter. All
the *alpha private adjectives (a-/an-) are this way: <i>agamos, agenealogeetos/on,
agnoostos/on, agrammatos/on, adeelos/on, adiabatos/on, adiakritos/on,
adialeiptos/on, adikos/on, adokimon/on, adunatos/on, adusbastoktos/on,
azumos/on, athemitos/on, atheos/on, athesmos/on, atheeios/on, aidios/on, (aischros/ee/on
= exception?), aiphnidios/on, aioonios/on, akarthrtos/on, akakos/on,
akarpos/on, akatagnoostos/on, akatalustos/on, akatastatos/on, akeraios/on,
akoimeetos/on, akratos/on, alaleetos/on, alalos/on, alogos/on,
(amarantinos/ee/on?exception), amarantos/on, amartupos/on, amachos/on,
amemptos/on, amerimnos/on, ametathetos/on, a,atekrineetos/on, ametanoeetos/on,
ameetoop, amiantos/on, amoomeetos/on, amoomos/on, anaitios/on, ,
anamarteetos/on, anantirreetos/on, anaxios/on, anapologeetos/on,
anarithmeetos/on, anegkleetos/on, anekdieegeetos/on, aneklaleetos/on,
anekleiptos/on, aneleeemoon/on, aneleos/on, anendektos/on, anexerauneetos/on,
anepaischuntos/on, anepileemptos/on, aneuthetos/on, aneemeros/on, aniptos/on,
anoeetos/on, anomos/on, anosios/on, antitupos/on, anudros/on, anupokritos/on,
anupotaktos/on, aopatos/on, apaideutos/on, aptaistos/on, osaparabatos/on,
aparaskeuastos/on, apatoor, apeirastos/on, apeiros/on, aperantos/on,
aperitmeetos/on, apistos/on, apobleetos/on, aprositos/on, aproskopos/on,
araphos/on, arreetos/on, asaleutos/on, asbestos/on, aseemos/on, asitios/on,
asophos/on, aspilos/on, aspondos/on, aseeriktos/on, astorgos/on, asumphonos/on,
asunetos/on, asunthetos/on, ascheemoon/on, ataktos/on, ateknos/on, atimos/on,
atomos/on, atopos/on, </i>authairetos/on, aphantos/on, aphthartos/on,
aphilogathos/on, aphilarguros/on, acharistos/on, acheiropoieetos/on,
achreios/on, achreetos/on, apsuchos/on. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek third-declension adjectives are
two-ending adjectives. One group of these is <i>-ees/es: agenees/es, aischrokerdees/es,
aklinees/es, akribees/es, aleethees/es, alusitelees/es, amathees/es,
anoophelees/es, apeithees/es, asebees/es, asthenees/es, asphalees/es,  authadees/es,
autarkees/es, aphanees/es, apsudees/es; note also arseen/en.</i> Another group
of third-declension Greek adjectives is oown/on, many of which are
comparative-degree: soophroon/on, aphroow/on, elassoon/on, kreissoon/om,
pleioon/on, meizoon/on, eessoon/on, cheiroon/on</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In addition to third-declension
adjectives, some, but not all (agapeetos/ee/on, diabatos/ee/on) adjectives
created from the sixth principal part of verbs show tos/-on, whether
alpha-privative or not: apodektos/on, apokrupos/on, artigenneetos/on, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek has (2) person-number ending sets on
its verbs, endings that have to agree with the person of the subject in each
case. Verbs of the first and second person singular and plural usually do not
also have subjects expressed. (If they do have them expressed, the subjects are
pronouns in agreement with the number and person in the verb and imply
emphasis). Most of the time, verbs in the third person, however, have separately
expressed subjects, which have to agree with the number in the verb. All nouns
have a third person reference; consequently, if a noun subject is used, the
verb needs to be a third-person form in the correct number. There are times, of
course, when third-person verbs have no noun subjects. In such cases, the
ending on the verb can be translated with an English pronoun.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The classical rule for neuter-gender words
was that they always used singular verbs, whether the nouns were singular of
plural. That practice is not uniform in the New Testament, but there are places
where neuter plural nouns have singular verbs: Acts<b> 5</b>:12 has two neuter
plural nouns tied to a singular verb. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A *collective noun in the singular may
take a plural verb: Lk <b>19</b>:37</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Compound subjects may take verbs in the
number of the nearest noun rather than a plural verb at all times (as in
English), but note Mt <b>6</b>:19 (also so worded in English translation: thine
<u>is</u> the kingdom, and the power, and the glory; the verb comes before
the subjects in the Greek and the English here); Jn <b>19</b>:26; 1 Cor <b>3</b>:8.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin has indicators for adjective-noun
and subject-verb agreement. Adjectives are singular if they modify two or more
singular nouns, but verbs are plural with two or more singular subjects. There
is an exception to this rule noted in Martial <b>8</b>.1, where two singulars
have a singular verb: Lector et auditor nostros probat, Aule, libellos.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Adjectives of the third declension use the
same form for the masculine and neuter. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew does not have case, just number and
two genders: masculine and feminine). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>Hebrew also has gender in verbs of the second and
third person. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A singular subject takes a singular verb;
two singular subjects take a plural verb in English, Latin, Greek, and Hebrew. There
are some departures from the pattern in the Greek of the New Testament. Acts<b>
4</b>:32 has two singular subjects with a singular verb. The same thing happens
in 1 Pet <b>4</b>:11 (see NASV). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Same as *concord. (in a set with *government)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>aka</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: abbreviation/acronym
for <u>a</u>lso <u>k</u>nown <u>a</u>s. (in a set with *alias, *pen name,
*pseudonym)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Aktionzart</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another word for *aspect. (in a set with *tense, *voice, *mood, *number,
*person)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>album</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: see webster</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>alcaic stanza </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>type
of poetic meter wh 340</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>aleph</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the first letter
of the Hebrew alphabet. Sometimes said to be silent, it is really a glottal
stop, equivalent to the smooth breathing in Greek and the <i>h</i> in <i>h</i>onor,
<i>h</i>eir, <i>etc.</i>: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:14.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>alexandrine</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a line of English verse in iambic hexameter with a caesura after the third
foot. A line of French verse with twelve syllables and a caesura after the
sixth syllable. Webster quote</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>alias: </span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>whereas <u>alias</u>
refers to an assumed name without further limitation, *pen name is associated
with claims of written authorship; the same can be said for the most part about
*pseudonyms, except that <i>pseudonym</i> may imply an intent to deceive. (in a
set with allonym, *pseudonym, *pen name, *aka) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>all caps</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: spelling a word
or *acronym with all capital letters instead of using a capital as first letter
and *small letters thereafter. (in a set with *capitals, *upper case, *lower
case, small letters, *higher case; see also majuscules, minuscules)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>allegorize a comparison</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to carry the parallels between image and fact farther than the author intended</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>allegory: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a
story whose elements parallel closely the parts of some lesson. The effort is
to establish some point of comparative meaning with each aspect of the story. Faery
Queen is an extended allegory. The Parable of the Tares approaches the nature
of an allegory (Mt <b>13</b>:24-30, 36-43). (in a set with *parable, *fable) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>alliteration/alliterative/alliterate</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having the same noticeable sound in successive or nearly successive elements. The
recurrent sound may be at the beginning, middle, or end of close words or on the
front of first words in an outline or poem: How a<u>b</u>out that <u>b</u>ig <u>b</u>aby
<u>b</u>oy in the <u>b</u>assinet. <u>P</u>at has been <u>p</u>raised, <u>p</u>am<u>p</u>ered,
and a<u>pp</u>reciated way too long.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>allocution</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a formal, authoritative speech. (in a set with<b>)</b> Webster</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>allograph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) alternative ways of making the same letter (capital Q and like a 2); (2) two
*digraphs for the same sound (f, gh, ph)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>allomorph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a parallel or equivalent form of a morpheme. <b>allonym</b>: a writers name
assumed from another historical person (webster) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *alias, *aka, *pen name,
*pseudonym)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>allophone</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a patterned sound variant like initial <i>t</i>s and <i>p</i>s (<i><u>t</u>op</i>
and <i><u>p</u>ot</i>), which are aspirated in English, in contrast to their unaspsirated
medial equivalents (<i>t</i>s and <i>p</i>s as in <i>s<u>t</u>op</i> and <i>s<u>p</u>ot</i>.
The letter <i>n</i> represents both the <i>n</i> sound and the <i>ng</i> sound,
depending on circumstance: fu<u>n</u>gus [<i>ng</i>], but <i>fu<u>n</u>ji</i>
[n]. Ahead of gutturals (<i>g</i> as guh, <i>k</i>, <i>c</i> as <i>k</i>, <i>ch</i>
as <i>k</i>) it has an <i>ng </i>value<i>,</i> a velar nasal; elsewhere it is <i>n</i>,
a dental nasal: <i>ran</i> but <i>rank/rancor/fungus</i>. Voiced and unvoiced
letters often represent each: <i>t</i> and <i>d</i> (rippe<u>d</u>), <i>b</i>
and <i>p</i>, <i>k</i> and <i>g</i>, <i>th</i> for <i>th</i> and <i>dh</i>
(bath and bathe), <i>c</i> covers <i>k</i> and <i>s </i>sounds</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek gamma has a regular <i>guh</i> sound
in all cases except where it appears ahead of another velar (</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,),
where it becomes an <i>ng </i>sound.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin urbs <i>b</i> is <i>p</i> before
terminal <i>s</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>allusion/allude</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a light or indirect reference to another written, or perhaps oral, source. An
allusion contrasts with a quotation by picking up only some of the verbiage or
by using entirely different terms for the event or concept. (in a set with
*citation, *quotation, *reference)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>alpha</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: first letter of
the Greek alphabet</span><span dir=RTL></span><span lang=HE dir=RTL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=RTL></span>:</span><span dir=LTR></span><span lang=HE style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span dir=LTR></span>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
transliterated </span><span style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>alpha privative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the prefix <i>a-</i> (<i>an</i>-before vowels) that negates the root: <i>adiaphora
</i>(indifferent matters)<i>, amoral, asymtomatic, *asyndeton, atemporal, <u>a</u>theist,
<u>a</u>moral, <u>an</u>ion; <u>an</u>hydrous, <u>an</u>isocytosis.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>alphabet</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the set of
letters/symbols used to represent the sounds of the language. The number of
letters/symbols is not the same as the number of sounds in a language. English
has forty-some sounds but only twenty-six letters. Classical Greek had
twenty-four letters with one variant form () but thirty?? sounds. Classical
Latin had ??? sounds, but only ??? symbols. Classical Hebrew had twenty-two
letters with five variant forms () but over thirty sounds.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (a) Some letters can cover more than one
sound when there are systematic shifts (*allomorph), as with the English
consonant <i>n</i> (in <i>ra<u>n</u></i>/<i>ra<u>n</u>k</i>) and the variant
values of all the vowels and diphthongs. The same goes for Greek  (g[uh] or <i>ng</i>
before *velars) and its long/short vowel variants in , , and <i><u></u></i>.
Latin <i>b</i> (<i>b</i>, but <i>p</i> before <i>s</i> and <i>t</i>). (b) Sometimes
a letter can represent more than one sound at the same time, as with *double
consonants like English and Latin <i>x, </i>or Greek , , and . (c) Sometimes
there are *digraphs, which use two symbols to cover one sound, as with English <i>ch</i>,
<i>dg</i> (= <i>j</i>), <i>gh</i> (as <i>f</i>), <i>ph, rh/rrh, th</i>. (d)
Sometimes the same sound is represented in more than one way. English writing
is especially complex in this regard both with consonant and vowels. (e) The
Hebrew alphabet was consonantal, i.e., having signs only for the consonant
sounds of the language (vowels were added later as points). The Cherokee
alphabet was (g) *agglutinative, representing syllables. (<b>get reference RD)</b>.
??? We start departing the idea of alphabet with (e) pictographic as with
hieroglyphics. Likewise, (g) Japanese and Chinese characters.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *consonantal alphabet,
*agglutinative alphabet, *manual alphabet)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>alphabetize</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
organize by putting in the sequence of the alphabet</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>alphanumeric</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
using a mixture of all the symbols used in written communication: symbols,
letters, numbers, punctuation marks</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>amanuensis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
An amanuensis writes what someone else dictates, whether a letter or a more
formal work. That vocation in ancient times could involve taking down dictation
in a kind of short-hand and then recopying it into final form. There may also have
been some smoothing out or rephrasing depending on the skill level of the
amanuensisdone, of course, with the approval and confirmation of the author. A
*scribe, however, also copied *manuscripts; hence, a scribe was engaged in a
wider range of work. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *scribe, *stenographer)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ambiguity</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
lack of clarity because of insufficient information, multiple meaning of words,
or variant connections between words and context.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Variant connections with context include
*squinting modifier, <i>of</i> phrases, adjective-noun sets, participles, <i>etc.</i>.
From the listeners side, ambiguity comes from expressions unknown to the
hearer. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:10.0pt;text-align:
justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Crossword
clues play on such problems. Bad fighter could be a fighter who is a bad
person (hood), who/what fights what is bad (good, e.g.), or someone who is not
good at fighting (awkward). </span></p>

<p class=MsoListBulletCxSpFirst style='margin:0in;text-align:justify;
text-indent:.25in'><u><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Noun + <i>of</i></span></u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
phrases. Love of God: get other example.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListBulletCxSpLast style='margin:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
.25in'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The
idea is sometimes advanced that the New Testament was written in Greek because
it was such a precise language. Actually, every language is sufficient for its
circumstance. It has to be; otherwise it could not serve its purpose and would
get modified or corrected. Every language has places that are not as clear as they
are in other languages. Greekand Latincan be ambiguous in its use of the
genitive case simply to tie one noun to another. From experience, the listener
has to connect the *referents properly. Greek loves participles, which can
substitute for a whole range of adverbial and adjectival values. There seems
to be no marker for distinguishing *restrictive and *non-restrictive clauses. The
influence of Hebrew usage can be seem in quite a few places. Being an ancient
text, Greekand Hebrew even more souses term, expressions, and structures that
are not always clear to modern reader in a different culture.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>amend</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to alter a written document to make it clearer. (in a set with *emend, *edit) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ampersand</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a symbol representing <u>and</u> (&amp;); a blending, or *crasis, of <i>and per
se and</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ana</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the record of
proceedings in a committee or open meeting</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anacoluthon</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an abrupt change within a sentence to a new construction inconsistent with the
first (Webster)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anachronism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a representation of something as occurring in the wrong time frame, especially
presenting a kind of thing as occurring earlier than it could have</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anacrusis: a set of </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>unstressed
syllables that precede the place in a line of verse where the reckoning of
meter begins.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anadiplosis (webster</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>):
a rhetoric device that, at the beginning of the next sentence, repeats the word
or words that closed the previous one.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anagoge/anagogy</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
<b></b>the mystical interpretation of biblical texts that finds allusions to
heaven and the afterlife in passages that do not ostensibly dals with those
matters.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anagram/anagrammatize</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word or phrase created by the rearrangement of all the letters in another
word or phrase.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>analphabetic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
not in alphabetical order (Gr. a[n] + alpha + beta) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>analogy</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a comparison
whether by description or by a story, as with Jesus introduction to certain
parables: the kingdom of God is like . . . . Analogies are used to visualize
and thus more easily remember the principle involved; it can add an affective
dimension to the issue at hand: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>analytical language learning</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a style of learning that highlights syntactical analysis and word *inflection
(in a set with *saturation language learning): </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>analytical lexicon</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a lexicon that gives the meaning of a word and also analyzes given specific
forms of the word as to number-gender-case or
tense-mood-person-number-voice-aspect-dictionary form, particularly in
instances where the form is irregular.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anapest</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a metrical foot
consisting of two short syllables followed by a long, as in <i>on a boat</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *trochee)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anaphora</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a figure of
speech that repeats the same word at the beginning of a series of like
constructions</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anarthrous noun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
not having an article. In English, having no article draws attention to the
kind of thing that the noun is; it emphasizes quality. Greek puts the same
value on its anarthrous nounsquality <i>vs.</i> identity. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *articular)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anastrophe</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(Webster): the reversal of the normal syntactical order of words: +Great is
your reward in heaven.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anathematize</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to proclaim someone to be unacceptable for fellowship; to excommunicate</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anecdote</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short account
for illustration or entertainment </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anglicize</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to adjust a foreign word to the features of the English language. That may be
done, for example, by using English terminations for plurals in place of the
ones used by the feeder language, or by adjusting the pronunciation of sounds
to fit the English sound inventory. (1) <i>Amoebas</i> may supplant <i>amoebae</i>
over time. (2) Unusual consonant combinations on the front of words
automatically get adjusted to related sounds native to the language: gn-, kn-,
kt-, pn--, ps-, pt-, wr-. Double *fricatives will get adjusted to stop +
fricatives (diptheria &lt; diphtheria; dipthong &lt; diphthong). People say <i>garage</i>
like they say <i>rage</i> rather than say <i>garazh</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anglicism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(in as set with *Hellenism, *Aramaism, *Latinism, *Hebraism)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anagogue</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a mystical
interpretation of a passage or some feature of a text that makes unfalsifiable
meanings out of a text. (in a set with *fourfold interpretation, *analogical
interpretation, *allegorical interpretation, *spiritual interpretation; see
*interpretation, *text) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>annals</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a chronological
record of a years events; a history; a journal that chronicles the events of a
field of learning or the accomplishments of a ruler or leader</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>annotated bibliography</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a bibliography with explanatory notes or evaluations of the works listed</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>annotation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
explanatory material that describes a word cited in a *bibliography or
*footnote</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>announcement</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a public statement to let people know about some occurrence</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>annual</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: some publication
issued on a yearly basis, particularly a book put together each year to
describe and picture a year of high school or college life</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anointing with oil</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the pouring of olive oil on the head of someone being appointed to a duty or
office, as a prophet, a king. (2) Also associated with a prayer for healing in
James <b>5</b>:14-15.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *gesture, *laying on of
hands)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anomaly</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a baffling
feature of inflection or syntax that has no apparent parallel or background</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anonymous/anonymity</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a designation for something whose authorship is not know. [no name]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>antecedent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the word that a *pronoun refers back to. In distinction to *referent, the
reality a word refers to, and *proleptic pronoun, the as-yet unmentioned noun that
a pronoun anticipates. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *proleptic pronoun,
*referent)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>antepenult</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the third syllable from the end of a word. [Lat. ante/before + paene/almost +
ultima/last]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anthem</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a hymn of
praise. Biblical words set to music.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anthology</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a collection of perhaps previously published writings by various writers on the
same subject. Similar to *compilation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>authorial intent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
what the writer or speaker meant to communicate as distinguished from
inferences beyond it or applications of it. (in a set with *interpretation,
*hermeneutics)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anthropocentric</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>viewpoint</b>:
recounted through the eyes of man instead of Gods eyes. (in a set with
*geocentric viewpoint, *omniscient viewpoint)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anthropomorphism/anthropomorphic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a figure of speech that applies human characteristics to what is not human,
that is, to animals, plants, objects, God. The wings of the cherebim, the wings
of morning and fly to the uttermost , God rising up early and , trees clapping
their hands</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>anthropopathism/anthropopathic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
attributing human feelings to what is not human. A biblical case may be the
statement ___ It repented God that he had made man.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>antinovel</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a fictional work that does not incorporate the features of a regular novel. Websterlike
plot</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>antiphon</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a liturgical
text sung responsively to a psalm or canticle Webster</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>antiphonal</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
pertaining to a text sung alternatively as by a choir and congregation, men and
women, <i>etc.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>antiphonary</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a collection of antiphons/antiphonies</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>antiphony</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
same as antiphon</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>antiphrasis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an expression used humorously in a way different from its usual meaning. Old
Ruthie decided shed had enough of that cushy job; shed been praised, pampered,
and appreciated way too long.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>antistrophe</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the second, fourth, sixth, <i>etc.</i>, stanza that uses the same meter in
contrast to the other stanzas that use a different meter. (in a set with
*strophe)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>***antithesis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a contrasting statement put next to a first one </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>antonomasia</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the substitution of a proper name for a group that could be designated by a
common noun. He is an <u>Einstein</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>antonym</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the opposite of another
word: tall <i>vs.</i> short; a term in a set of paired opposites. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *synonym)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>auto-pen</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a device that
can be used for signed official documents without the official being on site.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>aorist</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: simple action,
snapshot action, factitive <i>vs.</i> progressive, iterative, cyclical,
emphatic, and other aspects of action. Gr.<i> a</i> + <i>orizoo</i>, without
horizons.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>aorist tense</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the simple past tense classification in Greek (punctiliar) in contract to
imperfect tense (linear). The aorist tense equals one of the uses of the Latin
*perfect tense; another term for preterit/preterit tense.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *epistolary aorist,
ingressive aorist)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>aoristic present</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Among the possible *aspects that a Greek present-tense verb can cover is simple
action, also called factitive action. In such a case, the action is not being
thought of as in some way linear. (in a set with *aspect, Aktionzart, *factitive
action, *present tense, *simple action)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>aphaeresis/apheresis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an elision of a sound from the front of a word: <i>possum</i> for <i>opossum</i>;
<u></u><i>tis</i> for <i>it is</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>aphesis</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the loss of a
sound from the front of a word, usually an unstressed vowel: <i>possum</i>
&lt; <i>opossum</i>, <i>cuz</i> &lt; <i>because</i>, <i>bout, round, til</i>
&lt; <i>until</i>, The opposite of *prothesis, which is the meaningless
addition of a sound to the front of a word.. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *contraction, *elision;
*prothesis)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>aphorism</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short
statement of an idea: well begun, half done; an *adage</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>apocalypse</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a kind of writing filled with visions and symbolic figures used in prophesying
the near destruction of the world.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Apocalypse: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>another
name for the Book of Revelation, a name based on the Greek name for the book: Apocalypsis.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>apocalyptic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>apocalyptic literature</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
literature like Daniel, Ezekiel, and Revelation in the Bible. It is characterized
by animal symbolism, end-time epic conflict between good and evil,</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>apocopate/apocopated/apocopation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a shortened form of something</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>apocope</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the loss of a
sound at the end of a word: paradigm &lt; paradigm-<u>os</u> (Gr); victory &lt;
victori-<u>a</u>; sing &lt; sing-en; Webster </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Apocrypha: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>the
set of xx books added to the Old Testament canonical books and included in the
canon in Roman Catholic Bible (Old Testament Apocrypha). The New Testament
apocrypha include writings from after the apostolic period. By word picture
hidden-from (writings) (in a set with *pseudepigrapha and *canonical
writings) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>apocryphal</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
of questionable authority or authenticity</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>apocryphon</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>apodosis: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>the
independent clause in an if-sentence, or *conditional sentence; the consequence
clause</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *protasis)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>apologia</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an apology, that
is, a defense of some concept or belief.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>apologue</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a moral fable
that has inanimate or animal characters in it (webster)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>apology</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/<b>apologia</b>: a
formal defense</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>apophasis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an allusion to something by denying that it will be mentioned (Webster)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>aposiopoesis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(sp): a construction that does not complete its format: if you only knew . . .
; a trailing off without finishing the comment. In the New Testament, A-class conditional
clauses may be used alone in this way to mean not: Mk <b>8</b>:12; Heb <b>3</b>:11;<b>
4</b>:3, 5;<b> 3</b>:18.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>apostrophe</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a mark like a raised comma () with a space under it that in written English is
used (1) under it to indicate possession (sg. mothers; pl. mothers) so as to
distinguish possession from plurals (mothers). It is also used (2) as an
elision mark in spelling contractions (<i>tis, dont, were, evry</i>) or (3)
certain abbreviations (<i>natl, cont</i>); (4) to help spell the plural of
words as words or letters as letters (There are two ts in <u>little</u>;
there are two <i>the</i>s in that sentence).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek uses the same mark to indicate *<u>elision</u>
( ) with a space under and after it and a similar mark to indicate *<u>crasis</u>
but with no empty space under or after (, , , , );
it looks like a *smooth breathing mark. *<u>Compounds</u> use neither
apostrophe nor spacing ()</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(2)<b>
</b>a rhetorical device in which an actor addresses someone or something not
present</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>apothegm</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a *maxim, a
short, witty, instructive statement; a saying (Websters)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>appelation wh 218</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>appelative noun </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(in
a set with *attributive noun)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>appendix</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: one or more
additions at the end of a book that gathers together items that might be spread
throughout the work itself. Examples include the list of lyricists and
composers in the back of a hymnal, an alphabetical listing of sources for the
music, a metrical index, and the like.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>appositional <i>or</i>: </span></b><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Or</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> can
introduce an element that restates in <u>different words</u> what has been said
rather provide a <u>thing alternative</u> to it. It has the value of or, to
put it another way . . . . The medical term for drooling is <i>ptyalorrhea, </i>or
<i>ptyalism.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>appositive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
renames a noun; it is a different word for the same thing</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> An appositive relates to the noun to which
it is appositional in the same way a subject relates to a *predicate noun and
the way a *direct object relates to an *objective complement. One is the
particular and the other is the classas a smaller circle inside a larger one. In
English punctuation, it is best in most cases not to set the second noun off in
commas if the particular appears before the class. If the class appears before
the particular, then set the second noun of in commas. My brother John is a
teacher. But, John, my brother, is a teacher. If the appositive is long, however,
it helps the readers eye to set it off in commas regardless of whether class
or particular comes first. When <u>or</u> is used appositionally, it is best to
set it off in commas because the two terms are fully parallel; if that is not
done, the reader is left with supposing that <u>or</u> is introducing another <u>thing</u>
rather than another <u>term</u>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *prepositive,
*postpositive)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>appositive genitive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
also called genitive of apposition, where English uses <i>of</i> to equate the
two nouns involved and where Latin and Greek use the genitive case on the
second noun for the same purpose: the city of Cincinnati, the gift of
tongues.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>approximate numbers</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an assertion that does not intend to be exact and so an assertion that is not erroneous
or intentionally misleading in its inexactness. <i>I started to mow the lawn
yesterday at two oclock</i>; the exact time was <b>2</b>:10 (more exactly, 2:10:06,
when I started the mower). The degree of precision is determined by the
purpose of the statement. Since most numbers could be more precise, the real
issue is proper order of magnitude relative to the subject matter and purpose
of communication.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> This observation on approximate language
probably applies to 1 Kg <b>7</b>:23, when the text says that the molten sea in
Solomons temple was ten cubits across and three cubits aroundoff by a factor
of one-twenty-second. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>English
can say a little less than ___, a little more than ___, about ___, almost
___, as many as ____, approximately ___, -ish (as in <i>sixish</i>), less
than ___, more than ___, nearly ___, no more than ___, roughly ___,
something like ___. There may be no formula at all: There are sixty cars
in the racewell, actually 59.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin said </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek said <i>hos</i> + ____ ( ) or <i>heis/mia/hen</i>
+ ___ ( ). Also used was <i>hoosei</i> + ____ (Lk <b>22</b>:41) and <i>hos apo</i>
+ ___ (Acts <b>7</b>:14; note also Jn<b> 11</b>:18; <b>21</b>:8)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *round number)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>arabic numbers</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the normal numbers used in modern numerical notation in contrast to *Roman
numerals, *Greek numbers, *Hebrew numbers, and the like.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Aramaism</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: <i>lema</i>
(why?) (in a set with *Hebraism,*Latinism, *Hellenism, *Anglicism; *solecism)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>archaism/archaic: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a
word, expression, or meaning of such that is no longer used by speakers of the
language (in a set with *barbarism, *buzz word, *catch phrase, *colloquialism,
*curse, *formal term, *informal term, *malaprop, *oath, *obsolete
*provincialism, *regionalism, *slang, *street talk, vulgarism)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>argument</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a debate on some
disputed item, often implying an emotional element</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>argumentative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having the nature of an argument or discussion</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>argumentive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having a tendency toward arguing, arguing with attitude </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *polemical)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>arsis</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the unaccented
part of a metrical foot in quantitative verse or the accented part of a
metrical foot in *accentual verse. Webster)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>article</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: English has *definite
article, *indefinite article (singulars only), and *anarthrous usage (no
article with the noun). (a) Definite refers to a particular example in a
certain class: <i>The liberty we have in America is better than it is in many
countries.</i> (b) Indefinite refers to any example in a certain class. By
extension, since it does not matter which example, so to speak, indefinite can
also draw attention to the kind of thing it is. It is in this class of things,
not that one: <i>There is a liberty that enslaves.</i> (c) Having no article on
