a *common noun draws attention to the kind of thing it is: <i>Liberty is a
wonderful thing.</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Since *proper nouns are already definite
by nature, English does not use articles with names. Under some circumstances,
it is possible to have a definite or indefinite article with a proper noun
because more than one such person, <i>etc</i>., might exist: <i>There was <u>a</u>
Dmitri Breshnikov in our small towns telephone book. <u>The</u> John I meant
was John the apostle.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A given noun may not be able to illustrate
all three possibilities: <u>The tree</u> has not lost its leaves yet, that
is, the one in our front yard. <i>There is <u>a tree</u> in our front yard,</i>
one out of many examples of such a plant. Anarthrous usage will not work with <i>tree</i>:
treeness would be the idea, but there is hardly a likelihood of needing to
say such a thing.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Money</i> works differently. <i>The
money</i> I laid on the table is gone. It is important to have <i>money</i>
(anarthrous). A money is not a meaningful expression.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In the plural, English has the option of
using definite articles or no articles. The pronouns in this paragraph are all
third-person. Pronouns replace nouns.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin has no articles at alldefinite or
indefinite, but <i>ille</i> sometimes approaches the value of a definite
article, especially in identifications like Magnus Ille Alexander, Alexander
the Great. <i>Unus</i> sometimes approaches the value of the indefinite
article. These two points about <i>ille</i> and <i>unus</i> are connected to
the fact that their derivatives provide respectively the definite and
indefinite articles in French, Spanish, and Italian. In rendering Latin into
English, a translator automatically supplies the definite article, the
indefinite article, or no article on the basis of the nature of the case.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek has articlearticular and no
articleanarthrous nouns, distinguishing identity or quality rather than
definite and indefinite. English article usage calls for definiteness in many
places where Greek calls for identity; so, the is frequently used in
translation where <i>ho/hee/to</i> appears in Greek. But, strictly speaking,
the two ideas are not the same. English also can use the *indefinite article to
indicate quality, especially with a *noun typical of its class; so the Greek
anarthrous noun can often be translated <i>a/an</i>. The main thing to remember
in translating Greek articles is that the English <i>the </i>does not
necessarily equal the Greek article, and <i>a/an</i> does not necessarily equal
the Greek anarthrous noun. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In a circle that represents pronouns,
there are exs that represent individual pronouns. A particular pronoun (x) is
definite; so English has an article. Greek also has an article because it
identifies this <i>x</i> in contrast to any of the other <i>x</i>s. So, both
languages use articles but for different reasons. The English indefinite
article means that any <i>x</i> serves the purposes of this statement. If a
second circle is added that represents, say, nouns, then Greek puts an article
(identity) with <i>pronouns</i> because Greek is thinking of one circle in
contrast to the other (identity again), this time at the group level. But,
English uses no article here if it is looking at pronouns as one kind of thing
in contrast to nouns as another kind of thing. So, the English anarthrous usage
in the plural differs from Greek articular usage in the plural, and articular
Greek is translated to anarthrous English.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>Enter circle diagrams with exx inside
for illustrative purposes.</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Since Greek articles mark identity rather
than definiteness, it is apparently a matter of taste or perhaps emphasis
whether the article appears with a *proper noun. In Matthews genealogy of
Jesus, the article does not appear with the ancestor who begets, as in Abraham
begat. But the article does appear with the one begotten, as in begat Isaac.
When Isaac (the begotten) is repeated in Isaac begat (the begetter), the
article is omitted. That pattern holds throughout the genealogical list. In
Lukes account there is an article with each namewhich is unrepeatedperhaps
because of the implied son of between each name.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Relevant biblical examples: Jn<b> 1</b>:1
does not mean, In <u>a</u> beginning was <u>the</u> word and <u>the</u> word
was with <u>the</u> God and <u>the</u> word was <u>a</u> God. Without a Greek
indefinite article, the centurions outcry in Mt <b>27</b>:54 is somewhat
unclear: Truly Gods son this (man) was; or Truly, this (man) was <i>Gods
son/son of God/a son of God/the Son of God</i>. With no article on <i>God</i>
or <i>son</i>, the question is whether the outcry was about the kind of man he
was (quality) or indefiniteness. It depends to some extent on the level of the
centurions acquaintance with the claims of Jesus and with the Jewish
understanding of monotheism.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew has a definite article only, which
is prefixed to both the noun and its attributive adjective modifier. If the
article is omitted on the adjective, the construction is treated like a
*linking-verb sentence that has a *predicate adjective</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) A written piece of moderate
proportions within a larger work like a newspaper or magazine.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *articular, *anarthrous)  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *definite article,
*indefinite article)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>articular</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having an article, in contrast to *anarthrous, having no article. The
terminology is used particularly in the study of Greek, where the only two
options are having the article and not having the article. With three
possibilities in English, articular is ambiguous as to whether definite or
indefinite article is meant. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *anarthrous)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>articulte</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
adj., able to put ideas into words; able to express oneself clearly. <b>articulte,
</b>v. to put into words</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>articulation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a producing of words orally</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>aside</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a comment
somewhat off the subject, but thrown in for interest, color, or perhaps comic
relief.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>aspect</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the manner in
which action is looked at in contrast to tense, voice, mood, number, and
person.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Linear action</u> has translations that
include <i>was/were/is/are working</i>; <i>used to work</i>; <i>would work</i>;
<i>kept working</i>. In past time, Latin and Greek use the imperfect for linear
action in past time. English uses auxiliaries plus present participle: <i>was/were
working.</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Inchoative/ingressive/inceptive:
the beginning of an action; covered by the *imperfect tense in Latin but by the
*aorist tense in Greek.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Iterative: The grandfather
clock <u>chimes</u> every hour. It <u>will chime</u> every hour. It <u>chimed</u>
every hour.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Cyclical: The cam <u>turns</u>
at a thousand RPMs. It <u>turned</u> at a thousand RPMs. It <u>will turn</u>
at a thousand RPMs.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Progressive: is working, was
working, will be working</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Characteristic action: She <u>works</u>
at Walmart (present). She <u>would work</u> at Walmart during the day and <u>go</u>
to college in the evening (past). She will work at Walmart, not K-Mart
(future). English simple past often covers characteristic action in past time,
especially if linear indicators are present: She <i>often</i> <u>worked</u> at
Walmart in the daytime and <u>went</u> to college in the evening.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Punctiliar action</u> is also called
simple action, aoristic action, factitive action, snapshot action. I <u>say</u>
to you, you will get out till you have paid the last farthing/cent/quadrans
(Mt <b>5</b>:26, present). I <u>said</u> that you would not get out (past). I
<u>will say</u> this again tomorrow (future).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Ingressive action</u> is the beginning
of an action. In Greek, ingressive action was covered by the aorist tense; in
Latin it was covered by the imperfect tense. Inchoative/inceptive/ ingressive
action is both punctiliar and linear in that its inception is a point but its
continuation is linear; thus Greeks use of the aorist (punctiliar) and Latins
use of the imperfect (linear) to cover it.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Conative action</u> is attempted action:
On account of which work of these <u>are you stoning</u> me (trying to
stone/getting ready to stone)? (Jn <b>10</b>:32, present); were you trying to
stone me; will you be trying to stone me? The Latin and Greek imperfect can
cover the conative idea.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Perfect is action completed before some
point in time:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Strictly speaking, Hebrew verbs have only
aspect. The perfect and imperfect tenses are really completed or uncompleted
action. That is why there is no present tense form in the finite verb. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *person, *number, *tense, *mood,
and *voice as possible features of verb forms)  (in a set with *linear,
*punctiliar/*factitive/simple, *perfect)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>aspiration</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
adding an h sound to the front of a vowel or end of a consonant. The initial <i>p</i>
and <i>t</i> in English words have a puff of air after them; when preceded, for
example, by <i>s</i>, however, the aspiration is lost: <i>pit</i> <i>vs</i>. <i>spit</i>;
<i>pat</i> <i>vs</i>. <i>spat</i>; <i>pend</i> <i>vs</i>. <i>spend</i>; <i>pot</i>
<i>vs</i>. <i>spot</i>; <i>putter</i> <i>vs</i>. <i>sputter</i>; <i>tar</i> <i>vs</i>.
<i>star</i>; <i>ted</i> <i>vs</i>. <i>stead</i>; <i>till</i> <i>vs</i>. <i>still</i>;
<i>top</i> <i>vs</i>. <i>stop</i>; <i>tub</i> <i>vs</i>. <i>stub</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The Greek <i>rho</i> originally had an <i>h</i>
sound preceding it. English derivatives pronounce the <i>rh</i> simply as <i>h</i>:
rhododendron, Rhoda. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>assimilate/assimilation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a kind of euphony that changes the theoretical soundoften created by
inflectioninto another that is the same as or phonologically related to the subsequent
one: sy<u>n</u>dicate, but sy<u>m</u>- before lip letters (*labials) as in
symphysis; syl- before <u>l</u>s as in syllogism; cum becomes con-, com-
before labials, col- before l words (collate), cor- before r words
(corregenda). In Greek we have <u>gamma</u> changing value to *velar *nasal
(-ng-) before velars (<u>gogguzo</u>/gonguzo); <u>nu</u> changing to <u>ng</u>
represented by <u>gamma</u> in compounds (e<u>g</u>kasivizo/e<u>ng</u>kaivizo/to
<u>in</u>augurate)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *elision, *contraction)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>assonance/assonant</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having the same vowel sound as is Disneys <i>Huey</i>, <i>Dewey</i>, and <i>Louie</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>asterisk</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a symbol (*) for
drawing attention to some special feature in the written situationa footnote,
an omission, an irregularity; also more recently called *star.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>aspirate</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: having a puff of
air associated with it, as with initial <i>p</i>s, <i>t</i>s, and <i>c/k</i>s
in English. Also a designation used in older Greek grammars for the fricatives <i>phi</i>,
<i>chi</i>, <i>theta</i>. Initial <i>rho </i>had a rough breathing on it; thus
the transliteration <i>rh</i> in English derivatives. In Latin <i>ph</i> was
probably an aspirate rather than a *fricative.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>asyndeton</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> a
pattern of *syntax that does not connect grammatical items together with
conjunctions as would normally be done: That car is large, expensive,
different; I am not impressed. (in a set with *hypotaxis, *parataxis)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>asyntactic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
not following recognizable syntax.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>atony</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: without accent </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>attainable wish</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a wish that refers to the future. In classical Greek, it was covered by the
optative mood preceded by <u>ei gar</u> or <u>eithe</u> C &amp; SH 102)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Attic reduplication</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a kind of reduplication found in Greek verbs like the change from ago to egagon
(to lead), in going from first to third principle part.<b> </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>attraction of case: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>With
relative pronouns in Greek, attraction of case means that the case of the
antecedent is used instead of the case implied by usage within the clause; this
happens especially if the clause function would have been accusative. Latin
follows a similar pattern. (in a set with *attraction of gender)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>attraction of</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>gender:
</b>In Greek, attraction of gender means that the subject *relative pronoun
takes the gender of the upcoming *predicate nominative rather than the *gender
of the *antecedent. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *attraction of case)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>attributive adjective: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>an
adjective positioned next to the noun it modifies instead of being on the other
side of an expressed or implied *linking verb: he is a tall man <i>vs</i>.
that man is tall. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>In addition to adjectives, with personal possessive
adjectives English makes a <u>vocabulary</u> distinction between *attributive
and *predicate adjectives. <i>My, our, your, her, </i>and <i>their </i>stand
immediately ahead of the noun they modify. <i>Mine, ours, yours, hers, theirs</i>
stand only on the other side of linking verbs.<i> </i><i>My</i> plate is on
the table; but the plate on the table is <i>mine</i>. There is no
predicate-position form for <i>its.</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek there are *first attributive
adjectives, which appear between article and noun, as well as *second
attributive adjectives, which appear after the repeated article: article noun
article adjective. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *predicate adjective, *first
attributive position, *second attributive position) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>attributive noun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(in a set with *appelative noun)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>attributive adjective</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>audiolingual</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a type of language learning that is derived from the oral nature of language,
hence, an emphasis on speaking and listening.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>augment</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: In Greek, augment
adjusted the front of roots in *secondary tenses of the *indicative mood as
part of the sign for these tenses. (1) *Temporal augment applied to words
beginning with vowels was basically a matter of lengthening the vowel: alpha to
eta, epsilon to ei- or ai-, iota to long iota, omicron to omega, upsilon to
long upsilon. Omega and eta, of course, could not lengthen further. Diphthongs
followed the same pattern as single vowels: ai- eta w/ subscript, ei to eta w/
subscript, <i>etc.</i> New Testament verbs starting with eu- usually did not
lengthen the eu- to eeu- in the secondary tenses. New Testament Greek often omitted
the augment for pluperfects. Note: whereas temporal augment was a matter of
lengthening; *contraction was a matter of combining, which also created a long
vowel sound of some kind.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) *Syllabic augment added an epsilon to
words starting with a consonant. Additionally, initial <i>rho</i> became <i>err</i>-,
including the augment, that is, by doubling the <i>rho</i> before adding the <i>epislon</i>.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *syllabic augment,
*temporal augment, *tense formative, *tense sign)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>auricular confession</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in the Roman Catholic Church, the practice of confessing sins to a priest as an
intercessor to God on the sinners behalf. It is a confession into the ear of
the priest, especially since the confessional booth somewhat separates the
confessor from the priest visually (Lat. <i>auris</i>).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *priest, *prophet,
*intercessor)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>authentic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
actually written by the one it claims to have been written by</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>author</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: in a setting that
involves music, author refers to the word; *composer refers to the music; outside
that setting, composer may refer to the poet or writer in general. (in a set
with *lyric, *lyrics, *lyricist, *libretto)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>authorial intent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
what the speaker/writer/communicator means into the communication in contrast
to what the hearer/reader may make out of it.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>autobiography</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an account of ones life written by the person himself. [Gr. <i>autos</i>,
self; <i>bios</i>, life; <i>graphein</i>, write] (in a set with *biography,
*gospel): </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>autodaf</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the public
announcement of a sentence that was imposed by the Inquisition Webster</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>autograph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) a persons signature, the name personally written; (2) an authors
first-hand ancient writing in contrast to subsequent copies of it made by
others.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>autography</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
writing something in a persons own handwriting</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>auxiliary verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
also called *helping verb, one that accompanies the verb root in a verbal
phrase: <i>am</i> going, <i>are</i> going, <i>is</i> going, <i>has been</i>
going, <i>have been</i> going, <i>had been</i> going, <i>will have been</i>
going, <i>should</i> go, <i>should be</i> going, <i>were</i> going, <i>was</i>
going, <i>will/shall</i> go, <i>will be</i> going, <i>would</i> go, <i>may</i>
go, <i>might</i> go, <i>can</i> go, <i>could</i> go, <i>kept</i>
going, <u>used</u> to go, <u>tried </u>to go, Consequently, auxiliary
verbs create phrase verbs, progressive verbs, and other *aspects in verbs. A
feature of the English language that gives it greater precision of verbal
expression than many languages have. The use of auxiliaries contrasts with
using inflected forms on the verb itself.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>axiom</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an obviously
true principle, especially a statement of such. (in a set with *adage,
*apothegm, *proverb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ayin</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the sixteenth
letter of the Hebrew alphabet: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:
14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
dir=LTR></span><span style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span>; </span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>transliterated  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>backhand</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: handwriting that
slants to the left, a characteristic more often associated with lefthanded
writers.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>backslash</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(in a set with *slash)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>back talk</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(= *sass)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>backronym</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an acronym whose letters came first and then what they stood for was fig</span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>u</span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>red
out later: JOY for <u>J</u>ust <u>O</u>ld <u>Y</u>outh, or for <u>J</u>esus
first, <u>O</u>thers second, <u>Y</u>ourself last.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>balanced construction</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
English uses a comma between short parallel phrases/clauses; a long-time
principle of rhetoric that maintains balance in oral or written presentation. Greek
used <u>ho men</u> . . . <u>ho de</u> to mark a set of evenly weighted clauses;
likewise ou monon . . . alla kai. Latin has non solum . . . set etiam.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ballad</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: as poem that
tells a story, written with a view to being sung</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ballad stanza</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Webster </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>barbarism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the use of language in an incorrect or uninformed manner, representing the kind
of misuse of term or syntax that a foreigner would make. (in a set with
*archaism, *colloquialism, *catch phrase, *curse word, *formal term, *informal
term, malaprop, *oath, *provincialism, *regionalism, *slang, *street talk,
*vulgarism)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>banner</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a headline or
slogan, often written on a pennant </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>bar code</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a system of
short vertical line of varying widths that identify merchandise and prices that
are read by a scanner in stores. (in a set with *QR code, *language,
*semaphore)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>barbarism: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>an
expression that represents the kind of mistake in speaking that someone not
very well acquainted with the language would make; the kind of incorrectness a
foreigner would make.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>baritone</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: kind of Gr
accent???</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>base</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the unaltering
part of a word, to which suffixes, <i>etc.</i>, are added. Also called *stem,
*root.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>beatitude</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a statement about blessedness. The beatitudes usually refers to the initial statements
in Jesus Sermon on the Mount in Mt <b>5-7</b> or to the corresponding entries
at the beginning of the Sermon on the Plain in Lk<b> 6</b>:20-23.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>belles-lettres</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
literature regarded as beautiful for its form and sound more than for its
content</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>benediction</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the closing prayer at a religious service; a closing expression of blessing
pronounced on a congregation by the leader of the service. well + said</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>bestiary</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a collection of
stories about animals that gives moral interpretation of their behavior </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>bet/beth</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the second
letter of the Hebrew alphabet: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:
14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>beta</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: second letter of
the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Bible</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the Christian
scriptures comprised of Old and New Testaments and in Roman Catholicism
inclusive of the Apocrypha. It serves as the authoritative base for belief and
practice of the faith.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>biblical</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) originating
in the Bible; (2) not in conflict with biblical teaching despite not
originating there</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>bibliography</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a list of books, articles, and other resources that pertain to an area of
inquiry, items on which the present work is based, or sources of additional information
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *annotated bibliography)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>bibliolatry</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
excessive devotion to the Bible. Often a pejorative term used against those who
take a high view of scriptures reliability and authority, as with the belief
in *inerrancy. [Gr. <i>biblion</i>, book + <i>latreuo</i>, worship]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>bibliotheca</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a library, a collection of books, a catalog of books</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>bill of sale</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a document verifying the purchase and ownership of personal property</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>bilingual</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
able to speak two languages; written in two languages as a bilingual catalog </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *monolingual, *trilingual,
*multilingual) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>bilingual dictionary</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a dictionary that defines the words of one language in the words of another
language, as with an English-German dictionary. (in a set with *dictionary,
*lexicon)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>binomial nomenclature</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the system of scientific identification of plants and animals that has first a
Latin noun for the species followed by an adjective for differentiation from
others in the same species</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>bio</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>blessing</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a statement of
well-wishing. In newer versions, the Greek word translated blessed has been

<i>beatitudo</i> ??) of Mt <b>5</b>:3-12 (cp. Lk <b>6</b>:2-23). Such a
rendering loses the interpersonal element in the original Hebrew word picture (<i>baruch</i>),
which stresses the action of one person upon other. <i>Happy</i> describes
simply the condition of a person in a favorable condition, a condition that
could issue from something besides a favorable attitude pronounced by one
person pronounced on another.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an explanatory

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>borrow</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to use words

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>bound construction</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a set of words that cannot be rearranged, taken apart, or given inserts without

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>bound form</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an element that never stands alone. The Hebrew article and inseparable
prepositions are a case in point as well as English suffixes like <i>ness,
-ity, -ism</i>, <i>etc.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>boustrophedon</span></b><span

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>brachiology</span></b><span

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>brackets</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: used for

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>break</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: what a voice
does when it changes suddenly or slips into crying; the experience a young man
has when his voice is changing</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>breathe</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to speak in
*voiceless exhalation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>breathing marks</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
On all Greek words that begin with a vowel, one of two breathing marks is
added to indicate proper pronunciation. The smooth breathing corresponds to
the English <i>h</i> in <i>honor</i>; the rough breathing corresponds to the
English <i>h</i> in <i>home</i>. As such, they represented respectively a
glottal stop and a glottal *fricative. Therefore, all Greek wordslike all
Hebrew and English wordsbegin with a consonant. Additionally, all words
beginning with <i>rho</i> have a rough breathing mark.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Breathing marks are written ahead of
capitals, <u>over</u> the second member of a *proper diphthong (even if the
first vowel is capitalized), <u>before</u> acute or grave accents, and <u>under</u>
a circumflex. If an *improper diphthong happens to be capitalized (Hadees), the
iota subscript comes up on the line after the capital but the breathing mark
appears before the capitalized vowel (and also before any accompanying acute or
grave accent and under a circumflex since accents also have to be put ahead of
the capital). In this rather infrequent case, the iota subscript is treated as
if it did not exist.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>bulletin</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a brief message
such as would be placed on a bulletin board, an announcement. A general warning
placed through police communication channels; an APB.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>buzz word</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a new expression that catches on as a way of saying something that comes up
often in conversation. Ask your doctor if <u>xxx</u> is right for you. (in
a set with *buzz word, *catch phrase, *colloquialism, *curse word, *formal
term, *informal term, *obsolete *provincialism, *regionalism, *slang, *street
talk, *vulgarism)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>by-laws</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an agreed-upon
set of rules of operation by an organization. In a religious context, by-laws
differ from a *creed by avoiding doctrinal mattersat least as much as
possibleand by sticking purely to matters of procedure. (in a set with
*statement of faith, *scripture, *creed) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>by-word</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a proverbial
expression; an often-used word; an *epithet; an object of notoriety</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Byzantine text</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a late text form of the Greek New Testament; also called the *majority text (in
a set with *majority text, *neutral text,*western text)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cacophony</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
harsh, dissonant words in a literary work</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>call letters</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the capital letters used to designate a particular radio or television station.
(in a set with *handle)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>calligraphy</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
beautiful, ornate writing [&lt;Gr kalos + grapho]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>canon: </span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>the authoritative
body of literature that serves as the measure of orthodoxy for a particular religion.
In Christianity, the New Testament canon has traditionally been limited to (1)
writings by apostles or those who served as extensions of the apostolic
officein contrast to those written later and later anonymous writings (apostolicity).
(2) writings that were universally receivedin contrast to those that appeared
in one corner of the Mediterranean (catholicity), and (3) writings that harmonize
with the previous two principles (orthodoxy). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with<b> *</b>deutero-canonical) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>canticle: </span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Canticles</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
alternate term for *Song of Solomon, or *Song of Songs)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>capital letter</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the form of an alphabetical letter that is larger than *lower case. Also called
*upper case. It is the size and shape of the letter that is written with a
computers shift key pressed down: A B C D E F G H IJ K L M N O P Q R S T U V W
X Y Z.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>capitalization</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In English and Latin, capital letters are used (a) on the front of the first
word of a sentence, (b) on proper nouns, (c) on names of deity, and (d) on
personal pronouns for the Judaeo-Christian deity. Some writers in English have
extended this last usage to relative pronouns, reflexive pronouns, intensive
pronouns, and beyond; but the practice has not become standard because it seems
cumbersome and because there is no clear stopping place beyond nouns and
personal pronouns. The difference between common nouns and proper nouns in
English occasions some uncertainty about capitalizing certain nouns associated
with the Judaeo-Christian faith. <i>Bible</i>, the Books of the Bible, for
example, can be considered proper nouns. On the other hand,<i> </i>in an effort
to show respect, writers sometimes capitalize too many things The words <i>scripture</i>,
<i>church, </i>should be left uncapitalized because they refer to kinds of
things rather than to one entity <i>vs.</i> another within a shared class. In
the final analysis, consistency becomes the bail-out in ambiguous cases.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Capitalizing *proper adjectives is a
related question. The word <i>biblical</i> is best left as a lower case
adjective. The word <i>catholic</i> is capitalized or not depending on whether
it is in reference to the Roman Catholic Church but left in lower case if a
*synonym for universalthe church catholic. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Capitalizing <i>the </i>ahead of the name
for an institution depends on whether it is part of the official title. Thus,
it is The Southern Baptist Theological Seminary but not the Cincinnati
Conservatory of Music. ?????<b>example</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>German
has followed the practice of capitalizing *nouns and *substantive adjectives in
a sentence.???? </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew does not distinguish capital and
*lower case.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Capitalization in New Testament Greek
applies to proper nouns, the beginning of paragraphs (but not sentences), and the
beginning of *quotations (*direct discourse): Acts<b> 1</b>:6, 7, 11, 16, 20<sup>3</sup>,
24; 2:7, 12, 14, 17, 25, 34.) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Since the original New Testament
manuscripts were written in all caps (*uncials), interpretation and translation
can be affected. One recurrent issue is with the word <i>pneuma</i>, which can
mean wind, breath, spirit (as a part of humankind), the intent/meaning
of a communication, the attitude of a person, or the Holy Spirit. Editors
of the New Testament have chosen never to capitalize the Greek term for <i>Spirit</i>
or <i>Holy Spirit</i> because of this ambiguity of usage. As a result, readers
of the New Testament have to decide which idea fits the flow of thought. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A word is clearest when set in contrast to
parallel possibilities. The principle is called the law of opposition, the law
of contrast, the law of negation. Applied to this situation, the rule suggests
that <i>pneuma</i> is not the Holy Spirit if it contrasts with <i>flesh</i> as
in Gal <b>5</b>:16-26. Likewise, it is not the Holy Spirit when it contrasts with
<i>letter</i> of the law (Rom <b>7</b>:6). Acts <b>6</b>:10 poses an
interesting dilemma when it says that the fellow-members of the Hellenistic
synagogue in Jerusalem could not withstand the wisdom and the <i>pneuma</i> by <i>which/whom</i>
Stephen spoke. The NASB (1995) capitalizes <i>Spirit</i> but then says by
which (instead of <i>by whom</i>). The law of harmony suggests that <i>spirit</i>
fit in the same category as <i>wisdom</i> as something in the man. His
detractors were not able to resist his wisdom or his demeanor. Since, however,
the Holy Spirit correlates with the proper attitude, the spiritual (Gal.), the
intended meaning (Rom.), the issue does not end up creating a crucial difference.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with lower *case, *uncials,
*spelling)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>caps</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: short for <i>capitals</i>,
especially in the expression <i>all caps</i>, where the whole word or entry is
capitalized.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>caption</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short notation
under a picture or drawing that identifies the picture</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cardinal number</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a number that does not imply rank or sequence: one, two, three, four, five, <i>etc.</i>
(in a set with *ordinal number)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>caret</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an inverted
v-shaped mark used along the bottom of the line of writing to indicate the
place for an insertion, which is then written above the existing writing.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>case</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) The size
of letters as to whether they are capitals (*upper case) or *lower case;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) The function that a noun or adjective
has in a sentence. Nominative case contrasts with the *oblique cases, the cases
other than the nominative. Case is a matter of <u>function</u> (relationship to
other words in a sentence); *case <u>form</u> indicates what the function is. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English has three cases: *subjective,
*possessive, and *objective. The first is for the (1) *subject of the sentence
(and its *appositive), (2) a *predicate noun (and its appositive), (3) a noun
of *direct address, and (4) a *word used as a word. (1) <i>Ruth Ann, my wife,</i>
is 5</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>2</span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'>&quot;</span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
(2) That year I married <i>Ruth Ann, my wife.</i> (3) <i>Ruth Ann, </i>will
you marry me? I wrote <i>Ruth Ann </i>on the valentine<i>.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> There are more cases than case forms in English,
Greek, and Latin. To illustrate, Greek *nominative and *vocative have the came
form (with only one exception); Latin follows the same nominative-vocative
pattern. Greek and Latin neuters always use the same form for nominative and
accusative.<span style='text-transform:uppercase'> </span>Additionally, Latin
dative and ablative plural are always the same, and dative and ablative
singular are alike in second declension. In Latin second and fourth
declensions, nominative plural and genitive singular masculine and feminine are
the same. In first declension, nominative plural is the same as both genitive
and dative singular. In third, fourth and fifth declensions the plural
nominative and accusative are the same in all genders. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *case endings, *declension)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>case form/case endings</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the form that a word takes to indicate its function (*case) in a sentence. Thus,
English may be said to have *case, but it is limited in the use of case form,
which exists only in the possessive case and with pronouns. For the most part, English
uses placement in the sentence (*distribution) and accompanying prepositions to
show a words grammatical role.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Englishs three case are *subjective, *possessive,
and *objective; so it has case but little in the way of case form. First of
all, English nouns are nouns because of where they can be put in a sentence: subject,
direct object, indirect object, object of a preposition. Then, the case of such
nouns is specified by which noun slot they occupy. Accusative case is what
appears in the object-of-preposition slot, the direct object slot, and the
indirect object slot. Subject case is what appears in the subject slot. Possessive
case occupies adjective slots (*attributive and *predicate); and, except for
pronouns, has a case form that adds an <i>s</i>(<i>/z</i>) sound to the end.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> So, only the possessive case in English has
a distinctive case form, usually <i>s</i> for singular possession and <i>s</i>
for plural possession. Even here, the singular-plural distinction exists only
in writing, because the <i>s</i> and <i>s</i> sound the same. There are no
distinctive possessive forms for personal pronouns. Instead, there are
possessive adjectives, and none of them have the <i>s</i> or <i>s</i>
termination: <i>my/mine, our/ours, your/yours, his, her/hers, its, and
their/theirs.</i> Forms after slashes are *predicate adjectives (The book is <i>mine</i>);
the others are *attributive adjectives (<i>my</i> book).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> With the demise of case-form in English, typical
speakers have, to an appreciable extent, lost a sense of case form. That
deficiency shows itself in mistaken usage of pronouns, which do still have case
form. A typical error occurs in compound objects of prepositions: between you
and <i>I</i> instead of between you and <i>me</i>. Part of the problem stems
from thinking of <i>you and I </i>as a set expression, which is then used as a
unit without further regard for grammatical considerations. Another circumstance
is with predicate nouns, which should be nominative: Its <i>me</i>. In fact,
It is <i>I</i> sounds pedantic and contrived to the contemporary ear. The
usage illustrates the tendency for *distribution to take over the role of case
form. Anything that in terms of distribution appears <u>after</u> a verb gets
objective form. If it is deemed important to avoid such an irregularity,
rewording is advised: Its Virgil; this is Virgil; Virgil, here.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin identifies six cases: *nominative,
*genitive, *dative, *accusative, *ablative, and *vocative (and *locative). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Classical and Hellenistic Greek studies historically
have identified five case forms: *nominative, *genitive, *dative case, *accusative,
and *vocative. An alternative analysis uses an eight-case system: *nominative,
*genitive, *ablative, *dative, *instrumental, *locative, *accusative, and *vocative.
The five-case layout generally corresponds to the number of different case
forms in the language. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Over time, prepositions took over case
endings by themselves as indicators of grammatical function. What in classical
Greek was indicated by a case form only, came to be accompanied by reinforcing
prepositions in the New Testament and later Greek.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew does not identify case form except
for a few old accusatives (ah); it does use <i>eth</i>- as an object sign ahead
of the noun as distinguished from case form on the word itself. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *case, *distribution)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *case form, *nominative,
*genitive, *dative, *accusative, *ablative, *vocative, *instrumental,
*locative) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *gender and *number for
*locating a *noun or *adjective in its full *paradigm)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>catalectic/catalexis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
lacking a syllable in the last foot of a poetic line</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>catechesis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
oral instruction, especially when arranged in question-answer form and dealing
with religious doctrinal matters. Luke tells Theophilus that he is writing his
gospel so Theophilus can know for certain the things in which he had already
been orally instructed (Lk <b>1</b>:4).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>catachresis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the misuse of a word or set of words (In the KJV, Eve is a <i>help meet,</i>
not a <i>help mate</i>.) or a *mixed metaphor.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>catalog(ue)</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a publication that lists the items (for sale usually) in a certain sphere of
interest</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>catch phrase</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a nifty, expressive, memorable way of saying something, a *buzz word that catches
on like the newer expression right for you. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *archaism, *buzz word,
*colloquialism, *curse word, *formal term, *informal term, *obsolete term,
*provincialism, *regionalism, *slang, *street talk, *vulgarism)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>catch word</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an expressive term for a common idea; a slogan; a memorable way of saying
something</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>catechesis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(oral) instruction in the basics of religious matters</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>catechism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a book for religious instruction in the fundamentals of the Christian faith</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>catechist</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
one gives catechetical instruction</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>catechize</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to instruct orally in question-answer format regarding religious doctrine</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>catechumen</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
one receiving catechetical instruction in the Christian faith</span></p>
