<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>causal clauses</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
An adverbial clause that gives the reason for what happens in the main clause: Because
he ate green apples, he got the stomach ache. English has no distinct formula
for such clauses. Latin may use the subjunctive mood after conjunctive <i>cum</i>
in such a clause.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>Greek uses the formula <b>FORMAT</b> In Latin the
clause is created by <u>cum</u> plus subjunctive. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>causative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
giving causal meaning, as a suffix like <i>ize</i> and fy in English, -<i>izo</i>
in Greek.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cedilla</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the subscripted
addition to certain letters to signal altered pronunciation: faade, garon.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cento</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>; a literary word
comprised of writings from various authors</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>chapter</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a major division
in the text of a large work. In an especially long work, there may be volumes,
then parts, above the chapter divisions. In biblical references, chapters are
the largest breakdowns of the text. (in a set with *book, *volume, *part,
*paragraph, *verse): </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>chapter and verse</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an expression used in Christian circles for an exact place where some
authoritative evidence occurs in the *Bible.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>character</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a letter of an alphabet, a letter or mark in a writing system</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>chapter</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a major division
in a book. In biblical usage, the largest division of Old and New Testament
books with the exception of Obadiah and four short New Testament books that
have no chapter divisions: Philemon, 2 John, 3 John, Jude</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>chetubim</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the Hebrew term
for writing, one of the three basic divisions of Old Testament literature and
including Job, Psalms, Proverbs, Ecclesiastes, and Song of Solomon. (in a set
with *Torah and *Nebiim)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>chi</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: twenty-second letter of
the Greek *alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
Pronounced like the <u>ch</u> in <u>Bach</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>chiasmus</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a figure of
speech that involves a rhetoric inversion of the second of two parallel
structures p 242WB</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>chiastic concord</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
WG 242</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>choliamb/choliambic meter</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a metrical foot that has a trochee plus an iamb Webster<b> (Wh 292</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>chorus</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: contrast with verse</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>christen</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to name someone
(or something), particularly at the baptism</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>chronicle: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a
record of events (in a set with *biography, *autobiography, *gospel, *history) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cipher: </span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a message written
in code by substituting or transposing letters in a predetermined way. (2) the
number zero (0)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>circumflex</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an inverted arc placed above a vowel and representing in Greek a rise-fall tone
only on long vowels or *diphthongs of the last two syllables. Also shaped  in
some Greek texts. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A third form ( ^ ) is used in English for spelling
a few words and phrases<i>: bte noire, entrecte, entrept, matre dhtel,
papier-mch, pt, raison dtre, table dhte, tte--tte, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *acute accent, *grave
accent; *diacritical marks)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>circumlocution</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a speaking around something; a wordier way of saying something. The practice
exists either when the language does not have relevant *technical terminology,
because circumlocution may soften a potentially offensive matter, or because
the extra wording creates a *euphemism.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>circumstantial clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an adverbial dependent clause that indicates the attendant circumstance with
the main clause: When/while he was shoveling snow, he had a heart attack. Latin
has a specific formula for the idea: <u>cum</u> + subjunctive.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>citation: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a
reference to a passage or a location of a passage without quoting its words (in
a set with *reference, *quotation)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>clause</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a set of words distinguished
from *phrase by having a *finite verb instead of an *infinitive, *participle,
or no verbal at all. As such there are many kinds of clauses in various
languages:  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *independent clause/*insubordinate clause,
*dependent clause/*subordinate clause; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *noun clause, *adjectival clause,
*adverbial clause; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *adversative clause, *circumstantial
clause, *conditional clause, *concessive clause, *consequent clause, *elliptical
clause, *fear clause, *if-clause,</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *indirect discourse, (called *indirect
statement in Latin), *indirect question, *jussive noun clause [Lat], </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *object clause [Gr], *proviso clause,
*purpose clause, *relative clause, *relative clause of characteristic (L.), *result
clause, *temporal clause, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>coalesce</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to serve two
functions at once ???? In Hebrew, the <u>holem</u> and the dot above a *<i>sin</i>
indicates <i>sin</i> <i>vs.</i> <i>shin</i> and at the same time indicates the
o-sound that follows it.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>code word</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a term or expression that stands for more than it says. An insider expression
that hides its meaning from the general populace (in a set with *technical
term)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>codex</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a writing bound
together in leaves like a modern *book in contrast to a *scroll (in a set with
*scroll) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cognate accusative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
An accusative direct object after verb that is a related word: shoot a shot,
sing a song, I have fought a good fight (2 Tim <b>4</b>:7). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> in a set with *cognate)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cognate subject</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
A situation where the subject and the verb are related words: Peters shadow
might overshadow any one of them (Acts<b> 5</b>:16).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cognate words</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
words that have the same or a similar base: write, writer, writ, a writing,
handwritten, underwrite</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cognomen</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: ones *surname,
last name; a family name. In Roman names it was the third name, which marked the
individuals family name. (in a set with *nickname, *nomen, *praenomen)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cohortative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the terminology used in Hebrew grammar for what is called *hortatory subjunctive
in Greek and *jussive in Latin, a first-person plural verb form for urging
action. In Hebrew and Latin grammar it is called the jussive because of its
correspondence with third-person usage. Greek covers the third-person idea with
the imperative mood.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>coin a word/expression</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
make up a new term or phrase: <i>normalcy</i> is said to have been coined by
President Coolidge???? A *neologism.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>collate</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: bringing
together sources that deal with the same thing so as to produce a complete or
more accurate picture. Textual critics collate *manuscripts to access variant *readings
at certain points in the text or at times to fill in missing parts in a
defective copy of an ancient writing.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>collective noun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a noun that refers to a group of individuals: <i>clergy, committee, company, enemy,
entourage, family, flock, group, herd, public, seed, staff, task force, team. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Paul
observes that <i>zera</i>, the Hebrew word for<i> seed</i> in the promise to
Abraham (Gen <b>13</b>:15; <b>17</b>:8) is a collective nounfor kind of seed
rather than kernel of seedthat is to be identified with the Christ kindseed
by promise, not with the individuals that comprised Abrahams lineage (Gal <b>3</b>:15-16,
<i>sperma</i> [Gr], <i>semen</i> [Lat]). Acts<b> 7</b>:6 uses the singular
collective <i>seed</i> and them has a plural verb in <b>7</b>:7; Jerome uses
plural pronouns (<i>enos</i>) referring back to <i>seed</i> within the same
verse.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (See also *agreement) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>colloquialism/colloquial</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word or expression used in conversational language between friends and would
not likely appear in a public presentation, address, or writing. (in a set with
*archaism, *buzz word, *catch phrase, *curse word, *formal term, *informal
term, *oath, *regionalism, *provincialism, *regionalism, *slang, *vulgarism)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>colloquium</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a forum for the exchange of ideas, often part of the structure for a doctorate program
so that members of the group can entertain each others sometime tentative
proposals for debate and evaluation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>colon</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a mark of
punctuation that equals the value of that is, <i>i.e</i>.; heres an
example. Colons separate chapter and verse in biblical references: Jn <b>3</b>:16.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>column</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a block of print
less than a page wide in which newspaper articles and the like are written. By
metonymy, it is an article in such a publication.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>combining form</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:<b>
</b>the form of a root that is designed to combine with a subsequent word
element. The splicing letter, or connecting vowel, is most frequently <i>o</i>-
in English. If the next element begins with a vowel, in which case no
connecting vowel is necessary: <i>ot/o/rrhea</i> but <i>ot/algia</i>. Even when
the next element begins with a vowel, a connecting vowel is sometimes used
especially when the next letter is an <i>a</i>: psychoanalysis, The letter <i>i</i>-
occasionally serves as a connecting vowel: <i>algesimeter, noct/i/philia,
noct/i/phobia, rach/i/schisis, venipuncture, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>comedy</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a play or
written piece characterized by humor and leading to a happy ending </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *tragedy)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>comma</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a *punctuation
mark that subdivides a sentence following certain rules of usage. In English,
commas (1) separate *co-ordinate clausesunless they are short enough the eye
can see the full sentence; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) set off *appositives (with double
commas) unless the sequence of appositives is class- then-particular (my
brother John), where they are optional; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) set off parenthetical expressions
added in for color or balance (double commas); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (4) set off introductory *infinitive
phrases (always), *clauses (always), *prepositional phrases (unless short and no
difficulty is created), or *adverbs (unless no difficulty is created);</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (5) set off *non-restrictive clauses; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (6) separate items in a series of three or
more and then only if coordinate conjunctions are not used. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Occasionally, a comma can be used to (7) identify
a break, say, between subject and verb in a complicated structure that greatly
separates the subject from the verb. It is better to rework the construction to
avoid the extra comma. Besides, modern English usage does not prefer the long,
complex, Germanic sentence form where *subjects are overly distant from *verbs
and verbs are overly distant from *direct objects.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Additionally, to (8) separate very short
sentences, a comma may suffice in place of a semi-colon (or period) without
being considered a *comma splice: Illative correlates, causal causes (as in
distinguishing two meanings of <i>therefore</i>).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Over time, the more precise rules of comma
usage have shifted in English. For example, the King James Version uses (double)
commas to set off all adverbial and adjectival clauses: introductory adverbial
clauses and those at the end a sentence, *restrictive and *non-restrictive adjective
clauses, and all relative clauses: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> It uses commas between just two items in a
set: We have here but five loaves, and two fishes (Mt <b>14</b>:17); he
opened his mouth, and taught them, saying (Mt <b>5</b>:2). Contemporary usage
does not insert commas until there are at least three members in the set and
does so even then only when coordinate conjunctions are not used. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> TKJV uses colons in places where commas
appear now: Blessed are the poor in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of
heaven (Mt <b>5</b>:3).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>Examples </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Various
editions of the KJV handle these cases differently.<b> </b>So modern readers have
to keep those adjustments in mind when using the King James and other older
versions.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The Greek comma is shaped like English
comma, but its use does not follow the same rules of usage. For one thing,
Greek syntax can be rearranged to break up what would be set off with commas
and the surrounding text: Acts <b>5</b>:5, for example. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Another complicating factor in biblical
studies is that Old Testament Hebrew and Aramaic and New Testament Greek manuscripts
originally had little if anything in the way of punctuation. Punctuation in the
English Bible, therefore, represents the judgment of translators and textual
critics. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin also uses commas, but again the
rules of usage differ from English custom. The Vulgate, for example, often
inserts commas between two members of a set, something Old English did (KJV)
but modern usage does not do until there are three or more parts to the set.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *comma splice, *serial
comma, *run-on sentence)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>comma splice</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the joining of two independent clauses with a comma instead of a semi-colon or
a period plus capitalization. We knew it was going to be a battle, obviously
it was exactly that. <u>Man Merc</u> Sunday 9, 2012, p. 23,. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>command</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a directive
given by one person to another; commonly called *imperative in grammar. Commands
can use (1) the imperative mood in English, Latin, Greek, and Hebrew. Commands
can also be made (2) by infinitives in Greek ( ), and rarely in the New
Testament (3) by participles ( ). (4) The future indicative sometimes carries a
command force in English, Greek, Latin, and Hebrew. In New Testament Greek, the
prevalence of this *imperatival future may reflect a Hebrew usage of its
*imperfect tense.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Commands are frequently softened by
putting them in the form of vague request: Would you mow the lawn? Similarly,
Id like for you to mow the lawn. Let me help you.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *command form, *imperative
mood, *imperatival future)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>command form</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb form that gives a directive, advises, requests, or entreats. Same as
*imperative *mood. (n a set with *advice)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>commandment</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a wording that tells someone what to do. In biblical studies it has to do with
speaking authoritatively on divine, Christian matters, where ideally no
exceptions exist in the kind of circumstance in view. Not doing a commandment
is disobedience; not doing advice is taking a risk. Both ideas may come in the
form of a commandment. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *advice)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>comment</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a brief
*statement often of an evaluative or explanatory sort</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>commentary</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a presentation that evaluates or explains; a work that systematically explains
the meaning of a *text in accordance with the layout of the text.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>commercial</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a paid advertisement aired on radio or television, promoting a product or
service. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>commission</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a directive aimed at accomplishing some significant undertaking</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Commission, The Great: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Jesus
directive to his apostles as recorded in Mt<b> 28</b>, Lk, Jn, and Acts.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>common</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: not having a
distinctive form for masculine <i>vs.</i> feminine (1<sup>st</sup> per Heb
verb). Pronouns in English are common except for third singular; hence, the
growing tendency to use <i>their</i> for this purpose: In an academic area
like mine, it is unusual for someone to remain that long at the same
institution, let alone <u>their</u> alma mater.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>common noun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a noun for a person or thing at the class level as distinguished from a
particular one. Proper nouns are not so much for meaning as they are for
designation. <i>Man</i> is a common noun; <i>John</i> is a *proper noun. English
convention calls for capitalizing proper nouns and using lower case on common
nouns (except, of course, at the beginning of sentences). Same as *lower-case
noun. (in a set with *proper noun)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>communication</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
human communication can take place through <u>sounds</u> (language), <u>movements</u>
(*gestures, *sign language, *kinesics, *facial expressions, body language),
and <u>symbols </u>(*semaphore, *logos, *writing, *pictographs)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>communiqu</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
official announcement WB</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>comparative degree</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the form of an adverb or adjective that identifies a quality as being present
in greater *degree here than in another case. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *degree, *comparison of
adjectives, *comparison of adverbs)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>comparative linguistics</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
alternate label for *comparative philology. Comparative linguistics draws
correlations between the target language and related contemporary languages. *Historical
linguistics looks at the flow of a languages development as a way of
elucidating seemingly aberrant features of the language. *Descriptive
linguistics makes a complete analysis of a language at a particular stage of
its development in contrast to *historical linguistics and *comparative
linguistics. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *descriptive linguistics,
*historical linguistics; same as *comparative philology)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>comparative method</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a technique for working out the similarities between languages so as to
discover the common origin. Cp. *comparative philology.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>comparative philology</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of a language in light of its historical and geographical connections
with previous families of languages and surrounding cultures. It is done in the
context of all the linguistic understanding available on language as such. An
alternate label for *descriptive linguistics.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>comparison</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) Comparison, or analogy, exists in several figures of speech. Figures of
speech compare the point of interest to something that has notable elements of
likeness to it. This is particularly true when the point of interest is
abstract; the comparison gives tangible reference for the abstract idea. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) carrying adjectives and adverbs
through their three *degrees of comparison.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *degree, *comparison of
adjectives, *comparison of adverbs)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>comparison of adjectives</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Comparison of adjectives means carrying adjectives through the three possible
degrees of an adjective. The <u>positive degree</u> is the basic adjective
idea as used with no specific contrasts or comparisons in mind: he is tall. The
<u>comparative degree</u> of an adjective contrasts or compares the example at
hand with one other example: he is <u>taller</u> than his sister. <u>Superlative</u>
<u>degree</u> compares or contrasts the one at hand with all the others in some
frame of reference: he is the <u>tallest</u> person (in his family). <u>Elative
comparison </u>does not have a specific second example in mind: he is <u>rather
tall</u>. <u>Elative superlative</u> does not have specific others in mind: he
is <u>very tall</u>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Each adjective that is capable of degrees
has a different form for each degree of the comparison. In English, (1) -<i>er</i>
and <i>est</i> can be added to the positive degree adjective to create the
comparative and the superlative degrees respectively. One- and two-syllable
adjectives normally form comparatives and superlatives this way: big/bigger/biggest,
pretty/prettier/prettiest <b>[insert panel] </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>English
can also use (2) <i>more</i> and <i>most</i> ahead of the positive-degree form
to create the other two degrees. Adjectives with three or more syllables
usually form their other two degrees in this way: <i>more constructive/most
constructive: more infantile/most infantile</i> <b>[insert panel]</b> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Exceptions to this generalization occur
with *disyllables sometimes according to the speakers tastesome going one
way, some the other way, and some either way, depending on its effect on the
ear: <i>more eager, more normal</i>. Two-syllable, positive-degree adjectives
ending in <i>y</i> almost always add <i>er</i>: <i>bossier, crazier, dopier,
easier, filthier, gutsier, happier, itchier?, junkier, loftier, moodier,
nastier, oilier, prettier, sloppier, tackier, uglier, wittier, zanier. </i>(But
<i>more</i> <i>achy, more itchy/itchier</i>?more lengthy?). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Disyllables with <i>ful</i> normally use
<i>more/most</i>: <b>[insert panel] </b><i>more awful</i> (but <i>awfulest</i>),
<i>more bashful, more careful, more doubtful, more frightful, more grateful,
more helpful, more mournful, more needful, more playful, more restful, more
shameful, more tactful, more wasteful. </i>Disyllables in <i>ous</i> use <i>more/most</i>:
<i>more boisterous, more callous, more jealous, more monstrous, , </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Disyllables in <i>less, -ose, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In English, elative comparison can use a
doubled adjective before the noun: He is a good, good man; or <u>good and</u>
(Dig the hole good and deep), <u>pretty</u> (That tree is <u>pretty</u>
tall). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>comparison with adjectives/constructions</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(put also under *degrees of comparison)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin can use (1) <u>quam</u> + same case
on the second noun: <b>[insert panel]</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Latin
can use (2)<b> </b>ablative on second noun: <b>[insert panel]</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek uses (1) <u>eta</u> + same case on
the second noun: <b>[insert panel]</b> Jn <b>4</b>:1 </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek can use (2) genitive on the second
noun: <b>[insert panel]</b> Mt <b>27</b>:64; Jn <b>5</b>:20; <b>14</b>:28; Rev<b>
2</b>:19; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek can use (3) <u>para</u> or <u>hyper</u>
+ accusative on the second noun. In the New Testament, comparative degree
usually covers for superlative. It does so by lumping all the other examples
into a group and then doing a comparison between the one group (with one
example in it) and the rest. Superlative degree is left to have an elative
value in all but a very few cases: .</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew <i>min</i> + noun: Hebrew has few
adjectives to start with, but has no comparative or superlative adjectives at
all. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English <i>than</i> plus same case
(However, in current usage English speakers are more and more treating <i>than</i>
as a preposition followed by the accusative case instead of a conjunction
followed by the same case).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *degrees of comparison, *first
degree, *second degree, *third degree, *positive degree, *comparative degree,
*superlative degree, *than constructions)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>comparison of adverbs</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
check comparison of adjectives</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek and Latin, comparison of adverbs
of manner builds on the formation of comparison of adjectives </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin, ablative of comparison with
adverbs is limited to poetry</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>compendium</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a complete summary ideally of all the information on a subjectlike Greek
grammar. Pictures as situation in which information on some subject has existed
in multiple places disconnected from each other, but now is being drawn
together and organized in one resource.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>compensatory lengthening</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the lengthening of the immediately preceding vowel to make up for the loss of a
subsequent sound. The Greek nominative masculine singular present and second
aorist active participle shows <u>oon</u> because of the loss of the <u>ts</u>
in the theoretical <u>onts</u>. The same thing happens in the aorist aorist
active participle, which theoretically is sants in the nominative singular
masculine but becomes ss. In Hebrew if a letter is assimilated, the following
letter is doubled (except for gutturals and <i>resh</i>) with dagesh forte to
compensate for the loss. In Latin,</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>compilation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a bringing together of articles from various sources to create an anthology on
a given subject. Same as *anthology.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>complement</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
word or words that follow a verb in order to fill out its meaning</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>complementary infinitive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an infinitive that necessarily follows and completes the meaning of the main
verb and shares its subject, which is not re-expressed: I want to go home. The
infinitive amounts to a direct object. Not every verb has a meaning that
naturally leads to a complementary infinitive. English examples include <i>care
to go, dare to go, decide to go, demand to go, desire, <u>to </u>go, have <u>to
go</u>, hope <u>to go</u>, intend to go, ought <u>to go</u>, prefer to go,
refuse to go, seek to please, try to go, want <u>to go</u></i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin verbs that can be followed by
complementary infinitives include <i>audeo, debeo, malo, nolo, opto, possum</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek verbs </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>complete sentence: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>one
that is not a phrase, *dependent clause, or *sentence fragment. It expresses an
idea clearly without addition or modification. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *sentence fragment,
*phrase, *dependent clause; *aposiopoesis)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>complex sentence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a sentence structure comprised of one independent clause and at least one
dependent clause (in a set with *compound sentence, *compound-complex sentence)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>complimentary close</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a polite expression at the end of a letter above the authors signature. Examples
are sincerely yours, best wishes, in our common calling. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *inside address, *salutation,
*signature, *postscript) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>composite verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb that shares some of its principal parts with another verb. Latin has <i>fi,
fieri, factus</i>, where the last principal part has been borrowed from <i>facio,
facere, feci, factus</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *defective verb, *deponent
verb, *regular verb, *suppletive verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>composition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
can be (1) a short written piece, but <i>compose</i> is specialized into
musical composition where there are both words and music. Especially is the
distinction maintained with compos<u>er</u>. (2) the *compounding of two
separate complete words to make a new word: <i>homeland, homework</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Following A. T. Robertson is the analysis
of compounding in Greek that has (a) <u>proper composition</u>, where one root
is connected to the main word by a connecting vowel and the main root is the
only one inflected. Second is (b) the joining of two words without alteration
of either. Thirdly, (c) an already compounded word is further joined to another
element to create a tripartite term (<u>A Grammar of the Greek New Testament</u>,
p.161).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English uses type 2 composition frequently
in simply putting words together without alteration and no space between the
parts in written form: <i>heartburn, homework, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>compositum</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a compound word. Pl. composita</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>compound</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: made up of more
than one part. Also called *compositum. The process of compounding is called
*composition. (in a set with *compound words, *compound subject, *compound
noun, *compound verb, *compound adjective, *compound object of a preposition,
*compound preposition) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>compound adjective</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a set of adjectives modifying the same noun.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>compound noun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
A compound noun may be written together (lifestyle), may be hyphenated
(show-off), or may be written separately as two entries (book review)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>compound object of a preposition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
A compound object of a preposition has more than one object of the preposition.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>compound preposition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a set of prepositions with the same object: *over and above his normal work
load; above and beyond the call of duty.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>compound sentence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a structure that is composed of two or more independent clauses joined by a
co-ordinating conjunction or a semi-colon. (in a set with *complex sentence,
*compound-complex sentence)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>compound subject</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
A compound subject has two or more subjects of the same verb: Jim and John are
brothers. (see also *agreement)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>compound verb: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a
set of two or more verbs with the same subject(s) or a verb made up of more
than one root ().</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>compound word</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
A word created by putting together two or more roots (<u>phon</u>o<u>graph</u>),
a root and a prefix (<u>acr</u>o<u>megaly</u>), a root and a suffix (angi-itis),
or a combination of all such elements (en<u>cephal</u>o<u>myel</u>opathy). Depending
on the constituent parts, the words may be spelled in English with a hyphen or
perhaps a dieresis, but most commonly, with neither (*solid). Some compounds
can become quite lengthy: laparohysterosalpingo-oophorectomy, cholangiopancreatography;
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> GR. hyomneemoneumata, deisedaimonesterous
(Acts 17); Examples include Greek words formed from two prepositions plus a
verb: apo/kat/allassoo. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> German religions-geschichte; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin sapientissimasque.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Same
as *agglutination. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>compound-complex sentence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a sentence with more than one independent clause and at least one dependent
clause. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>conative</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: attempted
(action): They <u>tried to</u> stone him ( ). Conative action in past time can
be covered by the *imperfect tense in Latin, by the *aorist tense in Greek, and
by the tried-to/try-to phrase in English.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>concession speech</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an elected or selected candidates traditional public response to losing the
bid for an office of important position. (in a set with *acceptance speech)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>concessive clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a dependent adverbial clause introduced by although: Although he passed for
483 yards, the team (nevertheless) lost the football game. Latin uses <u>cum</u>
+ subjunctive for this idea; <u>tamen</u> in the main clause often helps
distinguish it from other cum clauses that have subjunctive verbs (*temporal
clauses, *causal clauses). It translates as although . . . , (nevertheless). Also
called *adversative clause.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>concord</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: *agreement
between parts of a grammatical set showing that items belong together. Examples
are agreement in number-gender-case between adjective and noun, person-and-number
between subject and verb. Another term for *agreement. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *government; singular,
plural; *number, *gender, *case)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>concordance</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a book alphabetically arranged that lists all the occurrences of the words or
phrases in a work or set of works</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>condensed books</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
books shortened by editorial subtraction, especially by removing sections while
leaving the remaining material untouched.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>conditional clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
includes various kinds of *if-clauses. (in a set with *consequent clause) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>conditional sentence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
 An if-clause plus main clause together</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek and Latin, conditional sentences
follow certain over-all formulae involving the indicative mood in some cases
and subjunctive mood in others. The particle <i>an</i> is also present in Greek
contrary-to-fact conditional sentences.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> as shown below with accompanying
translations.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek conditional sentences</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> present/past particular,
nothing implied</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> ei + present/
past indicative, any form</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  If he is
crossing the bridge, he is breaking the treaty.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If he
crossed the bridge, he broke the treaty.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> present general  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> ean + subjunctive,
present indicative</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If he (ever)
crosses the bridge, he breaks the treaty. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> contrary-to-fact</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>ei</i> +
secondary indicative, <i>an</i> + secondary indicative (<i>an</i> is sometimes
omitted in the New Testament: Jn <b>9</b>:33; <b>15</b>:122; Acts<b> 26</b>:32;
1 Cor <b>12</b>:17<sup>2</sup>, 19)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  If he
were crossing (impf ind) the bridge, he would be breaking (impf  ind)
the treaty. [present contrary-to-fact]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If he
had crossed (aor ind) the bridge, he would have broken (aor ind)  the
treaty. [past contrary-to-fact]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> vivid future/future more vivid</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> ean +
subjunctive, any future form (imp , subj, opt) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If he
crosses the bridge, he will break the treaty (subj).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If he
crosses the bridge, break the treaty (impr).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If he
crosses the bridge, he might break the treaty (opt). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  vague future </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> ei + optative, an
+ optative</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If he
would cross the bridge, he would break the treaty. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> future most vivid: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> ei + indicative,
+ future indicative</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If he will cross
the bridge, he will break the treaty.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek conditional sentences (second analysis,
particularly for New Testament Greek)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Real conditions</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Contrary-to-fact conditions</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek *mixed conditions appear in the New
Testament, and are so-called because they do not follow strictly the form for a
regular conditional sentence. The *protasis rules in classifying conditional
sentences.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:

text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin conditional sentences</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Simple fact present: si +
present indicative in both clauses [nothing implied] </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If he
crosses the bridge, he breaks the treaty.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Simple fact past: si + past ind
in both clauses </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If he
crossed the bridge, he broke the treaty. [nothing implied]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Contrary to fact present: si +
imperfect subjunctive in both clauses (for present </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> time)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If he
were crossing the bridge, he would be breaking the treaty.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Contrary-to-fact past: si +
pluperfect subjunctive in both clauses (for past time)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If he
had crossed the bridge, he would have broken the treaty.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Simple fact future (future
more vivid): si + future indicative in both clauses</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If he
crosses the bridge, he will break the treaty.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Future less vivid: si +
present subjunctive in both clauses [or any fut form in the </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> second]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
