text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If he
should cross the bridge, he would break the treaty.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If subordinate conjunctions replace the
if word, a temporal conditional clause is created. If a relative pronoun or
indefinite relative pronoun replaces the if word, an indefinite relative
clause is created.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(in a set with * particular conditional
sentence [Gr]/*simple fact conditional sentence [Lat], *contrary-to-fact
conditional sentence, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>*vague future conditional sentence
[Gr]/*future less vivid conditional sentence [Lat], </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>*vivid future conditional sentence
[Gr]/*future less vivid conditional sentence, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>*future most vivid conditional
sentence [Gr], </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>*simple fact future [Lat] </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>conflate/conflated/conflation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
mixed together in such a way that the original parts may be unretrievable as
separate items. The expression could be used of an account that blends items of
two accounts into one inclusive presentation as with the accounts of Jesus
life, the three accounts of Pauls conversion in Acts, the parallel entries
between Samuel-Kings and Chronicles. One example of conflation occurs on
Christmas cards that picture the shepherds and wise men together at the stable;
the Magi came to a <u>house</u> sometime later than the night of Jesus birth
(Mt <b>2</b>:11). Mt <b>24-25</b> conflate the destruction of Jerusalem and the
Lords Second Coming (Mk <b>13</b>; Lk <b>21</b>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>conjugation/conjugate</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
carrying <u>verbs</u> through their various possible forms; <u>declension</u>
carries nouns and adjectives through their possible forms.. The possible forms of
verbs can indicate *person (1, 2, 3), *number (singular, dual, plural), *gender
(in Hebrew second and third persons), *tense, *voice, *mood (*indicative, *imperative,*subjunctive,*optative,
*infinitive), *aspect, *participles, and *infinitives. (in a set with
*declension; *verbals)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>conjugations</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
sets of endings for specific verb types within a language</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English does not conjugate its verbs for
person except for the -<i>s/z </i>sound for third person, singular, present,
indicative active. Latin has four conjugations, whose present infinitives end
in -<i>are, -re, -ere, -ire</i>. Hebrew has seven *stems through which its
verbs may be carried. Greek has omega verbs, omega contract verbs (-<i>aoo,
-eoo, -ooo</i>), and <i>mi</i> verbs.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>conjunction</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word that grammatically ties parts of a sentence together </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Co-ordinating conjunctions tie equal
elements together whether words, phrases, clauses, or sentences: <i>and, but,
nor, or; et, sed </i>(Lat.);<i> kai, alla </i>(Gr.)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Correlative conjunctions are pairs of
conjoining words: <i>both . . . and</i>; <i>neither . . . nor</i>; <i>either .
. . or</i>; <i>not only . . . but also</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Subordinating conjunctions tie grammatically
unequal elements together, particularly dependent and independent clauses. English
examples are *temporal conjunctions <i>after</i>, <i>before</i>, <i>since</i>, <i>when</i>
as well as conjunctions with other values like <i>if</i>, <i>although</i>, <i>because</i>,
<i>whereas</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *concession, *coordinating
conjunction, *correlative conjunction, *subordinating conjunction)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>conjunctive accent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
 *Conjunctive accents indicate continuation and unity (phrasing) between words
in a Hebrew text.. As such, they contrast with *disjunctive accents (WG 251)
indicate separation or pause between words in the pointed text of the Hebrew
Bible. (in a set with *disjunctive accent)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>conjunctive adverb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word that joins two sentences together and so is usually preceded by a
semi-colon: He did not take the semester test; so, he flunked the course. Other
examples are <i>otherwise</i>, <i>so</i>, <i>consequently</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>conjunctive relative pronoun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
WH306#17 309#84 308#68</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>connecting vowel</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
since language usually alternates *consonants and *vowels, vowels are often
inserted between forms to make words pronounceable. (1) It can happen between
roots and personal endings on verbs (L. habe + [o] -s, -t, -mus, -tis, -nt; the
Greek -o/e- variable for the same purpose in the present, future, and
imperfect, and second aorist forms of *omega verbs. The absence of added
connecting vowels in the Greek perfect middle/passive created a fairly complex
set of alterations on the final consonant of the root because those root
consonants were jammed up against the mu, sigma, tau, and nt of the personal
ending set. (2) Vowels serve as splices between roots in compound English words.
Most frequently <u>o</u>- fulfills this role: therm-<u>o</u>-meter, Graec-<u>o</u>-Roman.
Sometimes <u>i</u>- is used: ven-<u>i</u>-puncture, alges-<u>i</u>-meter. German
invokes the <u>ess</u> sound for the same purpose: religion-<u>s</u>-geschichte.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *theme vowel, *epenthesis)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>connectives</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a term that covers types of words that connect syntactical segments. They
consist chiefly of *conjunctions, *prepositions, and some *particles.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>connotation/connote</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the additional meaning of a word beyond its basic factual meaning, derivational
meaning, or *word picture. Connotation comes from typical associations in
present time irrespective of historical or linguistic associations. Connotation
includes negative-positive implication, humor, social class connections,
intensity. <i>Notion</i> and <i>idea</i>, though synonyms in general, differ in
that <i>notion</i> connotes a weak or false idea. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The connotation of a word is not
necessarily shared across the board with other members of the word family. <i>Creature</i>
comes from Latin <i>creo, </i>to create; but<i> </i>it has gained the sense of
something dangerous or at least mysterious. It has lost its connection with
being created. <i>Secretary </i>is a word whose meaning has been determined by
specialized usage for someone who assists another person, particularly in an
office situation. It has lost conscious connection with keeping secrets. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *denotation) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>consequent clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the main clause of any conditional sentence: If he crosses the bridge, <i>he
breaks the treaty</i>. Same as *apodosis. (in a set with *if-clause)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>consonant</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a speech sound made by stoppage, restriction, or other manipulation of the air flow
through the oral and nasal cavities. Consonants include *stops, *fricatives, *flaps,
*trills, and *plosives, together with voicing and not voicing each and
ingressive/exgressive air flow. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with* vowel)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>consonantal alphabet</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a set of letters that represent only the consonants of a written languageHebrew,
for example.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'><b>consonant cluster</b>: a group of two or more
consonants with no vowels between them: <i>pl, pr, sp, st, str, spl, tr, br,
cr, cl, dr,</i> <i>etc.</i>, in English. From an English standpoint, Greeks consonant
clusters were sometimes unusual: <i>bd, ps, pn, pt, kt, gn, mn, chth, phth, thn</i>,
others????? </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *diphthong; *glide)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>construct noun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a Hebrew noun whose vowel pointing has been weakened to show its connection
with a subsequent noun, to which it is tied by a <i>makeph</i>.. The two nouns
relate like that of a noun plus genitive noun in Greek and Latin or like a noun
plus of-noun expression in English. The difference is that the first noun,
not the second, is the one altered. In addition, the two form a bound
construction, i.e., one that cannot be separated by other elements; hence, any
possessive suffix must be added to the end of the set as in the wife of his
youth (Mal <b>2</b>:14), for his young wife. The idiom seems to affect Greek
usage in the NT Ephesians. Examples = = </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>construction</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
usually referring to a set of words arranged according to formula (*syntax) for
the expression of particular concepts: <i>indirect-discourse construction</i> <b>{insert
panel]</b> <i>ablative absolute construction, absolute constructions,
accusative absolute construction, adversative clause construction,</i> <i>agency
with active voice</i>, <i>agency with gerundive, agency with passive voice,
appositive construction, causal clause, circumstantial clause, clause, commands,
complementary constr</i></span><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>uc</span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tion,
complementary infinitive, complex sentence, compound sentence, compound-complex
sentence, concessive clause, conditional clause constructions, construct state,
contrary-to-fact conditional sentence, cum clauses, dative absolute
construction, dative of possession, deliberative construction, exhortation, fear
clause, fused verb, future less vivid conditional sentence, future vivid
conditional sentence, genitive absolute, gerundive construction, indirect
discourse, indirect question, infinitive absolute construction, infinitive
phrase, jussive noun clause, manner constructions, merged verb, nominative
absolutes construction, object clause, objective complement, participial phrase
construction, passive periphrastic construction, passive transform, periphrastic
construction, periphrastic verb, phrase, phrase preposition, phrasal verb,
phrase verb, prepositional phrase, present/past particular conditional
sentence, progressive verb, prohibition, proviso clause, purpose clause, purpose
clause,</span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>relative clause, result clause, relative clause of
characteristic, sentence, subjective complement, temporal clause constructions,
than construction, time constructions, transform, vague future conditional
sentence, vav consecutive construction, wish construction.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(in
a set with *clause, *phrase, *syntax)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>conspectus</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a gathering together of related information for the purpose of easier
comparison. Ex. A conspectus of Greek mood usages. (in a set with *synopsis, *model)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>contingent action</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
action the depends on another action, one action that is a function of another
action. The type of action often covered by the subjunctive mood in Latin and
Greek</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>construction</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the arrangement of words into sets that expresses various degrees of complete
thoughts.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>context</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the surrounding
subject matter that qualifies and limits the conceivable meanings of more
statements within it. &lt; <i>con </i>(with) + <i>text</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>contract adjectives</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>contract nouns</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>contract rules</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Greek used a standard set of rules for contraction between short vowels before
vowels of any length (long vowels + long vowels did not contract):</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> epsilon-contract rules: e + o = ou;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  e +
e = ei; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  e +
a = eta; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  ee +
anything else = the anything else (that is, e + a long vowel </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  =
the long vowel</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> alpha-contract rules: a + o-sound = omega
(with subscript if an i-diphthong involved; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  a + e-sound
= long alpha (with subscript if i-diphthong involved); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  a + a = long
alpha</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> omicron-contrct rules: o + i-diphthong
(*proper or *improper) = oi; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  o +
naturally long vowel (eta or omega) = omega; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  o +
anything else = ou. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>contract verbs</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Greek has three types of verbs with three different weak vowels on the end of
their stems in the first principal parts: alpha contracts, epsilon contracts,
and omicron contracts. These vowels contract with the o/e variable that
connects the root with the endings for persons, participles, and infinitives. These
contract vowels lengthen before the tense signs in the other principal parts. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Contract verbs are the most regular Greek
verbs because their principal parts are almost always predictable: they
lengthen the contract vowel (epsilon to eta, alpha to eta, omicron to omega)
and then add the tense signs for future, first aorist, first perfect active,
and first aorist passive principle parts. The regularity shows also in that
they all have first aorists and first aorist passives, and do not have
*semi-deponents.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *contract rules)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>contraction</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
any of various ways of shortening words or word combinations. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Spoken English uses many examples of what
may also be called *crasis, but they are often given in full in written
dialogue. Contractions are usually not used in formal writing; they are used in
friendly communication to strike a relaxed tone. They are written with no
periods and no spaces, and usually have an apostrophe in place of the missing
letter(s): <i>aint, bcome, burbs, cant, cmon, cont, couldnt, couldntve,
couldve,</i> <i>dept, doesnt, dont, een, eer, em, </i>er (as in <i>fill
er up</i>), <i>govt, hed, held, heldve, hell, hes; howd, howeer, howve,
Ill, isnt, Ive, Idve; well; its, itll, itd, itldve; lets, mfg, lil,
mustnt, neednt, needntve, neer, neer-do-well, noreaster, nothin </i>(reallym,
all such spellings of <i>ing</i> words swap one nasal for another),<i> oclock,
rock n roll, shes, shed </i>(she had, shed would)<i>, shell, she ld;
sheldve; shouldnt</i>, <i>shouldntve, shouldve</i>, <i>smores</i>, <i>spose</i>,
<i>taint</i> (it aint)<i>, thatll; thats, theyll, theyre, theyve, they
ld, theyldve; whats, whatll; wed </i>(we had),<i> weve; sos;tis; we
ld (we would); were, werent, whateer, whats, wheneer, whereer, whoeer, whore,
wholl, whod, whos, whove, who ld, wholdve; wont, wouldnt, wouldntve,</i>
<i>wouldve</i>, <i>youd, yould, youldve, youll, youre, youve; up and at
em, whyd, zwounds</i> (by Gods wounds);</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> As a term, <i>contraction</i> especially
refers to a shortening <u>within</u> a word; <i>crasis</i> most particularly
refers to blending a word with the word <u>after</u> it; <i>aphesis</i> is a
shortening by an omissionusually a vowelon the <u>front</u> of a word.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek, contraction occurred with
*contract adjectives, *contract nouns, and *contract verbs. Additionally
contraction occurred when *intervocalic sigma fell out between vowels, which
then contracted.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek has three types of contract verbs,
verbs that have a weak vowel on the end of the root of the first principal part.
In the process of conjugation, when these epsilon-contract, alpha-contract, and
omicron-contract verbs have those weak vowels exposed to the <i>o/e </i>variable
before the personal endings <i>per se</i>; they combine with the <i>o/e</i>
variable by standard rules to make another, long sound. See *contract rules.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin poetry, contraction could occur
with perfects to accommodate the demands of meter (WH 314#122)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *aphesis, *crasis, *elision,
*syncope) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>convention</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the features of language are arbitrary rather than innate (inborn) or rooted in
the nature of things (inherent). Human convention determines the meaning of
sounds/words, syntactical relationships, punctuation symbols, <i>etc.</i> The
conventional nature of language does not imply that there is no need to learn
the oral or written conventions of punctuation and the like. For the most part,
these devices have been developed to afford clarity in the oral and written forms
of the language. Not knowing or using them implies lack of competence
generally. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The observation about convention also does
not imply that there is no need to learn the spoken conventions. Admittedly,
some fine distinctions are more precise than necessary for most purposes, and
in such matters *language drift occurs in greater degree. Ignorance of such
matters usually lies underneath much of the change that occurs, and it can do
so without confusion. If it caused confusion, the drift would not be able to
catch on. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Attempting to by-pass conventions and
indulge in simplification (a) often leads to ambiguity. (b) Not learning the
conventions can also mark a speaker as unreliable as to ideas as well. Other
people read off of ones departure from norm such things as ignorance, which disqualifies
his ideas from serious consideration. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (c) The choice of which set of conventions
to follow tends to categorize a communicator. There are formal and informal
usages of a language (*diglossia). There are *slang words and *provincialisms. There
are standard and conversational styles of speaking, and it is expected that a
person shape his communication to the setting*verisimilitude. Speaking and
writing in a highly educated manner among every-day people, for example, is a
turn-off t; they are likely to see it as pride more than ability. This speaking
above peoples heads is considered pedantic. Speaking beneath people can
imply ignorance of the speaker or lack of respect for the audience. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>coordinate clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a clause that is grammatically parallel to, or equal to, another clause; one of
two independent clauses joined by a *conjunction</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>coordinating conjunction</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word that joins two grammatically equal elements in grammar whether nouns,
adjectives, adverbs, verbs, clauses: <i>and</i>, <i>but</i>, <i>or</i>, <i>nor</i>.
Contrasts with *subordinate conjunction, which introduces grammatically unequal
elements like subordinate and insubordinate clauses: <i>when, if, although,
since,</i> and the like. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek coordinating conjunctions are<i>
kai, alla.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin coordinating conjunctions are <i>et,
sed</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Co-ordinating conjunctions tie equal
elements together whether words, phrases, clauses, or sentences.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *subordinate conjunction)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>copula</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a verb whose
meaning is not to convey actionas an *action verb, but to indicate identity. (in
a set with *action verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>copulative verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb that indicates being rather than action; another term for *linking verb,
*to be verb, *equative verb, *state-of-being verb. Note also *fientive verb and
*stative verb.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>corpus</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a body of
writings on the same subject or of the same sort.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>correlative(s): </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>terms
that share a common larger category and therefore are to be understood in a way
that honors that commonality. <i>Father</i> and <i>son</i> as correlative
terms, in the same context, are both meant physically or spiritually rather
than one taken physically and the other spiritually.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>correlative conjunctions</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
 Correlative conjunctions are pairs of conjoining words: <i>both . . . and</i>;
<i>neither . . . nor</i>; <i>either . . . or</i>; <i>not only . . . but also</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>correlative terms</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) terms that belong together in a construction, as with correlative
conjunctions: <i>both . . . and</i>; <i>neither . . . nor</i>; <i>either . . .
or</i>; <i>not only . . . but also</i>. (2) terms that are customarily used
together even though other second members of the pair would make sense: <i>question/answer,
problem/solution, big/small (little), yes/no,</i> (3) related words as in <i>neither/nor,
either/or</i>. Latin has pairs like <i>uter/neuter, umquam/numquam,
ullum/nullum. </i>(4) common sense between two termsas in figurative or
literal on both sides of the pair: <i>father/son </i>(physical or spiritual,
but not mixed). (5) correlative adjectives <i>so much as, so great as, for such
a[long time].</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>correspondence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
written personal messages exchanged between parties</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>correspondent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
one who corresponds, n.; corresponding to, adj.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>corrigendum/corrigenda</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a list of errors in a book and their corrections</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>corruption/corrupt</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a significant modification of a term or expression that belies its origin: <i>cuss</i>
&lt; <i>curse</i>, <i>cuz</i> &lt; <i>because</i>. In reference to a text, a
change deliberate or otherwise that destroys a texts original meaning or makes
that meaning unrecoverable.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>count noun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Webster unclear</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>countersign</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a add a second signature to a legal document as an assurance that the
responsibilities of the first person will be carried out by the second if the
first defaults.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>couplet</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a two-line piece
in poetry (in a set with *triplet) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>courtesy title</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
terms like <i>sir, -san </i>(Japanese), <i>maam, se</i></span><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif'></span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>or,
se</span></i><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Arial",sans-serif'></span></i><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ora, se</span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif'></span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>orita,
segnor</span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> that imply respect rather than legal standing or
right (in a set with *honorific)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>covenant</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an agreement
between persons for some kind of ongoing relationship. There were two kinds of
covenants in the ancient Near East: between equal partners and between unequal partners
get the names for these</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>covenant, suzerainry</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a covenant between unequals. The Pentateuch? Can be analyzed as a kind of
extended suzerainty covenant.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>covenant, </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>between
equals<b> </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cowrite</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to collaborate
in the production of a piece</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cradlesong</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a *lullaby</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>crasis</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the blending of
a word with a subsequent word; similar to *contraction (dont) and *elision; a
mixing of two words. For English examples, see *contraction.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek examples include <i>ho aner</i>,
which becomes <i>haner</i>;<i> to heteron</i> becomes <i>thateron</i>; <i>kai
egoo</i> becomes <i>kagoo</i>; <i>kai ekeivos</i> becomes <i>kakeivos</i>; <i>kai
ekei then</i> becomes <i>kakeithen</i>; <i>to onoma</i> becomes <i>tounoma</i>;
<i>ta auta</i> becomes <i>tauta</i>, ??<i>tounantion, ei + an becomes ean</i>. The
blending may be marked by an *apostrophe. D &amp; M, p.22. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin does the same thing with <u>ne</u> +
<u>volo</u> to get <u>nolo</u>; note also <i>videre licet </i>(to see is
permitted) as <i>videlicet</i>, an introduction to examples or lists.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>creed</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a formal,
authoritative summary of convictions that a communicant must be able to affirm
for inclusion in a specific religious entity. The objection to creeds has lain
in this displacement of authority from scripture to secondary literature. (in a
set with *statement of faith, *by-laws, *scripture) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>creole</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>crossword puzzle</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word game that gives brief clues for word entries across and down</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cryptic</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: intentionally having
secret, mystifying, hidden, or undecipherable meaning</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cryptogram</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
something written in secret code</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cryptograph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a system of written secret code</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cryptographer</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
one who specializes in writing secret code</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cryptography</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the process of writing secret code</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cryptology</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of written secret codes</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>crude</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a way of
speaking that is offensive, disgusting, impolite, vulgar</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cue</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cuneiform</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having a small wedge-shaped characters as used for writing ancient Akkadian,
Assyrian, Babylonian, Persian, or Sumerian texts.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>curated document</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
one that has been heavily edited and revised in route to its present form</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>curse formula</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a stylized expression that pronounces a curse on someone for doing something,
as an inscription on a tomb that pronounces a curse on grave robbers for
disturbing the remains of the one buried there. forbidden</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>curse word/curse/cuss</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(in a set with *oath, *swear; *archaism, *buzz word, *catch phrase,
*colloquialism, *informal term, *provincialism, *regionalism, *slang,
*vulgarism)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cursive</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a flowing form
of writing that joins letters together in contrast to putting them down
separately by printing; an easier form of writing that enables the scribe to
keep the writing utensil on the page instead of picking it up after each letter
entry </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *block lettering,
*printing, *writing) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>custom of usage: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Two
languages may share certain language features, but they do not necessarily use
them in the same situations. An example may be Latins usage of the imperfect
tense in different circumstances from where English does. English uses the
simple past if there are accompanying adverbs to indicate linear action: always,
usually, daily, <i>etc.</i> Latins omission of possessive adjectives in cases
where possession is clear from other facts in the sentence. English very much
wants to say his, their, her, our, <i>etc.</i> English uses a futuristic
present in if-clauses of the future; Latin and Greek use the future tense in
such situations. Greek has relative clauses, but they are not used as
frequently as in English because Greek likes participles.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cut</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a *slam, an *insult, a
*slur, an overt negative evaluative comment to a person; differs from *innuendo
and insinuation by being direct rather than implied and thus inferred. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dactyl</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: in poetry a
metrical foot consisting of one accented syllable followed by two unaccented
syllables, one long syllable followed by two short ones</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dactylic hexameter</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Wh 289</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dactylology</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the use of the fingers to communicate with the deaf using a *manual alphabet</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *signing, *sign language))</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dagesh forte</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a dot in the center non-guttural ???? Hebrew letters that indicates doubling.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dagesh lene</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a dot put in the center of six Hebrew letters (<i>beth, gimel, dalet, kaph,
phe, tav)</i> that shifts them from fricatives to corresponding voiceless
stops. In modern pronunciation, <i>gimel</i> and <i>dalet</i> are always
pronounced as stops regardless of the written form.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>daily</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: n. short for
daily *newspaper, one that comes every day, every</span><span dir=RTL></span><span
dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=RTL></span> </span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>day but one, or every weekday but not on
weekends</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dalet/daleth</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the fourth letter of the Hebrew alphabet: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL
style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dangling participle</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an introductory participle that does not modify the subject of the main clause:
Looking at the rest of the schedule, there are four home games left and two
away. A similar lack of proper connection exists when a preposition-gerund
combination begins the sentence: By driving the nail into a stud, it was
strong enough to hold the heavy picture. The actor in the *gerund should also
be the actor in the main verb: By driving the nail into a stud, I kept the
heavy picture from pulling it out.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dative absolute</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
one possible use of the dative case for an absolute construction in the New
Testament is ________.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dative case</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Dative case most basically indicates relationship. In that role there is
*dative of possession, *indirect object, dative case after certain verbs
implying relationship or attitude (Gr &amp; Lat), dative nouns with certain
verbs implying relationship. There is also *dative of degree of difference,
*dative of reference, *dative of separation (Lat).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek, the dative case appears after
certain kinds of prepositions, especially those that imply location (note *locative
case). The case also appears after certain Greek and Latin verbs that imply
relationship. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin has appropinquo, to draw near
to/approach near; credo, to believe; ignosco, to pardon/forgive; impero, to
command; invideo, to envy; nosceo, to harm; nubo, to marry; parco, to spare,
pareo, to obey; persuadeo, to persuade; placeo, to please; servio, to serve;
studeo, to study; as well as compounds that may govern the dative: adsum, to
support; obsequor, to obey; praesto, to surpass.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dative of agent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the case used on a noun for agency with gerundive (fut. passive ptc.)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dative of degree of difference</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
He was older <u>by six years</u>. Greek puts six years in the dative case
with no accompanying preposition. (Latin follows the same pattern, using the
ablative case.) Degree of difference calls for no special construction in
English. Instead it is covered by an adverb-adjective combination or by using <u>by</u>
plus the measurement: He was six years older; older by six years. (in a set
with *degree of difference, *ablative of degree of difference)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dative of interest</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
same as *dative of reference WH326</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dative of possession</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
appears in linking-verb Greek and Latin sentences to indicate the owner: There
is a lid <u>to the box</u>. (wh 349#6) Acts<b> 4</b>:32 says, No one was
saying that anything of-the-things being <u>to-him</u> was his-own.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dative of purpose</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Latin uses dative on nouns that can indicate purpose: WH 53: Vitae discimus (We
learn for life). WH330</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dative of reference</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/<b>interest</b>:
(Wheelock p. 270). In Greek an expression like Ananias by (Ananias onamati,
Acts <b>5</b>:1).)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dative of relationship</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
 Dative case appears on nouns connected to <u>adjectives</u> that
imply the manner of relationship introduced by English to: He was hostile to
his father [<u>father</u> = Greek and Latin dative case with no accompanying
preposition]. The dative case on nouns is used also in place of accusative in
Latin and Greek verbs that imply relationship: to follow (Gr), trust (L),
persuade (L), serve (L), <i>etc.</i> More specifically the usage is dative or <u>personal</u>
relationship. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dative of separation: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Wh
307#13 306#23 242 Latin</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Decalog(ue), The</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a designation for the ten commandments found in Jewish law (Ex <b>20</b>:1-17;
Deut <b>6</b>:6-21). [Gr deca + logos]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>decipher</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to figure out a
*cipher; to determine the meaning of a message written in code, to figure out
what is unclear, as with someone elses sloppy handwriting, an enigmatic
*notation, or partially destroyed *inscription</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>declamation: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>the
delivery of a memorized piece written by another; an vehement presentation
marked by strong feeling; a tirade</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *oration, *speech,
*reading)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>declaration</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a formal announcement delivered in writing or orally; a statement of goods
taken along when entering another country </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>declarative sentence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a sentence that is simply stating something in contrast to asking, exclaiming,
or commanding it; hence, it is punctuated with a period and does not use the *imperative
mood: He is going home. (in a set with *exclamatory sentence, *
interrogative sentence, *imperative sentence) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>declension</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
n. (1) the type of *inflection used on nouns and adjectives (2) a set of
endings for specific nouns and adjectives that indicated number, gender, and
case</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English does not decline its nouns except
for singular and plural and for possessive, but English pronouns do have different
forms for subjective, objective, and possessive usages.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek has three main declensions with six
subdivisions in the first declension, two subdivisions in the second, and
several subdivisions in the third. Latin has five declensions with three
subdivisions in the second (populus, magister/liber, concilium); five
subdivisions in the third; and two subdivisions in the fourth. In general,
Hebrew does not decline its nouns and adjectives for case. It does decline for
number (sg/pl) and gender (mas/fem).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> There is a general correlation between
declensions and grammatical gender. Greek first-declension nouns are feminine
in four subsets (-<i>ee, -, a/a</i>) and masculine in the last two subsets (-<i>ees,
-s</i>). Second declension noun in os are mostly masculine (except for ) and
on nouns are all neuter. The third declension, also called the consonant
declension, has nouns that are masculine and feminine sharing declension patterns
and neuter nouns that use a set with the same genitive and dative forms as the
masculines and feminines. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> First-declension nouns in Latin are
feminine except for <i>agricola</i> (farmer), <i>auriga</i> (charioteer), <i>conviva</i>
(dinner-guest), <i>incola</i> (inhabitant), <i>nauta</i> (sailor), <i>pirata</i>
(pirate), <i>poeta</i> (poet). Second-declension nouns in <i>us</i> are
masculine (except for <i>abyssus,</i> feminine) or neuter words in <i>um</i>. Third
declension uses the same ending set for masculine and feminine, and has neuters
that are like them except in the nominative/vocative and accusative. Fourth
declension has mostly masculines together with some feminines that use the same
ending set; there are a few neuters that are like the first subdivision except
for nominative/vocative and accusative. Fifth declension nouns are all feminine
except for the word <i>dies</i> (day).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *case [nouns/adjectives], *conjugation
[verbs]; *declinable nouns, *indeclinable nouns, *inflection [n/adj, v];
*dictionary form) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>declinable nouns</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Most nouns have a set of case forms in Greek and Latin, but a few have only one
form: <u>nihil</u>, <u>satis</u> (L) (in a set with *indeclinable nouns or
*indeclinable adjectives)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>decrypt/decryption</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to *decode, *decipher a *cryptogram. To change from a special code to an
understandable message; to figure out the meaning of what is obscure or
unreadable</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>deed</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: n. a statement
of ownership particularly landed property????? (in a set with *title, *writ) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>defective spelling</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the shorter form of a Hebrew word that does not have a doubled last consonant
with inserted vowel letter between the duplicates (in a set with *plene
spelling)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>defective verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb that does not have all its principal parts or lacks some forms within a
conjugation set. The Latin <u>inquit</u> appears mostly in third singular
present and less frequently in first or second singular, but does not have a
full conjugation; also <i>memini</i>,<i> meminisse</i>; (in a set with
*composite verb, *deponent verb, *regular verb, *suppletive verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>definiendum</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the word or expression being defined (Lat neut gerundive &lt; <i>definire</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *definiens)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>definiens</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the word(s) used to define another word (Lat nom/mas/sg/pres/act/ptc &lt; <i>definire</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>definite article</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In English, <i>the</i> is the definite article; it is pronounced thee before
vowel sounds and thuh before consonant sounds. The pattern is an oral one;
consequently, the variant pronunciation of <i>the</i> is relative to sound, not
writing. For example, people say <i>thuh</i> before <i>eu-/u</i> words that
have a <i>y</i> sound pronounced on the front: <i>thu</i> eulogy<i>, the
euphemism/eulogy/union, etc., </i><b>(insert panel</b>: <i>eucane, eucakyptol,
eucalyptus, eucharist, euchire, euchromatin, eudemonism, eugenic, eugenol,
euglena, euhermerism, eukaryote, eunuch, eunonymous, eupatrid, eupepsia,
euphonium, euphony, euphorbia, euporia, euphotic, euphuism, euplastic, euphold,
eupnea, eureka, euripus, europium, eurybathic, euryhaline, euryterid,
eurythermal, eurythmics, eurythmy, eurytopic, eustachian tube, eustasy,
eustele, eutectic, euthanasia, euthenics, eutherian, eutrophic; upsilon, user</i><b>).</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:4.5pt;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Thuh</i> occurs before a
few <i>o-</i> words with a <i>w</i> sound on the front. People say, He is not <i>thuh</i>
one; she gave it <i>thuh </i>once-over.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:4.5pt;text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>On
the other hand, people say <i>thee honor </i>because the <i>h</i> represents a
glottal stop (as it does in <i>heir, honest,</i> <i>hour, </i>and <i>humble </i>for
some speakers). (All other h words have <i>thuh</i>: <i>hassel, hearth, hit,
hook, hut, hydrant</i>.) The <i>h </i>on the special words has the same value
as the *glottal stop that is actually on the front of all English words written
with a first vowel; they really begin with a glottal stop, the sound
represented by the <i>h</i> of <i>honor, etc.</i> There is just no written
symbol used. Thus, <i>apple</i> is (with the <i>h</i> of <i>honor</i>) really <i>happle</i>,
<i>egg</i> is <i>hegg</i>, <i>it</i> is <i>hit, owe </i>is <i>howe, under </i>is<i>
hunder</i>; all <i>eu-u-</i> words, though, that pronounce a <i>y</i> on the
front replace the <i>h</i> glottal stop with that <i>y</i>. (All English as
well as Greek, Latin, and Hebrew, words begin with a consonant in point of
sound.) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> One refinement in English definite article
use is whether two definite nouns have an article with each one or one article
ahead of both. The difference is that two articles enter the nouns separately
into the sentence and give them equal attention. One article ahead of both
enters them into the sentence as a combination. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin has no articles at all, but <i>ille</i>
sometimes approaches the value of a definite article, especially in identifications
like Magna Ille Alexander, Alexander the Great.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greeks articles do not distinguish between
definite and indefinite, but between quality and identity. English article
usage calls for definiteness in many places where Greek calls for identity; so,
<i>the</i> frequently translates <i>ho/hee/to</i>. But, strictly speaking, the
two ideas are not the same. English also can use the *indefinite article to
indicate quality, especially with a *noun typical of its class; so the Greek
anarthrous noun can often be translated with a/an. The main thing to remember
in translating Greek articles is that <i>the </i>does not necessarily equal the
Greek article and <i>a/an</i> does not necessarily equal the Greek anarthrous usage.
Ex. Jn <b>1</b>:1 does not mean, In <u>a</u> beginning was <u>the</u> word and
<u>the</u> word was with <u>the</u> God and <u>the</u> word was <u>a</u> God.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *indefinite article)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>degrees of comparison</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an expression that applies to adjectives and adverbs in English, Latin, and
Greek. The first degree is called the *positive degree, the second degree is the
*comparative degree, the third degree is called *superlative degree. Adjective
comparison:<i> quick/quick<u>er</u>/quick<u>est</u> </i>or <i>dignified/<u>more</u>
dignified/<u>most</u> dignified</i>; adverb comparison: <i>quickly, <u>more</u>
quickly, <u>most</u> quickly. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew does not have distinctive forms for
comparative adjectives and adverbs. Instead, the idiom is as follows: <i>First
