noun of the comparison</i> is <i>adjective</i> + <i>from</i> (<i>min</i>) second
noun of the comparison: He is tall from his brother. (in a set with
*positive, *comparative, *superlative)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>degree</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>of difference</b>:
the amount of difference between two things in regard to time, space, weight, <i>etc</i>.,
most of the time involving a *comparative degree adjective or adverb. English
covers the idea by putting the measurement ahead of the adjective as a kind of
*adverbial noun (six inches taller; four minutes faster; two ounces
lighter) or by using <u>by</u> plus the measurement (taller by six inches;
faster by four minutes; lighter by two ounces). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek puts the measure in the dative case
(). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin puts the measurement in the ablative
case (). (in a set with *ablative of degree of difference, *dative of degree of
difference)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew has no comparative- or superlative-degree
adjectives. Consequently, it has no construction for degree of difference and
must rely on some kind of *circumlocution to express the idea.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>deictic</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: pointing out
directly, demonstrating</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><u><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dele</span></u></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: remove from the
text in contrast to *<u>stet</u>, let it stand.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>deliberative questions</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
questions that imply uncertainty: What are we going to do?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>deliberative subjunctive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the use of the subjunctive mood in Latin and Greek for questions that imply
uncertainty. Same as *dubitative subjunctive. (in a set with *deliberative
question)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>delta</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: fourth letter of
the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>demonstratives</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
pronouns or adjectives that point out</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>demonstrative adjective</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an adjective that points out: <u>this</u> book, <u>that</u> car. In English,
Latin, and Greek, demonstrative adjectives are the same as demonstrative
pronouns, the differences being whether there is an accompanying noun. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The Greek demonstrative adjectives are <i>houtos</i>
(this), <i>ode</i> (this), <i>ekeinos</i> (that). Demonstrative adjectives in
Greek always take predicate position, i.e., not between article and noun but
before article or immediately after noun. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latins demonstrative adjectives are <i>hic/haec/hoc</i>
(this), <i>iste/ista/istud</i> (that as of second person), <i>ille/illa/illud</i>
(that as of third person), <i>is/ea/</i>id (that), and <i>idem/iadem/idem</i>
(the same). They all are capable also of standing alone as *demonstrative
pronouns (or substantive adjective, if a person prefers so to call them).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>demonstrative pronouns</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
pronouns that point out: this and that. The English demonstratives <u>this/these</u>
are near demonstratives and <u>that/those</u> are distant demonstratives. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In contrast to Englishs two
demonstratives, Latin has three, each one corresponding to the persons in
verbs: hic/haec/hoc for <u>this</u> near me/us, ille/illa/illud for <u>that</u>
distant to both speaker and hearer, and iste/ista/istud for <u>that</u> associated
with the hearer/s. In addition, Latin has two other demonstratives that cover
third-person references. <i>Is/ea/id</i> is a less emphatic demonstrative than <u>ille</u>.
Is/ea/id can stand alone as a third-person pronoun parallel to <i>ego/nos</i>
and <i>tu/vos</i> (you), and it can modify nouns as a demonstrative adjective. The
suffix dem can be added to <i>is/ea/id</i> to make a word that means the same
(one/thing). Some adjustments in spelling are involved for ease of
pronunciation. Final <i>m</i> on <i>is/ea/id</i> shifts to <i>n</i>, a dental
nasal before a dental stop (<i>eu<u>n</u>dem</i>, <i>etc.</i>). The theoretical
nominative masculine singular <i>i<u>s</u>dem</i> becomes </span><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dem</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
losing sibilant <i>s</i> before a dental and showing *compensatory lengthening
on the <i>i</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> It may be a matter of taste whether lone
demonstratives are called pronouns or substantive adjectives. The difference is
whether they are thought of as being primarily alone and then used as
adjectives or vice versa. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *demonstrative adjective;
*near demonstrative, *distant demonstrative, *aforementioned demonstrative,
*to-be-said demonstrative pronoun)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>demotic</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an offshoot of
*hieroglyphics, a simplified form of hieroglyphics, as something more usable by
the common person; also modern colloquial Greek (Gr <i>deemos&gt;deemotees&gt;
deemotikos, </i>people)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *hieratic, *hieroglyphics)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>denominative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
formed from a noun as <i>muscular</i> from <i>muscle </i>(n &gt; adj) or <i>memorize</i>
from <i>memory</i> (n. &gt; verb).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>denotation/denote</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the straightforward, factual meaning of a term; perhaps its derivational
meaning or word picture; the original meaning from which specializations may
have developed </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *connotation)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dentals</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: sounds that are
made with the teeth: <i>t, d, th, dh, n</i>: (in a set with *labials, *labio-dental,
*velars/*palatals, *liquids, and *glottals)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dependent: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>an
element that can stand on its own to express a complete thought; some
grammatical feature that does not need another element in order to stand. (in a
set with *independent)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dependent clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Also called *subordinate clause. A dependent clause is a one that does not
stand by itself because it is not perceived to express a complete thought.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dependent verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the verb in a *dependent clause of a *complex sentence; a verb whose clause
cannot stand by itself.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (n a set with independent verb; *leading
verb, *main verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>deponent verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a Greek or Latin verb that lacks an active voice form. Consequently, its
(*middle voice or) *passive voice form is translated into English as active
voice. English does not have deponent verbs</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin deponents include <i>adhortor, adloquor,
adsequor/assequor, aggredior, apricor, deponents include admiror, arbitror, colloquor,
commoror, complector, confiteor, conor, consector, consequor, convivor, egredior,
emorior, experior, fateor, for, fruor, hortor, iaculor, imitor, infitior,
ingredior, intueor, loquor, meditor, mentior, mereor, miror, moderor, molior,
morior, nascor, nitor, obsequor, opinor, osculor, patior, peregrinor, persequor,
piscor, polliceor, precor, proficiscor, profiteor, profor, queror, regredior, rusticor,
sector, sequor, suspicor, testor, tueor, utor, vagor, vereor.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek deponents increased in number from
classical into the koine, especially in the case of intransitive verbs. Greek
deponents include <i>agoonidzomai, haireomai, aisthanomai, aischunomai,
akaireomai, anaballomai, anagnooridzomai, analogidzomai, anatassomai,
anatithemai, anemidzomai, anerchomai, anechomai, anthomologeomai, antagoonidzomai,
antapokrinomai, antechomai, antidiatithemai, antikeimai, antiparechomai,
antistrateuomai, antitassomai, apagchomai, apallotrioomai, aparneomai,
apaspadzomai, apekdechomai, apeipameen, apekduomai, aperchomai, apoginomai,
apodechomai, apokeimai, apokrinomai, apologeomai, apomassomai, apotassomai,
apophtheggomai, apophortidzomai, aspadzomai, asphalidzomai, aulidzomai,
aphikneomai, aphistamai, achreioomai, bdelussomai, bouleuomai, genealogeomai,
gi[g]nomai, daimonidzomai, diabebaioomai, diadechomai, diakatelegchomai,
dialogidzomai,dismarturomai, diamachomai, diaponeomai, diaporeuomai, diapriomi,
diastrellomai,diatarassomai, diatithemai, diacheiridzomai,
dienthumeomai,dogmatidzomai, drassomai, dunamai, dooreomai, egkauchaomai,
egkomboomai, egkrateuomai, eisdechomai, eiserchomai, eiskaleomai, eisporeuomai,
ekdapanaomai, ekdechomai, ekdidomai, ekdioeegeomai, ekthambeomai, ekkaiomai,
ekkechumai, eklanthanomai, eklegomai, ekluomai, ekpleessomai, ekporeuomai,
ekstrephomai, ektithemai, enantioomai, enarchomai, endeiknumai, endoxadzomai,
enthumeomai, entellomai, entrephomai, enupniadzomai, enootidzomai, exaiteomai,
exaporeomai, exerchomai, exeegeomai, exeecheomai, epaggellomai, epagoonidzomai,
epathroidzomai, epaischunomai, epakroaomai, epanapauomai, epanerchomasi,
epanistamai, epeiserchomai, epekteinomai, ependuomai, eperchomai, epiginomai,
epidechomai, epidiatassomai, epilambanomai, epilanthanomai, epimeleomai,
epiporeuomai, epickeptomai, episkeuadzomasi, eponomadzomai, ereugomai,
ereemoomai, erchomai, hessoomai, eulabeomai, eudoomai, euporeomai, ephallomai</i>,
<i>ephikneomai, heegeomai, heessaomai, heetaomai, thambeomai, thermainomai,
thumoomai, iaomai, hilaskomai, katheemai, kakoucheomai, katabaptidzomai,
katabasrunomai, ktagoonidzomai, katakaluptomai, katakauchaomai, katakeimai,
katanusomai, kataontidzomai, kataraomai, katasophidzomai, katachaomai,
katergadzomai, katerchomai, katioomai, katoprtidzomai, kausoomai, kauchaomai,
klydoonidzomai, koimaomai, kollaomai, krataioomai, ktaomai, kuliomai,
logidzomai, lutroomai, manteuomai, marainomai, marturomai, masaomai,
mataioomai, methuskomai, metaballomai, metakaleomai, metamelomai,
metamorphoomai, metatempomai, meteoopidezomai, meekunomai, mimeomai,
mimneiskomai (subscript), mneesteuomai, moichaomai, moomaomai, nomotheteomai,
nosphidzomai, xuraomai, odunaomai, homeiromai, hoplidzomai, optanomai,
orgidzomai, oregomai, orcheomai, ochleomai, paraboleuomai,
paraginomai,paradechomai, paraiteomai, parakathedzomzai, parakaluptomai,
parakeimai, paralegomai, paralogidzomai, paraluomai, paramutheomai,
paraporeuomai, paraeiserchomai, parechomai, paroichomai, paroxunomai,
parreesiadzomai, racchunomai, peipaomai, periblepomai, periergodzomai,
perierchomai, perikeimai, repileipomai, peripoieomai, perispaomai,
perpereuomai, petomai, pimpramai, pistoomai, politeuomai, poreuomai,
pragmateuomai, proaitiaomai, proginomai, proenarchomai, proepaggellomai,
proerchomai, proeuaggelidzomai, proechomai, proeegeomai, prokaleomai,
prokeimai, promarturomai, proporeuomai, prosapeileomai, prosdechomai,
prosergadzomai, proserchomai, proseuchomai, proskaleomai, proskleeroomai,
prosklinomai, proskollaomai, proslambanomai, prosormidzomai, prospoieomai,
prosporeuomai, protithemai, protrepomai, procheiridzomai, ptoeomai, pturomai,
punthanomai, puroomai, ripidzomai, ruomai, rupainomai, roonnumai,sebadzomai,
seleeniadzomai, seemeioomai, skotidzomai, skotoomai, spaomai, spendomai,
splagchnidzomai,stellomai, stenochooreomai, strateuomai, sugkakoucheomai,
sugkatapseephidzomai, sugchraomai, sullogidzomai, summeridzomai,
summorphidzomai, sumparaginomai, sumparakaleomai, sumporeuomai, sumphuomai,
sunagoonidzomai, sunalidzomai, sunanakeimai, sunanapauomai, sunantilambanomai,
sunapagomai, sunapollumai, sunarmologeomai, susauxanomai, sundeomai,
sundoxadzomai, suneiserchomai, sunepitithemai, sunepomai, sunerchomai,
suneuoocheomai, suneedomai, sunthaptomai, sunthlaomai,
sunkekerammaisugkekeramai, suntithemai, sunupokrinomai, sustauroomai,
suscheematidzomai</i>, <i>teekomai, tracheelidzomai, turbadzomai, tuphomai,
tuphoomai, huperairomai, huperekchunnomai, hupodeomai, hupodechoami,
hupokeinomai, phantadzomai, pheidzomai, phtheggomai, phobeomai, charidzomai,
cheimadzomai, chraomai, chreesteuomai, psuchomai, ooneomai, ooruomai. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Deponents in Greek and Latin are not
necessarily deponent in all parts. Some are active or middle depending on the
principal part: <i>erchomai-eleusomai-eelthon, gnoosko-gnoosomai,
isthioo-phagoo, kaioo, lambanoo-leepsomain, piptoo-pesoumain, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *first deponent, *second
deponent, *semi-deponent)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *composite verb, *defective
verb, *regular verb, *suppletive verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>derivation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another term for *etymology, the descent that a present term reflects. Derivation
can explain the difference in pronunciation between spellings that look just
alike. <i>M</i></span><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span></i><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tro-</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> and
m</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tro-
have long <u>e</u> and short <u>e</u> respectively because the former comes
from a Greek word with <u>eta</u> (<i>m</i></span><i><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tra</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
uterus) and the latter comes from another Greek word with short <u>e</u> (<i>metron</i>).
Similarly, ped- is pronounced with long <u>e</u> in words having to do with
child (<i>p</i></span><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span></i><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>diatrician</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
because it comes from the Greek word for child (<i>paid</i>-) , whose <u>ai</u>
over time went from <u>ai</u>, to <u>ae</u>, to </span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
<i>P</i></span><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Comic Sans MS"'></span></i><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>d- </span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>comes from the Latin root
<u>ped</u>-, which has a short <u>e</u> (pedal).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Derivation also explains why some odd
consonant combinations appear in words that are no longer pronounced with all
those sounds in them, especially words that have weird consonant combinations
on the front: pt-, pn-, kt-, thch-, -thph-, rrh /rh, gn-, gh, w(rung).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Derivation maintains spelling patterns
from feeder languages in the receiver language. <i>Abdomen</i> changes the <u>e</u>
to <u>i</u> when additions occur (cp. nomen &lt;nominis, <i>etc.</i>). <i>Dexter
</i>(right) drops the last <u>e</u> and becomes <i>dextrad</i> when suffixes
are added. Two consonants normally indicate a short previous vowel because that
is the way Latin spelling worked.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Derivation explains why words that do not
look like they are related are nevertheless related. <i>Agent</i> (leader) and <i>actor</i>
(doer) are related in that they come from different principal parts of the same
Latin verb: a<u>g</u>o, agere, egi, a<u>c</u>tus.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Derivation explains pronunciation patterns
that create silent letters. <i>S<u>c</u>ience</i> and related words have lost
the <u>k</u> sound that was in the Latin verb <i>scio</i>. English has
developed a pattern of pronunciation that makes the letter <u>c</u> say <u>s</u>
ahead of <u>e</u>, <u>i</u>, or <u>y</u>. So <i>resus<u>c</u>itation</i>, <i>science</i>,
and the like end up losing the <u>k</u> sound altogether; two <u>esses</u>
sound the same as one <u>ess</u>. For additional examples, see under *silent
letters and *spelling.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Derivation lies behind the less usual ways
of forming English plurals. on becomes a (protozoon &gt; protozoa, Gr.), -um
becomes -a (datum &gt; data, L. &amp; Gr.), -is becomes </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>s
(crisis &gt; crises, L. &amp; Gr.), -us becomes i (alumnus &gt; alumni, L.), -a
becomes ae (amoeba &gt; amoebae, L.), -ma becomes -mata (stigma &gt;
stigmata, Gr.), -ex becomes ices (cortex &gt; cortices), -ix becomes -ices
(appendix &gt; appendices), -ax becomes aces (thorax &gt; thoraces, Gr.), -nx
becomes ng</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Comic Sans MS"'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>s (menix &gt; meninges; phalanx &gt;
phalanges, Gr.), # becomes en (ox &gt; oxen). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Derivation shows what letters of a root
surprisingly may be kept when additions are made to the word. The general rule
is that is the vowel on the end of a root was part of the rootand therefore
invariant, that vowel stays when suffixes are added or compounds are made: tach<u>y</u>phagia,
trach<u>e</u>otomy, aud<u>i</u>ology, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> All Greek prepositions ending in a
vowelwith the exception of <i>amphi</i>, <i>peri</i>, and <i>pro</i>threw
away that vowel when prefixed to a root beginning with a vowel. That same
patternwith exceptionsobtains in English compounds involving those
prepositions.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>derivative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word descending from an earlier word in another language; a *paronym. Words
taken from Latin and Greek often lose their original n/g/c ending: victori-a
&lt; victory; Sometimes they are brought over without change from the
dictionary form:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>descriptive clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
alternate term for *nonrestrictive clause </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>descriptive genitive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the use of the Latin or Greek genitive case to tie a descriptive noun to
another nouncorresponding to an of phrase in English: a man of honor,
meaning an honorable man. WH333#16</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>descriptive grammar</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> a
grammar that simply shows how a language works without attempting to set
standards for its usage (in a set with *prescriptive grammar) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>descriptive linguistics</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the complete analysis of a language at a particular stage of its development in
contrast to *historical linguistics and *comparative linguistics. Historical
linguistics looks at the preceding (and succeeding aspects) of a languages
development as a way of elucidating features of the language. Comparative
linguistics draws correlations between the target language and related
contemporary languages.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *comparative linguistics,
*historical linguistics)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>descriptor</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a term or phrase that describes, or modifies.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>determiners</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
words that limit or restrict the number of those in a class: *definite
articles, *demonstratives, *possessive adjectives, and words like <i>any</i>, <i>all</i>,
<i>both</i> ahead of the nouns they delimit. Almost always, English omits <i>the</i>
when other determiners accompany the noun. Greek keeps the article with
demonstratives (<i>houtos, hode, ekeivos</i>), always putting them in
*predicate position.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>deutero-canonical</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having a secondary place of honor in the authoritative literature of a
religion. In Christianity there are some books of the New Testament itself that
some scholars consider *deutero-canonical because they have decided on literary,
historical, or doctrinal grounds that they are not like what they consider the
received literature within the canon. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *canonical) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>deutero-Pauline</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
secondarily Pauline; i.e., written by someone besides Paul, but following the
sentiments of the apostle. They may be said to be in the Pauline school or in
the Pauline tradition.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>deverbative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word formed from a verb in the same language rather than in terms of its
ancestral origins: <i>runner</i>, commandment, adoration, carriage. (in a set
with *denominative)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>devotion</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short, light presentation
intended to encourage the hearers devotion to God and to spiritual things</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>diacritical mark</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a mark used within a word to mark certain phonetic features, in contrast to
*punctuation marks to show relationship between words. As such, the category
includes the accent mark (fianc), diresis (the double dot []), an umlaut
(), the *cidella (as under the <i>c</i> of <i>faade</i>), the grave accent (
al mode), or the *circumflex (bte noire).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>diagonal</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: another term for
<i>slash</i>. a line rising to the right (/) used between entries for <u>different</u>
parallel realities: I/We must take care of the problem. Similar in value to <i>and/or</i>.
The idea contrasts from appositional <i>or</i>, which gives alternate names for
the <u>same</u> thing; it means another way of saying, to put it another
way. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> example </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(in
a set with *backslash) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>diagramming</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a technique of analyzing sentence structure so as to picture the relationship
of subjects to verbs to direct objects to indirect objects, the relationship of
subordinate parts to independent parts, the relationship of modifiers to phrase
heads, the relationship of adverbial clauses to main verbs. The process
requires the student to determine consciously these kinds of syntactical
features. It facilitates the analytical method of interpretation. It does not
so much teach the things involved as require concentration on them. After all,
a person has to know the relationships to choose how to picture them. <b>Append
a diagram of Hebrews 1:1-4</b> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dialect</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an adaptation of
a general language in a certain locale or in a certain community of speakers. The
kinds of things that occur are things like in African-American English, where
there is a tendency to drop the third singular final s on present tense
indicative active verbs, not pronouncing final consonants, developing new
meanings for words, and new words for things.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dialog/dialogue</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a discussion back and forth between two or more people about some issue;
contrasts with *monologue. (in a set with *monologue, *soliloquy)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Diatessaron</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an early Christian work that combined the four gospels into one narrative of
the life of Jesus Christ. Any work of that nature.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>diatribe</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an abusive
denunciation of someone or something; a *rant</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dictaphone</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the trade name for an instrument that records *dictation that can later be
retrieved in manageable segments by a typist or stenographer.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dictate</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to word out a
communication for someone who writes down what is said.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dictation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a wording out of a message to another person who is responsible for taking it
down and putting it into a form that can be sent to the addressee.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dictation theory of inspiration</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a view of divine-human co-operation in the production of scripture that
pictures the writer as taking down Gods words *verbatim. The idea surely
caricatures the belief that scripture <i>is</i> the word of God in contrast to <i>containing</i>
the word of God or <i>becoming</i> the word of God. The actual view of verbal
inspiration is that the wording freely chosen by the original human author is
protected from error. The Ten Commandments written by the finger of God might
indeed qualify as an example of dictation theory.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *dynamic inspiration, *infallibility,
*plenary inspiration, *verbal inspiration; *inerrancy)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>diction</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the choice of
words in speaking; distinctness, or clarity, of pronunciation in speaking or
singing. It deals with avoiding the choice of words with the wrong connotation
for the circumstance, with the wrong word out of a set that are similarlike
effect/affect. (in a set with *elocution, *enunciation, *pronunciation,
*saying, *slur)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dictionary</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an alphabetical listing of words in a language (in a set with *lexicon)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dictionary form</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the customary form of a words entry into a lexicon, dictionary, encyclopedia,
or glossary, which is organized by alphabetical sequence. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> With Latin and Greek <u>verbs</u>, the
dictionary form is first person, singular, present, indicative active. For
English verbs, the entry is the infinitive form (without <i>to</i>). For Hebrew
and Aramaic verbs, it is the third person masculine singular of the Qal stem. Lexicographers
list </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>Greek <u>contract verbs</u> in their uncontracted form
so the reader will know for sure what kind of contract verb it is. <u>Impersonal
verbs</u>, as they are called, appear in their third-person singular form,
because they are impersonal in that infinitives are their subjects. That
infinitive subject gets covered over by typically translating the construction
with the expletive <i>it</i>: <i>It </i>is necessary <i>to obey</i> in
everything: note </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>in
Greek.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> For English, Greek, and Latin <u>nouns</u>
it is the nominative singularfollowed by the genitive singular. These two case
forms are always enough to show which declension they are in.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> For Greek and Latin <u>adjectives</u> it
is the nominative masculine singular form, followed in order by feminine and
neuter forms (or perhaps only the variable terminations for those genders). Dictionaries
for Greek, Latin, and English may also give the forms for the comparative and
superlative degrees of an adjective, sometimes separately, sometimes put along
with the positive degree of that word. In Greek, some adjectives have one form
for masculine and feminine and another for neuter: such as alpha-privative
adjectives with first-second declension endings; third-declension adjectives</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Adverbs</u>, <u>interjections</u>, <u>prepositions</u>
usually one form. In cases where a preposition, e.g., has a different form
before vowels, its standardized form is entered alphabetically.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The dictionary form is basically the
simplest form of the word.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dictionary of slang</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a resource that organizes together the informal terms and expressions in
every-day use that are not normally included in a regular dictionary, as in a <i>Dictionary
of American Slang</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>didactic literature</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
content intended to teach, particularly religious teaching found in the New
Testament.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dieresis</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: two side-by-side
dots placed above a second vowel that immediately follows another vowel () to
show that the two vowels are pronounced separately instead of together as in a
diphthong or vowel glide: coperate, gastrontestinal, nave, psychoanalysis. In
familiar words like cooperate, the dieresis is usually omitted.  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek examples include the word <u>peristeemi</u>,
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The same symbol is used in phonetic
spelling to indicate the ah sound for an <i>a</i> ().</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The symbol is also used as an umlaut ()
in spelling German words with *rounded vowels. An alternate way of indicating
this feature of pronunciation is to put an <i>e</i> after the other vowel.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *punctuation marks)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>digamma</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: same as *stigma,
the Greek symbol for 6.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>digest</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a shortened and
perhaps simplified form of a longer writing. It is a process that can involve
removing of sections not as essential the presentation without altering the
remaining material.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>diglossia</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a situation where two levels of a language are used for different functions in a
society: high and low German ???, formal and familiar French, standard and informal/conversational
English</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>diglot</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a book with more
than one version, or language, of a text often in parallel columns [Gr] (in a
set with *polyglot): </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>digraph</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: two letters for
one <u>consonant</u> sound: ch, (dh), ph, gh, rh, sh, th, zh. The term could be
used to include writing the same consonant twice without any difference from
writing it once: hi<u>ss</u>, bu<u>zz</u>. (Often using two of the same
consonants together is done to indicate a short vowel ahead of the double
letter. Two letters for one <u>vowel</u> sound is usually called a *diphthong
in English. Note: in linguistic notation, placing an <i>h</i> after another
consonant often indicates a *fricative. (in a set with *double consonant, *vowel
glide, *spelling)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>digression</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a leaving of the subject at hand to discuss a perhaps related matter but in
such a way as to focus on it for its own sake. Then the speaker returns to the
original subject. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>diminutive form</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a form that means smaller than what the original term meant. Latin added an l-
+ case endings to a previous root for this purpose: ocellus for oculus (L) wh
306, misellus for miser, the <i>r</i> being assimilated Wh 306, anulus &lt;
anus ring wh 218 </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek has iota-diminutives: <i>amnos/amnion</i>
(<i>lamb</i>), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In English <u>ette</u> often has that
value: major, majorette (in a set with *iota-diminutive) WH306#6 333#13 322
#7#12</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>diphthong</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In English spelling, the term covers two kinds of things: (1) two vowel letters
that form one sound (writing) and (2) two vowels that cover two sounds where
there is a glide from one vowel to another (sounding). The former is like the
vowel letters in <i>feat</i>, <b>insert panel </b><i>feet, foot, taunt, bought,
goal, gr</i>ie<i>ve, groove. suit. </i>The latter is like the vowel glide in <i>real.
<b>Insert </b></i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>panel</span></i></b><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
bail, boil, bout, </span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Sometimes a diphthong in point of sound is
represented by only one letter in point of writing: <i>I, butte, made. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek, the written diphthongs represent
vowel glides to high front (i) and high back (<i>u</i>). Consequently, all its diphthongs
end in iota or upsilon, and the list of diphthongs can be generated simply by
starting at each of the other vowels and gliding to iota or to upsilon. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *digraph, *vowel glide,
*monophthong; see also **pronunciation)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>disputation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) argument about whether something is true; (2) a formal, perhaps learned
discussion in which the two sides give organized presentations for the view
being defended; a debate</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>disquisition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a formal discourse on a subject of importance</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>disuade</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: opposite of <i>persuade</i>;
to discourage someone from a certain course of action</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>distych</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an ancient
hinged writing tablet with two panels </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>direct discourse</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a quotation that gives the purported words of the original speaker. In Greek of
the New Testament the conjunction <u>hoti</u> appeared before the quoted
material even though in classical Greek <u>hoti</u> was used to introduce
*indirect discourse.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>direct object</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
answers the what question after a verb: The bat hit [what?], <i>i.e</i>., The
bat hit [the ball]. Direct objects are a kind of *verbal adjunct that appear
after action verbs whether finite, infinitive, participial, or gerund. Hebrew
uses eth as a direct object <u>sign</u>. Latin and Greek use the <u>accusative
case</u> to do so. English has certain <u>placements</u> for direct objects to
indicate that role int he sentence.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>direct question</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a question that purports to quote the very <u>words</u> *verbatim that a
questioner has used. Contrasts with *indirect question, which reproduces only
the <u>idea</u> in the original quotation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *question; * informational
question)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>directory</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an alphabetical listing of individuals, companies, <i>etc.</i>, compiled along
with relevant information for each one.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>discourse</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an oral presentation in public that includes *speeches and *addresses as well
as *sermons, which take place in religious settings. In the New Testament, the
gospels and Acts provide narratives with a significant number of discourse
interludes, which can be loosely classified as sermons, speeches, or informal
addresses, depending on preference in terms.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> From a grammatical standpoint, discourse
pertains to a construction that deals with another persons words. There is *direct
discourse, which gives the purported words of the speaker, and indirect
discourse, which gives idea the speaker expressed. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin the verb idea in indirect
discourse is covered by an infinitive. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In English it is covered by a finite verb.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek it was usually covered by a
finite verb in koine while classical Greek could use finite verbs, infinitives,
or participles, depending on the leading verb. Indirect discourse occurs after
verbs of speaking, mental action, or the senses: say/retort/exclaim/indicate/show
that; think/suppose/believe/imagine that; feel/feel/sense/see that.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek, indirect discourse labels what
can cover indirect statement as well as indirect question because the same
formula applies to both. In Latin, however, indirect <u>statement</u> covers
the verb with an infinitive, but in indirect <u>question</u> is covered by the
subjunctive with the clause introduced by an interrogative word or <i>ne</i>
added to the first word of the clause.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *sermon, *speech, *address<b>)</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>disjunctive accent: Hebrew disjunctive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
accents space, separate, or show slight pauses between words. Such accents
contrast with *conjunctive accents, which indicate continuation and unity
(phrasing) between words. (in a set with *conjunctive accent)  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dissertation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a formal writing that closely examines some topic; such a writing that results
from original research and is usually required for earning a doctoral degree.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>distant demonstrative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a demonstrative that points to something/someone thought of as distant from the
speaker: that/those. Latin had two, what could be called, distant
demonstratives, one associated with the hearer (<i>iste/ista/istud</i>) and
another for distant to both speaker and hearer (<i>ille/illa/illud</i>). (in a
set with *near demonstrative)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>distant future</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb form that indicates action to take place after a good while. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *near future, or *immediate
future; *temporary future, *permanent future)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>distant past</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb construction that indicates action that occurred a good while ago. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *near future, or *immediate
past)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>distinctive: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>related
in sound yet signifying difference in meaning: hi<i>t</i> <i>vs.</i> hi<i>d</i>
(vocalization); <i>d</i>ine <i>vs</i>. <i>n</i>ine (nazalization); <i>p</i>at <i>vs</i>.
<i>f</i>at (fricativization)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>distribution</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
placement in a sentence; one of the factors in defining *parts of speech. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *inflection for defining
parts of speech, alternative to *case form)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>distributive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in contrast to collective. Considering the members of a set individually: <i>each/every</i>
vs <i>all</i> as in <i>every</i> good boy does fine; <i>each</i> good boy
does fine; or <i>vs.</i> <i>all</i> good boys do fine. <i>Every </i>is
distributive singular in that it looks at the members of a set one by one; so <i>every</i>
has *concord with a singular verb.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek and Latin use the same word for
distributive and collective, the singular for distributive and the plural for
collective: <i>pas/pantes</i> (Gr); <i>omnis/omnes</i> (Lat). Greek also has <i>hekastos</i>
(each) for distributive. All three words can be pronouns or adjectives.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>disyllable/disyllabic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word having two syllables</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>disyllabic enclitic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a two-syllabic enclitic. Greek examples are <i>eisin, estin, esmen, eimi, este</i>?
and all the non-interrogative forms of <i>tines</i> &lt; <i>tis/ti</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dithyramb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a case of wildly enthusiastic speech-making. A Greek troupes frenzied hymn and
dance used in the worship of Dionysius. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Ditto</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) a double
vertical mark above the line of writing to indicate repetition of the item
directly above it in a list (&quot;). On typewriters the ditto was the same key
and shape as double quotation marks, which in turn were the same before and
after a quotation. With the advent of computers and their extra possibilities
and smart quotes, the ditto can be supplied from a specialty list.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>Ditto/dittos</i> has become a *short
for I agree with you. Cp. roger that.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dittography</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a case of writing something twice. In ancient manuscript copying, a word or set
of words might have been put down twice where they originally appeared once
(say, verily, verily instead of just verily). In todays circumstance, it
happens when a word like <i>the</i> is typed twice on a computer and a red
saw-toothed line shows up under the second entry. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *haplography, *homoioteleuton,
*metathesis as types of *scribal errors)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ditty</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short,
light-hearted, simple song or verse </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>doctrine/doctrinal</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the general teaching on a important subject, especially religious or political.
<i>A</i> <i>doctrine</i> refers to one specific belief within a whole body of
doctrine. As a general reference, <i>doctrine</i> is something conceptual in
contrast to *history, *exhortation, <i>etc.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *indoctrinate, *didactic
literature)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>document</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a written piece
serving as a formal source of information</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>documentary</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a presentation that reviews an important even or major issue</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dogma</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an authoritative
principle dealing with morality or belief associated with a particular
religious community or system of thought </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dot</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the term for a *period
when it is used in an e-mail address or web site</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>double accusative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Some a verbs can carry two objects, one of the person and one of the thing</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>double consonant</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a single letter for two sounds at once the English <i>-x</i> (<i>ks</i>), the
Greek <i>zeta</i>, <i>xi</i>, and <i>psi</i> (note Acts <b>5</b>:5, <i>exepsuxen</i>three
in one word) ; the Hebrew <i>tsade</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>double meaning</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) the usage of one word with two meanings simultaneously. Perhaps Joseph did
not want to make Mary a public example because he thought her story was
conceivable. On a 19 day, when my wife was glad that the sun was shining
bright, I exclaimed, Cool! Jokes often play on such usageespecially
groaners/*Tom Swiftys.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Other, more serious types of double
meaning have arisen. (2) Fourfold interpretation of supposed that divine
revelation in scripture carried more than the literal, straightforward meaning.
Hidden to the uninitiated eye lay figurative, spiritual, and analogical
meanings<b>check this out</b>. Philo of Alexandria was an early proponent of
this view of divine revelation, a notion about multiple meanings that continued
down into the time of the Reformation. In fact, one triumph of the reformation
was discarding this fanciful notion about language. The rejection of this false
principle is capsulized in Calvins famous dictum: The meaning of scripture is
one.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A vestige of the multiple-meanings notion
remains in the concept of (c) *double reference prophesy. It is an
interpretation device that seeks to justify apparent New Testament misapplication
of Old Testament predictions. In general, the answer lies elsewhere in class
prediction (which is particularized to a given case), original application is a
type of a similar case that better embodies the crucial element involved, <i>etc</i>.
The use of 2 Sam<b> 7</b>:14 in Heb<b> 1</b>:5 is a case in point (class
predictionelaborate).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>double negative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Im <i>not</i> doing <i>nothing</i>.<b> </b>In English, grammarians sometimes
claim that double negatives cancel each other out. That is not really what
happens, though, when such a proscribed construct is actually used. It just isnt
considered standard usage. For fun, there are even titles that spoof this
issue: Don t Nobody Bring Me No Bad News. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Certain kinds of double negatives are
allowed, as in certain kinds of *litotes where <i>not</i> combines with a
negative prefix: <i>not infrequently</i>. Though, strictly speaking, it is a
double negative, people commonly use the expression I <i>cant</i> help <i>but</i>
think rather than I cant help thinking. Unaccepted double negatives include
expressions like <i>cant hardly.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin and Greek doublingor even
triplingnegatives <u>stresses</u> the negativity. <i>Ou mee</i> occurs
regularly in Greek with this value.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>double signal</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
two entries for the same item in a segment of syntax. Examples include a
nominative pronoun plus a person-and-number verb termination (<i>s</i>he work<i>s</i>),
a prepositional prefix plus the same preposition placed independently (<i>in</i>truded
<i>into</i> the proceedings). Double signals often give emphasis. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *redundancy)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>double-space</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
