having two strokes of the space bar on a typewriter or computer. The spacing
used after a *colon, *exclamation mark, *period, or *question mark (usually). (2)
an empty line between lines of type; typed on every second line </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *single space, *space, *triple
space, *space-and-a-half)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>double subject</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Saying the subject of a sentence two different times: The times, they are
a-changin. (in a set with *nominative pendens)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>double talk</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
talking with intent to obscure, to keep the hearer from understanding
correctly, talking in a way that does not make sensible communication</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>double negative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
two negatives used together, a practice shunned in formal English writing and
speaking. In Greek and Latin, double (and even triple) negatives pile up to
emphasize the negation rather than to cancel each other out.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>doxology</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short Christian
hymn of praise to God often sung in response to an offertory. Aside from a
musical setting, doxology is used as a descriptor for certain eloquent passages
in praise to God: Rom <b>11</b>:33-34; <b>16</b>:25-27; (2 Cor <b>9</b>:15); Eph
<b>3</b>:20-21; Jude 24-25</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>drift</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the general line
of thought</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dual forms: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>some
languages have distinctive noun, adjective, pronoun, and verb forms for two of
something or someone. Hebrew uses the termination <i>ayim</i> for both
masculine and feminine duals. Classical Greek had duals forms for verbs that
were used in poetry. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *singular, *plural): </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dubitative subjunctive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
same as *deliberative subjunctive; the use of the subjunctive mood in Latin and
Greek for questions that imply uncertainty, inexactness, or tension created by
such as circumstance (in a set with *deliberative questions)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>duplicate</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in two copies, an expression that was used when typewriters were in general use
and the typist made a carbon copy at the same time as the original (in a set
with *duplicate)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dynamic inspiration</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a view of divine assistance in the speaking of human prophets where God gives
heightened abilities in contrast to dictated words, implanted ideas, planted
experiences, or granted offices (2 Sam <b>7</b>:3-17).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *dictation theory of
inspiration, *verbal inspiration, *plenary inspiration, *inerrancy)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>echolalia</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the involuntary repetition of words just heard</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>eclectic text</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a text like the Nash papyrus that evidently chooses variant New Testament Greek
readings and conflates them into its ongoing reading</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>eclogue</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a pastoral poem
in the form of a dialog between shepherds</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>economy of expression</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
efficiency in expression, getting a lot said in few words (in a set with
*terse)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ecstatic utterance</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
speaking that takes place in an altered state of consciousness, hence, not
necessarily having *linguisticality and not necessarily understood or
remembered even by the speaker. cp. the utterances of the priestess at the Delphic
oracle and the utterances of an aged woman in the Sibylline oracles. Sometimes
equated with tongue speaking in the New Testament (in a set with *glossolalia,
*speaking in tongues, *xenoglossia)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>edict: </span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>edit</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to correct, size
down, or otherwise improve an original manuscript (in a set with *amend,
*emend)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>editorial</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>editorial we</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the use of <i>we</i> for <i>I</i> to avoid taking undue credit or appearing
proud.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>elaboration</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
giving more information, fleshing out the picture. Elaboration can be done by
giving examples, reading a poem or scripture, telling a story that embodies the
point, fill in the accompanying feature of the situation, filling in more
details of the topic, showing how it connects to other things or differs from
them.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>elative</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: not having a
specific other referent in view (*comparative degree adjective) or not having specific
other individuals in a group/class (*superlative degree adjective)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>elative adjectives</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
elative comparative (rather __)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Elative superlative (<i>very</i> __); English
also uses expressions like <i>good, good</i> man; <i>good n deep</i> hole;
it is <i>powerful</i> cold; it is a <i>big-time</i> cold; it was <i>mega</i>
cold; it was <u>super</u> cold; and other *slang expressions.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>elegiac couplet</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
wh 301</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>elision/elide</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
elision drops out a sound for ease of pronunciation, <i>etc.</i> In Latin and
Greek dentals cannot stand before sibilants. One way to solve the problem in
the process of inflection, <i>etc.</i>, is to elide one or the other sound. A
similar thing happens in English when seemingly awkward consonant combinations
appear on the front of words that derive from Greek: <u>p</u>neumonia. It
happens on the ends of words like <u>paradigm</u>; when the <i>os</i> or <i><u>ma</u></i>
was lost, the<i> g</i> could no longer be pronounced with the preceding syllable;
so it has been elided and the <i><u>g</u></i> becomes a *silent letter. The
pronunciation becomes para<u>digm</u>. The contraction of <i>do not</i> to <u>d</u><i>ont</i>,
<i>etc.</i> is another kind of elision. Dropping consonant sounds on the end of
French words is another illustration.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek words whose vowel ending bumps up
against a vowel beginning on the next word, may elide the first vowel: <i>tout
estin</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *aphesis, *contraction,
*crasis; *ellipsis; *assimilation, *euphony)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ellipsis/elliptic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an omission perhaps from a quotation marked in writing by three double-spaced
periods or asterisks ( . . . ). In repetitive wording, the omission may be
marked with a comma. In Latin poetry, prepositions were often omitted to help
conform to the demands of meter. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>Example *</b><i>Elision</i> is usually
applied to an omission within a word; <i>ellipsis</i> is applied to omissions
within a group of words. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Ellipses happen in the New Testament Greek
text. In Lukes genealogical list for the Messiah, he omits the noun before <i>of</i>
___ (<b>3</b>:23-38). The direction of the genealogy runs backwards in time;
so <i>son</i> goes ahead of the next proper name. Other contexts may call for supplying
<i>father</i>, if the sequence is running forward, or <i>brother</i>, if the
context is contemporaneous. The word for <i>to be</i> is often omitted in
proverbs or *aphorisms, and other cases where <i>to be</i> does not have a time
reference *linking verb).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *elision, *elliptical,
*assimilation, *euphony)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>elliptical clause/sentence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a clause that omits words that would normally appear in a full sentence as
sometimes happens with *sayings in order to give them greater punch: What a
bummer! Well begun, half done; Penny wise, pound foolish. gregg23</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>elocution</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
use of language in a form well-suited to public speaking</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>eloquence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
elegant, powerful, persuasive discourse</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>elucidate: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>to
cast light on some statement by another person or in a text of scripture (in a
set with *ambiguity)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>emend/emendation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an emendation amounts to a correction of an obvious error in a writing,
especially an ancient one (in a set with *amend, *edit) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>emphasis</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: Stress sets up contrast
with parallel alternatives. Emphasis is achieved (1) by saying something louder
or more deliberately, (2) by gestures that accompany the speaking, (3) by
underlining it in writing; (4) by putting it in a prominent position like the
front, the end, or an otherwise unusual place in a sentence; (5) by assigning
two elements to it as in *hendiadys or double signal (as kind of redundancy), (6)
by making the word bigger as by adding a prefixed preposition (Latin and Greek
compounds) or lengthening the word from, say, <u>ou</u> (not) to <u>ouchi</u>
(surely not) in Greek. (7) Adding other words creates emphasis: I <i>certainly</i>
am. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin and Greek have verb endings that
indicate person and number; so pronouns in the nominative create a (8) double
signal, thus, stressing the subject in a way akin to underling it in writing. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Emphasis has been done also (9) by using
an unusual form: in classical Greek, after a past-tense main verb of fearing,
an optative verb covered the action in the fear clause; to emphasize the object
of fear, however, the subjunctive could be usedas it was in clauses after
primary tenses in the leading verb. The same optative-to-subjunctive shift
could occur in purpose clauses after leading verbs in a secondary tense.
C&amp;S192 (10) Hebrew used an infinitive absolute plus the same root in finite
form to say certainly do: Is <b>6</b>:9-10. General communication may use (11)
exaggeration for emphasis: Hes as big as a barn.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> At the word level, accent marks indicate
the emphasis, stress, accent a syllable with the word has. <u>Stress</u> and <u>emphasis</u>
indicate emphasis within a sentence or paragraph. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Emphasis, however expressed, most of the
time, sets up contrast with parallel alternatives; simply indicating something
without stress does not have parallel alternatives consciously in mind.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Exaggeration</u> is a form of emphasis
of content. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *accent, *secondary accent,
*stress, *accent, *double signal, *intense)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>emphatic form</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word that by its meaning shows emphasis. In English verb forms, using <i>do </i>as
an auxiliary verb creates an emphatic form in the present and past tenses: I <i>do</i>
like classical music; I <i>did</i> finish my homework. Emphatic future has
to rely on stressing the auxiliary verb <i>will</i>, which is a second way in
English to create emphasis: I <u>will</u> do my homework; just let me watch
the game first. <i></i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The
emphasis effect may also be achieved by making the words bigger (#6 under *emphasis).
Latin example include <i>exoro</i> &lt; <i>oro</i>, <i>namque</i> &lt; <i>nam;</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>emphatic negative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
<i>ou mee </i>in Greek for either questions or statements</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>enchiridion</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a handbook on some subject</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>enclitics</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
particularly common in Greekas well as in Latin, words pronounced with a
preceding word; as such, enclitics do not bear their own accent if they can
avoid it. In Greek, the enclitic threw <u>away</u> its accent if it could; if
it could not throw it away, it threw it <u>back</u>as an acute on the *ultima
of the preceding word. If it could not throw it back, it <u>kept</u> the
accent. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin the suffixed -<i>ne</i> on the
first word of a sentence makes a question out of the sentence. Latin also has the
intensive enclitic <i>ce</i><u> </u>Wh 310 </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English enclitics include situations like
Go, get <i>em</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *proclitics)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>encode</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to write a
message using special symbols that are not known by outsiders </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>encomium</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a tribute, a
formal expression of praise, eulogy.WH320</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>encrypt</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to put a message
into a secret code so the information is not so likely to fall into the wrong
hands</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>encyclical</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a writing intended for circulation. In the New Testament, Paul sent Galatians
to the churches of Galatia (<b>1</b>:2). Colossians was evidently intended for
such use (Col <b>4</b>:16) as well as a Letter to the Laodecians (Col <b>4</b>:16),
which may be the same as our Ephesians. The General Epistles were encyclicals
in Asia Minor (James <b>1</b>:1; 1 Pet <b>1</b>:1; 2 Pet <b>3</b>:1; Jude 17). Revelation
was to circulate among the seven churches of Asia (Rev <b>1</b>:4). Even Romans
was circulated among household churches within Rome (<b>16</b>:5, 14, 15). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In more modern usage, papal letters to the
hierarchy of the Catholic church have been called encyclicals. (in a set with
*personal letter)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>encyclopedia</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
usually a multi-volume work alphabetically arranged on major topics (in a set
with *dictionary)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>endearment term</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
same as *affectionate term.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ending</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a termination on
a word, such as one that signals singular or plural on nouns and verbs, or
person on verbs. A *morpheme found in this location. (*in a set with *zero
ending)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>endnote</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: serves the same
purposes as a *footnote but is located at the end of the article or chapter. The
practice replaces footnotes because of the greater ease of arrangement. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *footnote, *marginal note,
*marginalia, *sidebar, *sidenote)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>endorse</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to apply ones
signature to a check; to recommend a candidate for office</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>enigma/enigmatic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an unclear presentation, often intentionally so, that challenges the hearer to
figure out the mystery; a *riddle. Something that cannot be figured out because
crucial information has been lost.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>enthymeme</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(sp)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>entitle/entitled</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having a *title, or *heading as on an essay or other written piece</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>enunciate/enunciation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Enunciation stresses clarity of *pronouncing a <u>sound</u> within a word;
hence, it deals with phonemes. Enunciate contrast with *slur. Pronunciation
stresses saying the sound of the <u>whole word</u>; hence, it deals with part
of what is meant by *morphemes. Diction stresses the choice of <u>words</u>. Elocution
stresses the expressing phraseology<u>sets of words</u>; hence, it deals with
tagmemes. <b>check this out</b> As a result, enunciation, pronunciation, and
elocution have to do with the sounds, while saying can include the meaning
involvedas with diction. (in a set with *articulation, *pronunciation,
*elocution, *diction, *saying, *slur)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>epenthesis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the insertion of a sound in the middle of a word but without a view to altering
meaning, as it is with *infix. In some short verbs, Greek inserts a
corresponding nasal ahead of a final root consonant in order to build up the
basic rootshown in the aoristinto a form for the first principal part. Some
of these verbs also double the aorists initial root consonant with an iota
between them: <i>elabon &lt; la<u>m</u>banoo, elthon &lt; la<u>n</u>thanoo,
elipon &lt; li<u>m</u>panoo, elachon &lt; la<u>g</u>chanoo, emathon &lt; ma<u>n</u>thanoo,
emneesa &lt; mi<u>m</u>neeiskoo, epleesa &lt; pi<u>m</u>pleemi, enepreesa &lt;
empi<u>m</u>preemi, epreestheen &lt; pi<u>m</u>pramai, eputhon &lt; pu<u>n</u>thanoo,
ethigon &lt; thi<u>g</u>ganoo, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In addition to this set, there are other
instances of similar alterations that could be called <i>epentheses</i>. The <i>o/e</i>-
variable is a set of connecting vowels that joins root and personal endings in
the present, imperfect, and future tenses. <i>Hud<u>oo</u>r</i> is the nom sg
that has no vowel between delta and rho in the rest of the declension. Greek
does not like the <i>rho-sigma</i> sequence that the nom sg would theoretically
carry. It looks like an <i>omega</i> was inserted to solve the impossible
pronunciation <i>hydr</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:4.5pt;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The variant form of the
English indefinite article <i>a/an</i> affords many examples of a thing similar
to epenthesis in English even though it is between words rather than within
them. <i>An- </i>occurs before vowels and <i>a-</i> before consonants (except
*glottal stops and a few glottal fricatives). Since language is always a matter
of sound before it is a matter of writing, the <i>n</i> appears relative to
sound, not writing. English says <i>a </i>when a spoken <i>y</i> consonant
sound actually precedes the written <i>eu-/u-</i>:<i> euphemism/eulogy/union,
etc., </i><b>(insert panel</b>: <i>eucane, eucakyptol, eucalyptus, eucharist,
euchire, euchromatin, eudemonism, eugenic, eugenol, euglena, euhermerism,
eukaryote, eunuch, eunonymous, eupatrid, eupepsia, euphonium, euphony,
euphorbia, euporia, euphotic, euphuism, euplastic, euphold, eupnea, eureka,
euripus, europium, eurybathic, euryhaline, euryterid, eurythermal, eurythmics,
eurythmy, eurytopic, eustachian tube, eustasy, eustele, eutectic, euthanasia,
euthenics, eutherian, eutrophic</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:4.5pt;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Also note <i>u- </i>words with
with <i>y</i> pronounced on the front:<b> </b>(<b>insert panel</b>) <i>ubiety
ubiquitous, ufology, ukase, ukuklele, unanimity, una voce, uniaxial,unicameral,
unicorn, unicellular,uniform, unify, unilateral, unilinear, unilingual,
unilocular, uninucleate, union, unipolar, unique, unisex, unison, unitard,
unite, universal, univocal, uraes, uranium, urea, unredinium, ureter, urethane,
urethra, uric, urinal, urochord, uropod, uroscopy, use, usurp, usury, utensil,
utilitarian, utopia, utricle, uvarovite, uvea, uxorious. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:4.5pt;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Likewise
people say <i>an honor </i>because the <i>h</i> represents a glottal stop (as
it does in <i>heir, honest,</i> <i>hour</i>and <i>humble </i>for some speakers).
There is some variation ahead of the glottal fricative <i>h</i>: <i>anhydrous</i>,
but <i>a hassle, a hearth, a hit, a hook, a hut, a hydrant</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:4.5pt;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> A similar issue arises with
a few <i>o</i> words that are actually pronounced with the consonant <i>w</i>
sound on the front. People say, There is not <i>a</i> one that is righteous;
this is <i>a </i>once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The pattern obtains with the *<i>a</i>-
privative in Greek. It is plane <i>a-</i> before consonants including glottal
fricatives, that is, rough breathing marks: <i>aorist</i> (<i>a- + horizoo</i>).
Before smooth breathing, the prefix is <i>an-</i>: English derivatives
generally preserve this pattern: <i>agenesis, amoral, atheist, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin does something similar to Greek by
building up words that differ between third and first principal part. Words
like <i>vi<u>n</u>co</i> show <i>vici</i> in the perfect active stem; it is a
question whether the nasal is added to the first root or dropped from the third
(cp. Gr <i><u>la</u>m<u>b</u>anoo/e<u>lab</u>on</i>). Cp. <i>cer<u>n</u>o/crevi</i>,
<i>conti<u>n</u>go/contigi, contu<u>n</u>do/contudi</i>, <i>corru<u>m</u>po/corrupi</i>,
<i>desi<u>n</u>o/desivi</i>, <i>po<u>n</u>o/posui</i>, <i>profu<u>n</u>do/profudi</i>,
<i>reli<u>n</u>quo/reliqui</i>, <i>sper<u>n</u>o/sprevi</i>, <i>tango/tetigi</i>,
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *affix, *infix, *suffix;
*morpheme, *epenthesis, *excrescence; *allomorph)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ephemeral paper</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a publication that is not intended for long-term relevance or use; something
that, being subject to ongoing time, is apt to be supplanted by further
developments.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ephemeron</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an example of printed material that has temporary interest</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>epigram</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short, concise,
witty poem or paradoxical statement</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>epigraph: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>another
term for *inscription. A short introductory statement of a topic </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *inscription; epigram)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>epigraphy</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of *inscriptions, the writing on utensils, pottery, and the like [&lt;Gr.
<i>epi</i> + <i>grapho</i>, to write]: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>epilogue</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a brief
statement to the audience after a play or to the readership at the end of a
book. Epilogue and *prologue deal more with the historical setting (prologue)
and consequent occurrences (epilogue) than with conceptual and ideological
matters <i>per se</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *prologue, *preface,
*introduction) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>epistle</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a more formal
writing than <u>letter</u>. Epistle connotes a letter-form that emphasizes
explanatory, narrative, <i>etc.</i>, content. Inasmuch as letters and epistles
are sent, they are called missives. In the New Testament, <i>epistles</i>
designate the writings Romans through Jude in contrast to the gospels, Acts,
and the Apocalypse/Revelation. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *letter, *missive)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>episode</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: one installment
in a series of segments that make up a continuing, usually fictional, story as
with soap operas or series of shows with the same actors doing similar things
as in crime scene investigations. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *prequel, *sequel)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>epistolary</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the adjective for <i>epistle</i>; having to do with an epistle </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>epistolary aorist</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the use of a past tense for the present in anticipation of the readers point
in time. New Testament examples probably include Acts <b>23</b>:30; Phil<b> 2</b>:28;
Col<b> 4</b>:8.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>epitaph</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an *inscription
on a tombstone; a short piece about a deceased person intended for long-term
expression</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>epitasis</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the middle
section of a play that leads to the catastrophe</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>epithalamium</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a poem of praise for a groom and his bride on the occasion of their marriage</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>epithet</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a term, often
derogatory, for describing a person, possibly used in place of the persons
name. (in a set with *name calling, *by-word)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>eponymy</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the derivation
of the name of something from an individual, as <i>Bayer </i>aspirin, <i>Marriott</i>
hotel, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>eponym</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: someone whose
name is supposedly the person a city or place was named from: Edom, Moab,
Israel, Dan. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>epopee</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a lyric, epic
poem as a literary genre</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>epos</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a group of poems
that address the same important theme </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>epsilon</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: fifth letter of
the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Short
<i>e</i>, paired with <i>eta</i>, the long <i>e</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>equal sign</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a mathematical symbol equation (=)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>equative verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb that indicates being rather than action; another term for *copulative
verb, *linking verb, *state-of-being verb, *to be verb; cp. *fientive verb and
stative verb. (in a set with *active verb, *middle-voice verb, *passive verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>eristic</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: having the
character of a disputation, argumentation, polemics; a polemical writing or
argument </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>errata</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: errors; a notice
placed variously that identifies typos or printing mistakes discovered in the body
of the work</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>esoteric</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: suitable for use
by insiders, those prepared to understand its import; beyond the reach of
normal persons (in a set with *exoteric)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>essay</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a *theme, a
written explanatory treatment of some topic</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>eta</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: seventh letter of the
Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
Long e, paired with epsilon, short e.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ethogram</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a catalog that
summarizes pictorially the behavior of animals</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>etiology</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> the backstory
for some term, idea, or custom; their origin</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>etymology</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of the origin of words; also called *derivation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>etymon</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the earlier form
of a word or *morpheme whether in the same language, an earlier language, or
another contemporary language. (in a set with *loan word)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>eulogy</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a speech given
at a funeral or memorial service, praising the accomplishments, <i>etc.</i>, of
the deceased. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>euphemism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a polite or respectful way of saying something otherwise unpleasant. Euphemisms
often deal with death, bodily elimination, the place names for such processes. Death
is called sleep. A place for defecation or urination may be called a
restroom, mens room, water closet, someones facilities. Covering the feet
evidently has that meaning in the Old Testament.( ). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In the discussion about the elements in
the Lords supper, it has been proposed that fruit of the vine is a euphemism
for wine. The comment is in response to the idea that fruit of the vine is so
worded because it was not intended to be fermented wine. <i>Wine</i>, however,
is not likely to be considered a word or thing that someone would seek a
euphemism for.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *crude)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>euphony/euphonic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
well + sound; a way of making something seemingly easier to pronounce. English
speakers, for example, routinely say dipthong or diptheria instead of <i>di<u>ph</u>thong</i>
or <i>di<u>ph</u>theria</i>. The adjustment is from sequential fricatives to
stop plus fricative. Greek makes the opposite change: when a stop-fricative
sequence is created by inflection, word building, or word sequence, Greek
shifts the stop to a fricative to produces a fricative-fricative sequence. English
changed the Greek root <u>pn</u>e- to <u>n</u>eumonia rather than <u>p</u>neumonia.
The same happens to <i>kt</i>- and other odd consonant combinations. Some of
these are considered standard; others are considered _____</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The practice in English of voicing through
intervocalic consonants as in ladder for latter; udder for utter. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Adjusting voicing in clusters: <i>rex</i>
&lt; <i>regs</i> to <i>recs</i> to r</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>x, king (Latin).
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Sequencing words</u> like Donna Michelle
rather than Michelle Donna makes it easier to say. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin: irregularities in the irregular
verb <u>fero</u>: <i>ferris</i> for <i>feriris</i> (2<sup>nd</sup> pl pass ind
pres) <b>check other places. </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Various kinds of *<u>assimilation</u>, or
modifications that make sounds alike, (1) <u>during compounding</u>: col-late
(&lt; con + late); syl-labus (&lt;syn + ), sym-bol (syn + bol); e<u>f</u>ficio
(&lt; e<u>x</u> + <u>f</u>acio). It happens also (2) in <u>creating *cognates</u>:
scri<u>b</u>-o becomes scri<u>p</u>-tor when the agent ending <u>tor </u>is
suffixed to the root scrib. There are examples across (3) *<u>principal parts</u>:
scri<u>b</u>-o to scri<u>p</u>-si, when the *voiceless <i>s</i> is added to the
root after voiced <u>b</u> to help create the perfect active; likewise <i>a<u>g</u>-o</i>
becomes <i>a<u>c</u>tus</i> in the fourth principal part. (4) <i>Sequencing of
words</i> creates the same result: <i>haf to</i> for <i>have to</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek, like Latin, in general does not
tolerate dental-sibilant sequences. <i>Sy<u>n</u></i> (with) + <i>zao</i> (to
live) becomes <i>syzao</i> (to live with) by *eliding the <i>nu</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin <i>pot-sum</i> &gt; <i>possum</i>; <i>per</i>
becomes <i>pel</i>- when prefixed to roots beginning with<i> l</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew examples</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English does not write the oral
differences in nearly so many circumstances as does Greek especially and to a
lesser extent Latin. For that reason, an English-speaking student of Greek
senses that Greek presents an extremely large number of changes across
principal parts, inflection, word-building, and word sequencing. Most of these
irregularities are no more irregular than what occurs in English, but they
seem more so because they are written. The English habit of voicing through
voiceless consonants is one of those unwritten practices that create
difficulties for Spanish speakers, for example, because their first language
does not do this unexpected thing; consequently, they will say <i>sys </i>instead
of<i> sez.</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> So, when undesirable sound combinations come
about in *inflection, principal parts, *word-building, or word sequencing, various
changes relieve the difficulty, or foster ease of pronunciation, efficiency
of expression, or sound more pleasant to the ear. (1) The first letter is
omitted. The Latin <i>scribien<u>t</u>s</i> becomes <i>scribiens</i> (nom mas
sg present act participle); elsewhere in the declension the <i>nt</i> participle
morpheme shows up fully. In Greek, the <i>tau</i> in <i>thap<u>t</u>o</i> falls
out in the future (<i>thapso</i>) and first aorist (<i>ethapsa</i>). Likewise
with <i>sodzo</i>. Greek words in a sequenceone ending with a vowel and the
next beginning with a vowelmay *elide the first vowel: <i>apo archees kata
oikon</i> becomes <i>ap archees kat oikon</i>; <i>dia autou</i> becomes <i>di
autou</i>, <i>kata oikon</i> becomes <i>katoikon</i>, <i>oude an</i> becomes <i>oud
an</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) The second letter is discarded: Latin
shows <i>amor</i> for the theoretical <i>amors</i> of the third declension nom
mas sg. Greek *elides the sigma from the first aorist sign after roots ending
in lambda (*liquid aorists): <i>angello</i> &gt; <i>eengeila</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) Both letters may disappear. Greek
shows <i>agn</i> for theoretical <i>agon<u>ts</u></i> in the nom mas sg pres
act ptc (The elided <i>t</i> exposes the <i>s</i> to the <i>n</i> so that the <i>s</i>
is also lost; the previous <i>o</i> lengthens to *compensate for the double
loss). In Latin also, dental-sibilant sequences are not allowed, but <i>n</i>
is not included in the dental-sibilant category (<i>agens</i>).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (4) A <i>vowel</i> may be <u>interfixed</u>
to separate the offending letters: example. A <i>consonant</i> is frequently interfixed
to separate vowel-plus-vowel sequences. The English indefinite article varies
from <i>a </i>to <i>an</i>, depending on whether the next word starts with a
consonant or vowel. The same applies to the negating prefix <i><u>a</u></i>(<i>n</i>),
which produces <i><u>a</u>theist</i> and then <i><u>an</u>ion</i>. Greek adds <i>k</i>
to <i>ou</i> ahead of words beginning with vowels (<i>ouk echousin</i>) and
within a word adds a <i>k</i> to the <i><u>ou</u> + <u>eti</u></i> combination
to make <i>ou<u>k</u>eti</i>. (5) There may be a shift to a more acceptable
consonant combination. The Greek <i>ouk</i> becomes <i>ouch</i> before words
that start with a fricative. <i>Nu</i> becomes <i>mu</i> before *labials. Voiced
consonants become unvoiced before unvoiced consonants and vice versa. Non-nasals
become nasals before *nasals. (6) *Metathesis may take place to undo the
undesirable combination. In English dialect, <u>ask</u> becomes <u>ax</u>
(aks): Im not gonna ax you agin. Hebrew does this with the hithpael stem
when a sibilant begins the root that hi<u>th</u> comes up against.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In most of these examples the influence is
backwards onto the preceding sound.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *elision, *ellipsis, *elliptical,
*elision, *assimilation, *metathesis)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>evangelistic sermon</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a sermon whose purpose is to urge audience members to accept the Christian
good news about salvation through Christ; *outreach sermons</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>exact rhyme: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>repeats
the end sounds exactly: crime, thyme. (get other examples) (in a set with *eye
rhyme, *perfect rhyme, *near rhyme,<i> etc</i>.)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>exaggeration</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
saying something in a more extreme way than the situation really is; a device sometimes
used deliberately for emphasis instead of deception. A common characteristic of
humor. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *overstatement,
*understatement)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>exception</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
what does not follow the standard pattern. In language there are innumerable
exceptions to the very great number of patterns. They occur in the sound value
a certain letter or digraph may have (especially in English!), how a verb is
carried through its principal parts, how a verb is conjugated through its
person and number, how adjectives and nouns decline through their n/g/c, how
adjectives move through their degrees, <b>and the like</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>excerpt</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a portion lifted
from a larger writing or speech </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>exclamation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another term for *interjection. Latin interjections include <i>vae</i> ()<i>,
opi</i> (ouch)!<i>, heu,</i> alas)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>exclamation mark</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a mark (!) used for added emphasis. It usually appears after *interjections.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>exclamatory sentence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a sentence that expresses strong feeling in contrast to just saying it, asking
about it, or commanding it: In a huff he said, Im going home! (in a set with
*declarative sentence, *imperative sentence, *interrogative sentence)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>excrescence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a superfluous addition in the sense that it does not add meaning. An example is
grammatical gender when added as a feature of words for sexless things. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *epenthesis)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>excursus</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a separate essay
perhaps tangential to the topic of a book but added in the back to flesh out a
matter of related interest in a fashion that would interrupt the body of the
work as a digression.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>exegesis/exegetical</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
careful explanation that strives to get accurately the authors meaning out of
the text (in a set with *exposition/expository)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>exegete</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: one who does
*exegesis</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>exegetical sermon</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a sermon that ties closely to a text and endeavors to cover the same ground as
that portion of scripture includes. (in a set with *evangelistic sermon, *expository
sermon, *outreach sermon, *textual sermon, *topical sermon, *theme sermon)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>exhortation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
A sentence that says, <i>Lets . .</i> . or <i>Let us</i> . . . . Latin and
Greek use first person plural subjunctive to express exhortation. In Latin it
is part of the *jussive among independent subjunctive usages, a usage that also
applies to the first singular and to the third person: Let him do his own
work; let them do their own work. In such cases <u>let</u> does not mean allow.
(The Latin second person jussive is rare except in poetry, the *imperative mood
fulfilling that role in normal cases.) As a result, Latin does not distinguish
hortatory subjunctive because it is part of the jussive, a larger division of
subjunctive usage.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek separately identifies *hortatory
subjunction because the jussive idea for third (or second) person in Latin is
replaced by third-person imperative mood in Greek. (Latin has no third-person
imperative.)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The idea is called *cohortative in Hebrew.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>exoteric</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: suitable for
public use in contrast to what would be appropriate for insiders; contrasts
with *esoteric </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>expletive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word with no meaning in itself. It is used (1) to signal the fact that the
subject comes later. Two common English expletives are <i>it</i> and <i>there</i>,
one from pronoun origin and the other from adverb origin. For full credit, <i>it</i>
is necessary to complete the assignment (<i>to complete</i> is the subject);
There are monsters under my bed (<i>monsters</i> is subject). (2) Expletives
can fill out the structure of a sentence: <i>It</i> is raining outside. (3) a
synonym for *curse word.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>explosive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a lengthened form of *plosive, a linguistic term for an explosive sound like
the <i>ch</i> in <i><u>ch</u>uck</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>expos: </span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>the unveiling of
some topic, especially if it needs to be discredited</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>exposition/expository: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>explanation
that stresses bringing out the idea for a listeners benefit </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *exegetical/exegesis) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>expository sermon</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a kind of sermon that takes significant elements of a scripture portion and
forms them into a coherent sequence without necessarily trying to equal the
full range of subject matter the text contains. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *evangelistic sermon,
*exegetical sermon, *outreach sermon,*textual sermon, *topical sermon, *theme
sermon)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>express</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to put ideas
into words</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>expurgate</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to purge objectionable material from a publication or telecast; to bleep
certain vulgar, obscene, or simply false items or words.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>extemporary</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
presented orally without organized notes or extensive immediate preparation (in
a set with *ad lib, *off-the-cuff) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>extent of space</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Classical Greek used the accusative case on distance terms without an
accompanying preposition. Hex stadia edramen; He ran six stades.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>extent of time</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek and Latin, extent of time is covered by the accusative case on the
time word with no accompanying preposition: He worked <i>(for</i>)<i> six
hours</i>. The idea can be diagrammed as an arrow: </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:Wingdings'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
English may or may not use <i>for</i> with the time word.  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *time, *time when, *time
during/time within which)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>extinction</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the process of passing out of existence as in the case of a language that no
longer has native speakers</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>eye rhyme</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
what on a page looks like it would rhyme, but doesnt: <i>home/come; tomb/comb.</i>
The phenomenon can occur in English because the same sound may be spelled in
more than one way, and the same spelling can indicate more than one sound. (get
different examples)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>fable</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a story with a
moral point to it. It does not have to be as true to life like Jesus *parables,
and so uses plants and animals anthropomorphically in narrative form to make a
proverbial point. Jothams Fable of the Bramble Bush (Jud <b>9</b>:8-15) is an
example. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *parable/parabolic, *story,
*morality play)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>facetiae</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: factitious
writings; humorous, lighthearted sayings</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>factitive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) a type of verb that can govern a direct object plus objective complement as
in They chose him governor. (2) a descriptor for *aoristic action, or simple
action, action that is simply referred to as a fact in any tense without
linear, perfect, conative, or ingressive implication: I worked at the store, I
see the results already, <i>vs.</i> I used to work, I was working, I
tried to work, I began to work, I work at the store,  I am working, I
have worked all night, I have the work done, I will be working. Factitive
