action is punctiliar or snapshot rather than motion picture. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *aspect, *aktionsart;
*verb; *tense)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>familiar address</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a manner of speaking as to equals, using first names; contrast with *polite
address. (in a set with *honorifics)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>farce</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a play with an
improbable plot and exaggerated character with actions designed to be funny;
like the skits by The Three Stooges. An absurd, slap-stick, ludicrous,
ridiculous play.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>fascicle</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (also <b>fascicule</b>):
a work published in sections as available and then often published complete as
one volume when all the parts have been prepared</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>fear clause: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a
kind of *object clause that appears after a leading verb of fear. In classical
Greek it called for a special formula: <u>me</u> + subjunctive after *primary
tenses; and <u>me</u> + optative after secondary tenses. Using the subjunctive
after secondary tense stressed the object of the fear. Latin had the same
construction. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>feminine ending</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a declension ending on nouns or adjectives that indicates whether the word is
grammatically feminine instead of *masculine or *neuter. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *masculine ending, *neuter
ending)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>feminine rhyme</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a rhyme pattern that does not accent the last syllable <i>mother/brother.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>festschrift</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a collection of essays in honor of a scholar, written by colleagues, by
well-known persons of the same discipline, or by former students.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>fiction</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a *genre of
writing in story form that does not purport of tell about actual persons and
events. (in a set with *non-fiction)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>fientive verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
verbs found in Greek, Latin, and Hebrew that correspond to an English linking
verb plus predicate adjective: Latin <i>salver</i>, to be safe; <i>sapere</i>,
to be wise; <i>valeo</i>, to be strong; Greek <i>chalepaino</i>, to be angry; <i>heetaomai</i>,
to be inferior; Hebrew <i>katon</i>, to be small. Also sometimes included in
*stative verbs. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *active verb, *middle-voice
verb, *passive verb; *stative verb; *copulative verb, *equative verb, *linking
verb, *state of being verb, *to be verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>figurative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having to do with the usage of a word or phrase where the thing meant is
referred to as something else or in other than a straightforward manner. Contrasts
with *literal. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *literal; *figure of speech)
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>figure of speech</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
any of a number of ways of saying something in other than a straightforward fashion;
a *trope. Some kind of comparison between the thing intended and the word/words
used is often involved.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Allegory/allegorical: allegorizing the comparison</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Anaphora</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> chiasmus</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Hendiadys</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> irony</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Metaphor: calls one thing something else</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Metonymy: calls the whole by a part
(metonymy of the whole) or calls the part by the whole (metonymy of the
part)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Parable of tares and of sower close to
allegories</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Simile uses <i>like</i> or <i>as</i> in
comparing one thing to another.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> zeugma</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Euphemism: a polite way of referring to
something distasteful, something in poor taste; or personal, private, sensitive</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *euphemism, *hendiadys,
*irony, *metaphor, *metonymy, *mixed metaphor, *simile, *zeugma) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>filibuster</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
prolonged speechmaking intended to delay the legislative process at least until
such time as the side doing the filibuster has driven away enough of the
opposition to gain a victory in the voting<b> </b>(in a set with *talkathon)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>filler words</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
words used to fill time during speaking so the speaker can thinks of what to
say next: <i>er, uh, you-know, like</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>fine print</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
details of a contract or written agreement that are tucked away in an ambiguous
placeor print sizeso the signator will tend not to notice the objectionable
clause in the document.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>finite verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a type of verb that has person; hence, limited to a certain grammatical person Contrasts
with infinitives, participles, and gerunds (and Latin gerundives) as possible
kinds of verb forms</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *verbals; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>first aorist</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek, first aorist verbs use sigma-alpha as part of the tense sign for aorist
active and middle voicethe verbs third principal part.<b> </b>(in a set with
*second aorist)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>first aorist passive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek, first aorist passive verbs used theta-eta as part of the sign for the
aorist passive/future passive tensesthe sixth principal part. (in a set with
*second aorist passive)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>first Asclepiadean </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>wh
290 a type of poetic meter</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>first attributive position</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in Greek the placement of an adjective between article and its noun--in
contrast to *second attributiveafter a nouns repeated article. In addition to
adjectives, first attributive modifiers can be genitive nouns or prepositional
phrasesin short, anything that can have an adjectival value except a relative
clause.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *attributive adjective,
*predicated adjective, *second attributive position)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>First Great Commandment, The</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the shema of Deut <b>6</b>:4-5 (cp. Mt<b> 22</b>:34-40): The first great commandment
is to love God without restraint.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>first deponent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek, a verb that lacks the active voice, but has middle and passive voice.
A first deponent will not have a fourth principal part because only the perfect
active is built on that root. So, the remaining five principal parts are
represented, but they are entered in the lexicon with a middle-voice ending in
the first three parts. (in a set with *deponent, *second deponent,
*semi-deponent).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>first perfect</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek, first perfect verbs uses k(a) as part of the sign for the perfect
active voicefourth principal part. (in a set with *second perfect). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>first person</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the one/ones speaking, in contrast to the one/ones spoken to or the one/ones
spoken about </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *second person, *third
person)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>flapped <i>r</i></span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(in a set with *trilled <i>r</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>font</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>foot:</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> in poetry a set
of syllables grouped by a pattern of accented-unaccented syllables, long-short
syllables; a metrical foot </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>footnote</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an entry at the
foot of a page that elaborates (content footnote) or gives reference(s) for
the claim made in the text above (in a set with *endnote, *marginal note,
*marginalia, *sidebar, *sidenote) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>foreword</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: usually the
first entry, often not written by the author, that prepares the reader for what
is to be said in the book. It often explains the historical factors that prepared
the way for the writing and highlights the writers experience and
qualifications for the undertaking.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *introduction, *chapter,
*part, *epilogue, *appendix, *index)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>form</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) form in
language contrasts with function and meaning. (2) <i>A</i> form is a particular
possibility a word may have that identifies it by number, tense, and the like. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with formant, *formative)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>form letter</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a letter that is the same for every addressee with only those items changed
that are peculiar to a particular recipient. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>formal equivalence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a type of translation that endeavors to provide word-for-word correlation with
the original language.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>formal term</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a term used in academic or elite circumstances (in a set with *archaism, buzz
word, *informal term, oath, *obsolete term, *provincialism, *regionalism,
*slang, *technical term, *vulgaris)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>formant</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an element added
to a root in inflected languages to indicate *tense, *person, *mood, *number, *voice,
*aspect; *gender, *case. (in a set with *morpheme; *form, *formative)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>formative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an element added to roots to make connection with additions to the word: connecting
vowels, tense signs; signs for number, gender, and case. *<u>Form</u> looks at
the whole word with all its combined elements of meaning and usage. *<u>Formant</u>
is a morpheme that contributes one added element of meaning to the *root, such as
a *tense formant. *<u>Formative</u> can be a splicing mechanism that ties root
and formant together, as a *connecting vowel. A <u>morpheme</u> is any meaning
unit including the root itself and those units that change the part of speech.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *morpheme; *form, *formant)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>formulaic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having a set wording as on ancient bills of sale, funerary curses, repeated
verbal religious rituals, <i>etc.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>four-letter word</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a way of referring to a curse word since many such words have four letters.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>fragment sentence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a sentence that does not have all the parts needed for expressing a complete
thought. Fragment sentences happens mostly in written communication because the
written medium is not one in which some people habitually operate; and it is slower
to put down, which sets a person up for omitting something important to the
thought. See also *sentence fragment.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>frame of reference</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the intended range of topic. An example of issue is the use of Rom <b>5</b>:12-21
to argue that there was no such thing as death in the animal kingdom before
Adam and Eve sinned; by implication animals did not eat other animals; there
were no carnivores, only herbivores. The apostle, however, is talking about
humankind and sin reigning in death even over them that had not sinned like
Adam did (<b>5</b>:14). Over-interpreting it to apply more widely loses
apostolic authority for that further claim. One might think accordingly that
animals will be resurrected because the text goes on to say that by man (<u>the</u>
Man) came will come eternal life (<b>5</b>:21).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>free verse</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
so-called because it is free of the typical forms associated with poetry. Instead
of rhyme scheme and meter, free verse may strive only for heightened imagery,
*balanced construction, or *elliptical expression. (in a set with *poetry,
*prose) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>frequentative form</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Latin added <i>t</i>- to a root to indicate frequently doing the action indicated
by the root WH 292, 307). In Greek, <i>izo</i> verbs originally had a
frequentative, or repetitive, value.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>free-standing</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
considered a separate word and so written in contrast to existing only as an
affix or *combining form in other words. The word <i>all</i> in contrast to <i>tion</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>fricative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a sound made by restricting the air flow at variouis pronunciation points: <i>f/ph</i>,
<i>v</i> (<i>bh</i>, *bilabial *voiced); <i>th</i> (<u>th</u>in), <i>dh</i> (<u>th</u>en);
<i>ch</i> (Ba<u>ch</u>), <i>gh</i> (voiced *palatal/*velar); <i>h</i> (<u>h</u>onor;
Greek smooth breathing [], Hebrew <i>aleph</i>).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>function word</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
preposition, conjunction, and article Goetchius, 25)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>funerary inscription</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an inscription placed at a burial sight</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>fused verbs</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another term for *merged verb or *phrasal verb.????</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>fused sentence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another term for *run-on sentence<b> </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(in
a set with *comma)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>fusillade</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
n. a rapid barrage of insults </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>future tense</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(a) English <i>will</i> (<i>shall</i> for emphatic), (b) <i>going to</i> __
this job. The older will-shall distinction no longer holds: <i>shall</i> for
first person and <i>will</i> for second and third person, their being reversed
for emphasis. Most of the time in spoken English, emphatic future stresses the
auxiliary word, but a pattern has been developing in written English of
underlining the auxiliary or using <u>shall</u> for emphasis. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *imperatival future, *near
future, *distant future, *futuristic present)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>future perfect</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a tense that indicates action completed before some future point in time: <i>will
have done</i> it, <i>will have</i> it <i>done</i>. The latter option indicates
a *stative idea. A tense formed by combining <i>will have</i> with the past
participle (the third principal part of the English verb). Greek and Latin have
equivalent forms.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>futuristic present</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In if-clauses and other introductory adverbial clauses, English can use the
present tense with future force: If he goes to college, he will be more likely
to succeed. Wherever he works, he will need to learn to get out of bed in the
morning. New Testament examples include Mt <b>7</b>:41, 42, 52; Jn <b>14</b>:18.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>galley proofs</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the pages of a book as they come from type set or computer-generated copy. Any
typographical mistakes found by the author or other proof readers are noted and
corrected before final publication. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *galley sheets, *proof
reader))</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>galley sheets</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another expression for *galley proofs.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gamma</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: third letter of
the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gazette</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a newspaper or
official journal</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gazetteer</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> a
geographic index or dictionary Webster)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gender: </span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Gender is a
grammatical category that could in most cases as easily be called <i>x, y,</i>
or <i>z</i>. In grammar issues, gender is not *sex reference. While languages that
have grammatical gender usually do use masculine for male referents and
feminine for female referents, sexless items may be masculine, feminine, or
neuter. In form, English has sex-reference only, and then only in pronouns and
possessive adjectives of the third person singular. With pronouns there are *masculine,
*feminine, *neuter, and *common. Gender distinction exists in third-person
singular reference (<i>he/she/it</i>), but not in first or second person or in
third-person plural. Outside third singular, pronouns and possessive adjectives
are common (<i>I/me/my</i>; <i>we/us/our</i>; <i>you/your</i>; <i>they/them/their</i>).
Third person personal pronouns are limited to <i>he/she/it</i>. The same is
true of *reflexive and *intensive pronouns: <i>himself, herself, itself.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In popular usage outside the realm of
grammar, the word <i>gender</i> has come to have sex reference as in
social-cultural contexts. That leaves <i>sex</i> for biological contexts.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In grammatical gender, the rule in Greek,
Latin, and traditional English has been that masculine takes preference in
ambiguous, mixed, or indifferent situations. With the abandonment of
grammatical gender in favor of sex-reference only, modern English usage of
third singular pronouns has posed an issue of late. Current practice has
started using the third plural common possessive <i>their</i> (and even pronouns
<i>they</i> and <i>them</i>) for singular ambiguous, mixed, and indifferent
situations. So, comments are made like this one, their, a person. These
are considered less cumbersome than the he or she, he/she, s/he phraseology
or alternating he and she for indifferent references in an ongoing text.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin and Greek customarily used <u>neuter</u>
for ideas or general reference: <i>Nobiscum versari iam diutius non potes; <u>id</u>
patiar</i>; You are no longer able to stay with us now; I will not permit <u>it</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span lang=DE style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Masculine gender</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span lang=DE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Feminine gender</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span lang=DE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Neuter gender does not exist
in Hebrew.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span lang=DE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Common gender is a
feature of many English pronoun types and of the first person endings on Hebrew
verbs, which distinguish masculine and feminine gender in the other persons. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *number and *case for
*locating a *noun or *adjective) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *masculine, *feminine,
*neuter, *common)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>genealogy/genealogical lists</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In the Old Testament, the historical connection of persons to the past is
maintained by genealogical lists; they keep track of inheritance issues and
authority/responsibility lines. The two genealogies in the New Testament trace
the origins of Jesus. Matthews list presumably traces his genealogy through
Joseph, while Lukes trace his genealogy through Mary, replacing Marys name
with Josephs in the immediately previous generation. These lists converge in
two different sons of David/Solomon.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>generalization</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a statement that speaks of a category while meaning less than the category. It
is an instance of the difference between form of statement and meaning of the
statement. American are money-hungry probably indicates the speakers belief
that a sizeable portion of American people have that characteristic.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>generative grammar</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in the case of previously unwritten language, linguists attempt to analyze the
language systematically, discover its rules of operation, and delineate them in
organized fashion. In so doing, the linguist is generating a grammar that can
enable a new speaker to communicate in the language.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>genitive absolute: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Greek
used the genitive case for the subject and participle of an *absolute
construction; hence, it is called a <u>genitive absolute</u>. Classical Greek
often widened the condition for usage by specifying that the subject of the
dependent element not appear as the subject of the main clause rather than the
subject not appear at all in the main sentence.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>genitive case: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Genitive
case equals the *possessive case in English terminology. Most often genitive
case ties one noun to another, the nature of the case determining the exact way
the genitive-noun *referent relates to the *phrase head: to the carrying away <i>of-Babylon.</i>
The carrying away was <i>to</i> Babylon, but the Greek merely ties <i>Babylon</i>
to the preceding noun (Mt <b>11</b>:1, 12). Consequently, the hearer must be
more actively involved by needing to figure out that real connection. Greek and
Latin genitive case is handled in English with a possessive case (<u>s</u> or <u>s</u>)
or an of prepositional phrase.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The genitive case can express the part of
the whole: he conquered <i>part of</i> the city. See *descriptive genitive, *genitive
of apposition, *genitive of material, *genitive of possession, *objective
genitive, *partitive genitive (genitive of the whole), *genitive of value, *subjective
genitive. In Greek the genitive case appears after certain prepositions,
especially those implying separation. Many genitive usages in Greek and Latin
correspond to of expressions in English.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>genitive of apposition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
same as appositive genitive; the genitive case renames the noun it is attached
to: the city of Cincinnati. In most places where English uses of, Greek and
Latin use the genitive case, and Hebrew has a *construct form on the phrase
head.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>genitive of indefinite value</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
WH354#10</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>genitive of measure</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Greek uses the genitive case on measurement words to indicate amount. Acts<b> 4</b>:22:
The man on whom this sign of healing occurred was of over forty years [<i>etoon
pleioon tessarakonta</i>)? Did you sell the land <i>for so much</i>? (Acts <b>5</b>:8,
of-so-much). Latin: <i>Arma sunt <u>parvi pretii</u></i> (The weapons are <i>of
little value</i> WH 231#2); akin to *genitive of value.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>genitive of value wh 216</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>genre/literary genre</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a category of literature like *history, *prophecy, *wisdom literature, *gospel,
*apocalyptic, *acts, *novel, *poetry, *didactic.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gentilic</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a termination
that indicates someone as being a resident of or in the nation of; often
translated in scripture from Hebrew <i>i </i>as <i>ite</i>; cp. biblical and modern
terms <i>Bangladeshi, Canaani, Irani, Iraqi, Israeli, Kuwaiti, Pakistani,
Uzbekistani, Waorani, Yemeni.</i> Other endings of similar import are (Mexic)<i>an</i>,
(Egypt)<i>ian</i>, (New York)<i>er</i>, (Scots)<i>man</i>, (Chin)<i>ese</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>geocentric viewpoint</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
events viewed from the standpoint of the earth rather than of heaven of God or
from an omniscient perspective. The beginning of Genesis starts with an
omniscient viewpoint (1:1, heavens and the earth, universal reference), moves
to a geocentric viewpoint (<b>1</b>:2-<b>2</b>:3), narrows to an
anthropocentric viewpoint (<b>2</b>:4ff.). Thence it narrows further to Seths
descendants, to Noahs family, to Seth, to Abraham, to Isaac (<i> vs.</i>
Ishmael), to Jacob (<i> vs.</i> Esau). The result is a document that provides
the setting that zeroes in on place of National Israel in the scheme of things.
(in a set with *anthropocentric viewpoint, *omniscient point)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gerund</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: In English, a
gerund is a verbal noun with an <i>ing</i> termination: <i>Giving</i> is more
blessed than <i>receiving</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *finite verbs,
*infinitives, *participles)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gerundive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in Latin, another name for the future passive participle, a passive verbal
adjective often uised to express obligation or necessity</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>geschichte</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
German for history (sp)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gesticulate</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to use bodily motions to indicate or reinforce ideas expressed while speaking</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gesture</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: visual indicator
of some message: (1) a sign or signal: bowing, curtsying, holding ones hand up
(as if to answer), holding ones hand out with the palm facing toward someone
(meaning stop), nodding, pointing with the chin, rolling the eyes, rub ones
stomach, shaking the head, *shrugging, snapping the fingers, squinting the eyes,
sticking out the tongue, thumbing the nose, winking,<i> etc</i>.; (2) an act of
kindness by which a person communicates goodwill with perhaps the implication
of willingness for further efforts toward a meeting of minds or change of
procedure. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Biblical gestures in the first sense include
(1) shaking the dust off your feet at someone ();</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) putting ones hand under another mans
thigh accompanying a legal agreement (); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) spitting in someones face as a
gesture of contempt (Num <b>12</b>:14; Job <b>17</b>:6; <b>30</b>:10; Is <b>50</b>:4);</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (4) removing a shoe and spitting in the
face of someone who does not want to fulfill the Levirate marriage
responsibility (Deut <b>25</b>:5-10; Ruth <b>4</b>:7-9);</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (5) sitting in sackcloth and ashes as a
gesture of repentance (); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (6) rending ones garments as a gesture of
abhorrence (); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (7) stretching forth the hand to signal
attention to what a person is about to say to a group of people ();</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (8) prostrating oneself before another as
a sign of total submission and the complete abandonment of personal dignity, in
the style of Muslim prostration in worship.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (9) wagging the head, (moving the top of
the head back and forth?) or shaking the head (moving the front of the face
from side to side as in the current American gesture?); <i>kinoutes</i> (Gr)
means moving in general; so unclear): Mt<b> 27</b>:39 = Mk <b>15</b>:29; cp.
Job <b>16</b>:4; Ps <b>22</b>:7; <b>109</b>:25; Lam <b>2</b>:15; Zeph <b>2</b>:15;
). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (10) hissing: Jer <b>19</b>:8; Zeph <b>2</b>:15.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (11) the laying on of hands in connection
with appointment to a duty or office; the bestowal of a blessing, the
transmission of supernatural gifts, the bestowal of healing</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (12) anointing with olive oil in
connection with appointment to a duty or office: the appointment of a prophet
(), a king ()</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (13) using third person for second person
as a sign of respect when speaking to a dignitary (Num <b>27</b>:15-17)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *kinesics, *anointing with
oil, *laying on of hands)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ghost writer</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the person who actually wrote the book even though the name of another person
appears as official author. A practice sometimes followed when the subject of
the article or book is not particularly skilled in written communication even
though his or her life or ideas provide the subject matter for the writing.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Similar to the phraseology by __________ <i>with</i>
_____, where the second person actually put the article or book together on
the basis of information supplied by the first through interviews.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gibberish</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gimel</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the third letter
of the Hebrew alphabet:</span><span style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL
style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>given name</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the first name, which distinguishes one person from others within a related
group (in a set with *surname)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>glossary</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a collection of
terms belonging to a field of study or thought, usually placed after the body
of a book. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>glossolalia</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a speaking in tongues, which some Christians equate with ecstatic utterance
but others with xenoglossia, as descriptions of the New Testament phenomenon. (in
a set with *ecstatic utterance, *xenoglossia, speaking in tongues): </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>glottals</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (in as set with
*labials, *dentals, liquids, and *velars)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>glyph</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a carved symbol
for a meaning or sound, usually incised/engraved rather than raised; a figure
like an arrow or a human on a sign that gives information</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>glyptics</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the art of
engraving on precious stones</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>glyptograph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an engraving on precious stones</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>go-between</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an *intermediary, as a prophet or priest in divine-human relations </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *prophet, *priest,
*intercessor, *intermediary)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gonzo</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: highly
unconventional, subjective, exaggerated style in journalism; similar to *yellow
journalism</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gospel</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: as a literary
unit, <i>gospel</i> refers to canonical, uncanonical, and pseudepigraphical (1)accounts
of the life of Christ. Over time, a gospel came to be thought of also as (2) a
literary form. It was a specialized biography that focused on the years of his
ministry and stressed the final week of that ministry. Prior to the beginning
of Christs ministry, the canonical gospels tell only about events surrounding
his birth (Matthew and Luke) and a set of incidents when he was twelve at his
dedication in the temple. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Uncanonical and pseudepigraphical gospels
tried to fill in the gaps from those earlier years. <i>Gospel</i> thus became a
type of literary *genre in post-apostolic times in which to indulge the
imaginations of writers and put their own ideas into the mouth of Jesus.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In *lectionaries, gospel refers to (3) a
reading from the gospels in contrast to one taken from the epistles.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *biography, *
autobiography): </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>govern/government</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
is in a set with *concord to form the manner of connection between parts of an
expression. Governance refers to what one word requires another to be like. That
can happen (1) between a preposition and its object as in <b>English</b>, where
prepositions require their objects to be in the objective case. <b>Greek</b>
prepositions require their objects to be in the genitive case (especially if
the preposition implies separation), dative case (especially if the preposition
implies location), or accusative (especially if the preposition implies
destination). <b>Latin</b> prepositions call for objects in the ablative case (especially
if the preposition implies separation or location) or the accusative case (especially
if the preposition implies destination). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Governance also refers to (2) what a verb
requires its object to be. After most English, Latin, and Greek verbs the
accusative case appears. In some instances where Latin and Greek verbs imply
relationship, the object is in the dative case, a type of *dative of
relationship. In some Latin verbs that imply separation, the objects appear
in the ablative case. In some instances where the verb affects only some of the
object, the genitive case appears. Comparable to eat <u>of</u> the fruit of
the tree. The Hebrew equivalent of this last construction uses <u>min + maqef</u>.
(in a set with *concord)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>grace</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: prayer at a meal</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>grammar</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) collectively,
the devices that show the relationship between parts of a sentence. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) A book, or text, that describes the
workings of a language. An <u>instructional grammar</u> is designed to introduce
students to the language; so it sequences aspects of the language for learning
purposes. Vocabulary sets and exercise become part of the grammar. Larger items
like subjunctive mood will probably get spread out across different chapters. By
contrast, a <u>descriptive grammar</u>, or <u>reference grammar</u>, presents in
one place everything the author wants to say about each feature of the language.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>grammarian</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
one who deals with grammar</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>grammatical</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having to do with the syntax and perhaps the inflectional forms of a language (in
a set with *syntax, *inflection; * declension, *conjugation)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>grammatical gender</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the gender assigned somewhat arbitrarily to nouns in inflectional languagesand
to verbs sometimes. Since adjectives in such languages must agree in gender
with their nouns, adjectives also have gender, but not in themselves.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English grammatical gender is almost
non-existent except for an occasional usage of <i>she</i> for a ship and the
like. <i>She </i>is typically used in Iceland for the volcanoes that are there,
and may be so called when brought into English. Masculine and feminine genders
usually correspond with male and female sex, but neuter things and abstractions
are assigned various genders. Latin, for example, often class abstractions as
feminine. Other classifications are correlated with certain nominalizing *morphemes:
<i>-al, -e, -ar</i> (neuter), <i>-or, -tor</i> (masculine). Greek is similar in
this regard. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Common gender means that a form lacks
gender distinction in an otherewise inflectional setlike English first and
second person pronouns and possessive adjectives and third person plural
pronouns and possessive adjectives: <i>I, me, my, mine; we, us, our, ours; you,
your, yours; they, them, their, theirs; </i>but <i>he, his; she, her, hers; it,
its.</i> Hebrew, which uses gender in its second- and third-person verbs, has
common gender in first person.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew has only masculine and feminine (and
common) grammatical gender while Greek and Latin have also neuter. As noted
above, English has virtually no grammatical gender and so, for the most part, has
common nouns.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Grammatical gender gets involved in the
translation process when pronouns whose Greek or Latin *antecedents are a
different gender from what is appropriate in English. On such case of interest
pertains to the Holy Spirit. If a person first concludes for the personality of
the Spirit, then <i>He</i> is the appropriate pronoun reference in English even
though Greek uses a neuter pronoun is to match the antecedent. Acts <b>8</b>:16
refers to the Spirit (neuter) of <b>8</b>:15, but the ASV of 1901 says <i>it</i>
fell on none of them, a matter corrected in the NASB: <i>He</i> fell on none
of them. Examples of neuter pronouns for the Holy Spirit include Jn <b>14</b>:17;
<b>15</b>:26.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *gender; *masculine,
*feminine, *neuter, *common; *translation; *capitalization)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>graph</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a letter of the
alphabet, the spelling of a word, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>grapheme</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a letter of the *alphabet;
all the alternative forms (letters, *digraphs, or *consonant clusters) for
representing the same sound/*phoneme. English includes the following:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>Consonants </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>c<sup>1</sup></i> [generally before <i>a,
o, u</i> as in <i><u>c</u>oat</i>], <i>k </i>[leu<u>k</u>ocytopenia]<i>, ch</i>
[s<u>ch</u>ool], <i>ck </i>[bla<u>ck</u>] for the phoneme <i>/k/</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>f, ph, gh </i>[enou<u>gh</u>] for the
*phoneme <i>/f/</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> g<sup>1</sup></span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> [generally
before <i>a, o, u</i> as in <i><u>g</u>oat</i>], gg [] for the phoneme <i>/g/</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>g<sup>1</sup></i> [re<u>g</u>ime], <i>s
</i>[mea<u>s</u>ure and with most medial <i>si- </i>words like <i>deri<u>s</u>ion</i>],
ss<sup>1</sup> [fi<u>ss</u>ion] for the phoneme /<i>zh</i>/ </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>h<sup>1 </sup></i>[<u>h</u>onor]<i>, # </i>[zero
symbol, i.e., no letter, but a *glottal stop pronounced as in <i>apple</i>] for
the phoneme<i>/</i></span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span dir=LTR></span><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span>/</span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>j, g<sup>1</sup></i> [generally before <i>e,
i, y</i> as in <i><u>g</u>in<u>g</u>er</i>] for the phoneme <i>/j/</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>ch<sup>1</sup></i><sup> </sup>[<u>ch</u>urch],
<i>tch</i> [ba<u>tch</u>] for the plosive phoneme <i>/ch/</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> ng, n</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
[before all *velars as in ra<u>n</u>cor, li<u>n</u>go, ra<u>n</u>k, co<u>n</u>ch]
for the phoneme <i>/ng/</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>s<sup>1</sup> </i>[<u>s</u>ilent]<i>,
ss<sup>1</sup> </i>[mi<u>ss</u>ing], <i>sc </i>[<u>sc</u>ythe and all others <i>sc
</i>followed by<i> e, i, </i>or <i>y</i>] for the phoneme <i>/s/</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>sh<sup>1</sup>, sch </i>[bu]<i>, ss<sup>1</sup>
</i>[mi<u>ss</u>ion]<i>, ti </i>[fic<u>ti</u>on]<i>, si </i>[]<i>, ci</i> for the
phoneme <i>/sh/</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>t, d<sup>1</sup> </i>[rippe<u>d</u>]<i>,
th </i>[th<u>y</u>me] for the phoneme <i>/t/</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> w, # </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>[zero
symbol, i.e., no written letter as on _<i>one</i>] for the phoneme <i>/w/</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> x, cks [ra<u>cks</u>], ks [] , cs [sac<u>s</u>]
for the phoneme <i>/ks/</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> y, #</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
[zero symbol, i.e., no written letter as often on the front of words with <i>u-</i>
or <i>eu-</i> as in _<i>union</i> and _<i>euphoria</i>] for the phoneme <i>/y/</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>z, s<sup>1</sup></i> [rid<u>s</u> and
most cases where preceded by a vowel or *voiced consonant] for the phoneme <i>/z/</i>
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> To this list theoretically could be added
most cases of single and doubled consonants: <i>b/bb, c/cc, d/dd, f/ff, g/gg,
l/ll, m/mm, n/nn, p/pp, r/rr, s/ss, t/tt, v/vv, z/zz.</i> The qualification,
however, is that several of these consonants as singles have other values
besides the one they share with their doubles.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>Vowels</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>a, ay</i> for //</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>e, ea, ee, ey, -y, i</i> [reg<u>i</u>me]
for //</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>i</i> [li<u>n</u>e]<i>, igh</i> [blight,
fight, high, might, nigh, plight, sigh, thigh] for //</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> o</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
[lone]<i>, oa </i>[loan]<i>,</i> for //</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>u,</i> -<i>eau-</i> [b<u>eau</u>ty] for
//</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *pronunciation, *spelling)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>grave accent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an accent mark that slants up to the left (`). In English spelling the grave
accent appears on a few words and phrases of French origin, though often not
actually written except in formal settings:  la carte,  la mode, cause
clbre, crche, pice de rsistance, pied--terre, vis--vis, voil.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek spelling, the grave accent
represents a fall tone and appears only on the last syllable. (in a set with *acute
accent, *circumflex accent; *diacritical marks)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>greater Asclepiad</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
kind of meter Wh 337</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
