font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>greeting</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (a) an address
to someone when they meet.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (b) the opening address to the recipient(s)
of a letter. Paul, James, Peter, John, Jude begin all their letters in this
way: Luke includes his greeting to Theophilus in his introductions to the gospel
(<b>1</b>:30 and Acts (<b>1</b>:1): Rom <b>1</b>:1-7; 1 Cor <b>1</b>:1-9; 2 Cor
<b>1</b>:1-2; Gal <b>1</b>:1-5; Eph<b> 1</b>:1-2; Phil <b>1</b>:1-2; Col <b>1</b>:1-2;
1 Th <b>1</b>:1; 2 Th <b>1</b>:1-2; 1 Tim <b>1</b>:1-2; 2 Tim <b>1</b>:1-2; Tit
<b>1</b>:1-4; Phil 1-3; James <b>1</b>:1; 1 Pet <b>1</b>:1-2; 2 Pet <b>1</b>:1-2;
1 Jn <b>1</b>:1-4; 2 Jn 1-3; 3 Jn 1; Jude 1-2; Rev <b>1</b>:4-7. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *introduction, *salutation)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Grimms Law</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a pattern of consonant change from Indo-European to Germanic correspondents. In
general, the alterations stay within the same pronunciation points: labial,
dentals, and velars. The changes mean that <i>p, t, k</i> became <i>f, th, h</i>
(voiceless stops became voiceless fricative); <i>b, d, g</i> became <i>p, t, k</i>
(voiced stops lost voicing); and <i>bh,dh, gh</i> became <i>b, d, g. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (voiced fricatives became voiced stops)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>groaner</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a bad joke (but not *risqu), a *Tom Swifty, often taking advantage of the
multiple meanings of a word (in a set with *Tom Swifty, *double meaning,)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>guideword</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the words at the top of a dictionary page that show the first and last word
entered alphabetically on that set of pages; guidewords make it faster and
easier to see whether the desired word falls on those pages</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gutturals</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Hebrew <i>aleph, he, heth, ayin</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hackneyed</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an trite, overused expression that marks the speaker as uneducated</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Haggadah</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the part of the
Talmud that deals with historical material in contrast to legal concerns</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Hagiographa</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
holy writings; one of the three basic divisions of Old Testament literature: The
Writings along with the Law and the Prophets. Same as the Hebrew term <i>Chetubim</i>.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *Torah, *Nebiim )</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Hagiography</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
literature, often idealizing, about the lives of saints </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>handbook</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a *manual brief
summary of subject matter associated with a special field of operation (in a
set with *manual)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>handle</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the name or
expression used by Cbers to identify themselves. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *call letters)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hapax legomenon/hapax legomena</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
once-used word within some category, whether in all the literature of that
language, in a certain work, in a certain writer, in a given time frame, and
the like. [Gr once + said]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>haplography</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an omission, especially of repeated elements, a kind of copyist error</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with homoioteleuton,
dittography, metathesis as types of scribal errors)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>haplology</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the dropping of a repeated element in a word. An examples is <i>cephalgia</i>
as a short for <i>cephalalgia</i>, the more original word being comprised of <i>cephal</i>-
(head) and <i>algia, a </i>suffix for pain. Latin has <i>nutrix from
nutritrix</i>, (nurse). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>harangue</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><u><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>he</span></u></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the fifth letter
of the Hebrew alphabet</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><u><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>he</span></u></b><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
directional/directive</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the old Hebrew accusative ending <i>ah</i>
appended to an appropriate noun can signal direction toward, as with <i>mitsraim<u>ah</u></i>
for toward Egypt.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><u><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>he</span></u></b><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
interrogative</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: prefixed to the front of the first word
of the sentence to show that a questiion is being asked.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><u><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>He</span></u></b><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
locale</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>: in Hebrew language study, an older designation for
direction. (*<u>He</u> directive)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>heading</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (In a set with
*title)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>headline</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a summarizing
set of words over an article in a newspaper, magazine, or other *ephemeral
paper</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>heavy endings</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in Hebrew, the pronominal endings for second and third person plural verbs and
possession</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Hebraism</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a distinctive
manner of expression found only in Hebrew, but translated word-for-word into
Greek or English. (in a set with *Hellenism, *Latinism, *Aramaism, *Anglicism)
Dana &amp; Mantey, <u>Manual Grammar</u>, pp. 14-15.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hellenism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(in a set with *Hebraism, *Aramaism, *Latinism, *Anglicism)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>helping verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another term for *auxiliary verb, separate words that combine with the verb in
contrast to inflectional changes to the verb itself</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hendecasyllabic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having eleven syllables</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hendiadys</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a figure of speech in which appear two nouns, two entries, two *word pictures
for the same thing. It is kind of acceptable redundancy. So, two nouns joined
by <i>and</i> say what could be said by an adjective-noun combination. NT
examples. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hendiadys raises the well-known question
in Gen<b> 1</b>:26 as to what the difference is between the imago dei and the <i>similitudo
dei</i>. Whereas it may be possible to imagine some plausible distinction
between the two phrases, they may be nothing more than two words pictures for
the same general idea of likeness to God. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hermeneutics</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a more formal word for interpretation that includes the discipline of *interpretation
as such as well as the process of integration that carries all the way up to
*worldview. (in a set with *authorial intent, *interpretation)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>het/heth</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the eighth
letter of the Hebrew alphabet: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:
14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hexameter</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a line of verse containing six metrical feet </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *trimeter, *tetrameter,
pentameter)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hieratic</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an offshoot of
hieroglyphics (in a set with *demotic)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hieroglyph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a pictograph; a pictorial symbol that represents meaning or sounds [Gr <u>hieros</u>,
holy + <u>glyphein</u>, to carve]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>High Priestly Prayer, The</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
The extended prayer of Jesus recorded in Jn <b>17</b>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hint</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a kind of
implication that deliberately requires the listener to infer some further point.
Hint differs from *innuendo and *insinuation by having a neutral connotation;
it differs from *slam and *cut by being indirect.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>historical linguistics</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Historical linguistics looks at the preceding (and succeeding stages of a
languages development as a way perhaps of elucidating seemingly aberrant
features of the language. *Comparative linguistics shows the similarities
between contemporary related languages. *Descriptive linguistics focuses on a
certain stage of a language without concerning itself with historical
backgrounds or other contemporary related languages.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *comparative linguistics,
*descriptive linguistics)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>historical present</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a present tense verb used for relating a past event. Also called *vivid
narration: Last week I was walking along the railroad tracks, and this
six-foot-long black snake <u>crawls</u> across the gravel about five yards
ahead of me, and <u>starts</u> over one of the rails just before a freight
train <u>comes</u> barreling down on us. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>history</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with
*storie, *saga, *epic, *historie, *novel, *novelle, *geschichte)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>homily: </span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a<b> </b>sermon, a
presentation in a religious setting (in a set with *sermon, *sermon types , , ,
)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>homiletics</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the discipline of sermon preparation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>homoioteleuton</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a kind of copying error that omits the material between a recurrent element in
a segment of text. (in a set with *metathesis, *haplography, *dittography as
types of *scribal errors)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>homolegoumena</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
books of the Bible that everyone accepted as canonical in the early years of
the church</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>homograph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word spelled like another word but with <u>different pronunciation</u> and <u>different
meaning</u>, a two-pronunciation word: <i>abuse</i>, <i>aged</i>, <i>attribute</i>,
<i>bases</i>, <i>bass</i>, <i>blessed</i>, <i>boule,bow<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>/bowed/bower</i>,
<i>buffet</i>, <i>business</i>, <i>close </i>(v, adj)<i>, closer </i>(n, adj), <i>concrete</i>,
<i>content</i>, <i>contrary</i>, <i>crooked</i>, <i>desert</i>, <i>divers, do</i>,
<i>does</i>, <i>document</i>, <i>dogged/doggedly</i>, <i>dove</i>, <i>drawer</i>,
<i>excess, excuse</i>, <i>expose</i>, <i>fine</i>, <i>fragment, glower</i>, <i>grease,
house </i>(n, v), <i>implement</i>, <i>infinite</i>, <i>insurance</i>, <i>invalid</i>,
<i>lead</i>, <i>learned</i>, <i>legged, live,</i> <i>lives, minute</i>, <i>moment</i>,
<i>moped</i>, <i>mouse </i>(-s or z), <i>mouth</i>, <i>mow/mowed/mower</i>, <i>number<sup>1</sup>,
nun (Hebrew letter), offence</i>, <i>overage</i>, <i>pan, peaked</i>, <i>perfected,
</i>(<i>Polish/polish</i>), <i>read</i>, <i>refuse, regress, route, row, separate,
sewer, shower, (sine/sine), sow, striped, supplement, tender, tear, tier/tier, tow,
tower, use, wicked, wind, windy, wound. </i>Note also <i>decent/descent</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A large group of words ending in <i>ate</i>
can have a verbalways in teand a corresponding adjective or agent-noun in
te. <b>[insert panel-also under pronunciation]</b> <i>advocate</i>, <i>aggregate</i>,
<i>animate, approximate</i>, <i>articulate</i>, <i>associate</i>, <i>consummate</i>,
<i>coordinate, correlate</i>, <i>delegate, deliberate</i>, <i>deviate</i>, <i>document</i>,
<i>duplicate</i>, <i>elaborate</i>, expatriate, <i>graduate</i>, <i>initiate</i>,
<i>intimate</i>, <i>moderate</i>, <i>officiate, palp, pan<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, personate,
precipitate</i>, <i>predicate</i>, <i>profligate</i>,<i> regenerate,</i> <i>ruminate</i>,
<i>separate</i>, <i>streaked</i>, <i>subordinate, syndicate</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The <i>ate</i> with adjectives and nouns
may have a long <i>a</i> if there is no related verb. <b>[insert panel-also
under pronunciation]</b> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Many two- or three-syllable words can be
verbs or nouns, spelled the same way but often accented on the first syllable
as nouns or adjectives and on the second syllable for verbs: <b>[insert
panel-pronunciation]</b> <i>absent</i>, <i>addict</i>, <i>address</i>, <i>appropriate,
attribute</i>, <i>cement</i>, <i>collect</i>, <i>combat</i>, <i>combine</i>, <i>commune</i>,
<i>compact</i>, <i>console</i>, <i>construct</i>, <i>consummate, content</i>, <i>contest</i>,
<i>converse</i>, <i>convert</i>, <i>convict</i>, <i>defect, desert</i>, <i>digest</i>,
<i>entrance</i>, <i>envelope</i>, <i>impact</i>, <i>import</i>, <i>incline</i>,
<i>increase</i>, <i>intimate</i>, <i>liver, object</i>, <i>perfect</i>, <i>pervert,
predicate, present</i>, <i>proceed, produce</i>,<i> progress, project</i>, <i>rebel</i>,
<i>recall</i>, <i>record</i>, <i>refuse</i>, <i>regress, reject</i>, <i>reprint,
retread, separate</i>, (<i>shit</i>), <i>subject</i>, <i>suspect, transfer</i>,
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *homonym, *homophone)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>homonym</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a word sounding
like another word with the same spelling but <u>different meaning</u></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>aircraft, alert, beat</i>, <i>bid</i>, <i>bison</i>,
<i>bit/bit</i>, <i>bound, burst</i>, <i>clad</i>, <i>cost</i>, <i>craft</i>, <i>cut</i>,
<i>deer</i>, <i>drove</i>, <i>elk, felt, fish</i>, <i>flounder</i>, <i>founder,</i>
<i>fry</i>, <i>ground</i>, <i>hit/hit</i>, <i>hurt</i>, <i>knit</i>, <i>let</i>,
<i>lit/lit</i>, <i>live</i>, <i>luster, miss</i>, <i>mouse, muff, muffle, mug,
mule, mull, mum, mummy, mush, nag, nap<sup>1, 2, 3, 4</sup>, nave, net, nit, nix,
nog, noodle, novel, nun, pant, parr </i>(sg &amp; pl),<i> peck, pen, perch,
peer, pet, put, quit</i>, <i>rid</i>, <i>rifle, rose</i>, <i>saw, set</i>, <i>shed</i>,
<i>sheep</i>,<i> </i>[shit], <i>sounder,</i> <i>spit</i>, <i>split</i>, <i>spread</i>,
<i>stern</i>, <i>stole, stranger</i>, <i>swallow, sweat, tales, tote, trailer</i>,
<i>wet</i>, <i>wilt, you/ your </i>(sg $ pl)<i>, . </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Depending on how broadly <i>homonym</i> is
defined, there is a large number of places in Latin and Greek where the same
form within a word covers more than one place in the inflection. Latin and
Greek both use the same form for nominative, vocative, and accusative on neuter
words. In Latin the nominative plural and genitive and dative singular are the
same in the first declension (-<i>ae</i>). Second-declension us nouns have the
same ending for nominative plural and genitive singular (-<i>i</i>). The same
pattern applies to fourth declension masculines with the accusative plural also
the same -</span><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Comic Sans MS"'></span></i><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>s</span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>. Fifth declension
nominative singular and plural are alike with the accusative plural also the
same (-</span><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Comic Sans MS"'></span></i><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>s</span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>). Third declension
masculines and feminines use the same ending for nominative and accusative
plural (</span><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Comic Sans MS"'></span></i><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>s</span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>). Except for the
singular of second declension <i>us</i> nouns, which use <i>e</i> for
vocative, vocatives for nouns in any gender are the same as the nominative, -<i>ius</i>
nouns and -<i>mi</i> excepted (-i). Dative and ablative plurals are always the
same. Third conjugation first singular verbs are the same in future indicative
and present subjunctive (<i>faciam</i>, <i>e.g.</i>). Third declension
adjectives are the same for masculine and feminine. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek has about the same array of common
forms within inflections. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> With a broad definition of <i>homonym</i>,
English homonyms are much more frequent because of the paucity of distinctive
inflectional forms to distinguish case, gender, number, tense, voice,<i> etc</i>.,
in nouns, adjectives, and verbs. Englishs high number of feeder languages
creates the same end product beginning at entirely different starting points.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *homonym, *homophone)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>homophone</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word that has the same sound as another with <u>different spelling</u> and <u>different
meanings</u></span></p>

tacked/tact, tacks/tax, tael/tail/tale, taint/taint, talks/tocks/tox taper/tapir,
tard/tarred, tare/tear<sup>1</sup>, tarry/terry, tau<sup>1</sup>/taw, taught/taut/tot,
taupe/tope, team/teem, tear<sup>1</sup>/tier, teas/tease/tees, tel/tell, tense/tents,
tenuis/tenuous, tern/turn, the<sup>1</sup>/thee, their/there/theyre,
theres/theirs, tern/turn, therefor/therefore, throes/throws, threw/through, throne/thrown,
thyme/time, tic/tick, tidal/title, tide/tied, tier/tire, til/till, timber/timbre,
to/too/two, toad/toed/towed, tocsin/toxin, toe/tow, toed/towed/toad, toke/toque,
tole/toll, told/tolled, tole/toll, ton/tun, tool/toule, toon/tune, tor/tore/torr,
tort/torte, toughed/tuft, track/tract,trade/trayed, tromp/trompe, troop/troupe,
trooper/trouper, turban/turbine, undo/undue, use/yews, vain/vane/vein,
vale/veil, vary/very, vealer/velar, venous/Venus, verses/versus, vet/vette,
vice/vise, vial/vile/viol, viral/virile, vocalize/vocalize, waddy/wadi, wade/weighed,
waist/waste, wait/weight, waive/wave, waiver/waver, walk/wok, wand/wanned, want/wont,
war/wore, ward/warred, ware/wear, warn/worn, waive/wave, wart/wort, watt/wot), wattle/waddle,
waver/waiver, way/weigh, ward/warred, ware/wear, wares/weirs?, weak/week,
weave/weve, wed/weed/weld, well/weal, which/witch, whoa/woe, whos/whose,
wind<sup>1</sup>/wined, winds/winze, wood/would, yack/yak, yall.yawl, yawn/yon,
yawned/yond, yoke/yolk, yore/your/youre, youll/yule, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *homograph, *homonym)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>honorific</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a title standing alone or put ahead of a persons name to indicate respect,
especially in reference to a social superior. These may be stand-alone terms
like Your Honor, Reverend, Doctor; or titles of public office (Mayor Johnson,
Senator Riggs, President Lincoln; or to the *titular system of countries that
have such a system (Lord Mills, Queen Mary)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hortatory</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the adjective for exhort/exhortation in contrast to narration or explanation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hybrid verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb whose principal parts come from different roots. Also called *suppletive
verb.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hymn</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with
*ode, *paean): a song of praise or gratitude to God</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hype</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: exaggerated
praise or claims of greatness, importance, and the like. Hype can show up in
advertisements, which often exaggerate need and the advertised solution to
need.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hyphen/hyphenation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a one-space horizontal line used (1) to join two words into one whole. It is
used to join words, for instance, that together make a unit of modification
attached to the next word: a superlative-degree adjective. In this example, <u>superlative</u>
modifies <u>degree</u> and the two in turn taken together modify the next term.
To say a community-church building is not the same thing as to say a
community church-building. A hyphen helps the eye distinguish, say, a noun
(stick-up) from a phrase (stick up the bank). Consistency is hard to discern in
the hyphenation pattern for two words, hyphenated words, and joined words. It
is really a matter of time where the left-to-right stages of the pattern has
developed to. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> It may make a difference in hyphenation
where the word set appears: That is a big-time win for us (attributive
adjective) <i>vs.</i> That win was big time for us (predicate adjective).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hyphens are not used to join adverbs to
adjectives that in turn modify nouns: a quickly written note. Such a set of
words usually stand out well enough not to confuse a reader. Sometimes an adjective-noun
combination makes such an obvious combination that a readers eye connects the
two words naturally without using a hyphen: a second declension noun, a First
Temple sarcophagus. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) Hyphens also mark the break in a word
that is too long to fit on the line of writing. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) In telephone numbers, a hyphen
separates the exchange from the specific number: 539-5031. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (4) A similar usage applies to lengthened
area codes: 66502-2314. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (5) Finally, a hyphen appears as part of
the standard spelling of words made up of two parts, especially if not using
the hyphen would create a diphthong or unpronounceable letter combination: <i>co-operation,
pick-up</i> [truck], <i>co-ordinating, semi-colon, salpingo-oophorectomy.</i> Since
custom drives usage, words that were formerly hyphenated are now considered one
word to the extent that the hyphen is considered no longer needed: <i>cooperate</i>.
Writing conventions sometimes take a while to catch up with the spoken
realities. For instance, <i>rain check</i> has the same accent and pitch
pattern as <i>homework, rainbow, railroad,</i> <i>etc.</i>, but dictionaries
still list it as two words. About all a writer can do is consult a dictionary
to see how far convention has carried a particular word.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  (in a set with *dash, *dieresis).
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hypotactic/hypotaxis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the pattern of subordinating clauses and phrases to other clauses and phrases
rather than making them grammatically parallel: She stayed <u>and helped</u>
with the clean-up; <i>vs.</i> She stayed <u>to help</u> with the clean-up. NT
ex. Acts 5:19 (in a set with *paratactic; note also *asyndeton)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>iambic pentameter</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (note
other forms of poetic *meter)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>iambic trimeter wh 343</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>iambic dimeter wh 217</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ibidem</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a Latin term
that means in the same place as the previous reference. (abbreviated <u>ibid</u>.
in *footnote/* and endnote references</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>identical rhyme</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the full repeat of the word: home, home (get other examples) (in a set with *exact
rhyme, *eye rhyme, *imperfect rhyme, *rime riche, *suspended rhyme)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>idiom</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an expression that
carries a meaning not easily associated with the normal meaning of its words and
a meaning that would not convey its idea if translated by word picture into
another language. English ex.  I dont give a hoot. The meaning of an idiom
lies at the level of the whole expression instead of at the level of its combined
constituent parts.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>if-clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the dependent part of any *conditional sentence: <i>If he crosses the bridge, </i>he
breaks the treaty. Same as *protasis.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>illative</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a continuation
of an idea without exactly involving the precise meaning of the connecting
word: inerrancy is the word of God written and <u>therefore</u> inerrant in the
autographs. It is one thing to </span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>s</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ay that <u>because</u>
scripture is the word of God written, it will have no mistakes in it; it is
another thing to say that <u>in keeping with the fact that</u> scripture is the
word of God written, it is inerrant. One causes (causal), the other correlates
(illative); <i>therefore </i>can be used both ways<i>.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>illiterate</span></b><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>unable
to read (in a set with *literate)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>immediate future</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb construction for action in the *near future. Same as *near future. (in a
set with *distant future). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>immediate past</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb construction for recent action. (in a set with *distant past). Same as
*near past.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>immediate prohibition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Hebrew distinguishes immediate prohibition from *permanent prohibition by using
<u>lo</u> + imperfect (rather than <u>al</u> + shortened imperfect). (in a set
with *permanent prohibition): </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>imperatival future</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the future tense used to express a command. In English such a usage often has
an intensive value: Yes, you will. Particularly under the influence of Hebrew
idiom, the future indicative in New Testament Greek may carry an imperatival
force: Acts<b> 1</b>:8. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin the same possibility existed: you
shall not steal. (L, ex. Wh 319, 320)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>imperatival infinitive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an infinitive that has the value of a command:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>imperatival participle</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek, a participle that has the value of a command. The Great Commission
says, strictly, Having gone, make-disciples. An aorist participle depending
on an imperative ends up also being imperatival. See possible imperatival <b>participles
in Romas .</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>imperative mood</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
The imperative mood gives a command, advice, request, or entreaty.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Additionally, there are some cases of
idiomatic usages: Jesus says, Destroy this temple, and in three days I will
rebuild it (). Paul says, Be angry, and do not sin ().</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The idea of permissive imperative, identified
in some New Testament Greek grammars, may misunderstand the let idea as allow
in English. Let doesnt mean that in English idiom either.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek the imperative second plural
always has the same form as the corresponding indicative.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *indicative, *subjunctive,
*optative, and *infinitive moods; *commands) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>imperative sentence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a sentence that gives a commanduses the imperative moodin contrast to simply
declaring it, asking about it, or emotionally saying it: Its late, John; go
on home. (in a set with *declarative sentence, *exclamatory sentence,
*interrogative sentence)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>imperfect rhyme</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Only some of the sounds match: cat, cot; hop, cup. Get other examples. Also
called *near rhyme. (in a set with *eye rhyme, *perfect rhyme)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>imperfect tense</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Latin and Greek, the imperfect tense is a past tense that looks at action as
being in motion, as motion picture <i>vs.</i> snap shot, linear <i>vs.</i> *punctiliar,
*progressive <i>vs.</i> *factitive. Linear can be continuous, iterative, *characteristic,
*progressive, *cyclical, *tendential/*conative. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The imperfect tense can be translated <i>was
working </i>(<i>progressive action</i>), <i>would work </i>(characteristic
action), <i>tried to work</i> (*conative/*tendential action), <i>used to work</i>
(action no longer occurring). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin, the imperfect tense also covers
*inceptive/*inchoative/*ingressive action in past time, an aspect associated
with the *aorist tense in Greek.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Since Hebrew does not have tense, strictly
speaking, but completed <i>vs.</i> uncompleted action, its imperfect tense
corresponds more closely with the future tense: <i>will work</i>, <i>will be
working</i>, <i>etc.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *present tense, *past
tense, *aorist tense, *future tense, *perfect tense, *past perfect
tense/*pluperfect tense, *future perfect tense)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>impersonal verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb that regularly is used only in the third person singular because it
typically uses an infinitive as its subjects and is typically translated into
English with the expletive <u>it</u>: Greek <i>dei</i> (it is necessary); <i>chree</i>
(it ought); Latin: <i>licet</i> (it is permitted).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>improper diphthong</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a Greek diphthong comprised of a long vowel plus iota. Such an iota does not
affect pronunciation, a fact shown by subscripting it under the long vowel. If,
however, the long vowel gets capitalized, the iota comes back up on the line
after it and any accents or breathing marks are written ahead of the capital: Hadeees.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>imply/implicatio</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>n<b>:
</b>an unsaid idea that follows from what has actually been said. A speaker
implies; the hearer infers. (in a set with infer/inference, innuendo)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inceptive action</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an aspect of verbal action that refers to the start of an action. Same as
*inchoative and *ingressive. approaching something wh 312 = ingressive?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inchoative action</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an aspect of verbs that refers to the beginning of an action; also called
*ingressive or *inceptive action. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *continuous action,
*cyclical action, *iterative action, *linear action, *progressive action)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inclusive language</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the attempt to avoid terminology that uses grammatical gender in situations
that are not specifically male or female. The practice sets aside the pattern
descending from Hebrew and the classical languages of masculine taking
preference in mixed or ambiguous situations. In part, the perceived difficulty
is a function of Englishs loss of grammatical gender; so all that is left for
pronoun usage is sex reference. To remedy the situation, writers and speakers
resort to saying he or she or even alternating <i>he</i> and <i>she</i> in
the same segment of writing. The first procedure seems awkward; the second creates
ambiguity and grates on expectancy. Returning to the use of the indefinite
pronoun <i>one</i> resurrects the stilted connotation that word has picked up. A
person may work better. At least in deference to feminist sensitivities, some
kind of restructuring or *circumlocution seems preferable to the first three.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Inclusive language has been brought into
speech about the Judaeo-Christian God. Although there are a few cases where he
is pictured as fulfilling a role normally associated with female, He is revealed
to us, and talked about, as male despite the obvious point that God, being
spirit, is neither male nor female. That matter is in stark contrast to, and
surely deliberately different from, the conceptualizations of deity/deities in
surrounding Near Eastern cultures. It is clear, then, that the reason for usage
is to indicate something besides sexuality. That reason must have to do with
projecting greater power and final authority. The issue comes down, then, to
agreeing or disagreeing with the fundamental idea that there is absolute
equality between men and women as to roles, a viewpoint that scripture denies
in favor of division of labor and complementary roles. That point is different
from equality of worthunless a person is prepared to claim that being higher
in authority means greater in worth.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> At any rate, in the translation of
scritpture, it is the translators role to translate what the text says rather
than to make it say what the translator prefers to have it say. (in a set with
*politically correct)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>incorporative language</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a language that compounds sentence parts into one unit. (in a set with
*inflectional language, *isolating language, *agglutinative language)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>indeclinable: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>In
inflected languages, a noun or adjective without case forms like the other
words do: Latin examples include centum (adj., hundred),nihil (n. nothing),
satis (n., enough), necesse (adj., necessary). English nouns and adjectives are
not declinable except for the apostrophe s for possessive case. Since that
general feature exists in the language, speakers get tangled up in the use of
pronouns, which are still declinable for the most part. As a result, people
misuse pronouns in places like the compound object of prepositions:  between
you and <u>I</u> instead of between you and <u>me</u>. As evidence that
declension is continuing to disappear from English, note the current practice
of avoiding <u>whom</u> lest the phraseology sound pedantic: Who are you
talking to? instead of To whom are you talking?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In the New Testament, Greek brings most of
the Hebrew names over as indeclinable nouns. The Greek infinitive also can be
called an indeclinable noun; if its case is important to identify, the neuter
singular article may accompany it.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek has the indeclinable adjective perix
(Acts<b> 5</b>:16).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin has the indeclinable adjective <i>quot</i>
(how many).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>indefinite article</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In English, <i>a/an</i> is used before consonants and vowels respectively to
indicate one of something where there is no specific example in mind. The <i>a</i>
form of the indefinite article is pronounced uh, not <i><u></u></i>, and is
treated much like a *proclitic, pronounced with a light accent and attached to
the next word.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin does not have articles, although <i>unus</i>
sometimes approaches that value.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek article vs no-article does not
distinguish between definite and indefinite, but between quality and identity. However,
<i>heis/mia/hen</i> seems to approach the value of an indefinite article in
some New Testament cases: Mt <b>9</b>:18; <b>12</b>:11; <b>25</b>:60; Acts <b>28</b>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *article, *definite
article, *determiner)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>indefinite pronoun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
someone, something; anyone, anything; a person; one; you used advisedly;
they with indefinite reference: Well, thats what they say.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>indefinite relative pronoun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
whoever, whomever, whosever [who<u>so</u>ever], whatever [what<u>so</u>ever]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>indentation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a spacing to the right in the first line of a paragraph, traditionally a
half-inch. English customarily calls for six spaces in writing/typing/printing.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>independent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
said of clauses that carry the main thought of the sentence, a clause to which
other clauses grammatically attach. Same as insubordinate. (in a set with *dependent)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>independent clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a clause that can standing alone because it is conceived of as being completeas
making sense without further explanation. Also called an *insubordinate clause.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>independent verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
*same as main verb or *leading verb in a *complex sentence; the verb in a
clause that can stand by itself . </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *main verb, *leading verb ;
*dependent verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>independent nominative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
same as parenthetic nominative, where the nominative noun does not serve as
subject of any verb.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>index</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a unit in the
back of a book that lists items within the work as a whole: scripture
references cited, *excerpts or quotations from ancient authors cited (as NT
quotations of OT texts), *allusions and verbal parallels to the Old Testament found
in the New, manuscripts consulted as in the original text of the Bible,
abbreviations used, pages where various specific subjects are covered,<i> etc</i>.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>indicative mood</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the *mood of a verb that simply indicates action in contrast to commanding
action (*imperative mood) or suggesting action. *contingent action
(*subjunctive mood), oras in Greekuncertain action (*optative mood). The last
mood is missing in English and Latin. So its values get absorbed into the
subjunctive in Latin or covered by *circumlocution. Likewise, the subjunctive
has virtually disappeared from English, its usages being absorbed into the
indicative.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *imperative mood,
*subjunctive mood, *optative mood, *infinitive mood)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>indictment</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>indirect /imperative/command</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
The dative-case noun or pronoun in the main clause is the same referent as the
subject of the subjunctive verb in the dependent cluase. Copnsequently, English
can translate the construction with an infinitive phrase: <b>example </b>Several
Latin verbs can be followed by *jussive clauses in the subjunction: <i>hortor,
impero, moneo, oro, persuado, peto, quaero, rogo</i> (as well sometimes as <i>malo,
nolo, volo</i>). WH ch. 36 314#123 334#20 (in a set with *indirect discourse,
*indirect question, *indirect statement)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>indirect discourse</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a dependent construction that gives the idea in a speakers original wording in
contrast to *direct discourse, which gives the purported words that were used
to say something. Depending on how the term is used, indirect discourse can make
a statement or ask a question (*direct question). Not every verb can introduce
indirect discourse. It follows verbs of speaking (say, tell), mental action (hope,
think, believe, suppose), and the senses (feel, see, hear, sense). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English usually uses a finite verb, but it
can use an infinitive if the subject in the indirect discourse part is the same
as that of the main verb. English uses <u>that</u> to introduce indirect
discourse, but <u>that</u> is often omitted: My son said ( ) he was going to
take a nap.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Since Latin uses an infinitive
construction for *indirect statement, it needs to be categorized separately
from *indirect question within indirect discourse; it is, strictly speaking, a
phrase in that language. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Classical Greek likewise could use
participles and infinitives in addition to *finite verbs, depending on the identity
of the leading verb; those cases should be classified under phrases as well. New
Testament Greek usually used a finite verb with <u>hoti</u> as the introductory
conjunction.  (in a set with *indirect statement, *indirect question;
*direct statement, *direct question, *quotation)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>indirect object</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the person or thing to whom or for whom the verb operates on the *direct
object. Consequently, there can be no indirect object without a direct object. If
<i>to</i> appears where no direct object exists, it does not indicate an
indirect object: I went <i>to</i> town; I was bored <i>to</i> tears; I was
important <i>to</i> him; I raised the bid <i>to</i> $10; I wanted <i>to</i>
go. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The indirect object in English is
indicated by the preposition <i>to</i> if it comes after the direct object. If it
precedes direct object, <i>to</i> does not appear: she gave <i>the poor dog</i>
a bone; or she gave a bone <i>to the poor dog</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin and Greek, the dative case without
a preposition indicates the indirect object. Hebrew uses the *inseparable
preposition </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span dir=LTR></span><i><span
lang=HE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span> </span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prefixed to a noun or a pronominal suffix
to show indirect object: <u>he</u> directive. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *direct object)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>indirect question</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a dependent grammatical structure that conveys the <u>idea</u> that was in a
direct question rather than the very <u>words</u> originally used. The leading
verb will mean <i>ask</i>, <i>question</i>, <i>wonder</i>, <i>tell</i>. It can
be introduced by interrogatives (how, when, who/what/which, why), by whether/if,
and the like. To introduce the dependent construction, Greek uses introductory
interrogatives and <u>ei</u> (if/whether).<b> </b>Latin likewise uses interrogatives
(<i>cur, quam, quando, qui/quae/quod, quis/quid, ubi, unde), uter, utrum . . .
an</i>), -<i>ne</i> (on the first word of the dependent clause). Latin uses
subjunctive mood on the verb inside the indirect question. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *indirect statement,
*indirect imperative/command)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>indirect reflexive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
WH315#170</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>indoctrinate/indoctrination</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to teach someone, usually with the negative implication that the teaching is
done in such a way as not to allow the student to know or understand and
evaluate alternative viewpoints (in a set with *doctrine) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ineffable:</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Not
able to be uttered because of its great dignity; applied to the *tetragrammaton,
the four-consonant personal name for the Hebrew God. Based on the commandment
not to take the Lords name in vain, a Jewish tradition developed of not saying
the name at all. Since the Hebrew alphabet had consonants only, the original
vocalization was lost. The New Testament follows the *Septuagint in not challenging
this custom, using Lord (<i>kyrios</i>) where the personal name of God would
appear. That choice of substitution coincides with the Hebrew practice of
saying my Lord (<i>adonai</i>) instead of Gods proper name when the
tetragrammaton appears in the Old Testament text. See also *Jehovah.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inerrancy</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a term used in Christian circles for the belief that scripture does not err
relative to the intended content of scripture as such. As such, it is not meant
to include a readers misinterpretation, scribes transmissional errors,
mistakes of form or grammar, substitution of synonyms (spelling, diction, <i>etc.</i>).
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *dictation theory of
inspiration, *dynamic inspiration, *infallibility, *plenary inspiration, verbal
inspiration)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>infallible</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a view of the nature of scripture originally synonymous with *<u>inerrant</u>. With
the rise of the inerrancy debate in the late twentieth century, <u>infallible</u>
shifted toward meaning able to accomplish that whereunto it was sent (cp. Is <b>55</b>:10-11).
That more functional emphasis left open the question of whether there might be
errors of content in the Bible that in fact everyone has to usetransmitted,
conflated, and the like. it would not, in this view, have to be accurate in
certain kinds of informationscience, history, geographythat lay outside the purpose
of divine revelation: human-divine behavioral relationship. Such a view has
been criticized for putting the nature of scripture beyond confirmation, beyond
the realm of verifiability and falsifiability.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>infallibility</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Infallibility pictures inspiration as an operation relative the purpose of
revelation, which entails Gods word not returning to him void, but fulfilling
the purpose for which he sent it (Is <b>55</b>:10-11). Matters of science,
history, geography could conceivably lie outside this purpose and therefore not
be subject to the *inerrancy principle. <i>*Plenary inspiration</i> and <i>*inerrancy</i>
are terms invoked to contrast with this looser definition.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *dictation theory of
inspiration, *dynamic inspiration, *plenary inspiration, *verbal inspiration;
*inerrancy)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>infer/inference</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the drawing of a further idea out of what someone has said. The hearer infers;
the speaker *implies. (in a set with *imply/implication, *innuendo) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>infinitives</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Infinitives are infinite in that they are not limited by person. They are not
*inflected except for voice and tense. In verb *paradigms, they parallel *moods
and *participles. Infinitives can fill *noun slots, adjective slots, or adverb
slots. If infinitives have subjects, the subjects are in *accusative case: Dad
wants <i>me</i> to play taps on Memorial Day. Infinitives can have all the
*verbal adjuncts used with *finite verbs: adverbial modifiers (to go <i>soon</i>;
to go <i>to town</i>), *direct objects (Dad wants me to play <i>taps</i>), *indirect
objects (He went to give <i>the cows</i> some hay), *objective complement
(They tried to make Jesus <i>king</i>), and *retained object (They wanted
Jesus to be made <i>king</i>).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English infinitives usually have <i>to</i>
as their accompanying sign. Certain constructions, however, omit it: Let me <i>do</i>
it; she may <i>go</i> home; Could/would/should they <i>come</i> over
tomorrow?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
