text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Participles also are infinite in that they
do not have person, but they differ from infinitives in having
number-gender-case form in Greek and Latin and thereby attach to nouns as
modifiers.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *complementary infinitive,
*split infinitive, *imperatival infinitive, *finite verb, *participle, *gerund)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>infix</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a change in the
middle of words that changes the meaning. English infixes can make some nouns plural,
change the tense of verbs, or create cognate words. (Entered here by sound
rather than spelling since some words like <i>break/broke </i>have or pick up a
non-syllabic <i>e</i> or other feature<i> </i>in spelling.)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Noun plurals</u>: <i>foot/feet</i>; <i>goose/geese</i>;
<i>man/men</i>; <i>mouse/mice</i>; <i>woman/women</i>; <i>this/these</i>
(omitted here are <i>is</i> words that become plural by <i>es</i>; the <i>is</i>
is an ending rather than part of the root)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Verb tenses</u>: <i>abide/abode</i>, <i>bear/bore</i>(<i>bare</i>);
<i>beget/begot(begat), begin/began</i>; <i>behold/beheld, bid/(bade</i>), <i>bind/bound</i>;
<i>bite/bit</i>; <i>blow/blew</i>, <i>break/broke</i>; <i>breed/bred</i>; <i>break/broke</i>,
<i>breath/breathe, </i>(<i>bring/brang</i>), <i>choose/chose</i>; <i>cleave/clove</i>
(or <i>cleaved/cleft</i>; formerly <i>clave</i> as in KJV Gen. 34:3), <i>come/came</i>;
<i>dig/dug</i>; <i>dive/dove</i>; <i>draw/drew</i>; <i>drink/drank/drunk</i>; <i>drive/drove</i>;
<i>fall/fell</i>; <i>feed/fed</i>, <i>freeze/froze</i>; <i>fight/fought</i>; <i>find/found</i>;
<i>forbid/forbad//forbade, forget/forgot</i>; <i>forgive/forgave</i>; <i>forsake/forsook,
freeze/froze</i>, <i>get/got</i>(<i>gat</i>); <i>grind/ground</i>, <i>give/gave</i>;
<i>grow/grew</i>; <i>hang/hung</i>; <i>heave/hove</i>; <i>hide/hid</i>; <i>hold/held</i>;
<i>know/knew</i>; <i>lead/led</i>; <i>leave/left</i>, <i>light/lit</i>; <i>may/might</i>
(<i>maghd&gt;might</i>); <i>meet/met</i>; <i>misread/misread, mistake/mistook, rad/read</i>/;
<i>ride/rode</i>; <i>ring/rang/rung</i>; <i>rise/rose</i>; <i>run/ran</i>, (<i>see/sawI,
seek/sought</i> (&lt;<i>seeghd&gt;seekt&gt;sought</i>); <i>shake/shook</i>, <i>shine/shone</i>,
<i>shoot/shot</i>, <i>shrink/shrank/shrunk</i>; <i>shrive/shrove, sing/sang/sung</i>;
<i>sink/sank/sunk</i>; <i>sit/sat</i>; <i>slide/slid</i>, <i>smite/smote,</i> <i>sneak/snuck</i>;
<i>speak/spoke</i>(<i>spake</i>); <i>speed/sped</i>; <i>spin/spun</i>; <i>spit/spat</i>;
<i>spring/spran/sprung</i>; <i>stamp/stomp</i>; <i>stand/stood</i>; <i>steal/stole</i>;
<i>stick/stuck</i>; <i>sting/stung</i>; <i>stink/stank/stunk</i>; <i>stride/strode,
strike/struck</i>; <i>string/strung</i>; <i>strive/strove, swear/swore</i>(<i>sware</i>);
<i>swim/swam</i>/(<i>swum = swimmed</i>); <i>swing/swung</i>; <i>take/took</i>;
<i>teach/taught</i> (&lt;<i>teeghd &gt; teacht</i>); <i>tear/tore</i>; <i>tooth/teeth,
throw/threw</i>; <i>tread/trod</i>; <i>understand/understood</i>; <i>wake/woke,</i>
<i>wear/wore</i>; <i>weave/wove</i>; <i>win/won</i>; <i>wind/wound</i>; wit/wot,
<i>wring/wrung</i>; <i>write/wrote</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Sometimes infixes combine with suffixes
for tense change: <i>deal/dealt, feel/felt, flee/fled, hear/heard, mean/meant, sell/sold</i>,
<i>tell/told, weave/woven</i>. Latin does the same thing going from first to
third principal part: <i>venio/v</i></span><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ni,</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Cognate</u> words: <i>abide/abode; bind/bond;
blew/blown; breathe/breath; deep/depth, died/dead; feed/fed, give/gift
(&lt;gived); heat/hot; lift/loft, melt/molten, ride/road; shine/sheen, sing/song,
sip/sup/soup?; shoot/shot, sit/seat; stamp/stump; strike/stroke; strip/stripe; sup/soup;
thief/theft wind/wnd</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek often creates cognate words and
principal parts by shift <i>e</i> to <i>o</i>: <i>legoo/logos, pempoo/pepompha,
</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *affix, *epenthesis, *prefix,
*suffix) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inflected languages</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
languages that use endings on nouns to indicated their sentence functions, on
adjectives to show what they modify, and on verbs to indicate *aspect, *mood, *number,
*person, *tense, and perhaps *gender.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inflection</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Inflection carries a word through its possible forms. It includes what can
occur in *declension for *nouns and *adjectives and *conjugation for *verbs. (in
a set with *distribution for defining *parts of speech; *indeclinable,
*declinable, *declension, *conjugation)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inflectional language</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a language that indicates the relationship between communication parts by the
use of *affixes on roots. (in a set with *inflectional language, *agglutinative
language)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>informal term</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an every-day term used by people who does not function in the technical field
involved. (in a set with archaism, buzz word, catch phrase, curse word, *formal
term, *oath, *obsolete term, *provincialism, *regionalism, *slang, *street
talk, *vulgarism)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>informational question</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a form of question that asks for information without implying either an
anticipated positive or negative response; a straightforward question, nothing
implied, but one that does anticipate response in contrast to *rhetorical
question.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *question; *rhetorical
question; *question anticipating negative response, *question anticipating
positive response)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ingressive action</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the start of an action; also called *inceptive and *inchoative (in a set with *ingressive
aorist, *inchoative, *incorporative language, *ingressive imperfect)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ingressive aorist</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the aorist tense was typically used to cover past-tense ingressive action in
Greek. Acts 3:8 seems to have an *ingressive imperfect, however (cp. Latin).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ingressive imperfect</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Latin could use the imperfect tense to cover the beginning of an action in past
time. Acts 3:8 may be a Greek example of using the imperfect rather than the
usual aorist for this idea.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>initial</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: v. to put ones
*initials on something to indicate approval of its contents</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>initials</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the combination
of the first letters of a persons name. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *abbreviation, *acronym)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>innuendo</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an indirect *put-down,
*insinuation, subtle derogatory remark; *hint<b> </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>instrument: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>also
<u>means</u>; refers to the tool used for accomplishing something: he cut
down the cherry tree with a hatchet. Latin uses the ablative case on the noun involved
with no preceding preposition. Greek uses the dative case for this conceptalso
without a preceding preposition. New Testament Greek often adds <i><u>en</u></i>
(in) ahead the dative-case noun for the instrument.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>instrumental dative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the dative case in Latin and Greek used to indicate the means (<i> vs.</i>
personal agency) by which something is accomplished. In New Testament Greek, <i>en</i>
often precedes the noun.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>instrumental case</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in the eight-case analysis of Greek, the instrumental dative is separated out as
a case function by itself.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inscription/inscribe</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a writing on some object like a coin, sarcophagus, pottery, or a wall. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inseparable prefixes</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
prefixes that exist only in combination with roots; they are not free-standing.
Greek has <i>a</i>(<i>n</i>)-, a prefix meaning not; <i>archi</i>-, ; <i>dus</i>-,
; <i>nee</i>-, ;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inseparable preposition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Hebrew certain prepositions that do not stand alone, but are prefixed to
their object: <i>le</i>- (to), <i>be</i>- (in), <i>ke</i>- (as/like), (and <i>me</i>
&lt; <i>min</i> [from]).  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inseparable suffixes</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Latin used several additions on the ends of words, additions that did not
appear free-standing and were not part of the suffix system on nouns, adjectives,
verbs, and cognate-noun creators: -<i>ne</i> (attached to the first word of a
clause to indicate that a question is being asked if there is no interrogative
that would otherwise so indicate), -<i>ve</i> (attached to the second element
in a list to mean or), -<u>que</u> (attached to a word in a list that meant
and), -<i>dem</i> (added to the regular third-person personal pronoun to make
an indefinite pronoun -<i>is</i> to is<i>dem</i>),</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Older English had the directional suffix <i>ward</i>
as in us<i>ward</i> for toward us. Modern English still uses after<i>ward</i>,
to<i>ward</i>, heaven<i>ward</i>, home<i>ward</i>; lee<i>ward</i>; south<i>ward</i>,
north<i>ward</i>, east<i>ward</i>, west<i>ward</i>; in<i>ward</i>, out<i>ward</i>;
up<i>ward</i>, down<i>ward</i>;<i> </i>on<i>ward</i>, way<i>ward</i>; for<i>ward</i>,
front<i>ward</i>, back<i>ward</i>; un<i>toward</i>. Another directional suffix
is <i>ad</i>: <i>caudad</i>, toward the tail, <i>cephalad</i>, toward the
head, <i>dextrad, </i>toward the right, <i>sinistrad</i>, toward the left</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *separable suffixes,
*suffixes)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inside address</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
The date, name, and address of the recipient are repeated from the envelope on
the letter itself to avoid confusion if the letter gets separated from its
envelope. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *salutation, *body,
*complimentary close, *signature, *post script as parts of a letter)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>insinuation/insinuate</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a negative comment not directly said, an expression that expects the hearer to
infer the intended negative connotation. Insinuation and *innuendo differ from
*cut, *slam, and *insult by being indirect. It differs from *hint* by being
negative.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>instructional grammar</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a grammar designed to introduce a student to a language. Its layout involves
exercises, vocabularies, units sequenced to inform on a graduated basis. (in a
set with *manual grammar, *reference grammar, *descriptive grammar)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>instrumental dative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek the dative case without accompanying preposition can be used on a noun
to indicate the thing someone used to accomplish a result. In places, the New
Testament uses <u>en</u> ahead of such a noun.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>insubordinate clause: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a
clause that can stand alone because it is considered to express a complete
thought. Also called an *independent clause. Contrasts with *subordinate
clause, or *dependent clause. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>insult</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a direct
negative comment to a person that either stretches the truth or intentionally
misrepresents his character. A *cut, *a slam. An insult differs from *innuendo
and *insinuation by being direct. It differs from hint by being negative.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>intense/intensive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Prepositional prefixes in Greek and Latin words were sometimes simply
intensifiers. <i>Eathioo </i>in Greek means to eat;<i> </i>katesthioo means
to hog it down, to gluttonize. The Piel? (active) and Pual? (passive) stems
in Hebrew are intensive stems. There are intensifiers that can be added to
Greek and Latin verb roots in order to intensify the meaning of the root.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *emphasis)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>intensive pronoun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In English, -<i>self</i> pronouns restate a noun. Historically intensive
pronouns were placed immediately after the associated noun. The modern habit is
to make it *postpositive at the end of the clause if the intensive restates the
subject: John <u>himself</u> did it <i>vs.</i> John did it <u>himself</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> To create intensive pronouns, English uses
the <i>self</i>/<i>-selves </i>suffix on <i>my</i>-, <i>our</i>-, <i>your</i>-,
<i>him</i>-, <i>her</i>-, <i>it</i>-, <i>them</i><b>-</b> (but not on I/me,
we/us, you, he/his/she/its, or they/their). The <i>self</i> *morpheme does not
combine with *nominative/*subjective forms of pronouns. More complicated is
that fact that in first and second persons, <i>self</i>/<b>-</b><i>selves </i>is
added to the <u>possessive</u> pronoun form, but in the third person <i>self-selves</i>
is added to the objective/<u>accusative</u> form of the pronoun rather than the
possessive. As a result, it is considered ungrammatical to say <i>meself</i>,
or <i>hisself</i>, <i>theirselves</i>; and <i>itself</i> is not spelled <i>it<u>s</u>self</i>,
which would be a possessive form attached to <i>self</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>singular</u> <u>plural
</u></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> 1 myself ourselves</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> 2 yourself yourselves</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> 3 himself/herself/itself themselves</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek, <i>autos</i> serves as the
intensive pronoun for all persons if it is in *predicate position, that is, if
it stands before the article or after the noun. If <i>autos</i> stands in *attributive
position (between article and noun or after the article repeated), it means
same. Standing alone outside the *nominative, it is a *personal pronoun for
the *third person. If it does appear alone in the nominative, it emphasizes the
subject expressed in the ending on the verb; in doing so, it is comparable to underlining
the pronoun in written English: <u>He</u> crossed the bridge.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin, <i>ipse/ipsa/ipsud</i> are the
nominative forms of the intensive pronoun for all persons.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>intercede/intercession</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to be the go between on someone elses behalf. *Intercessory prayer is on
behalf of someone else.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>intercessor</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a go-between, especially from man and God. A priest intercedes for men to God;
a prophet is a *spokesman for God to men. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *intermediary, *priest, *prophet;
*auricular confession)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>intercessory prayer</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
prayer on behalf of someone else. In liturgical church, a *priests role as
intercessor is signaled by his facing away from the congregationin the same
direction as the congregationwhen offering the pastoral prayer. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>interfix</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to add a sound
between undesirable sound sequences to make them pronounceable.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>interject</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to insert something into a speech or perhaps previously prepared text being now
delivered orally as at a scholarly conference. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>interjection</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word or phrase, not part of the syntax of the sentence, that expresses
emotion: <i>alas</i>! <i>boy</i>! <i>hot dog</i>! <i>ho hum!</i> <i>hurrah</i>!
<i>man</i>! <i>ole</i>! <i>ouch</i>! <i>pah</i>! <i>pash</i>! (short for <i>passion</i>),
<i>pshaw! oyez oyez</i>! <i>rah</i>! <i>ugh</i>!, <i>wahoo, whee,</i> Some
words said to animals offer further examples: <i>click click</i> (to a horse), <i>git</i>
(to a dog), <i>hey </i>(to a cow),<i> scat</i> (to a cat), <i>shoo</i> (to a
chicken), <i>sooey</i> (to a pig). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin: <i>hui</i> (boy, whee)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek: idou (behold), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>intermediary</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a *go-between, an *intercessor like a *priest or *prophet in divine-human
relations. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In some societies, important business is
carried through an intermediary as a sign of respect rather than transacted
face to face, the latter being consider too forward, too presumptuous, too in
your face. The practice is seen in Gen <b>32</b>, when Jacob returns to Canaan
to meet his brother Esau. Similarly, at the behest of Nathan the prophet, Solomons
mother approaches David about having Solomon succeed him as king of Israel (1
Kg <b>1</b>). In the New Testament, James and John evidently have their mother
approach Jesus about having them sit on the right hand and on the left in His
kingdom. Since it was really James and John who were making the request, Mk <b>10</b>:35-41
can present it as their approach to Jesus while Mt <b>20</b>:20-24 reports it
as their mother approaching Jesus with the request.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>interpolate/interpolation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
A copyist might correct his work by interpolating a previous omission
(*haplography). A *copist, *editor, or *redactor may add an explanatory note, one
entered into the text line rather than in a footnote or in the margin. The concern
is that a marginal note, taken by a later copyist as a previous omission, was
added into the regular line of writing. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Gen <b>35</b>:6; Josh <b>1</b>:10, 11, 23
illustrate the kinds of things that might constitute interpolations. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>interpretation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
ideally, coming to understand the authors meaning; as a term it is often used
to include a readers inferential application beyond *authorial intent.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>interrogative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having to do with asking a question. Asking a *question is done in a number of
ways. (1) There are *interrogative words, words that by their very meaning ask a
question: <i>why, who, where, what when, how</i> (on the front of a sentence);
Latin: <i>cur</i>/why, <i>ubi</i>/where; Greek <i>tis/ti</i> (with acute on
first syllable = who/what/why). (2) a suffix on the end of the first word: <i>-ne</i>
on the first word of a Latin *informational question whose word order is
identical to the wording of a statement. (3) rearrangement of words in English:
Are you coming? as a transform of You are coming. (4) distinctive pitch
pattern: raised pitch at the end of an English sentence makes a question even with
the same wording as in a statement: You are coming? (5) helping words in the English
verb form: Did you look? <i>vs.</i> You looked. (6) Hebrew uses an
interrogative <u>ha</u>- prefixed to the first word of an informational
question, whether direct or indirect question. (7) punctuation in a written
language: English (?); Greek (;).  In English, Latin, and Greek,
interrogative pronouns, interrogative adjectives, and adverbs may indicate
questions.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> So, there are interrogative pronouns (<i>Who</i>
stole my book?), interrogative adjectives (<i>Whose</i> book did he steal?),
or interrogative adverbs (<i>Where</i> did he stash the stolen book?), <i>When</i>
did he steal the book? <i>Why</i> did he steal the book? <i>How</i> did he
steal the book?). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In all these languages indicators for interrogation
tend to come first in their clauses. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *direct question, *indirect
question, *informational question, *rhetorical question, *question anticipating
a negative response, *question anticipating a positive response).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>interrogative adjective</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
question-asking adjectives that modify nouns: <i>which, what </i>in initial
position: <u>What</u> (book) are you reading? <u>Which</u><i> </i>(book) are
you reading? The interrogative adjectives are adaptations of interrogative
pronouns, which are among the question words that stand alone.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>interrogative adverb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
<i>when, where, how </i>in initial position as a question in English.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>interrogative conjunction</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Latin has <i>an</i> Wh 232</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>interrogative pronoun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
<i>who/whom/whose, what</i> in initial position </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Gr </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Lat</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>interrogative sentence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a sentence that asks a question in contrast to simply saying something,
commanding something, or emotionally expressing something: When will you be
going home? </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *informational question;
*question anticipating positive response, &amp;question anticipating negative
response; *declarative sentence, *exclamatory sentence, *imperative sentence)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>interrogative words</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
words that always ask a question. Certain English words always ask questions if
they appear first in the clause: <i>Who/whom/whose, what; when, while, where;
which.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek interrogative words include <i>tis/ti</i>
with acute accent on the first syllable; it is usually first in clause, but not
necessarily (Jn <b>21</b>:12), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin interrogatives include <i>cur</i>
(why), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>interrogatory</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another term for *interrogative</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>intervocalic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
between vowels. English tends to vocalize intervocalic voiceless *consonants.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>intervocalic sigma</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Greek developed a practice of eliding intervocalic sigmas when inflection
placed sigma after a short vowel and before another vowel of any length;
exposed vowels then contracted according to the same rules of contraction. The
phenomenon shows up in the genitive plural of the second declension; the ending
was originally asoon, which became -oon circumflexed: -asoon &gt; oon
(gephurasoon &gt; gephuroon); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> wherever <i>sai</i> occurs as the second
singular middle/passive: -esai &gt; eei (luesai &gt; lueei)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> wherever <i>so </i>occurs as the second
singular middle/passive: eso &gt; ou (lueso &gt; luou) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (note also *contraction)  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>intonation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the use of pitch to distinguish questions from statements rather than depending
on some syntactical transform or additional wording to do so: You are happy? <i>vs.</i>
Are you happy? (2) akin to *modulation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>intransitive verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb that does not have a direct object in a given sentence. Intransitiveness
has to be figured on a per-sentence basis because a given verb may be used
transitively or intransitively depending on the sentence, in He worked
yesterday <i>vs.</i> He worked the clock. Consequently, a dictionary can
give only general information on this aspect of a verbs usage.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A verb like <i>drink</i> may change
meaning in the different usage. Intransitively, <i>drink</i> means drink
alcohol; transitively can be used for drinking anything.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *transitive verb; *linking
verb/*equative verb/*to be verb/*copulative verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>introduction</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a standard element in longer writings, such as a book, that states the purpose
of writing, the method of research that underlies it, the scope of the
presentation, and any distinctive viewpoints taken or notable structure of
presentation, the manner of presentation for optimum benefit to the reader. In
ancient literature, there are New Testament examples at the beginning of Lukes
gospel (Lk<b> 1</b>:1-4) and his Acts of the Apostles (<b>1</b>:1-2ff). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *acknowledgments, table of
contents, *epilogue, *greeting, *preface, *prologue) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>invective</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a denunciation, an abusive discourse</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inveigle</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to win over by
coaxing</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inverted pyramid</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a structure of writing in newspaper articles that starts with the main idea and
works down to more detailed matters as the piece proceeds.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inverted sentence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a sentence that places the subject after the verb: Here are two examples of my
writing. My objections to the proposal are <i>these.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>invocation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a prayer at the beginning of a public gathering, especially one of a religious
nature</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>iota</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: ninth letter of
the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>iota-diminutive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in Greek terminology iota was sometimes added to a root to create a word to
indicate something in smaller form: biblos &gt; biblion, biblaridion, teknion
&lt; teknon, paidon (&lt; pais), chorion &lt; chera, (the added iota gets the
accent)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>iota subscript</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
The Greek iota is written under a long vowel since it does not in that case
affect pronunciationas in the dative singular of the first two declensions or
as the result of contraction in contract verbs and elsewhere. The iota
subscript is written on the line after the main vowel if all capitals are
used or if the long vowel is capitalized in c and lc; subscripts are not
written under capitals (Aidees).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ipsissima verba</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the exact words, the very words of another; the words themselves [Lat]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>irony</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a figure of
speech that says the opposite of what is meant and does so in a way that makes
the real meaning clear. Hes a great man, said in a way that denies that he
is great. The opposite, intended meaning is indicated by an opposing context, by
tone of voice, by a contradictory facial expression or some other accompanying
gesture. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Paul evidently meant his words ironically
in 2 Cor <b>12</b>:13: How were you inferior to the other churches except that
I was not a burden to you? <u>Forgive me this wrong</u>!</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>irregular</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an case of not following expected pattern, whether for making a plural, for
moving through the principal parts of a verb, for moving through the degrees of
an adjective or adverb, for the formation of *cognate words, or even for moving
through the declension of a specific noun or verb. Latin uses a different
dative and ablative plural for <i>dea</i>, goddess. By pattern it should be <i>deis</i>
in those spots; but since <i>deus,</i> god, would be the same thing in those
places, Latin reaches over into third declension to get substitute endings <i>de</i><i>a-bus</i>
to supply a form that is distinguishable from the masculine word <i>deis</i>. The
nominative masculine plural of <i>deus</i> should be <i>dei</i>, but as time
went on <i>di </i>replaced it. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *regular) (*defective verb,
, *deponent verb, *impersonal verb, *irregular verb, *suppletive verb).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ironic</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: characterized by
*irony. Ironic can describes incongruities, adverse effects, surprise
consequences.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>irregular adjectives</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Latin, there is a group of nine first-and-second declension adjectives that
among themselves are alike but differ from the other adjectives in this group
by having <i>ius</i> in the genitive singular of all three genders and <i>i</i>
in the dative singular of all three genders. Additionally, they may show <i>ud</i>
in the neuter nominative/accusative singular. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>irregular nouns</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>irregular verbs</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb whose conjugation is unusual in some way. In many languages, the verb
to be, for example, is irregular. That may result from the fact that the
forms of this verb are so often used. In English, there are <i>am, is,</i> and <i>are</i>
in the present tense and <i>was, were</i> in the past. Besides, with singular <i>you</i>
belongs <i>were</i> even though everywhere else <i>were</i> is a plural form.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin there <i>volo</i> (vis, vult, <i>etc</i>)
does not move through its person-and-number format in the normal way. Some
words exist only in the third person, sometimes called *impersonal verbs: <i>inquit?
</i>(Lat); <i>deoo? chree</i> (Gr)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin,</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *regular verb; *composite
verb, *defective verb, *deponent verb, *suppletive verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>irregular comparison of adjectives</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Irregular comparison of adjectives means that the roots of the three *degrees
of the adjective do not come from the same root; they are like the English
good, better, best.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>irregular comparison of adverbs</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the roots of the three *degrees of the adverb do not come from the same root.
Latin Greek In Latin and Greek, since adverbs of manner are usually built on
corresponding adjectives, the irregularity of adverb comparison parallels the
irregularity of the corresponding adjective comparison.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>isolating language</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a language that does not use inflection to indicate the association of language
parts, using instead *distribution/*word order, pitch pattern, <i>etc.</i>, for
that purpose. Contrasts with *agglutinative language, which uses separable
affixes to indicate relationship, and *inflectional language, which uses
terminations to convey connections, and *incorporative language, which combines
sentence elements into one compounded form. (See Dana &amp; Mantey, <u>A Manual
Grammar of the Greek New Testament</u>, p. 5.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>itacism</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the tendency for
other Greek vowels to move in the direction of short iota, starting in the
fourth or fifth century A. D.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>italic/italics, italic script</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a type style that is more slanted than the normal type (in a set with *underlined
and *bold-faced) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>iterate</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to repeat </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>iterative action</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
action that occurs repeatedly. The type of action originally indicated by -<i>Izo</i>
verbs in Greek.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>itization (sp)</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>jargon</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: every-day
special words and phrases associated with a certain subject or field of
activity. <u>Jargon</u> has more of a down-to-earth ring to it than *technical
terminology. (in a set with *technical terms)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>jeer </span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Jehovah</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an artificial
personal name for the Hebrew God. It is formed from the consonants of His
ineffable name and the vowel points from <u>adonai</u> (my Lord), which in
the standardized Hebrew Old Testament text the Masoretes put on the four
consonants of the tetragrammaton as a reminder not to say the divine personal
name itself.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>jingle</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a saying that is
short, light-hearted, memorable, perhaps musical, and used frequently in
advertising (in a set with *catch phrase)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>jot</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the smallest Hebrew
letter, the <i>yod/yodh</i>, called an <i>iota </i>(Mt <b>5</b>:18), the
closest Greek equivalent letter: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:
14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>journal</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) a scholarly
*periodical published usually each quarter.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) a *diary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) a record of travel</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>jussive</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: equivalent to a
command form but for first and third persons. Latin uses the independent subjunctive
for this idea. Greek has a third person imperative that is equivalent in value
and is translated let just like the Latin jussive.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>jussive noun clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a Latin construction that indirectly reports a command or entreaty. It is
comprised of a leading verb that implies urging to action, a pronoun object and
ut/ne + subjunctive: Imperavit eis ut hoc facerent (He commanded them to do
this). English covers the idea with an infinitive verb and no re-expression of
the subject since it is the same as the leading verb. WH 253 (Cp. *object
clause in Greek.)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>kana</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: Japanese
syllabic writing used alongside kanji for noting inflection, particles,
function word WB </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>kaph</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the eleventh
letter of the Hebrew alphabet: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:
14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
dir=LTR></span><span lang=HE style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span dir=LTR></span> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>with<span
dir=RTL></span><span lang=HE dir=RTL><span dir=RTL></span>  </span><span
dir=LTR></span><span lang=HE><span dir=LTR></span></span>as its terminal form</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>kappa</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the tenth
letter of the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>kenning</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a figuratively,
compound expression used in place of a noun or name. A <i>storm of swords</i>
is a kenning for <i>battle.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>key</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the answers to a test</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>kinesics</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: movements and gestures
that are used to convey meaningto reinforce or elaborate accompanying verbal
communication: raised eyebrows, rolling the eyes, a shrug, a wink, snap of the
fingers. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>kappa</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: tenth letter of
the Greek alphabet</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>kethibh</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: what is
written in the Hebrew text of the Old Testament in contrast to what is to be
read. (in a set with *qere): </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>koph</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the nineteenth
letter of the Hebrew alphabet, also <i>qoph</i>: </span><b><span lang=HE
dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></b><span
dir=LTR></span><span lang=HE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span dir=LTR></span> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>koppa</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: Greek symbol for
ninety</span><span dir=RTL></span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span dir=RTL></span>:</span><span
dir=LTR></span><span lang=HE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span dir=LTR></span> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>labio-dental</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
sound made by the lips and teeth in combination (usually the top teeth and the
bottom lip): <i>f/ph, v. </i>(l<i>ab</i>-, cp. <u>l</u><i>ip</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>labials</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: sounds that are
made with the lips: <i>p, b, f/ph, v, m, </i>along with bilabial fricative,
bilabial trill </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *dentals, *velars, liquids,
and *glottals)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lallation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the substitution of the phoneme <i>/l/</i> for <i>/r/</i>, a speech shift
associated with oriental</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
speaking English</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lambda</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: eleventh letter
of the Greek alphabet: </span><b><span lang=EL style='font-size:14.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></b><b><span
style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span></b><b><span
lang=EL style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lamed/lamedh</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the twelfth letter of the Hebrew alphabet</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: </span><b><span
lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lament</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an expression of
grief; a * lamentation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lamentation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a writing that is sorrowful about current or anticipated circumstances; a
*lament</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>language</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a conventional sound-symbol
system for transferring information from one mind to another. Written language
is subsequent to spoken language inasmuch as it merely indicates by symbols the
speech-sounds that already exist. Sign language uses <u>gestures</u> in place
of <u>sounds</u> to convey thought.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Human language has a number of basic
features. It is <u>hierarchical</u>, meaning that it has systems within
systemsinflection of word forms within clauses, within sentences, within
paragraphs, <i>etc.</i> Language is <u>conventional</u>, i.e., it is arbitrary
as to what sounds have what *referents; it does not need to be inherently the
way it is, and it is not in-born (innate); it is learned rather than inherited.
It is subject to <u>change</u>, or drift; it is virtually impossible to keep a
language from changing its features over time. Language is <u>productive</u> in
that it develops new utterances and features. Language is <u>displaceable</u>
in that it does not need to be in the presence of what it describes. Language
has <u>specialization</u>; it is culture specific. It has all the features that
are necessary for covering what needs to be covered within its culture surrounding.
Finally, language is <u>interchangeable</u>. The same one person can both send
and receive messages.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> As a result of the characteristics, it is
not appropriate to speak of one language as better than another. Every
language, in fact, takes care of everything its culture needs to talk about. Some
languages do have more developed, or replete, verb systems, for example. English
has an especially elaborate verb system that by form can distinguish more
tenses and aspects than most language can. Its vocabulary is also quite
extensive. Lastly, as a matter of practical fact, English has a highly
developed terminology for all the technical and scientific things that have
come into usage in the modern world.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Furthermore, it is not appropriate to blur
the distinction between human language and animal communication systems. With
rare exceptions, its particulars are innate. They may be iconographic, as the
dancing of bees to tell where honey is. They are one-level rather than
hierarchical, and the like.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Language drift/linguistic drift</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Over time, various influences cause a language to change in vocabulary,
inflection, grammar, and sound. English has a rather extreme example in meaning
drift on the word <u>let</u>, all the way from prevent to allow! In the
King James Version (1611) of Rom <b>1</b>:13, Paul says that he wanted to come
to the Romans many times, but he was <u>let</u> hitherto; that is, he was
prevented previously. The word <i>bad</i> has come to mean very good in the
sense that someone is difficult to outdo. Same as *linguistic drift. (in a set
with *meaning)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>last word</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the practice of trying to say the last thing in a discussion or argument to create
the impression that in so doing a person has won the day.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lateral</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:<b> </b>having to
do with a sound made by pass air along one or both sides of the tongue, as in
the lateral <i>s </i>or <i>l</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lateral s</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the sound for a bilateral l put in place of the expected <i>ess</i> sound. The
tip of the tongue is not cupped downward with air moving only through that
restricted path. Instead, it is cut off at the alveovelar ridge and has
voiceless air moving around it, as with the first <i>l</i> in the double <i>l</i>s
(Lluwellyn sp?) of Welch names.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Latinism</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (in a set with
Hebraism, Aramaism, Hellenism, Anglicism) See Dana &amp; Mantey <u>Manual
Grammar</u>, p. 15; A. T. Robertson, <u>Grammar of the Greek NT</u>, 108-11.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>laying on of hands</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) a *gesture for appointment to an office or duty. New Testament examples
include the appointment of the seven to serve tables (Acts <b>6</b>:1-6). The
formal setting aside of Paul and Barnabas by the church in Antioch for the
first missionary journey of Paul (Acts <b>13</b>:1-3). The appointment (and
endowment?) of Timothy for ministry with Paul by the presbytery and Paul (1
Tim <b>4</b>:14; 2 Tim <b>1</b>:6). In the Old Testament there was the
appointment of the Levites before the Lord (Num <b>8</b>:10) and the
appointment of Joshua as Moses successor (Num <b>27</b>:15-23; Deut <b>34</b>:9),
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) a gesture accompanying the
transmission of supernatural gifts (Acts <b>8</b>:17-19).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) a gesture associated with supernatural
healing (<b>????)</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>leading verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
same as independent clause or *main verb of a sentence, but tends to be used
when talking about a subsequent *subordinate clause. (in a set with *independent
verb, *main verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>leaf/leaves</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the sheet of material that make up a book/*codex (in a set with *pages) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lection: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>what
is to be read in contrast to what is on the page. A reading, especially one
that is part of an arranged series or readings used to cover the Bible in an
ecclesiastical year.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lectionary</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a book comprised or religious texts arranged to correspond to events in the
religious year.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lecture</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a formal
presentation by a notable speaker or one offered by a professor in formal education
as part of a college course-for-credit; contrasts with recitation course,
practicum, colloquium, reading course, directed study .</span></p>
