<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lectureship</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a series of college-level presentations outside the regular curriculum and
usually open to the college or university generally.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>legend</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) kind of
person in the past; a type of record of some significant event not able to be
verified; in a class with folklore. Often a label used for someone particularly
outstanding and well known as in the expression He was a legend in his own
time. Differs from *myth in that the latter does not intend to be taken as partaking
in real history.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) a written collection of symbols used
in an accompanying document</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lene</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with
*dagesh lene, *dagesh forte)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lesser Asclepiad</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
type of poetic meter wh 342</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>letter</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an alphabetic
symbol that represents a sound, set of related sounds, or *allomorphs in a
language. The different values of the letter get sorted out by circumstance or are
simply known by the speakers of the language. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>Letter</i> can also be a relatively
short communication usually without an official implication. Less formal than a
*missive or an *epistle. The difference between a letter of the alphabet and a
letter to communicate is signaled in Latin by using the singular on <i>littera </i>for
the former and the plural for the latter.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *character, *grapheme; *consonant,
*vowel; *digraph, double consonant; *diphthong, *spriant letter, vowel glide) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *epistle, *missive) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *enunciation,
*pronunciation)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lexeme</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the basic form of
a word; its dictionary form on which other forms make adjustments. <i>Sing </i>is
the lexeme for<i> sing, sang, sung.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lexical meaning</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the meaning given in a dictionary in contrast to *structural meaning, meaning
based on alterations of the word (*form), *distribution/word order/position,
and *intonation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lexicology</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of the components of a language</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lexicography</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the work of gathering together the words in a language and giving their various
meanings in written form usually in alphabetical order</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lexicon</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an alphabetical
arrangement of the words in a language; a term used more for ancient languages
in contrast to a <i>dictionary</i> of modern languages <i>Lexicon</i> may imply
a greater degree of presentation and examples of usage than what a dictionary
might contain. Lexicons and dictionaries deal with words whereas an
*encyclopedia deals with topics. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *bilingual dictionary, *dictionary,
*encyclopedia)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lexis</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the full set of complete
words contained in a language</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>library</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a collection of
books and other writings</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>libretto</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the words of a
musical work, especially those of an extended work like Handels <i>Messiah</i>
or of a dramatic musical work like an opera. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *lyrics, *lyricist,
*writer, *author; *composer)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lie</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to intentionally say
what is not true; to *prevaricate</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>limerick</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a whimsical
anapest poem with five lines and a rhyme scheme <i>aaba</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>line</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) a piece of
writing that goes all the way across the page; a *stich. (2) a statement that
gives a standardized representation of things, which may not be the speakers
real conviction, but is nevertheless said in order to mislead the hearer; the
party line. (3) a pick-up statement or presentation that is designed to gain
another persons trust or even romantic involvement; a pick-up line. So, <i>line</i>
often implies that there is something wrong motive. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *spin, *party line)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lines: </span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>the lines of text
that comprise a written work, especially those that make up a poem. (in a set
with *stichoi)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lingo</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an informal, lighthearted
term for the way of talking about a subject (cp. *jargon) or a way of talking
within a group of speakers (insider talk).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lingua franca</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the language that serves a wide area where many local languages serve as first
languages. In the modern world, English has become the nearest thing to a universal
language. Greek and Latin held that role for centuries around the Mediterranean
area. Earlier, Aramaic served that purpose for a number of centuries in the ancient
Middle East.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lingual</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a sound whose
production involves the use of the tongue as with <i>t, d, th,dh; j, s, sh,zh;
l, r;</i> <i>c/k, g, gh,</i> (Ba)<i>ch</i>; in contrast to <i>p, b, f/ph, v</i>,
<i>h</i>(onor), <i>h</i>(at); that is, *dentals, *sibilants, *liquids, and
*velars, but not *labials and *glottals.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>linguist</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: one who
specializes in language analysis</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>linguistic atlas</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a map of the areas where the various languages are spoken</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>linguistic drift</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
same as *language drift, the pattern of change that occur unofficially over
time</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>linguisticality</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having the character and characteristics of actual human language in contrast
to disorganized utterance, *ecstatic utterance (as when in a trance), *noise, *glossolalia</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>linguistics</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of language as such in contrast to the study of <u>a</u> language. Formerly
called *philology.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lining out</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a pattern of delivery sometimes used in teaching the words to a song or poem. The
leader says a line and the audience repeats it. (in a set with *antiphonal)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>linking verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb that indicates being rather than action; another term for *copulative
verb, *equative verb, *state-of-being verb, *to-be verb; cp. also *fientive
verbs, non-action verbs use adjectives (or nominative-case nouns/pronouns) after
them instead of adverbs: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> to be </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(good),
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>become</i> (good), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>get</i> (good at what he does), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>seem</i> (good), <i>feel</i> (good, not
well unless <i>feel</i> means act of feeling), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>look</i> (good, unless <i>look</i>
means act of looking ), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>sound</i> (good), <i>taste</i> (good,
unless <i>taste</i> means ability to taste), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>smell</i> (good, unless <i>smell means
ability</i> to smell).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>stands </i>(complete)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Linking verbs are also created by passive
transforms of sentences with direct objects plus objectives complements, where
the former direct object becomes the subject of the equivalent passive
sentence: [<i>Joseph</i>]<i> found Mary pregnant</i> appears in Matthew 1:18
in passive form: Mary was-found pregnant, the construction for <i>pregnant</i>
being in the nominative case. The O. C. can be either a noun, adjective, or
participle; when transformed it becomes nominative becomes the equivalent of
Mary was pregnant. The phenomenon occurs in English, Latin, and Greek.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>liquid future</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a kind of Greek verb that ends its root with lambda or rho. Sigma, the sign for
future tense, does not easily follow those sounds; so an epsilon is interfixed
between the root and the tense sign. Then the intervocalic sigma rule comes
into play; so the sigma drops out and the epsilon contracts with the o/e
variable of the ending according to regular contraction rules. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>liquids</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: sounds that may
be thought of as between vowels and consonants: r and l.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>liquid aorist</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
A kind of Greek verb whose root ends in a lambda or rho. Sigma alpha (-sa), the
sign for first aorist, does not easily follow those soundssigma not at all; so
the sigma drops out and the rest of the conjugation remains the same as regular
first aorists. (in a set with *aorist tense, *first aorist, *second aorist)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>liquid verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek, a verb whose root ends in lambda or rho. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lisp</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a sound that
substitutes the voiceless th for the ess sound: I mi<u>th</u> my big
brother.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>litany</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a liturgical
prayer, that is, a prayer used in public worship in which the leader recites a
series of petitions to God followed by fixed responses by the congregation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>literal</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a rather
imprecise term for things like <u>word picture</u> or <u>strictly taken</u> in
contrast to figurative interpretation (in a set with *figurative) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>literally</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in a straightforward way</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>literary</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: having to do
with literature, with written works in contrast to oral communication.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>literate</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: able to read</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>literati</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: literary
intellectuals literary intelligentsia</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>literatim</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
letter for letter, similar to word for word, but applicable to a kind of
copying that would be done by someone who does not know the meaning of the
things being copied or someone who thinks of his efforts aside from
understanding what he is reading. A way of reproducing by hand a previous work
with such exactness that no editorial or redactional amending or emending is
considered appropriate. (in a set with *verbatim)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>literature</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a body of written material, perhaps from a certain author, a given time frame,
a certain geographical area, or on a given topic. Writing that lies above the
level of a particular writing. It is a kind of thing more than a thing, and
implies a quality of treatment worthy of attention.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>litotes</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a construction
that denies the negative as a way of affirming the position: Tarsus was no
mean city (Acts<b> 21</b>:39). <i>Litotes</i> amounts to the same thing as the
*obverse.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *metaphor, *metonymy,
*simile, *zeugma)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>loan word</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word introduced from another language because perhaps the new language lacks
a term with that precise meaning or connotation: aloha, luau.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>locate</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: identify the
place of a form in a words inflection set, in its *paradigm</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Declension inflection (for nouns and
adjectives)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Conjugation inflection (for verbs)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>locative case</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the form of a word that indicates place where something occurs. In Greek there
is ahead of such nouns a preposition (usually *governing the *dative) that
implies location (in contrast to separation or destination). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin, the ablative case fulfills this
same role with an accompanying preposition. With the names of cities, towns,
and small islands, however, along with the three words <i>domus</i>, <i>rus</i>,
and <i>humus</i>, location is indicated without a preposition. In these latter
situations, the locative case-form replicates the genitive on place-nouns of
the first and second declension; elsewhere it is the same as the ablative.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>locus classicus </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a
prime text for studying an important issue. Platos Gorgias is a source for
asking whether desire goodness more than we seek our own advantage. <u>Imprimis</u>,
newsletter of Hillsdale College, June 2023. A general work dedicated to
surveying such matters is <u>Great Ideas: A Syntopicon</u>, Britannica, 1952.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>locution</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a
person-specific manner of speaking or *phraseology.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>logion</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a supposed
saying of Jesus from outside the canonical gospels but is found in early apocryphal
writings. Pl. logia.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>logo</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a symbol that
stands for a company or business. (in a set with *symbol, *trademark), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>logogram/logograph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a symbol for a word, something written that does not use letters to indicate
its sound (<i>&amp;</i>, <i>numbers </i>for their words in a line of writing)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>logogriph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word puzzle or a code enmeshed in an otherwise innocuous missive. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *anagram)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>logomachy</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an argument that turns out to be a dispute over terms instead of referents.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Lords Prayer, The</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
also called *The Model Prayer (Mt <b>6</b>:9-13) and *Pater Noster, the Latin
name.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>logorrhea</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
verbosity, excessive use of words</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>longueur</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a tedious,
protracted passage in a work of performing ar or literature.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lower case: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>the
smaller size of letters in contrast to capitals (in a set with *capitals,
*upper case; *minuscules, *majuscules) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lucid</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: easily
understood relative to language expression; clear-headed relative to a persons
thinking</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lullaby</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a cradlesong, a
song for babies or young children</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>LXX</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the Roman numerals for
seventy used as a shorthand reference to the Septuagint, the standard Greek
translation of the Hebrew Old Testament in use at the time of Christ. Seventy
translators were credited with the work.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lyric</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a kind of expression
especially in poetry that stresses the subjective, the affective, the psychological,
how a person fells about the matter addressed. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lyricist</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: one who writes
the words for a musical piece </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *lyric, *lyrics, *writer,
*libretto, *author)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lyrics</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the words to a
song (in a set with *lyric, *lyricist, *writer, *libretto)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>macron</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short,
horizontal mark placed above a vowel in phonetic spelling to show that it is
long rather than short or otherwise pronounced.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>magazine</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *periodical)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>maiden name</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a womans last name before she marries and adopts her husbands last name. When
her full name is given later, she is said to be *nee (<u>maiden name</u>). <i>Nee
</i>equals French for born. (in a set with *name, *nee, *cognomen, *first
name, *last name, *middle name, *surname)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>main clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In a *complex sentence or *compound-complex sentence, the main clause is the
one that could stand by itself and be considered a complete thought. It is the
*independent clause, or the *insubordinate clause, on which the other clause(s)
depend(s): If he crosses the bridge, <i>he breaks the treaty</i>. If he does
not cross the bridge, and if he has no weapons, <i>he does not break the treaty</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>main verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the finite verb in the *main clause of a complex or compound-complex sentence. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>majestic plural</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a Hebrew usage of the plural to indicate great degree. The idea has been
associated with the word for <i>God, </i>(<i> </i></span><span lang=HE dir=RTL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span dir=LTR></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span dir=LTR></span>), a plural form (-<i>im</i>)
nevertheless used with a singular verb for the one God of Israel.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>magic square</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
see Lat III T &amp; Qs folder in the back</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>majority text</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the text form of the New Testament that has the greatest number of manuscript
witnesses. They are largely *minuscules from dates later than the *uncials. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *Textus Receptus,
*Byzantine text, *neutral text, , *uncials, *western text) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>majuscule</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a *capital letter; and *upper case letter (in a set with *minuscule)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>malaprop/malapropism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a misused word that sounds similar to the correct one</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mandate</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a requirement
issued by someone with authority to do so (in a set with *edict, *proclamation)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>manner</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the way in
which something is done</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Adverbs are used for this concept: he
worked <i>quickly</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Prepositional phrases are likewise used: he
worked <i>in earnest</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Participles can cover the idea of manner.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A noun in the Latin ablative (with or
without the preposition <i>cum</i>) can mean manner; in Greek a dative-case
noun does the same thing. In the New Testament <i>en</i> often precedes the
dative noun).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>manual</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a small
*handbook that tells how to do something, operate something, or use something (in
a set with *handbook)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>manual grammar</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a grammar that is constructed in a such a way that it may be used as a
reference resource on a given language. In so doing it assembles all the
material on each aspect into one place in its layout, in contrast to a
sequencing of material that serves to introduce the student to the language. (in
a set with *descriptive grammar, *reference grammar, * instructional grammar)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>manuscript sermon</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a sermon read that is read rather than given spontaneously (in a set with
*spontaneous delivery)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Masoretic text:</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> the
standardized text of the Hebrew Old Testament prepared cir. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mass noun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
compare *collective noun</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>manual alphabet</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an alphabet signaled by manipulation of the fingers, as used in deaf
communication (in a set with *alphabet, *dactylology, *sign language, *signing)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>manuscript</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
used especially for ancient writings done by hand; more recently applied to the
original copy of a work submitted to a publisher (in a set with *scroll,
*codex)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>marginal note</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an explanatory note that enlarges on something in the text that could be
unfamiliar to the typical reader (in a set with *endnote, *footnote,
*marginalia, *side bar, *side note)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>marginalia</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
notations made in the margin of a writing to clarify or expand something in
the text (in a set with *endnote, footnote, *marginal note, *sidebar, *sidenote)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>masculine ending</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(in a set with *feminine ending, *neuter ending)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>maxim</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an *apothegm; a
short, witty, instructive *saying</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>means</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: The instrument
that an agent uses to accomplish something. While agency is personal, means is
impersonal. Both concepts, however, can be covered in the New Testament by
Greek constructions like dia + genitive: Acts<b> 5</b>:12. Same as *instrument.
(in a set with *instrumental dative)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>meaning</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: Society (<i>
vs.</i> <u>nature</u> or birth) determines the general meaning of words in a
languages vocabulary. Meaning indicates what by <u>convention</u> a word
refers to; so its meaning is determined by usage. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Within this framework, in a given case, precise
meaning of a word or passage is determined most exactly by the authors intent
rather than by the readers input. Precise meaning is determined by <u>authorial
intent</u> rather than by word picture, by derivation, by general usage, by its
meaning with other topics, or as used in some other circumstance. That meaning
is retrieved (interpretation/hermeneutics) by giving attention to contextual considerationsby
what fits with the topic as treated by this author (law of harmony, nature of
the case). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The basic meaning of a word is its *denotation;
its feel or implication from accompanying factors is its *connotation. The *word
picture is its meaning based on derivation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Meaning development</u>, or
proliferation, involves several factors that arise from usage. In scientific
*nomenclature, (1) deliberate effort has systematically <u>coined</u>
two-term *descriptors for plants and animals. The *terminology comes from Latin
vocabulary and consists of a *noun followed by an adjective. The term plays on
some distinctive feature of the living thing; so it is not an exhaustive
description, but one designed simply for identification purposes. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) A description for one thing gets
applied to other things that have a <u>similar feature</u> of the original
usage but do not have its main feature. Weigh in comes from the boxing and
wrestling scene, where participants are asked to weigh officially to verify
that they belong to the correct weight class before they can engage in the bout.
The situation involves getting started, special persons qualified to take part,
expressing themselves by the weighing-in process, and the actual weighing. The
last, main feature gets dropped when someone is asked to weigh in on the
discussion of some topic. The person is asked to get involved; the person is
someone whose viewpoint is apt to be helpful; but there is no weighing. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Rain check went from being a note that
allowed a fan to attend a later rematch of an outdoor sport that was rained
out. Now, a shopper gets a rain check for a sold-out sale item; the shopper can
return later and buy the item for the sale price even after it is no longer on
sale. Rain has nothing to do with it.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) <u>Specializing</u> takes a general
expression and reducing its application to one possibility or reduces the . It
has become a technical term. A grocery store can sell thousands of items every
day, but today coffee is on sale. The expression has narrowed to an item that
is being sold at a price lower than usual; <u>lower than normal</u> is a new
specific that has been added within the general idea of <u>selling</u>. <b>Find
example</b> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(4)
Words and expressions, especially less-used words, can <u>sharpen their
meaning</u> by people getting in the habit of using them for some recurring
topic. Right for you becomes something of a set phrase for personalized
applicationcorrectness in light of individual persons differences..</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (5) The overuse of a word like <i>awesome</i>
tends to <u>dull its meaning</u> over time so that it does not have the punch
in may have had originally.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (6) Spreading from one application to <u>something
related</u>. The Greek preposition <i>para</i> first of all meant beside. It
drifted from meaning beside (parallel) to near (paralegal), then to near on
the other sidebeyond (paranormal). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (7) Several *prepositions illustrate the
process of going from <u>concrete to abstract</u>. She went <u>into</u> the
living room; she went <u>into</u> politics. <i>Pro </i>can apply to space,
then to time, then to logical sequence.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The reason multiple meanings can exist for
the <u>same word</u> is that each meaning is sorted out by context. That is the
reason the advice to young readers works: read the whole sentence and the
meaning of an unfamiliar word may become clear. A word like <i>run</i>, for
example, can have enough multiple meaning that it takes two columns in a
standard dictionary to outline its usages. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The similar meaning of <u>different words</u>
(synonyms) involves getting the words sorted out by what subjects they apply
to: small, wee, tiny, little, infinitesimal, microscopic, short, <i>etc.</i>,
are not exactly interchangeable. <i>Summation</i> and <i>summary</i> may differ
in that the former is used in courtrooms for a lawyers closing arguments; <i>summary
</i>does not sound right in that circumstance<i>.</i> Some words are more
formal while their equivalents are informal, whimsical, slang, archaic,
regional, provincial, vulgar.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Whereas in English there is seldom any
thought about the meaning of namesexcepts perhaps nicknames, ancient Hebrew as
well as Greek held the meaning of names closer to the surface. Instead of their
being for identification only, they were descriptive as well, at least in their
origination.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *referent, *reader
response theory, *interpretation, *hermeneutics, *semantics, *word picture)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>media</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the typical public
sources of information like television, radio, and newspapers.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>medial form</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the distinctive form of a letter that is used on the front or in the middle of
a word. Hebrew examples in square script are <u>kaph</u>, <u>mem</u>, <u>nun</u>,
<u>pe</u>, <u>tasde</u>. The Greek <u>sigma</u> had a distinctive terminal
form. (in a set with *terminal form)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>meditation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> n.
a short, light piece intended to make the audience thoughtful about some
serious matter.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mem</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the thirteenth letter
of the Hebrew alphabet: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span dir=LTR></span><span
lang=HE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>with <span lang=HE dir=RTL></span></span><span
dir=LTR></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span> as its terminal form</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>meme</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a unit of
cultural information, belief, or idea that is often repeated; it catches on
as people assume its truth because they hear it often. An example may be the
off-expressed idea that ancient Israel was chauvinistic or misogynist because
it was patriarchal. The wise men did not go to the Bethlehem stable despite the
recurrent pictures on Christmas cardsa *conflation of birth-narrative items
for completeness sake (?).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>memo</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: short for
*memorandum</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>memorandum</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a short reminder often distributed within an office, a company, or government
agency</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>merged verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a main verb plus a subsequent *particle that can be in immediate succession or
separated (split): I have to <u>take out</u> the trash; or I have to <u>take</u>
the trash <u>out</u>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *fused verb, *phrasal verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>message</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short
communication however transmitted</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>metaphor</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a figure of
speech that directly calls one thing something else because the two are similar
in some way. Jesus called Peter Satan in Mt <b>16</b>:23. He calls Herod
Antipas that fox in (Lk <b>13</b>:32). Paul calls the high priest a whited
wall in Acts (Acts<b> 23</b>:3). Jesus calls conversion a new birth (Jn<b> 3</b>:3;
cp.<b> 1</b>:13). Paul calls our body the <i>temple</i> of the Holy Spirit ()
and a <i>vessel</i> (). Paul speaks of his thorn in the flesh (2 Cor <b>12</b>:7).
Jesus calls the new life in him a new <i>birth</i> (Jn <b>3</b>:3ff.). Jerusalem
is called a widow (Lam <b>1</b>:1). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *name calling, *epithet;
*figure of speech, *metonymy, *simile, *zeugma)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>metaphrase</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to deliberately change the wording of a text as in paraphrasing, recasting
poetry into prose; even to translate into another wording as from formal to
slang. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>metaphrast</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
one who deliberately alters the wording of a text</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>metathesis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a type of scribal error that switches the order of (letters or) words in the
text being copied. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In a linguistic application, metathesis
also occurs deliberately in the hithpael stem of Hebrew verbs whose roots begin
with a sibilant after the <i>hith</i>- prefix. Occasionally an English name is
actually pronounced with reversals of what the spelling would call for: Fiensy,
pronounced Finesy. Little children sometimes do a reversal in pronouncing words
new to them: aminal, elphanants, merember, basketti, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *haplography,
*homoioteleuton, *dittography) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *assimilation, *elision,
*euphony) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>meter</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the pattern of
accented and unaccented syllables and the number of such standard patterns in
poetry. (in a set with *rhyme scheme; iambic pentameter, <i>etc.</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>metonym</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a word used in a
*metonymy</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>metonymy</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a figure of
speech in which a part of the whole is put for the hole (*metonymy of the
whole) or vice versa (*metonymy of the part); the part becomes a symbol of the
whole</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>metonymy of the part</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>metonymy of the whole</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>metrical foot</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>metrify</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to put into
poetic *meter</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mezuzah/mezuza</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a small Hebrew copy of Deut <b>6</b>:4-9 and <b>11</b>:13-21. The first of
these texts by itself is also called the <i>shema, </i>the Hebrew word for<i> </i>its
first word: hear.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *shema)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>-mi verbs</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Greek verbs that have mi as their dictionary form rather than oo. They differ
from each other only in forms that come from the first principal part. During
the koine period several of the former <i>mi</i> verbs were regularizing into
oo verbs. (in a set with *oo verbs, *contract verbs)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>middle voice</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a voice form in Greek where the subject of the verb acts on itself (direct
reflexive) or the subject acts through the verb on an object in such at way
that the effect redounds to itself (indirect reflexive). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *active voce, *passive
voice)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>middle-voice verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an action verb in the middle voice (in a set with *active verb, *passive verb;
*fientive verb; *stative verb; *copulative verb, *linking verb, *state-of-being
verb, *to be verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Midrash</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: Hebrew
commentary material written from A. D. 400-1200 on the Old Testament text
containing take-offs on characters and events.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>minimal pairs</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> two
words that are just alike except for some feature. Collecting such cases help
linguists figure out how a language makes plurals, changes person and number,
alters tense, and the like.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>minus sign</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a mathematical symbol for subtraction (-)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>minuscules</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
cp. *lower case: small Greek letters or the kinds of manuscripts written in
such letters. (in a set with *uncials)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>minutes</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the written
record of meeting</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>misconstruction</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a grammatical construction that does not follow the rules of usage between
words or within phrases, clauses, and sentences.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mislabel</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to call something
by the wrong word or name, especially to do so deliberately</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>misnomer</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a wrong or
unsuitable word or name for something (or someone); noun equivalent of *<i>mislabel</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>misplaced modifier</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a modifier whose location in the sentence connects with the wrong word: (in a
set with *modify, *squinting modifier)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>misplaced only</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Ideally the word only should immediately precede the verb or adjective it
modifies, but English idiom has developed a habit of separating it from the
adjective it modifies: The football team has <u>only</u> allowed <u>two</u>
sacks and committed six turnovers all season. The same pattern can happen with
just: They just committed eight turnovers all season.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mispronounce</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to pronounce a word incorrectlyin an uninformed manner: abltive rather than
blative, dtive rather than dtive, <i>etc</i>.; Lets get <i>goin</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>misread</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to mispronounce
a word in reading out loud, as when saying <i>read</i> (<i>rd</i>, present
tense) for read (<i>rd</i>, past tense), the verb <i>lead</i> (<i>ld</i>)for
the noun <i>lead</i> (<i>ld</i>), <i>brought</i> for <i>bought</i>, <i>etc.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>missal</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a book
containing all the prayers and responses of the mass for the whole liturgical
year in the roman Catholic Church; a prayer book</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>misspoke</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: originally
meaning spoke out of turn, did not say it the way I meant it, did not say
it the way I should have, gave erroneous information. By extension the term
has come to be a *euphemism for lied.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mixed condition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a conditional sentence, particularly in the New Testament, that does not fully
conform to a regular *conditional sentence format. In Greek, it can happen
especially in present particular conditions by putting any verb form in the *apodosis,
and by putting any future form in the *apodosis of a *vivid future condition: Acts<b>
5</b>:29).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mixed metaphor</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an expression that contains two metaphors to the same thing: mixed row road to
hoe. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mode</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an older
designation for mood of verbs</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Model Prayer, The</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
also called *The Lords Prayer (Mt <b>6</b>:9-13) and *Pater Noster, its Latin
name from the opening two words Our father.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>modal</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: pertaining to
mode, or mood, as a feature of verbs</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>model verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb that serves to illustrate a certain pattern of complete conjugation: <i>luoo</i>
in Greek, <i>qatal</i> in Hebrew; <i>laudo/moneo/ago/audio/capio</i> in Latin.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>modify</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to make the
meaning of another word more specific by adding the meaning of another word to
it; to add meaning to the bare term by connecting another word to it. *Adjectives
modify *nouns; *adverbs modify *verbs, adjectives, other adverbs, and *prepositions:
<i>big</i> man, ran <i>quickly</i>, a <i>very</i> happy mother, <i>way</i>
beyond the fence. *Prepositional phrases can be adjective or adverbial
modifiers: The horse pulled the sleigh <i>over the river</i> and <i>through
the woods</i> [adverbial, modifying <i>pulled</i>]; The little brown church <i>in
the vale.</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Clauses can also be adjectival and
adverbial. Relative clauses are (usually) adjectivalclauses with <i>who</i>, <i>which</i>,
or <i>that</i>: The young man who mowed our lawn . . . . Adverbial clauses
are dependent clauses that connect with the main verb: When I saw the signal,
I ran as fast as I could [the introductory clause connects to <i>ran</i>].</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>Modifiers in a series</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Two modifiers for one phrase
head. </span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>If a modifier precedes two phrase heads, it is most
natural to connect it with both: The tall man and woman live up the street. The
likelihood is that a reader/listener will suppose that both people are tall. If
that is not the case, the writer needs to place second the noun it does modify
and put the modifier immediately before it: The woman and tall man up the
street. Another option is to say, The tall man and the woman up the street. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
