"Times New Roman",serif'> This same pattern applies to <i>the</i>
ahead of more than one noun in a series. If two nouns are being thought of
separately, <i>the</i> appears twice: The man and the woman. If they are
being thought of as a set, <i>the</i> appears onceahead of first noun only: The
man and the woman.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Since Latin has no indefinite or definite
articles; the placement of adjectives is even trickier. Adjectives usually
follow nouns. If there are two nouns ahead of the modifier, the question
becomes the same as above in the English examples: does it modify both nouns or
just the last one? Even if the adjective follows the first noun, it may still
be meant to connect with the second one as well.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Modifiers of words used as words are
singular in Latin, Greek, and English: <i>This <u>foolish ones</u></i> is
translated <i>fools</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *agreement, *misplaced
modifier, *punctuation, *serial comma, * serial modifiers, *squinting modifier,
*double meaning)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>modulation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the inflection of the voice as to pitch, timber, volume while speaking; in
contrast to speaking in a monotone (in a set with *monotone)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>moniker</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: *nickname</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>monoglot</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a person that
knows only one language</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>monogram</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a persons initials,
or first letters of first, middle, and last name; especially so-called when the
letters are put on a public document, pennant, and the like. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *abbreviation, *initials)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Monograph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a scholarly writing of book length on a specific, limited subject</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>monolingual</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
able to speak one language only. (*bilingual, *trilingual)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>monolog(ue)</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a presentation by one speaker <i>vs.</i> a discussion between two or more
people; part of a play where one actor gives a more lengthy segment. A segment
spoken by one person between musical segments of a cantata. Normally associated
with telling about persons and events rather than about scholarly, conceptual
matters </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *dialogue) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>monophthong</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) one vowel sound represented by two vowel letters as <i>ea</i> in <i>beat</i>.
(2) a vowel sound that does not glide from one vowel to another, as in <i>met.</i>
A characteristic of Italian vowels, which makes it particularly suitable for
operatic singing.???????</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *diphthong; *vowel glide)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>monosyllabic/monosyllable</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having one syllable: Greek: <i>pous</i> (foot), ek (out of); Latin: <i>ars</i>
(art), ab (away from); Hebrew: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>monotone</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: speaking at the
same pitch, speed, timber, and volume </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *modulation) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mood</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: also mode, in
earlier usage; the manner in which an action is meant</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Indicative mood simply indicates action.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Imperative mood commands action, including
request, advice, and entreaty [English, Greek, Latin, Hebrew]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Subjunctive mood suggests action [Greek,
Latin, English rarely]. Subjunctive is used in *contingency clauses, where the
actions is dependent on some other action.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Optative mood supposes/wishes action
[Greek]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Infinitive: [older English]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *contingent action (*subjunctive mood),
oras in Greekuncertain action (*optative mood). The optative mood is missing
in English and Latin and reduced in New Testament Greek. So its values get
absorbed into the subjunctive in Latin or covered by *circumlocution. Likewise,
the subjunctive has virtually disappeared from English, many of its usages
being absorbed into the indicative.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The various moods are indicated in
inflectional languages by signs. Greek signals subjunctive mood by <u>lengthened</u>
connecting vowelslengthened o/e variable. The optative sign is an <i>i</i>-diphthong
in the connecting vowel position. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin signals the subjunctive by <u>switching</u>
connecting vowels of the four classes of verbs. Instead of <i>-, - -, --,</i>
and <i>-</i> in the first, second, third, and fourth conjugations
respectively, there is <i>e-, -ea, -a-,</i> and <i>ia</i>- (w<u>e</u> f<u>ea</u>r
<u>a</u> l<i>ia</i>r/l<u>e</u>ts <u>ea</u>t c<u>a</u>v<u>ia</u>r).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *person, *number, *tense, *voice,
and *aspect as possible features of verb forms)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mood sign</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek the sign for the subjunctive mood is the lengthened connecting
vowelthe o/e variable lengthened to omega/eta. The Greek sign for optative
mood is an iota diphthong in the connecting vowel position, either oi, -ai, or
-ei.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin the sign for the present-tense subjunctive
mood is switched connecting vowels. In the layout according to customary mood
numbering, are, -</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>re, ere, -ire verbs have their vowels
switched according to the jingle W<u>e</u> f<u>ea</u>r <u>a</u> liar or L<u>e</u>ts
<u>ea</u>t c<u>a</u>v<u>ia</u>r. The basic idea is to use an a vowel in the
connecting-vowel position in place of the vowel that the last three
conjugations have there. Since the first conjugation has an a vowel in that
position already, it uses an e vowel.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>morality play</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>morph</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an allomorph</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>morpheme</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the smallest
unit of meaning at the word or sub-word level. Morphemes are used to create one
part of speech from another in a set of *cognate words; to indicate singular
and plural, person, tense, aspect, voice gender in verbs; case, number, gender
in nouns. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *tagmeme, *phoneme) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *suffix, *prefix,* infix,
*affix, *word roots, and the like) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mophemics</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the specialty that deal with *morphemes, entailing identification, description,
and classification of meaning units per language</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mot</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a witticism, a witty or
insightful remark</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>morphology</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of the indivisible units of meaning that indicate inflection,
derivation, and word formation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>morphophonemics</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of the pronunciation changes caused by neighboring sounds during
inflection, derivation, or grammatical relations</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mother tongue</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
ones *native language, or first language; the language wherein we were born
(Acts <b>2</b>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>motto</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a saying that
highlights a concept that group members consider their guide for operation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>movable</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a letter, usually
a consonant on the end of a word, that is added to separate vowels: the <i>a/an</i>
variant for the English indefinite article, the <i>a/an </i>variant on the
Greek negating prefix as in <i><u>an</u>ion, <u>a</u>theist</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The <i>n</i>-movable in Greek appeared
after all <i>si</i> endings if the next word started with a vowel or if there
was punctuation. It appeared after third singular endings in plain<i> e</i>
(rather than <i>ei</i>). It was used also after <i>esti</i>(<i>n</i>), <i>etc.</i>
The New Testament affords innumerable examples of using the <i>nu</i> movable
before consonants as well. So the rule is breaking down from the pattern in
classical Greek. Other examples of movables in Greek are <i>houtoos</i> (<i>
vs.</i> <i>houtoo</i>) before vowels, <i>ouk</i> (<i> vs.</i> <i>ou</i>) before
non-fricative consonants (<i>ouch</i> appeared before fricatives) and </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
before vowels, <i>achris</i> (<i> vs.</i> <i>achri</i>) before vowels. GET EXAMPLES<b> </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>In
Latin<b> , </b>the same thing happens<b> </b>when <i>e</i> before
vowels becomes <i>ex</i>, <i>a</i> becomes <i>ab</i>, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mu</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: twelfth letter of the
Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>muddy the waters</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
confuse the issue by bringing in irrelevant considerations, examples that are
not parallel, and the like.<b> </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>multilingual</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
using more than one language, using many languages </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *monolingual, *bilingual, *trilingual)
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>musical</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a play or movie
that has dialogue interspersed with musical passages.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mute: </span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>synonym for a
*stop; the letters <i>p, b; t, d; c/k, g</i>(<i>uh</i>). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>myth</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a fictitious or largely
unhistorical narrative that pictures an ideology or attempts to explain some
natural phenomenon that is improperly understood or difficult to describe
clearly. It historicizes or gives eventness to recurrent principles at work in
mans interaction with his environment </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>name</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: The noun that
someone or something is called to distinguish it from others. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *alias, *appellation, *attributive
name, *cognomen, *first name, *given name, *last name, *maiden name, *middle
name, *nee, *nickname, *nomen, *proper name, *surname)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>name calling</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Calling someone something derogatory as when Jesus called Peter <i>Satan</i> in
Mt <b>16</b>:23. He calls Herod that old fox in Lk <b>13</b>:32. Paul calls
the high priest a whited wall, and then apologizes (Acts <b>23</b>:3). (in a
set with *epithet)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>name dropping</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
using the name of a well-known or important in such a way as to imply personal
relationship and therefore the importance of the speaker.<b> </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>namesake</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the person
someone is named after or the person named after the other person; someone who
has the same name.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>narrative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nasal</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a sound made by
moving air through the nose instead of the mouth. Different kinds of nasal
sounds are created by closing off the air at different pronunciation points in
this process. A labio-nasal (<i>m</i>) cuts off air at the lips; a dental-nasal
(<i>n</i>) cuts it off behind the teeth; a velar nasal (<i>ng</i>) cuts it off
at the back of the soft pallet.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nasalize</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to say a sound,
particularly a vowel, in a way that runs the air through the nasal cavity
instead of the oral cavity.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>native language</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
same as *mother tongue, ones *first language</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>near future</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a form of the verb that indicates something fairly soon to happen. Same at
*immediate future.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>near demonstrative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a demonstrative that points out something/someone thought of as near the
speaker: this/these. Classical Greek had two near demonstratives, which
distinguished aforesaid (houtos) from to be said (hode). The distinction is
not maintained in the New Testament. (in a set with *distant demonstrative)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>near past</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb construction that indicates that the action took place recently. Contrasts
with *distant past. Same as *immediate past.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>necessity</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In classical Greek, necessity could be expressed by an impersonal verbal (C
&amp; S 178). In Latin it could be expressed by gerundive (future passive ptc);
Plus novisti quid faciendum sit (You have learned more what must be done wh
224#4AS).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>negation</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: indicating that
something is <u>not</u> so. Greek A-class conditional clauses may be used alone
as a kind of *aposiopesis to indicate negation: Mk <b>8</b>:2; Heb<b> 3</b>:11;
<b>4</b>:3, 5; cp. <b>3</b>:18.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>negatives: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>words
or word-elements that deny an assumed reality; in western languages there is a
strong association of initial <i>n</i> with negation: German <i>nein</i>,
Russian <i>nyet;</i> English</span><span style='color:#9B00D3'> </span><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>no,
not, un- </span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>(untrue), <i>in-/im-/il/ir- </i>(invalid/impersonal/illogical/irreverent),
<i>non-</i> (nondenominational), <i>never</i> (<i> vs.</i> <i>ever</i>), <i>none</i>
(<i> vs.</i> <i>one</i>), <i>nobody</i> (<i> vs.</i> <i>somebody</i>), <i>nor</i>
(<i> vs.</i> <i>or</i>), <i>neither</i> (<i> vs.</i> <i>either</i>), <i>nothing</i>
(<i> vs.</i> <i>thing</i>), <i>no one </i>(<i> vs.</i> <i>someone</i>), <i>nil,
null, no-no, nah</i>, and the word <i>negate</i>, <i>etc.</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Some nuances between these words can be
subtle. <i>Non</i>- can mean having no reference to (non-denominational, having
no reference to denominationalism); <i>un</i>- means not (undenominational, not
denominated).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin prominently uses the<u> </u><i>n</i>
sound, especially an initial <i>n</i> sound, for negation: <i>nolo</i> (<i>ne</i>
+ <i>volo</i>), <i>non, nonne, numquam</i> (<i> vs.</i> <i>umquam</i>), <i>neuter</i>
(<i> vs.</i> <i>uter</i>), <i>nullus</i> (<i> vs.</i> <i>ullus</i>), <i>nescio</i>
(not to know <i>vs.</i> <i>scio</i>), <i>nemo</i> (no one), <i>nisi</i> (if
not <i>vs. </i><i>si</i>, if), <i>neque/nec</i> . . . <i>neque/nec</i>
(neither . . . nor), <i>nonnumquam</i> (never), <i>nego</i> (to deny), <i>nihil</i>
(nothing), <i>nihilum</i> (nothing), <i>nimis/nimium</i> (excessively,
exceedingly), <i>nisi</i> (if not) <i>vs.</i> <i>si</i> (if); <i>nondum</i>
(not yet <i>vs.</i> <i>dum</i> while), <i>necesse</i> (unnecessary), <i>num</i>
(introduces indirect questions that anticipate a negative response), <i>ne</i>
(negative with subjunctives in dependent clauses), <i>neve</i> (nor, used for
continuing <i>ut</i> or <i>ne</i> + subjunctive). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin tends to negate the direct object in
places where English negates the verb: <i>Nullam pacem habere poteramus</i> (We
were able to have no peace); <i>quoniam tyrannus copias ducit, nullam pacem
habebimus</i> (Since the tyrant is leading the troops, we will have no peace.
Note a similar thing in Greek when Paul writes to the Galatians: Christ will
profit you nothing instead of Christ wont profit you any (<b>5</b>:2).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek has two negatives and their
cognates: <i>ou</i> and <i>mee</i>: <i>ouchi; ouketi/meeketi</i>; o; <i>oude/meede,
oudeis/meedeis, oudepote</i>/<i>meedepote</i>, <i>oupww/meepoo</i>, <i>oute/meete;
ou mee equals emphatic negative</i> (certainly not). As a general pattern in
New Testament Greek, <i>ou</i> and its cognates go with the indicative mood; <i></i>and
its cognates go with other verb forms.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew has two negatives: </span><span
lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
dir=LTR></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span>, </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span dir=LTR></span><i><span
lang=HE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span> </span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>neoplastic ????</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>neologism/neologize/neology</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a new word, expression, or new meaning for an old one. To create a new word;
same as *coin a term. Several words were coined for <i>Lord of the Rings</i>: <i>halfling,
hobbit, ork,,</i> (in a set with *nonce, *coin a word)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>neuter</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: In English,
gender corresponds almost completely with sex reference; so neuter refers to
sexless things <i>vs.</i> person or animals. In Greek and Latin, neuter is used
for some sexless things, but masculine and feminine are also used for them; it
is therefore a grammatical category. Greek may be said sometimes to use neuter
for *common, as in the case of *<i>brephos</i> (baby), <i>paidion</i> (little
child), <i>teknon</i> and <i>teknion</i> (child and little child). This
practice could also be viewed as applying to those of such age that gender is
irrelevant.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In older English idiom, feminine gender (she)
was occasionally applied to ships, countries, cities; but the practice has
almost completely fallen out of usage.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *feminine, *masculine;
*gender)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>neutral text</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(in a set with *majority text, *western text, *Byzantine text)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>newsletter</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a regular communique from an organization that is sent out ot its supports or
those interested in its work. It tell news about events instead of dealing
with ideas as such. A kind of *ephemeral paper.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>newsmonger</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a person fixed on telling other people what is happening as a way of feeling
important; a gossip.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>newspaper</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
designed primarily to help the readership keep up on events </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *magazine, a *daily, a
*weekly; *periodical)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>newspeak</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>; a deliberately
unclear way of speak as a way to manipulate and mislead speak. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *double talk)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nickname</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a familiar,
unofficial name given by others in popular use as a replacement of the persons
real, or given, name; a *moniker. It may be a term based on some noticeable
trait or it may be a short like the letters of a first and middle namelike
J.T.  Ex. Joseph, called Barnabas by the apostles (Acts<b> 4</b>:36). WH333#11</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>night letter</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a telegram sent at night for a lower cost to be received by the next morning.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Neviim</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: Hebrew word for
prophets and a designation for one of the three basic divisions of Old
Testament literature. (in a set with *Chetubim and *Torah)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nod</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to make a gesture
meaning yes by moving the head up and down </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *gesture)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>noise</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: sounds that do
not have linguisticality</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nom de guerre</span></b><span lang=FR
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a fictitious name, a pseudonym</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nom de plume</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
French for *pen name, the *alias that a writer writes under to hide his
identity for some reason or to help set some air of humor or seriousness that
would not be created by the use of his real name. Fearing that her words would
not be taken as seriously as they should, a woman in previous times might use a
pen name or mere initials to sign her work. A writer may fear that his message
would be dismissed as insignificant because of who he is known or thought to
be. (in a set with *aka, *alias, *pen name, *pseudonym) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nomen</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the middle name
in the Latin three-name system (in a set with *praenomen, *cognomen)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nomenclator</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a person involved in developing the terminology for a discipline</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nomenclature</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a set of special, often systematic terminology associated with a particular discipline
or area of interest.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nominal</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) having to do
with proper names; (2) having to do with nouns (in a set with *verbal,
*prepositional, adverbial, *adjectival) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nominative absolute: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>English
has a <u>nominative absolute</u> that corresponds to the Greek genitive
absolute and the Latin ablative absolute: <u>that being said</u>, I still do
not think he will succeed. As with all absolute construction, the subject of
the dependent element cannot appear in the main clause or at least as subject
of the main clause.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> As an expression, *nominative absolute can
be used to cover for certain Greek *hanging constructions (*pendens) that do
not replace the pendens with a subsequent pronoun. (Lk <b>21</b>:6 D &amp; M
70)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nominative case</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
same as <u>subjective case </u>in English grammatical terminology. Nominative
case serves (1) as the subject of a finite verb: I love chocolate. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) for *predicate nominative in a
linking-verb sentence: She is my <i>mother</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) on a *word used as a word (*nominative
of appellation; Jn <b>13</b>:13): He wrote <i>I</i> on the chalkboard.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (4) as the noun, adjective, or participle after
a passive-verb transform of an active-voice sentence that had a direct object
plus *objective complement: They elected him president transformed to He was
elected <u>president</u> by them. This last instance is really an extension of
the predicate noun idea since it amounts to saying, He became president (Note
Lk<b> 2</b>:21; <b>19</b>:2) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (5) New Testament Greek shows some
examples of *independent nominative, or *parenthetic nominative, a hanging
noun in the nominative that is not the subject of any verb (Lk<b> 21</b>:6; Mk <b>8</b>:2;
Eph <b>4</b>:15, <i>etc.</i> D&amp;M70). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Finally, (6) the *nominative of exclamation
is a noun with no verb and carries an exclamatory intent (Rom <b>7</b>:24; Mk <b>3</b>:4;
Rom <b>11</b>:33). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *nominative of appellation,
*parenthetic nominative, *subject)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nominative pendens</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a hanging construction in the nominative case. It consists of a lead-in that
is then replaced with a pronoun to sum it up before the speaker continues with
the thought. Akin to *double subject: The deadthey also are fortunate. (in
a set with *accusative pendens, *double subject, *independent nominative) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nomothetic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having to do with the writing laws</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nonce</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a term created
for a special occasion; a kind of *neologism</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>non-distinctive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a *phonemic difference that does no change the meaning; the kinds of variants
that exist in regionalism of in the systematic mispronunciations that speakers
make in a second language </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>non-fiction</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a genre of writing in story form that recounts actual events. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a se with *fiction)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>non-literate</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
pertaining to a society that does not have a written form of the language</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>non-restrictive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
not limited to one item within a class. In English punctuation, non-restrictive
clauses and participial phrases are set off with commas, but non-restrictive
adjectives and prepositional phrases are not marked in this way. Also called
nonessential to the grammatical structure within which they appear. Non-restrictive
clauses are also called *descriptive clauses.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>examples of non-restrictive phrases and
adjectives</b>: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Do not be <i>unequally </i>yoked together
with unbelievers (2 Cor <b>6</b>:14). The point is not that it is okay to be
equally yoked together with them. Rather, Paul is concerned about believers
being connected with unbelievers, which is an unequal situation that may put
them in compromising situations.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Not being greedy of filthy lucre does
not mean it is okay to be greedy of clean lucre. (Tit<b> 1</b>:7, 11; 1 Tim<b> 3</b>:3,
8; 1 Pet <b>5</b>:2). The non-restrictive element in the English translation is
meant to emphasize rather than contrast the filthiness of greediness.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> You, being evil, know how to give good
gifts to your children (Mt <b>7</b>:11). Jesus does not mean to say that the
ones of you who are evil know how to give good gifts to you children; others
do not. Being evil characterizes everyone in his audience, and so is not
restricted to some.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *restrictive)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>non-verbal</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
communication other than through words; hence, gestures as well as
unintentional, unconscious cues people give that show what they are thinking or
how the feel. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *body language)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>normalize</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to alter peculiar or unusual features of a language in a way that conforms them
to standard patterns of inflection, pronunciation. To standardize; in the case
of English usage of words originating elsewhere, to anglicize. Using <i>amoebas</i>
for the plural of <i>amoeba</i>, <i>hippopotoamuses</i> for <i>hippopotomi</i>.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>normative grammar</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an approach to grammar that calls for following conventions already
established; contrasts with descriptive grammar, which merely tells how people
actually use their language aside from any consideration of what is proper or
improper.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>notary</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a public
official authorized to witness the legality of public records </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>notice</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an announcement;
a formal or even legal warning</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>noun</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a part of speech
that can stand before <i>the</i>; a word that can be made plural by adding s/(z)
or other some other suffix or infix indicating plurality; it can occupy *subject,
*direct object, *indirect object, and *object of the preposition slots. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *construct noun [Heb], *abstract
noun, *appelative noun, *attributive noun, *collective noun, *common noun,
*predicate noun, *proper noun, *noun typical of its class) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>noun clause: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>A
clause that fills a noun slot: subject, direct object, indirect object, object
of a preposition. Examples are the *indirect discourse section of a sentence
(but Latin uses an infinitive phrase), *indirect question, *object clauses of
different sorts. In older English usage seldom occurring now, a relative clause
could fill a noun slot: Whom the gods love dies young. (in a set with
*adjectival clause, *adverbial clause *jussive noun clause [L]): </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>noun typical of its class</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
usage of a noun in the singular in such a way that it stands for all the
members of the group it is in. In English, a definite article was used with
such a noun until more recently. In more modern usage, an indefinite article
customarily appears: the artist should have a thorough understanding of human
anatomy; <i>vs.</i> an artist should have a thorough understanding of human
anatomy. In Greek, the article appears with a noun typical of its class.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>noun slots</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
subject, direct object, indirect object, object of a preposition</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nu</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: thirteenth letter of
the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
<u>Nu</u> was a movable letter after third singulars in plain <u>e</u>, after
all words ending in -<u>si</u>, after <u>esti(n</u>), <u>eisi(v</u>). In the
New Testament the movable <u>nu</u> was always attached, regardless of
circumstances, to third singulars of the imperfect and second aorist
indicatives. The movable was inserted if there was upcoming punctuation or if
the next word began with a vowel.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nuance</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a subtle
adjustment of a words meaning to adapt it to the demands of a new subject. cp.
*connotation)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>number</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (grammatical
number) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Used on nouns, verbs and adjectives in
Greek, Latin and English. Only *demonstrative adjectives (<i>this, that</i>) in
English distinguish singular and plural by form.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Singular</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Plural</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Dual: in classical Greek, especially in
poetry, there were distinctive dual forms ? in the verbs and nouns???</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek, Latin, and English, *word used
as a word are considered singular: <i><u>This</u> foolish ones </i>describe<u>s</u>
the monkeys. The same goes for *hendiadys: The <i>God and Father</i> of our
Lord Jesus Christ <i>is</i> (1 Th <b>1</b>:3).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *gender and *case for *locating
a *noun or *adjective)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *person, *tense, *mood,
*voice, *aspect [*Aktionzart] as possible verb forms)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>numbers</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: Greek, Latin,
and Hebrew have words for numbers, just as English does. In addition, Greek and
Hebrew used letters of the alphabet for numbers. When so used in Greek, the
letters had a horizontal line above them or a short slanted line upward to the
right after the letter. Using the same symbol to the lower left multiplied the
number by one thousand. They could be added together to form numbers between
the tens i(a). note sampi, san, koppa, digamma stigma in the scheme.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Cardinal numbers: There was <u>one</u>
horse in the corral.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Ordinal numbers are adjectives: Blackie
was the <u>first</u> horse to get in the corral.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In sets, English can say two by two or
two at a time. Greek used <u>kata</u> + a number for this idea: for example,
kata duo = two by two: Mk <b>14</b>:19; Jn <b>8</b>:9; 21:15; Acts <b>21</b>:19;
Rom <b>12</b>:5; 1 Cor <b>14</b>:31; Eph <b>5</b>:33; Rev <b>4</b>:8. Greek
could also put numbers side by side for this purpose: For example, duo duo =
two by two: Mk <b>6</b>:7.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *arabic numbers, *approximate
numbers, *round numbers; *ordinal numbers, *cardinal numbers; *Roman numerals)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>nun</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the fourteenth letter
of the Hebrew alphabet: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:14.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span dir=LTR></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span> with </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span dir=LTR></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span> as its terminal form</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>oath</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) a commitment
not to lie in a legal proceeding; (2) coarse, impolite language expressed in
anger (in a set with *archaism, *buzz word, *coarse talk, *colloquialism, *curse/cuss,
*swear; *archaism, *buzz word, *catch phrase, *colloquialism, *form term,
*informal term, &amp;obsolete term, *provincialism, *regionalism, *slang,
*vulgarism)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>obelisk/obelize</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a reference mark shaped like a dagger or cross</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>obelus</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a mark like a
dash or division sign ( or ) used in ancient manuscripts to indicate that a
passage may be spurious (not original), incorrect, or uncertain in some way.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>obfuscate/abfuscation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
intentionally to hide the meaning rather than unveil it; to make difficult to
understand by using highly complex grammatical structures, by unexplained
technical vocabulary, by confused or meaningless expressions and inappropriate
grammatical connections. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *ambiguity)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>obituary</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> a brief article
announcing the death of a person and giving an outline of her life, relatives,
major events, and achievements.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>object</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a word
grammatically governed by another word. A *direct object is governed by the
verb and so is put in the objective, or accusative, *case. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> An *indirect object likewise comes off of
a verb that also governs a direct object; in English indirect objects are
objective case after the preposition <i>to</i> if placed after the direct
object or in the objective case without<i> to</i> if preceding the direct
object. In Latin and Greek, the dative case without a preposition indicates the
indirect object. Hebrew uses the *inseparable preposition </span><span lang=HE
dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
dir=LTR></span><i><span lang=HE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span dir=LTR></span> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prefixed
to a noun or a pronominal suffix to show indirect object. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The *object of a preposition is governed
by the preposition. English always uses objective case after all prepositions. Greek
has prepositions that govern the genitive, the dative, and the accusative cases,
depending on the preposition. Latin prepositions govern the accusative or
ablative case, depending on the preposition.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>object clause: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>one
of several kinds of clauses that serve as replacements for a direct object; so
they have a substantive value: indirect question, indirect statement (in some
Greek indirect-discourse constructions), and non-interrogative how clauses
after verbs of striving, effecting, caring for (He is planning <i>how to
persuade them</i> C &amp; S p. 166).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>objective case</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the English grammatical term for *accusative case, the case used in <br>
English for *direct objects, *indirect objects, and *objects of prepositions. Greek
and Latin use *dative case for indirect objects; Greek and Latin use objective
case after some prepositions, especially those that imply destination.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *subjective case,
*possessive case)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>objective complement: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Some
active-voice verbs can govern (a) two objects (*nouns, *substantives): one of
the person, the other of the thing: they elected him <i>president</i>. That
second noun complements the *direct object <i>him</i>. The relationship of
direct object and objective complement is the same as the relationship between
a subject and a *predicate nominative, the same as the relationship between a
noun and its appositive, and the same as the relationship between the subject
and predicate noun in the passive transform of a sentence that had an objective
complement. They elected him <i>governor</i>; He was<u> </u><i>governor</i>;
He, the <i>king</i>, led forth in battle; <i>He</i> was elected <i>governor</i>.
In each case, the more narrow-reference substantive is the class; the other is
the particularlike a circle within a circle.  Verbs typically involved in
objective-complement constructions are <i>call, choose, consider, deem, elect,
find, name, think</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Objective complement can happen also with (b)
<u>adjectives</u>. Passive transforms of objective-complement adjectives occur
in Acts <b>5</b>:39, And you-be-found (to be) God<b>-</b>opposing<b>-</b>(ones).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>Mt <b>25</b>:38:When did we see you a <u>strange-(one)</u>
and <u>naked</u>? </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> An objective complement can be a (c) <u>participle</u>:
Mt<b> 25</b>:37, 39; Whenever he saw anyone poorly <i>clothed</i><u> </u>, . .
. (WH Latin grammar). They found the prison <i>locked</i>; they found the
guards <i>standing</i> (Acts <b>5</b>:23). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The English examples above have parallels
in Greek and Latin as well. Acts <b>5</b>:31 says, This one God raised up (as)
leader and savior. Acts <b>13</b>:5; 1 Jn <b>4</b>:14; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Sometimes Greek adds <i>hoos</i> ahead of
the objective complement in a fashion similar to the English <i>as</i> in the
translation of Acts <b>5</b>:23 above: They regard him as [<i>hoos</i>] a
prophet (Mt <b>14</b>:5). Another, equivalent format uses <i>eis</i> to
introduce the complement: They regarded him unto [being] a prophet (Mt<b> 21</b>:46).
What of <i>einai</i>?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> An adjective objective complement occurs
in 1Tim <b>6</b>:1:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A participial objective complement occurs
in Mt <b>24</b>:30:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>objective genitive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek and Latin, objective genitive involves a noun tied to an action noun
by the genitive case. The genitive-case noun refers to the <u>object</u> of the
action that is in the other noun: the love of God, meaning love <i>for</i>
God, as in the love that I have <i>for</i> God. Objective genitive contrasts
with *subjective genitive: the love of God, meaning love <i>by</i> God, as
in the love that God has for me. Note the situation in Rom <b>8</b>:35, (37),
39. English can use an of construction for either idea. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *subjective genitive)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>oblique cases</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
as a set, the cases outside the *nominative</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>obloquy</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: abusive language
address at a person in order to disgrace him; calumny</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>obscenity</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a vulgar expression, a curse word, a swear word, an oath; a *four-letter
word; often intended to show disrespect, hurt someones feelings; words often
used in times of stress, fear, and anger. On the eve of the crucifixion,
Peters reaction the second time he was accused of being one of Jesus
followers (Mt <b>27</b>:74). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>obsolete term</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a term no longer used or a meaning no longer used with that word. People may
understand the meaning of an <i>obsolete</i> word, but <i>archaic</i> tends to
refer to a meaning no longer in memory. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *archaism, buzz word, *catch
phrase, *colloquialism, *curse word, *formal term, *informal term, *oath, *provincialism,
*regionalism, *slang, *technical term, *vulgarism)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ode</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a poem of praise, a
rhyming tribute (in a set with* hymn, *paean, *psalm) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>octosyllable</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a line of verse containing eight *syllables</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>off script</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
speaking other than the official position taken by the group the speaker
represents; speaking in a way, instead, that reflects the speakers own
convictions. Contrasts with *on script.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>off-color</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
terms, expressions, or jokes with sexual inuendo. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>off-the-cuff: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>without
forethought, preparation, or careful weighing of pertinent information; cp. *ad
lib, *extemporary;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>omega</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: twenty-fourth
letter of the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
