Long o, paired with omicron, short o. [o + mega, big o]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>omega verbs</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Greek verbs that have oo on the end of their dictionary forms rather than <i>mi</i>.
They differ from each other only in forms that come from the first principal
part. (in a set with *mi verbs, *contract verbs)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>omicron</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: fifteenth letter
of the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
Short o, paired with omega, the long o. [o + micron, small o]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>omniscient viewpoint</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an account told from above, or outside, the events rather than through the eyes
of a character in the episode. (in a set with *anthropocentric viewpoint,
*geocentric viewpoint, *omniscient viewpoint()</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>on script</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
speaking in a way that represents the groups standard claim (standard line)
rather than the position the speaker personally believes. Contrasts with *off
script. (in a set with *spin, *line)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>oneiromancy</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the interpretation of dreams, especially as an aid to prediction</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>onomastics</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of the origin and form of proper names or specialized terms in a
certain field together with the patterns of formation through which such items
pass in the process of word building</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>onomatopoeia</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the formation of words that sound like what they mean. English has<i> buzz,
clunk, hiss</i>, <i>boom</i>, <i>crash, murmur, splash, ululate </i>(lament
loudly),<i> zip</i>. All the words for animal sounds: <i>arf</i>, <i>baa</i>,
<i>caw, cheep</i>, <i>cluck</i>, <i>meow</i>, <i>moo</i>, <i>neigh</i>, <i>oink,
peep, quack, ruff, woof, yap, yip</i>; these are words in that they are
stylized sounds that do not exactly reproduce the sound the animal makes, and
they are subject to *inflection for number, case, tense, person, and the like/</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek has some examples of anonmatopoeia as
well: <i>gogguzoo </i>(grumble),<i> thalassa/thaattal</i> (sounds vaguely like
the waves of the sea), <i>ptuoo</i> (to spit). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><u><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>op. cit</span></u></b><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
abbreviation for opus cited; that is, a work referred to earlier in the text
or previous footnotes.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>opposition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the contrast in a language between two phonemest that create meaning
differences or systematic ways of changing parts of speech: English <i>read/read,
lead/led, </i>Greek uses <i>o/e</i> to distinguish verb and noun roots and
principal parts of verbs: <i><u>gen</u>naoo/<u>gon</u>eus </i>(to beget/a
parent), <i><u>leg</u>oo/<u>log</u>os</i> (to speak/word), <i>leipoo/loipos, menoo/hupo<u>mon</u>ee</i>
(to remain/perseverance [remain under]), <i>speiroo/spora</i> (sow/seed), <i>speudoo/spoudee</i>
(hasten/zeal), <i><u>tem</u>noo/<u>tem</u>os</i> (o cut/incision), <i>trepoo/tropos</i>
(turn/a turn), <i>tremoo/tromos (tremble/a trembling), trephoo/trophee</i>
(nourish/nourishment), <i>pheroo/phortion</i> (to bear/burden); <i>rempoo/pepompha</i>
(1<sup>st</sup>/3<sup>rd</sup> principal parsts of send), <i>peitho/pepoitha/epepoitheiv</i>
(1<sup>st</sup> <i>vs.</i> 3<sup>rd</sup> and 4<sup>th</sup> principal parts,
persuade), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>optative mood</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a mood in Greek verbs used for expressing a wish and other types of more vague
and uncertain action. It often replaced the subjunctive in subordinate clauses
after *leading verbs in past tenses. The mood is tending to fall out by the
time of New Testament Greek, appearing about 120 times. In Latin the function
of the optative is taken over by the subjunctive. English also lacks the mood
as a verb form, but covers its ideas by *circumlocution or the subjunctive
mood.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *indicative, *imperative
mood, *subjunctive mood, *infinitive mood)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *attainable wish,
*unattainable wish)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>oracle</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a person through
whom God gives answers, commands, or predicts; the revelation itself,
especially an enigmatic and therefore mysterious directive or prediction. Its
ambiguity makes it easier to equate with a subsequent event that it purports to
envision. An example like the famous oracle of Apollo at Delphi.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>oracular</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: adjective for
*oracle.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>opus</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a creative
work, whether musical or literary, that is part of an authors or composers
larger output. (in a set with *body of work)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>opuscule</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: diminutive of <i>opos</i>,
a lesser item in an authors or composers *body of work.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>oracle</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the response of
a medium who reiterates a message from a deity </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>oral communication</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
communication by spoken sound in contrast to *written communication, sign
language, semaphore, signals, and gestures. (in a set with *written
composition)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>orate/oration</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the delivery of a piece composed by the speaker in a polished, artistic, formal
manner. (in a set with *declamation, *speech, *reading)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>orator</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: one skilled in
oratory </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>oratory</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) the art of
delivering orations; (2) a place for prayer, a chapel</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ordain/ordination</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to appoint to a religious office or duty, especially in connection with the <u>laying
on of hands</u>. New Testament examples include the appointment of the seven to
serve tables (Acts <b>6</b>:1-6). The formal commissioning of Paul and Barnabas
by the church in Antioch for the first missionary journey of Paul (Acts <b>13</b>:1-3).
The appointment (and endownment?) of Timothy for ministry with Paul by the
prebystry and Paul (1 Tim. <b>4</b>:14; 2 Tim <b>1</b>:6). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In the Old Testament the laying on of
hands was used in the appointment of the Levites before the Lord (Num. 8:10),
the appointment of Joshua as Moses successor (Num <b>27</b>:15-23; Deut <b>34</b>:9).
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Anointing with olive oil</u> was
another gesture of appointment (<b>????)</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ordinal number</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a number that implies rank or sequence: first, second, third, fourth, <i>etc.</i>
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *cardinal number)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>orthoepsy</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
proper pronunciation, the standard, informed way of saying a word, as in ab</span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ltive
rather than ab</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Comic Sans MS"'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ltive; dtive, not dtive. (in a set with
*pronunciation)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>orthography</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of standard spelling; the method of expressing the sounds of a language
in written letters. Orthography is an issue in English spelling more than in
most languages because of the wide variety of foreign and derivational
influences that have been brought to bear on the language. (1)Several ways
exist for notating the same sound, and (2) the same notation can cover more
than one sound. There are many (3) *silent letters to contend with as well. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *spelling, *silent letters)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>outcry</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a loud protest,
a protest made by many people</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ovation</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: loud, prolonged
applause of approval or welcome</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>overpersuade</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to induce someone to act contrary to personal conviction by continued or
intense urging</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>overstatement</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
saying something in a way that is more extreme than the situation really is;
exaggeration. (in a set with *understatement, *exaggeration)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>oxymoron</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an incongruous
or contradictory combination of words, often adjectives plus nouns: (Webster,
deafening silence); a revealing cover-up; upward fall, an expression
someone might use who does not believe in the historic fall of Adam and Eve; it
becomes a picture of learning from ones mistakes. Other examples are the
following: the more you spend, the more you save; He died that I might
live; a male mare; a legitimate excuse.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>oxytone</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: having an acute
accent on the *ultima, the last syllable</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paean/pean</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a song of exuberant joyful praise or exultation, especially in classical Greek
tribute to Apollo.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paeon</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: in quantitative
verse, a foot of one long syllable and three short syllables occurring in any
order (webster) (in a set with *hymn, *ode, *anapest, *trochee) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>page</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the numbered
faces of the leaves of a codex. (in a set with *leaf) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>palatals</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an earlier name
for velars, sounds made off the soft-palate in the back of the mouth</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paired opposites</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a set of words or word parts that make *antonyms and are conventionally
contrasted with each other: ab-/ad-, before/after, big/little, brady-/tachy-, do</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>dos/donts, dys-/eu-, ebb/flow, good/bad, hypo-/hyper-,
iso-/aniso-, large/small, micro-/macro-, -osis/-penia, -phobia/-mania,
poly-/oligo-, pre-/post-, pro/con, proximal/distalto/fro, top/bottom, up/down</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>palatal</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: another term for
*velar, a consonant sound made by placing the tongue against the soft </span><span
style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>palate</span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
<i>k/c, g</i>(uh), (Ba)<i>ch, gh</i> (*voiced fricative), velar *trill voiced
or unvoiced.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paleography</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of ancient writing, particularly the shape of letters used with a
view to determining thereby, if possible, the antiquity of the sample</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>palimpsest</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a re-used manuscript on which a second writing has been written over an earlier,
faded one </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>palindrome</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word, phrase, sentence that reads the same way backwards as forwards: Able
was I ere I saw Elba. Maam, Im Adam. </span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'>    </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(Wash (your) sins, not only your face.) Individual words can be palindromic: <i>ana,
Bob, dud, gag, mom, noon, nun, pop, rotor, sis, toot, wow.</i> [Gr run + again]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pamphlet</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a brief, unbound
treatment designed often for manual distribution; its purpose is to introduce
the issue rather than give exhaustive information. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *book, *reference book,
*monogram, *tract) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pan</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to give severe
criticism in a review as of a movie, book, performance, or some other creative
or artistic effort</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pantomime</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a form of silent communication that uses gestures and bodily movements to
convey the message</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paper</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a formal,
scholarly presentation intended for an audience already basically familiar with
the subject; a lighter assignment perhaps for high school or college course.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paper, ephemeral</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a presentation not meant to have lasting usage</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parable</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: The use of the
word varies in the New Testament. Most familiarly a parable is a story with a
point, particularly in the *synoptic gospels. It is generally true-to-life
rather than fanciful, like a *fable. It is a story form with usually one moral lesson,
and unlike an *allegory does not have a point-by-point correspondence between
the lesson of the story. The word picture in <i>parable</i> (<i>parabolee</i>)
is to throw alongside. Hence, a comparison.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Another word translated parable occurs
in Johns gospel (), but it is a more general term that draws attention to a
comparison for the sake of interest and clarification. Word picture</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In older versions of the Old Testament, <i>parable</i>
translates the Hebrew word () in Balaams parables ( Num <b>23</b>:7-10,
18-24; <b>24</b>:3-9, 15-24)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Jothams parable of the bramble bush
(Jud <b>9</b>:8-15) qualifies as a *fable because of its unreal character.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> FINISH OUT THIS ENTRY</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *allegory, *account,
*fable, *figure of speech) [&lt;Gr. parabole, throw alongside] </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paradigm</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the layout of a
words pattern of inflection<b> </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paradox</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a contradiction
of words but not of realities. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paragraph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a sub-unit of written communication consisting of more than one sentence and
ideally containing a *topic sentence, elaboration, and finalizing comment. (in
a set with verses, chapters, parts,* books, volumes); in a set with *words,
*sentences) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parajournalism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a kind of journalism that mixes in exaggeration and fictional elements (in a
set with *pesher?)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parallel</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a sign
indicating material presented elsewhere in a note or reference</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parallelism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) the primary characteristic of Semitic poetry in which relatively brief statements
are arranged in succession. These successive entries may say the same thing a
second way (*synonymous parallelism), in a contrasting way (*antithetical
parallelism), the same thing in an extended way (*synthetic parallelism).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) The use of parallel syntactical
structures for the purposes of balance and elegance. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paralogism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a form of argument that conforms to the form of proper reason but in fact leads
to an illogical conclusion. An example would be the informal fallacy of the
undistributed middle. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Elephants love
peanuts;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> this animal loves
peanuts;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  therefore, this
animal is an elephant.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paraph</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a flourish over
or under a persons signature</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paraphrase</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to express something in wording that does not correspond word for word with the
original quotation or translation, a re-expression that strives to maintain
content but in a way the present speaker or writer would word it from
scratch. It is like translating a sentence or paragraph at a time rather than
a word at a time.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paraphrasis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
noun for *paraphrase</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pariphrastic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
adjective for *paraphrase.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parapraxis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
small error, slip of the tongue, that supposedly reveals a subconscious motives
Webster)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paraprosdokian</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paratactic/prataxis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
The use of parallel, independent constructions in contrast to subordinating one
idea to another: She stayed <u>and helped</u> with the clean-up <i>vs.</i>
she stayed <u>to help</u> with the clean-up. Of course, the two sentences do
not make the exact same statement, but the habit of choosing the and format
(which says less) does not make the conversation ambiguous; it just requires
the listener to be more active in bringing what he knows from his own
experience and adding it to what the speaker has actually said. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Parataxis also applied to parallel parts
in compound words, to parallel clauses or phrases laid side by side with or without
*co-ordinate conjunctions or connectors between them. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *hypotactic; *asyndeton)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parent language</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the language from which another language has descended, as Spanish and the
other Romance languages have come down from Latin.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parenthesis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
two vertical arcs ( ) used basically for separating its contents from the rest
of the surrounding material. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In writing, the two arcs are placed (a)
before and after an insertion within a line of writing, syntactically
disconnected from that setting, and adding related information not directly in
the flow of thought. Implies as greater disjunction from surrounding material
than a double *dash does.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (b) Separates the area code from the rest
of a phone number.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (c) Groups subunits in a mathematical
expression.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (d) Marks off enumerated entries as in
this list of parenthesis usages.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>?? in the formation of words, the practice of
compounding words by putting previously existing words side by side with little
or no alteration.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parenthetic nominative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another term for *independent nominative, one that does not serve as subject of
the upcoming verb; one not syntactically part of the sentence structure. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parenthetical clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
WH309#96</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parenthetical expression</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
elements in a sentence that are not necessary for expressing the basic meaning
and completing the required structures of a sentence. Examples are items like
appositives that are set off in commas, items that are indicated between
dashes, or information put inside parentheses.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parisyllable/parisyllabic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having the same number of syllables in the nominative and genitive singular. The
phenomenon occurs in Latin third declension nouns like <i>auris/auris,
civis/civis, hostis/hostis, nubes/nubis, </i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parlance</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the terminology,
wording, or way of saying something in a distinct circle of language users or
in a certain frame of reference, as in <i>legal parlance</i> or <i>Christian
parlance</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parody</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a humorous reproduction
of another persons literary work; if not intentional, it is so poorly done as
to seem like a mockery of the original work.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paronomasia</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
*word play, *pun, *Tom Swifty</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paronym</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a word that is
derived from the same root as another word</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paronomous</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
related to another word by being derived from the same root</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paroxytone</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having an acute accent on the *penult, the next-to-last syllable.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parse</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to locate a form
in its *paradigm; to identify the formal features of a term or set of words; to
identify the role of a term in a sentenceto analyze syntax</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parsing guide</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> a
tool for locating words in their paradigms. It may be organized according to an
important text like the Hebrew/Aramaic Old Testament or the Greek New
Testament. Note the parsing guides for OT and NT.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>part</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: In larger works,
a <u>part</u> is a division down from the whole work or from a volume within a
multi-volume set. (in a set with verse, chapter, paragraph, book, volume). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>part of speech</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Part of speech is not determined by
meaning, but by inflection and distribution in a given sentence of a given language.
Consequently, a noun is not particularly the name of a person, place, thing, or
abstraction. It is a word that carries certain formal characteristics
(*inflection) and occupies certain slots (*distribution).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A noun, then, is a word that can have <i>the</i>
put in front of it, and can be made plural in ways characteristic of the
language. A verb has inflectional terminations that indicate mood, tense,
person, voice, and the like. An adjective is a word that can set directly ahead
of a noun, on the other side of a verb that indicates linkage, or after a noun
(objective complement) that itself receives the action of a certain kind of
verb (active).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Part of speech is a more stable feature of
inflected language like Greek and Latin because the alterations pretty well
determine whether a word is a noun or adjective. In Latin there is <i>amicus </i>and<i>
amica, t</i>wo nouns for male and female friend. There is a corresponding
adjective <i>amicus, -a, -um,</i> which can carry ending sets for all three
genders of the root. Greek behaves in the same way.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English, however, does not have much
inflectional change. Consequently, part of speech is a more fluid matter that
has to be determined on a case-by-case basis. The same spelling and sound may
make an adjective, noun, or verb depending on where it is placed in the
sentence. It is distributionsentence placementthat most decisively determines
part of speech. <i>Work</i> can be a verb in the sentence, They all work
together. It is a noun in the sentence, Work can be fun. It is an adjective
in the sentence, He is really a work horse. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In the last illustration, <i>work</i>,
which is more usually a noun or a verb, has been inserted into an adjective
slot, the place directly ahead of the noun <i>horse</i>. As a result, it is an
adjective. Over time the two words <i>work</i> and <i>horse</i> can be hyphenated
and later written solid; so we end up with a compound word like workhorse. Often
it is necessary to consult a dictionary to determine whether standard usage
still considers it two words, a hyphenated word, or one solid word. In spoken
language, <i>work</i> and <i>horse</i> get two equal accents at the same pitch.
With time, the pronunciation shifts to a heavy-light accent pattern accompanied
by a drop in pitch. Ideally the change would be reflected in the written form,
but that is often notor not yetthe case.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In summation, part of speech cannot be
indicated by dictionary entry, but by usage in a specific cases. A dictionary
only indicates a words predominant usage as a part of speech. <i>Position </i>is
historically a noun; but it is a verb if it is put in a verb slot and/or given
verbal *formatives: He positioned himself to receive another promotion. <i>Friend</i>
has historically been used as a verb, but here of late in computerese it has
become a verb on Facebook entries: He asked if he could friend me. <i>Partner</i>
has become a verb: We are partnering with another agency to solve the crime.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *nouns, *pronouns, *adjectives,
*verbs, *adverbs, *conjunctions, *prepositions, *interjections, *determiners, *expletives,
*particles)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>participial phrase, introductory</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
for claritys sake, an introductory participial phrase needs to modify the
subject of the independent clause of the sentence; that arrangement make the
subject of the sentence also the subject of the introductory participle. Otherwise,
it is called a *dangling participle because it may not be immediately clear
who the actor is in that participle: <i>Leaving</i> home at fourteen, my <i>father</i>
had to fend for himself. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>participles:</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek
and Latin participles have tense, voice, number, gender, case, aspect, and
*verbal adjuncts but not person. Hebrew participles have voice and gender as
well as the aspects that derive from the various *stems, which all contain participles.
English active participles end in <i>ing</i> and passives that end with <i>ed</i>
(a plann<i>ed</i> outing). Since English has additional ways of forming the
passive past participle (its third principal part), there are also passive
participles ending in <i>t</i> (<i>meant</i>), -<i>en</i> (<i>broken</i>), and
-<i>n</i> (<i>sown</i>). Other verbs create the past participle with an infix
change (sit &gt; <i>sat</i>) or a combination of alterations (<i>flown</i>). In
a verbs *paradigm, participles are parallel to *moods and infinitives.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Adverbal participles</u> can cover for
time (as, while, when, after, during), means (by, with), manner (as, -ly),
cause (because), condition (if), concession (although), attendant circumstance
(co-ordinate circumstance), purpose, result. In Latin, the *gerundive usually carries
the idea of necessity. In Greek the future participle most often indicates purpose.
Adverbial participles equal *circumstantial participles.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Adjectival participles</u> connect with
nouns in the same way adjectives do: he is a <i>working</i> man. Adjectival
participles equal *attributive participles.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek, the distinction between
adverbial (circumstantial) and adjectival usage generally corresponds respectively
to anarthrous and articular usage of participles. One exception can be an
participle that modifies an anarthrous noun. Sometimes even with anarthrous
nouns, an articular participle occurs and so guarantees it adjectival intent.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  [Latin also has gerundives.]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Participles can be called infinite in that
they do not have person, but they differ from infinitives in having
number-gender-case form in Greek and Latin and thereby attach to nouns. English
participles differ from infinitives in form and usage. As the most basic form
of the verb, an infinitive is not inflected except for tense, voice, and aspect
and has the accompanying <i>to</i> in most usages. Infinitives fill noun,
adjective, and adverb slots. Participles, on the other hand, attach only to
nouns. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English active participles (-<i>ing</i>
forms) have the same form as *gerunds but the latter have only active form and
occupy only noun slots: <i>Working</i> is fun (S); the weather kept us from <i>working</i>
(OP); Dad always emphasized <i>working</i> (DO). Participle and infinitive
usages differ as follows: <i>Working</i> every day in the gym, he got in shape
(ptc); By <i>working</i> every day in the gym, he got in shape (ger). Adding
the preposition <i>by </i>creates the noun slot occupied by <i>working</i>. Both
<i>ing</i> forms do need to connect with the main subject to show who is
acting (clarity), but their syntactical placements differ (grammar).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Abstract verbal ideas in English can be
covered either by gerunds or infinitives, but not by participles: <i>Seeing</i>
is <i>believing</i> or (less usual) <i>To see</i> is <i>to believe</i>. Thus
when rendering noun Greek infinitives, the translator can use a gerund in order
to fit English idiom better. [ ] Similarly, Greek participles are not rendered
with English gerunds: For example, Jn <b>13</b> says, I am the voice [f] of <i>(one)
crying</i> [m] in the wilderness (anarthrous *substantive participle), not I
am the voice <i>of crying</i> in the wilderness (whatever that would mean).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>Are there a couple gerund-usage
participles in NT?</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *finite verb, *infinitive,
and *gerund)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>particle</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short,
uninflected form that is not a normal part of speech. Websters cites <i>to</i>
as an example in English. See A. T. Robertson for list in Greek. In some usages
of the word <i>particle</i>, it can refer to short words like articles, prepositions,
conjunctions, or the additions to an English phrasal verb.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek, a number of light, uninflected, relatively
short words that nuance meaning in ways often untranslatable.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>partitive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Latin, the genitive case was used to indicate that the action in the verb
affected only part of the item: WH305#15#4 <i>Medius</i> in Latin was a
partative adjective despite sharing number, gender, case with the accompanying
noun: <i>in medias res</i>, in the middle of things.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>party line</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the official, public position taken on some issue by a certain group, a
position that members of the party are supposed to present and defend rather
than a different opinion they may have personally. (in a set with *spin, *line)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>passage</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short segment
of a written work</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>passive verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an action verb in the passive voice (in a set with active verb, middle-voice
verb; *fientive verb; *stative verb; *copulative verb, *linking verb,
*state-of-being verb, *to be verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>passive voice</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the form of verb that directs the action onto the subject rather than onto a
direct object. The article <u>was written</u> yesterday by the editor of the
newspaper <i>vs.</i> The editor of the newspaper <u>wrote</u> the article
yesterday. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Passive voice exists because (1) sometimes
the speaker does not know who did the action. At other times, (2) the
speaker/writer may not want to make a point of who the actor is. It may not
matter who did it, or the speaker does not want to make known who did it. (3)
Sometimes the flow of thought ties in better with the new sentence if the
object of the action is mentioned first and therefore made subject. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Teachers of public speaking and writing
recommend using the passive voice as little as possible. Active voice seems to
have more punch; so it creates a crisper expression.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *active voice, *middle
voice; *copulative verb, *linking verb, *state-of-being verb, *to be verb; cp.
*fientive verb.)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>past participle</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the third principal part of an English verb, as in <i>take, took, <u>taken</u></i>.
It is used in creating (1) all passive-voice forms: am being taken, am taken,
was being taken, was taken, will be taken, have been taken, had been taken,
will have been taken; (2) all actives in the perfect system: have taken, had
taken, will have taken; along with the infinities and participles in those
same sets.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>past tense</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
action occurring prior to present time. In English that means the progressive
past (<i>was working</i>, <i>used to work, would work, tried to work, kept
working</i>, <i>began to work</i>), simple past (<i>worked, have worked</i>),
past perfect (<i>had worked, had been working</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Pater Noster</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
The Our Father, the Latin name for *The Lords Prayer (Mt <b>6</b>:9-13a; in
the Latin *version lacking 13b, For thine . . . Amen.); also called The *Model
Prayer.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>patois</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a regional
*dialect that has not been reduced to writing, not the standard form of the
language. (in a set with *creole)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>patronym/patronymic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a term that is derived from the name of ones father or ancestor</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pe</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the seventeenth letter
of the Hebrew alphabet. Also <u>phe</u>: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL
style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pedagogue/pedagogical material</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
teaching material, *didactic material</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pedagogy</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the art of
teaching</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pedant/pedantic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an outmoded or unnecessarily formal way of saying something. An example is the
use of one as an indefinite pronoun. It is almost always avoided in favor of
using someone, a person, or *<i>you</i> advisedly: <i>One</i> does not need to
sound impressive when <i>one</i> is talking to a child. <i>You</i> dont need
to . . . .</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pejorative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having a negative connotation or implication, especially if aimed at a person</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pen name</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the *alias under
which an author presents his or her work, as Mark Twain for Samuel Clemens. It
has been done to avoid prejudice, as in the case of a female author who feared
that her presentation would not be given proper credence under an obviously
female name. In almost the opposite vein, someone well-known and liked might
hide identity so the subject matter would stand on its own merits without
interference from fame and love. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *aka, *alias, *allonym,
*pseudonym)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pendens</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an unattached
word or phrase at the beginning of a sentence that marks the topic of
conversation before proceeding to specifics; a kind of double reference that
brings emphasis to the doubled element. (in a set with *accusative pendens,
*nominative pendens)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pentameter</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a line of verse consisting of five metrical feet; same as English *iambic
pentameter </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *trimeter, *tetrameter, *hexameter)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pentastich</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a poem with five lines</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>penult</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the next-to-last
syllable (in a set with *ultima, *antepenult, *pre-antepenult)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pep talk</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a speech given
especially by a coach to a team to fire them up before the game</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>perfect tense</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb form that indicates the fulfillment of an action prior to a point in
time </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with present perfect tense,
*past perfect tense, *future perfect tense)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>performative act</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an act that says something; an act by which one makes a statement: burning the
flag, burning the books about magic in Ephesus (Acts<b> 19</b>:20). Baptism and
the Lords supper have that value as well. Differs from a *gesture by
participating in the reality instead of signaling something beyond itself.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>period</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a dot on the
line of writing used after a complete sentence, with *abbreviations, in web
site addresses and e-mail addresses (*dot), or as a decimal in numbers (*point).
An abbreviation at the end of a sentence uses one period for both the
abbreviation and the sentence. Greek and Latin periods are the same as those in
English, but their use does not include decimals and abbreviations. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *dot, *point)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>periodical</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a *magazine or *journal that tends toward learned presentations. Libraries use
the term to cover a fairly wide range of items that come out on a regular
basis, all the way from newspapers to scholarly journals. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>periphrasis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another word for *circumlocution </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>periphrastic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
using two or more words for an idea rather than by just one; periphrastic verbs
are construction that use *auxiliaries rather than inflected forms</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>permanent prohibition: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>formed
in Hebrew by <u>al </u>+ shortened imperfect (WG 114). (in a set with
*immediate prohibition, or temporary prohibition)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>permissive imperative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
The idea of permissive imperative seems to misunderstand the let idea for
translating third-person imperatives as allow in Greek, Latin, and Hebrew. Let
doesnt mean that in English idiom either. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>persistent accent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
accent tht stays on the same syllable (as counted from the front) throughout
the inflection of the word. In Greek, accents on nouns and adjectives are
generally persistentexcept for <i>ma</i> nouns of the third declension, where
they are *recessive.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *accent; *recessive accent)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>person</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the one acting
in a verb. *First person is the one speaking (singular) or those standing with
him (plural). *Second person is the one/ones spoken tothe one/ones addressed. *Third
person is the one/ones spoken about. All nouns, therefore, are third-person
references.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The use of third person for second person
appears in scripture as a way of expressing respect, as when Moses approaches
God, asking him to appoint a successor (Num <b>27</b>:15-17).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *number, *tense, *mood, *voice,
*aspect; *gender in Hebrew verbs)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>personal letter</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a letter sent to a person rather than to a business. In the New Testament, Paul
sent such letters originally to Timothy (1 Tim <b>1</b>:1-2; 2 Tim <b>1</b>:1-2),
Titus (Tit <b>1</b>:1-4), and Philemon (1). Similar are 2 John (1) and 3 John
(1). Acts <b>23</b>:26-30 preserves a letter from Claudius Lysias, a
chiliarch/tribune in Jerusalem, to Felix, the governor in Caesarea, explaining
his reason for sending Paul down to him. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *encyclical; *epistle)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>personal pronoun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word used in place of a noun without further implication and occurring only
in places where a noun can occur. <i>Personal</i> pronoun is a technical
expression in that it is not limited to persons, <i>per se</i>; beyond
references to persons (<i>I, she, you</i>,<i> etc</i>.), it includes things: <i>it</i>.
Thus, a personal pronoun is a word that stands for (<i>pro</i>-) a noun
without added qualifications. As such, personal pronouns contrast with </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *differential pronouns (<i>Which</i> is
easier?), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *indefinite pronouns (<i>any </i>can work
here; <i>anyone</i> can do this; <i>anything</i> goes; <i>some</i> can do
this; <i>someone</i> can do this; <i>something</i> just fell; a tall <i>one</i>
is needed here; he would not do <i>a thing</i>; <i>a person </i>can
change; <i>each one</i> teach one; <i>everything</i> is different now; <i>everyone</i>
has to do it). Several of these indefinite pronouns can also serve as
adjectives: <i>any, some; each every. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *indefinite relative pronouns (I thank <i>whoever</i>
did this); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *intensive pronouns (I <i>myself</i> did
it or I did it <i>myself</i>); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *interrogative pronouns (<i>Who</i> did
this?); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *reciprocal pronouns (They like <i>one
another</i>); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *reflexive pronouns (I shot <i>myself</i>
in the foot); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *relative pronouns (The woman who did
this; the tree <i>that</i> blew down), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>personification</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a figure of speech that ascribes personal/human characteristics to impersonal/non-personal
things. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *anthropomorphism,
*anthropopathic) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>persistent accent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
accenting that stays on the same *syllable (as counted from the front) during
inflection as long rules of accent allow. (in a set with *recessive accent) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pesher</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>petition</span></b><span style='font-size:
