12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a request for
official action signed by individuals. A circulated form on which signatures
are gathered to request government officials to take some course of action.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>petroglyph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a symbol or figure carved or otherwise inscribed on stone by prehistoric people</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Phalaecean (meter Wh309) = hendecasyllabic</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phatic</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: having to do
with speech that communicates feelings and mood in order to establish comradery
and sociability rather than to convey ideas.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phe/pe</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the seventeenth
letter of the Hebrew alphabet:</span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:
14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
dir=LTR></span><span lang=HE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span dir=LTR></span></span><span
dir=RTL></span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span dir=RTL></span></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>with
</span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span dir=LTR></span><span
lang=HE style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span> </span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>as its terminal form</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phenomenological language</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
language based for the way something looks rather than for the way the speaker
knows it is: the sun rises in the east. <i>Heartburn</i> is more the way it
feels than something that has to do with the heart (pyrosis). In scripture,
death is called sleep, not only as a *euphemism, but because a person who has
died looks like someone who is asleep: they are not moving; the eyes are shut. For
that reason, it is not wise to allegorize the comparison between death and
sleep and conclude that in the intermediate state a person is not in a
conscious condition.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phi</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: twenty-first letter of
the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>philology</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of language in contrast to the study of <u>a</u> language; a term formerly
used for *linguistics</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phone</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a speech sound
in and of itself without consideration of meaning connection or other
linguistic relationship to phonemes and *allomorphs</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phoneme</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the smallest
unit of sound that by alteration can change meaning: <i>d </i>and <i>t </i>in <i>dot</i>
and <i>tot</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *allophone, *grapheme)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phonetic alphabet</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a standard set of symbols that cover all the sounds of a language or of
language in general.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phonetician</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a specialist in phonetic notation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phonetic spelling</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
spelling words by the way they sound using a uniform value for letters and
other symbols without regard to preserving derivational origins of the words;
the kind of spelling given in dictionaries for the standard pronunciation of words</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phonetics</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the part of linguistics that deals with the way sounds are made, how they are
combined, and how they are represented; the practice of spelling words by a
standardized use of letters, diacritical marks, and symbols.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phonic</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: having to do
with human speech sound</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phonics</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a method of
teaching children how to read by showing them how letters and combinations of
letters represent human speech sounds</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phonology</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of the sounds and combinations of sounds that make up a language</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Consonants</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Vowels (rounded and unrounded)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Liquids</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Dentals</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Gutturals</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Palatals </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> velars </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> labials</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> liquids</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> nasals </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> stops: sounds formed by stopping the
airflow at some pronunciation point; also called mutes (in a set with fricatives,
plosives, trills, nasals) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> fricatives: sounds formed by narrowing the
air flow at various pronunciation points; also called mutes. (in a set with
stops, plosives, trills, nasals)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> plosives (in a set with *stops, *fricatives,
*trills, *nasals)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> ingressive/egressive air flow</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> trills (in a set with stops, fricatives,
plosives, nasals)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> sibilants: s, sh,z, zh sounds</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> clicks</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> aspirates</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phrasal verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb made up of more than one word where the added word is an adverb that <u>follows</u>
the main verb; thus, not to be confused with *progressive verbs, whose added
words <u>precede</u> the main verb: call out, calm down, come in, shut up. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *merged verb, *fused verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phrase</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: set of words
that does not contain a finite verb in contrast to *clause, which does have a
finite verb. A phrase may serve as a *noun, *adjective, or *adverb. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *prepositional phrase, *participial
phrase, *infinitive phrase)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phrase book</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a handbook of foreign expressions and their translations; organized per
language and dealing with sets of words rather than individual terms. Perhaps
an *idiom book. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *dictionary, *lexicon)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phrase head</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the main word to which the other words in a set connect: that great big <u>house</u>;
she very quickly <u>went</u> home; The <u>man</u> that I met on the street
turned out to be a college professor.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phrase prepositions</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Prepositions in English sometimes are thought of as having more than one word: <i>because
of, by means of, due to</i> (though not preferred since dues adjectival force
is lost), <i>for the sake of, in regards to, in the interest of, in accordance
with, instead of, on account of, on behalf of, on the way to, owing to,</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phraseogram</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a *shorthand symbol that * stenographers use to cover a <u>set of words</u> in
contrast to a letter (usually for one <u>sound</u>) or an abbreviation (for one
<u>word</u>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *letter, *abbreviation,
*acronym)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phraseograph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a phrase represented by a *phraseogram</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phraseology</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the turn of expression a person may use that would not have to be exactly that
way</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phrasing</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the way an
expression is worded</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pi</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: sixteenth letter of the
Greek alphabet.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pictograph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a *hieroglyph; a picture that represents a word or idea in contrast to a
letter, which represents a sound or syllable</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pigeon language</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pitch</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a presentation
intended to get someone to accept or buy something. Used as a light, perhaps,
pejorative term for such an instance.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>plagiarize/plagiarism/plagiary</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to present someone elses ideas as ones ownespecially written ideas. The act
or practice of so doing.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>play on words</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) a comment that plays on <u>alternate meanings</u> a word may have. You
need to learn how to handle people; people have been handled too much
already. Im sorry. Youre sorry, all right. (2) a case of taking
advantage of alternate sounds between <u>similar words</u>: the use of the
coined expression around Halloween: spooktacular.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pleonstic/pleonasm</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an expression that is fuller than it need be; a kind of hendiadys in some
cases. It is a Greek phenomenon in the New Testament that was perhaps
encouraged by the repetitive, or pleonastic, tendency of Hebrew idiom: cry out
and say (Mt <b>12</b>:44); cry out saying (Mt <b>8</b>:29); ask and say (Jn <b>1</b>:25);
testified and said (Acts <b>13</b>:21); A. T. Robertson 1136</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pleasantries</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
positive comments made between people, especially when they first meet on a
given occasion. The comments are intended to indicate a positive attitude
between people by avoiding serious, sad, or controversial matters: Its good
to see you; How are you? How have you been doing? Youre looking good
today; <i>etc.</i> A person does not normally answer How are you? with
comments about his recent setbacks even if both people know those setbacks have
occurred. If real information is meant by what could be considered a pleasantry
in other situations, the speakers voice modulation and accompanying kinesics
will make that clear.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (Note *idiom)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>plenary inspiration</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
fully inspired in contrast to a divine inspiration limited to religious
matters but not including scientific, historical, geographical matters. With
infallibility, as it is called, inspiration is pictured relative the purpose
of revelation, which entails Gods word not returning to him void, but
fulfilling the purpose for which it was given (Is <b>55</b>:10-11). If the
purpose of revelation is thought of as limited to religious concerns, then
scripture does not necessarily have to be accurate in other areas in order to
meet the meet the criterion involved. <i>Plenary inspiration</i> has been used in
contrast to that limitation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *dictation theory of
inspiration, *dynamic theory of inspiration, *infallibility, *verbal
inspiration; *inerrancy)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>plene spelling</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a lengthened form of a Hebrew word created by doubling the last consonant and
inserting a *vowel letter between the duplicated letters. (in a set with
*defective spelling)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pluperfect</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another term for past perfect, a verb tense that indicates a completed action
prior to a past point in time: He had worked there for one month.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>plural, grammatical </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(<i>
vs.</i> plural by sense; <b>plural, poetic</b> wh 209</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>plural</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: more than one. Although
English uses the <i>s</i>/z sounds most frequently to indicate plural (<i>hat/hats,
job/jobs</i>), it forms plurals in several other ways particularly because of
its many derivatives from Latin, Greek, and Anglo-Saxon/Germanic background: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -s(z) (<i>work/work<u>s</u></i>), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -s (where <i>s</i> is voiced, <i>gram/gram<u>s</u></i>);
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>us/i</i> (<i>radius/radii</i>), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>um/a</i> (<i>continuum/continua</i>, <i>curriculum/curricula,

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span lang=DE style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>-<i>ma/mata</i> (<i>schema/schemata,
stigma/stigmata</i>), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>-<i>is/</i></span><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>s</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(<i>basis/bas</i></span><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span></i><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>s,</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
where the <i>e</i> is always long in contrast to <i>base/bass</i>), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>#/-en</i> (<i>ox/oxen</i>), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>a/ae</i> (<i>alga/algae, alumna/alumnae</i>),
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>os/oi</i> (<i>stichos/stichoi</i>), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span lang=FR style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>-<i>on/a</i> (<i>protozoon/protozoa,
logion/logia</i>), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>nx/ng</i></span><i><span
lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span></i><i><span
lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>s</span></i><span
lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(<i>phalanx/phalanges</i>),</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ex/ic</i></span><i><span
lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span></i><i><span
lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>s</span></i><span
lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(<i>index/indices</i>), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ix/ic</i></span><i><span
lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span></i><i><span

(<i>appendix/appendices</i>), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>-<i>ax/ac</i></span><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>s</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(<i>thorax/thorac</i></span><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'>s</span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> There are also several words that form
plurals by using *infixes: <i>foot/feet; goose/geese; man/men; mouse/mice;
woman/women; this/these. </i><b>[[see *infixes]]</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Some have no distinct plural form: <i>bison</i>,
<i>craft </i>(boats), <i>deer</i>, <i>elk, fish</i>, <i>heathen, moose, sheep</i>.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> With these belong all English adjectives
used as *substantives, that is, adjectives used in noun slots. They do not add <i>s/z</i>
to the root to form plurals, often have <i>the</i> ahead of them, and have
plural verbs: <i>few, many, most, several, some,</i> <i>the dumb, the educated,
the gifted, the halt, the ignorant, the lame, the maim, the poor, the weak</i>;
i<i>n the singular, in the plural.</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin and Greek also use adjectives as
substantives, but use them in both singular and plural. English translation often
requires adding <i>ones, things, people. </i>Sometimes English happens to have
a noun that can replace such substantives, as when <i>the foolish</i> is
translated <i>fools.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Not all English words ending in <i>s</i>
are plurals: <i>aerobics, apologetics, athletics, </i><b>[insert panel] </b><i>calisthenics</i><b>
</b>(s /pl),<b> </b><i>civics, cybernetics, dynamics, economics, esthetics,
ethics, eugenics, euphemics, eurythmics, euthics, fiberoptics, genetics, geriatrics,
graphics, gymnastics, hermeneutics, histrionics, homiletics, kinesics, linguistics,
logistics, mathematics, (Popular) mechanics, metaphysics, mnemonics, morphemics,
morphophonemics, numismatics, obstetrics, optics, pediatrics, phonics, phonemics,
phonetics, physics, poetics, polemics, politics, pyrotechnics, Reaganomics, robotics,
series, statics, statistics<sup>1</sup>, summons, tagmemics, theatrics, </i>Many<i>ics</i>
terms identify disciplines or areas of study. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> For *agreement purposes, English, Latin,
and Greek use singular verbs and modifiers with a *word used as word: <i>This</i>
<i><u>foolish ones</u></i> describe<i>s</i> the monkeys. Cases of hendiadys
also have singular verbs: The God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ <i>is</i>
(1 Th<b> 1</b>:3).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew masculine nouns (usually) end in <i>im</i>
while feminine plurals usually end in <i>ot/-oth.</i> Consequently, words like
the following that appear in older translations are plural: <i>Anakim</i> [not <i>Anakims</i>,
KJV], <i>Anamim, cherubim, nephilim, seraphim, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *singular, *plural by
sense, *poetic plural, *word used as a word)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pi</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the sixteenth letter
of the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>plural by sense: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>English
committee <u>are</u>, especially in British English </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *collective noun, *mass
noun) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>plural, poetic </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>wh
209</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>plus sign</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a symbol for addition (+)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>poem</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a highly
structure piece traditionally with rhyme scheme and meter</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>poet</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: one who writes
poetry</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>poesy</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the art and
practice of writing poetry</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>poetaster</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
someone who writer poor-quality poetry</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>poetic:</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> having characteristics
of poetry like *rhyme scheme and *meter; expressed in a picturesque way</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>poetics</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a branch of literary
criticism that deals with the characteristics of poetry</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>poetic license</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
departure from normal usage to meet the requirements of poetic formrhyme
scheme and meterand to accommodate exaggeration for emphasis..</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>poetry</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a division of literature;
a form of writing that in English traditionally uses *rhyme scheme, *meter, and
parallel lines. Latin and Greek poetry had meter and parallel lines. Hebrew
poetry had *parallelism only and then a parallelism of ideas more than form. Thus,
parallelism is the most basic feature of poetry, to which are added the other
devices of form.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in contrast to *prose, *free verse)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>point</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the term used
for a *period when it serves the purpose of a decimal point</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pointed text</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a Semitic text with vowel points added to the original consonantal text </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *unpointed text) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>poisoning the well</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In debate, disproving an argument before the opponent has brought it into the
discussion.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>polemic/polemical</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a confrontational, argumentive, defensive, apologetic presentation which may be
so-called even when someone representing the opposing viewpoint is not present
or is not involved in an interchange [&lt;Gr <i>polemos</i>, war)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>polemics</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the art or
practice of argumentative delivery</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>polite address</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
respectful approach as with the use of words like <i>sir </i>or <i>maam</i>
during the conversation, the use of <i>Mr./Mrs./Miss</i> plus last name in
contrast to using a persons first name. Contrasts with *familiar address (<i>Tu</i>
<i>vs.</i> <i>du</i> in GERMAN/French?)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *honorific)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>politically correct</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
speaking in a way that avoids any negative evaluative or prescriptive behavior.
One aspect of this practice pertains to *inclusive language, the avoidance of
masculine terminology in mixed, uncertain, and ambiguous circumstances. The
situation involves finding substitute expressions for negative connotations in
words like retarded, mentally handicapped, and the like. Challenged, for
example, substitutes for teh negative element: mentally challenged, and so
forth. The awkwardness of the phraseology has occasioned some interesting
humor.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> While the desire to avoid hurting peoples
feelings is admirable, attempts to avoid terminologically anything that
indicates failure, weakness, lower than norm, and the like, becomes unreal. It
also seems to attribute meaning only to the use of vocabulary. The larger arena
of discourse can relieve hurtful comments; and the overall attitude of a
speaker is indicated by kinesics, pitch patterns, and other features of
communication. In this attempt to solve the problem terminologically, there is
a tendency to psychologize terms beyond what people normally mean by them. (in
a set with *inclusive language)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>polyglot</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a book with more
than one language or *version (*translation) in parallel columns, an
arrangement used in modern times for several translations of the Bible put side
by side for comparison purposes. (in a set with *version, *diglot,
*Diatessaron) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>polyphone</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a written character that can stand for more than one sound in the language</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>polyphonic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having more than one phonetic value</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>polysemous</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having many meanings. The meanings of a word like <i>on</i> are so numerous that
it takes one whole column of small print in a standard dictionary just to
summarize its uses.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>polysyllable</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word having more than three syllables: cholangiopancreatography,
laparohysterosalpingo-oophorectomy!</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>polysynthetic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
pertaining to a language type with highly complex words created by affixes that
express word relationships and meaning elements that in other languages are
covered by separate words. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pony</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a word-for-word
translation of a text that makes it nearly possible to reconstruct the original
text from the translation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>possession</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) a characteristic attached to a noun; (2) owning something</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Grammatical p<i>ossession </i>and<i>
possessive </i>does not mean ownership particularly. More broadly it means
having some feature of identity connected to it: the <i>tables</i> leg was
bent; the leg <i>of the table</i> was bent. The possessive case in the first
instance and the <i>of</i> phrase in the second instance merely tie <i>leg</i>
to <i>table</i>. How they relate has to be supplied by the listener on the
basis of his own experience rather than the speakers indication. Different
real connections exist in the following examples despite the fact that they use
the same <i>of </i>expression: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> love of a mother (<i>by </i>a mother;
*subjective genitive in Greek and Latin); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> love of a mother (love <i>for</i> a
mother; *objective genitive); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> the city of Cincinnati (equals;
*appositive genitive); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> house of sticks (made of; *genitive of
material); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> word of truth (description; *descriptive
genitive); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> distance of four miles (measure; genitive
of measure);</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English uses the<i>s/s </i>or of expression
to tie one noun to another. Though the two constructions are similar in
meaning, they are not interchangeable ways of attaching a characteristic to a
noun. GET A RULE FOR DISTINCTION</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek and Latin, possession is
expressed by verbs meaning to have, by the genitive case that ties one noun
to another, and by the dative case in linking-verb sentences.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> There is a difference in idiom between
English and Latin, for example, in the use of possessives. English wants to
specify the possessor even if it is clear from context who the possessor is: I
wanted to <u>my</u> old car. Latin is satisfied simply to say, I wanted to
sell the old car. Ex<i>. Ille poeta unus multa carmina de fratre beato
scribebat</i> (That one poet was writing many songs about the happy brother
[no word for <i>his</i>]). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) The verbs <i>have</i>, <i>owns</i>, <i>etc.</i>,
covers the idea of owning something. Finally, there is the use of <i>to</i>
after a linking verb: There <u>was</u> a thrill <u>to </u>the experience.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>possessive adjective</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
adjectives that by their <u>meaning</u> (<i> vs.</i> genitive <u>form</u> as
with nouns) indicate possession, and like all adjectives are tied to the
accompanying noun by sharing number, gender, and case.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>postfix</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: another term for
suffix, an element added to the end of a word to add to or otherwise adjust its
meaning.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>posthumous</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
published after the death of the author</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>postpose</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to place a word
or set of words after other sentence parts in order to maintain better
connection, say, between the verb and an element that would not otherwise fit
in the sentence or would make its connection ambiguous: He threw some hay to
the cow on the other side of the fence, which is slightly better than He
threw the cow over the fence some hay.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>postpositive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a structure in English, Latin, and Greek where certain words do not appear
first in their clause, phrase, or construction. I say, <u>then</u>, that you
have done well. Traditionally, <i>however</i> has been used in this way,
although the practice is becoming less uniform.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek, there is <i>gar, de, men, te,</i>
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin, <i>causa</i> is accompanied by a
preceding genitive: <i>salutis communis caus</i>, for-the-sake-of common-safety.
Other examples are <i>autem</i>, <i>igitur</i>, <i>enim</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *appositive, *prepositive; *postpositive
conjunction, *postpositive particle, *postpositive preposition, *postpositive
verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>postpositive conjunction/adverb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an adverb that does not come first in its clause; it usually appears second. Previously,
the word <i>however</i> was not put first in its clause. <i>Then</i> and <i>therefore</i>
often do not begin their sentences. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>postpositive particle</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a particle that does not appear first in its clause. Greek had <i>an</i> as
part of the formula for the *consequent clause of a *contrary-to-fact *conditional
sentence; <i>men</i> in the first half of a *balanced construction that had the
effect of saying on the one hand. It also appeared in the consequent clause
of a *vague future conditional sentence, and in the *potential optative
construction.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>postpositive preposition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a preposition that appears after its object. In English, this can take the form
of a delayed preposition: You are the one I am thinking <u>of</u>; I just
have my brief case today; so I have a free hand to carry my coffee <u>with</u>.
In these examples there is also an omission of the relative pronoun that would
have been used in the more pedantic layout: the one of <u>whom</u> I am
thinking. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin regularly suffixes <i>cum</i> (with)
to a personal-pronoun object: nobis<u>cum</u>, <i>etc.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Gr ex.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>postpositive verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
The Latin <i>inquit</i> is placed after one or more words of a *direct
quotation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>postscript</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an added note following the signature on a letter that comments on something
perhaps aside from the main text; abbreviated PS, Latin for <u>post scriptum</u>.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *salutation, *complimentary
close, *signature) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>postvocalic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a consonant sound that follows a vowel, a suffix that occurs only after vowels.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pot shot</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a critical
comment made without much thought</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>potential</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a construction for what <i>may </i>or can happen.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>potential optative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in Greek, a vague future conditional sentence without the if-clause: [If he
would/should cross the bridge,] he would break the treaty: [<i>ei</i> +
optative,] <i>an</i> + optative.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>praenomen</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the first name in the Latin three-name system (in a set with *nomen, *cognomen)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>praise</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (c) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>praxis</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the pattern or
practice done in certain circumstances.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>preach</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to deliver a
message in a religious setting, or service. Preaching tends to imply a greater
stress on behavior response and affective dimension than *teach, which stresses
content and understanding. Sometimes educators and preachers do not like to
make the distinction just now offered since there is content in preaching and
motivation in teaching. Maybe for them, the difference is more a matter of
place and circumstance than anything else. Outside a religious context, <u>preach</u>
has become a pejorative term for overly presenting an idea in a critical or
extreme way. (in a set with *teach) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>predicate</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
The second part of a clause from the verbs to the end of the clause. It
includes the verb, direct object, and indirect object together with any modifiers
of these elements. (in a set with subject)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>predicate adjective</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an adjective on the other side of a linking verb and modifying the subject of
the sentence.<b> </b>So, it is not just an adjective in the predicate, but an
adjective in the predicate of that modifies the subject of a linking=-verb
sentence: The tree was <u>tall</u>. The adjective may be a prepositional
phrase: The tree was <u>on the</u> hill. Acts<b> 4</b>:33 </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *adjective, *attributive
adjective, *compound adjective, *proper adjective, *substantive adjective)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>predicate genitive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Latin, a genitive of possession used in the predicate. Latin construction WH322#67
332#69</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>predicate noun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a noun in the predicate of a linking-verb sentence that renames the subject. The
two nouns involved have the same relationship as the two nouns in apposition
and two nouns that are direct object plus objective complement.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>predicate position</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek, an adjective that appears before a nouns article or after the noun;
it does not appear between the article and its noun. In possessive personal
adjectives, English has a distinction akin to this *attributive-predicate
distinction. <i>My, our, your, her, </i>and <i>their </i>stand immediately
ahead of the noun they modify. <i>Mine, ours, yours, hers, theirs</i> are used
only on the other side of linking verbs.<i> </i>There is no predicate-position
form for <i>its.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>My</i> plate is on the table; but
the plate on the table is <i>mine</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *attributive position,
*second attributive position)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>preface</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a section near
the front of a work that may give historical background to the work at hand (in
a set with *acknowledgements, *prologue, *introduction, *body of the work, *epilogue,
*index, *table of contents)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prefix</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an addition on
the front of a word that adjusts the meaning of the root. As to meaning, these
same elements may appear in altered form as suffixes or free-standing words; so
a prefix is defined by position at a word-specific level. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> If certain recurring elements appear only
in first position, it may be practical to call them prefixes. In medical
terminology, it is a matter of taste whether to call audio-, cranio-, <i>etc</i>.,
prefixes or common first roots of compounds. English draws on a plethora of
Latin and Greek preposition, numbers, even roots to create lengthened forms. Consequently,,
all the old Greek and Latin prepositions and prepositional prefixes along with
numerical indicators are considered prefixes in this list of English
derivatives. Initial morphemes like <i>audio</i>- [processes], <i>cephalo</i>-
[body parts], <i>xantho</i>-, <i>erythro</i>- [colors], and the like have been
considered first parts of compound words.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English prefixes: a-/an- (not, often
without reference to rather than opposed to; cp. non-): amoral, asymetrical,
atheism, aniconic, anion, anhydrous, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> ab- (away from): abnormal </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> loco- (in one place), lyo-

metrio- (womb), metro- (measuring), micro- (small), mid- (middle), mel-, midi-/mid-,
milli- (thousanth), mini- (small), mis-, mono- (single), multi-(many), myco-
(fungus), myo-/myoso- (muscle), nano-, narco-, naso-, necro-, nemato-, neo-
(new), nephro-, neuro- (nerve), nicotin-, nitro-, nomy-, non- (not), non[i](enne[a],
nor-, novem-?, nucleo-. nudi-, nulli- (none), ob-, octo-, off-, ole/o-, oligo-
(few), omo- (mass), on-, onto-, oo- (egg, ovum), opto- (vision, eye), ortho-
(straight), osteo-, oto- (ear), out-, over-, ovi-/ovo-/ovulo- (egg, ovum),
oxi-/oxo-/oxy- (oxygen), pale/o-, pan- (all), par-/para- (beside, apartment
from, abnormal), paro- (birth), patho- (disease, suffering), patr/i-, pedo-

(fondness, attraction to), pneo- (breathing), pneumo (lung, air), peumono-
(lung, air), poly- (many), pre- (before), post- (after, behind), postero- (back

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> schizo-</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> self-, semi-(hemi, half), sept-/septi-
(seven), sesqui-, sex- (sex), sexi-sexta(hexa, six), </span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> shisto-</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> sinistro-, sono- (sound), step-,
sub-/suf-/sul?/sum-/sup- (under), sui- (self), syn-/sym-/syl-/su- (with,
together), tachy- (fast), tardo- (slow, late), tele- (distance), tetra- (four),
thermop- (heat), toxo- (poison), trans- (across), tri- (three), ultra-
(beyond), uni- (singular, not combined with), un- (not), xantho- (yellow),
xeno- (foreign), xero- (dry).</span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> super-/supero- (super refers
to something above or beyond what is in another category),</span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> supra- (may be distinguished
from super in the same manner as intra is distinguished from inter; supra
refers to something above that is parallel within a common larger category;
super refers to something above that is in another category. In medical
terminology, for instance, supra refers to something above that is within the
body) , sur-, syn-/syl-/sym/syp-/sys-, tachy-, tetra-, trans-, tri-, trito-, ultra-,
un-, under-, uni-, up-, xantho- (yellow), xeno-, </span></i><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>paired
opposites in these prefixes:</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek prefixes: a(n)- (negation of the
root) ; archi- (chief ___); dus-, ; heemi- (half); nee- () <b>enter when get
Greek font</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin prefixes: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *affix, *suffix, infix, *epenthesis,
*morpheme)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>orthoepy</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the study of the
customary pronunciation of words, a term especially appropriate for the
surprise pronunciations of words, say, with *silent letters, or variant values
of the same letters. It is a relevant discipline since (1) oral language
precedes written language, (2) language drifts over time so that its
appropriate original spelling may no longer be used, (3 there is a tendency to
assign quality of persons to certain ways of saying words.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *pronunciation)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>orthography</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of spelling and the way letters are used to represent the oral
expression of terms</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prefixed preposition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek, Latin, and English, free-standing prepositions may be attached to
the front of nouns, verbs, adjectives, and adverbs to adjust their meanings. (in
a set with *prefixes, *suffixes)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prepositional prefix</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in Greek and Latin, there are many compound words made by putting prepositions
on the front of them. The phenomenon compares to English <u>fused verbs</u>. Often
the cases that follow such compound verbs in Latin and Greek are the cases that
would follow the prefixed preposition if it were free-standing. In these two
languages there are three possibilities for verb and preposition relationship: (1)
the plain verb with the preposition and its object separate. (2) the
preposition prefixed <u>and</u> separately expressed (L. <u>e</u>gredere <u>ex</u>
urbe, leave the city). (3) the preposition prefixed but not separately given. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>preposition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word that shows relationship between referents. In the classical languages, case
forms were more basic than the prepositions used with them, being derived from
earlier adverbs. Over time, Greek tended to use prepositions increasingly where
case sufficed before. English has dropped case form almost completely in favor
of prepositional constructions.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English prepositions include: before, in,
of, on, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek prepositions include: aro, circum,
epi, ek/ex, hypo, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin prepositions include: a/ab, in, sub,
circa, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *phrase prepositions,
*prefixed prepositions [Greek, Latin, English, Hebrew], *prepositional phrase, *sequential
preposition; *parts of speech; *nouns, *adjectives, *verbs, *adverbs,
*conjunctions, *inseparable prepositions [Hebrew], *interjections, *particles,
expletives;)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prepositional phrase</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a *preposition plus its objects together with the modifiers of the preposition
and its object(s). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> One feature of usages bears noting. Sets
of prepositional phrases in English, Greek, Latin, and Hebrew are put in series
rather than in parallel: to the praise of the glory of the grace of him
(translates a series of genitives; Eph<b>1</b>:6); he ran to the top of the
hill. In each case, the next phrase modifies the object of the previous
phrase. There is a breach of this principle in title of one religious
organization: The Church of Jesus Christ of the Latter-Day Saints, where both
phrases modify the same *phrase head.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *phrase preposition)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
