text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prepositive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
sequenced ahead of another word or prefixed to another word</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *postpositive, *appositive)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prequel</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a previous
episode or piece written after one already published and purports to create a
history that leads up to the one already in existence. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *episode; *sequel)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prescription: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a
medical doctors<b> </b>(usually written)<b> </b>order for drugs that are not
available over the counter</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prescriptive grammar</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a grammar that tries to set norms for oral and written language usage in
contrast to one that merely describes how people use the language. A
prescriptive grammar describes contemporary consensus on what is considered
proper, appropriate (*verisimilitude) for formal and informal situations,
uneducated, regional, provincial, slang, and the like. It identifies
conventions in punctuation so ideas may be best represented without ambiguity.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *descriptive grammar) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>present participle</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
An <i>ing</i> form in English that is created from the first principal part of
the verb and characterizes present active verbals in contrast to <i>ed</i> (<i>work<u>ed</u></i><u>)</u>,
-<i>en</i> (<i>beat<u>en</u></i>), -<i>n</i> (<i>draw<u>n</u></i>), and other
forms that characterize *past participles (third principal part), which are
passive voice. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Present participle means present relative
to the main verb rather than present relative to the speaker of the sentence. In
other words, a present participle is present in relative time rather than in
absolute time. If the main verb is past tense, then a present participle (relative
time) has a past-time reference (absolute time): </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Working all night, he is able
to finish the job (present-time action relative to the </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> speaker and the present-time main verb). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Working all night, he
finished the job (past-time action relative to the speaker</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> and present time relative to the
past-tense main verb).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek, present participle is also the
terminology used for active, middle, or passive participles, which are created
from the first principal part. Again, tense in participles ais figured relative
to the tense of the main verb rather than relative to the time of the speaker.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin, participles in the present tense
are active only, so that, as with English, present means contemporary with
the main verb rather than contemporary with the speaker of the sentence.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *relative time, *absolute
time)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>present perfect</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb tense that refers to action completed by the present time: I have worked
through the problem. <i>Have/has</i> are the auxiliary verbs used to express
the idea in English.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>present tense</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
action going on at the same time as the speaker: <i>he works </i>(characteristic
action); <i>he is working</i> (progressive action); <i>he does work</i>
(emphatic present). Greek and Latin simply have present tense in that they
cannot distinguish formally the difference between these aspects of the verb.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>preterite tense/preterite?</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
past tense, especially the *simple past (*aorist tense in Greek, and one of the
values of the *perfect tense in Latin)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prevaricate</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to *lie, to deliberately give false information or at least evade the truth</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>preverb</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a particle
prefixed to the root of a verb, as the <i>for- </i>in <i>forget </i>(Wb ex) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>priest</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an *intercessor
for men to God in contrast to *prophet, a *go-between from God to man </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *go-between, *intercessor, *intermediary,
*prophet)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>primary accent: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>on
longer English words, one syllable may get the heaviest stress while another
gets less stress, as in admini<u>stra</u>tion. (in a set with *secondary
accent)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>primary endings: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>personal
endings used in the *primary tenses of Greek (present and future) and in the
subjunctive mood. (in a set with *secondary endings) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>primary tense</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the present and future tenses, the perfect and future perfect tenses, so called
in Greek because they shared certain inflectional characteristics: personal
ending sets and lack other features found only in *secondary tenses (like
augment). (in a set with *secondary tense)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>primer</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an
elementary-level book that teaches children how to read; an entry-level text
for teaching information on a certain subject.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>primitive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the original form from which others developed or the one onto which inflectional
adjustments are made.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>principal parts: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>the
basic forms of verbs from which its full conjugation derives.<b> </b>In English
those are the present, past, past participle. English verbs most frequently
have principal parts in <i>#, -ed, -ed</i> (<i>work, worked worked</i>). Another,
albeit less frequent, format has <i>#, (infix),</i> -<i>en</i> (<i>ride, rode,
ridden</i>). There are also *irregular verbs like <i>go/went/gone, hit/hit/hit,
sit/sat/sat, </i><b></b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>In
Greek they are the present (1<sup>ST</sup>), future (2<sup>nd</sup>), aorist (3<sup>rd</sup>),
perfect active (4<sup>th</sup>), perfect middle (5<sup>th</sup>), and aorist passive
(6<sup>th</sup>). From the first pp come all voices and moods of the present
and imperfect tense. The second gives the base for future active and middle
voice. The third give the base for aorist active and middle. Number four
provides the base for perfect active, and the fifth supplies it for the perfect
middle and passive. The last pp is the foundation for aorist and future
passive.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin has present (1<sup>st</sup>),
present infinitive (2<sup>nd</sup>), perfect (3<sup>rd</sup>), perfect
participle (4<sup>th</sup>). The first two underlie all the forms in the
non-perfect system, that is, the present, imperfect, and future. The last two
give the base for all forms in the perfect system. In general, the perfect
system of Latin covers the aorist and perfect tense of Greek. Latin principal
parts parallel English principal parts if the first two items in the standard
four-entry Latin list are combinedas they are really.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew studies do not speak of principal
parts; instead they speak of stems, of which there are seven in a complete
regular verb: *qal, *niphal, *piel, *pual, *hiphil, *hophal, and *hithpael.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>printing</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: as form of
handwriting that makes each letter separately from the others (in a set with
*writing, *block lettering, *scribble)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>privative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a prefix or suffix that negates the a root to which it is added: the alpha
privative in Greek and its derivative forms (<i>a-theist</i>), <i>in-/un-,
non-, less</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proclamation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) a deliberate, public presentation of some message</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) a public declaration about some rule
of action; cp. *edict</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proclitic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word pronounced with the succeeding word; as such, it does not bear its own
accent except at the end of a sentence, where there is nothing to pronounce it
with. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek, if a proclitic was followed by
an *enclitic, enclitic rules take precedence; a proclitic can receive an accent
from an enclitic but not vice versa. If two or more proclitics appear together,
none of them has an accent. Greek proclitics are <i>eis, en, ek/ex </i>(preps.);<i>
ho/hee/hoi/hai </i>(the nom. mas &amp; fem sg art);<i> ou/ouk/ouch </i>(neg.);<i>
ei, hoos </i>(conjs.). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *enclitic) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proem</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a preface or
introduction</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>progressive verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb form that looks at the action as in progress rather than as a fact or as
characteristic, cyclical, emphatic, and other aspects of verb action: <i>I</i> <i>am
working</i> <i>vs.</i> <i>I work</i>, <i>I do work hard.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prohibition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a command <u>not</u> to do something</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English normally uses <u>dont/do not</u>
+ indicative verb to create a negative command. Let him not (think) or dont
let him (think) are less usual formulas for third-person reference. Negative
future indicatives make prohibitions as well: You will not use the car tonight.
You are not to (go into their back yard).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin ordinarily uses non + imperative to
cover prohibitions. Latin can also use nolo + a complementary infinitive. The
negative future indicative can prohibit. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew never employs the imperative with a
negative to mean prohibition. Instead, it uses <u>al</u> + shortened imperfect
for *immediate prohibition and <u>lo</u> + imperfect for *permanent
prohibition. (Weingreen, 114.)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek, (a) me + present imperative third
person indicates prohibition; rather infrequently (b) the aorist imperative
serves this purpose in the New Testament; (c) <u>me</u> + aorist subjunctive: present
imperative for prohibition forbids the continuation of some act (cessation);
aorist subjunctive forbids starting to do it. (d) <u>Ou</u> plus future
indicative can likewise be a prohibition. Both Greek and English may have been
influenced in this regard by Hebrew practice. They may have picked up the You
shall not way of speakingas occurred notably in the ten commandmentsbecause
of the prominence of Hebrew idiom behind New Testament Greek and consequent
literal translation of those constructions into English. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A refinement in Greek prohibitions may be
that <u>me</u> + present imperative means to stop doing something <i>vs.</i> <u>me</u>
+ aorist imperative for saying not to start doing it. (Goethius, 269) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prohibitory subjunctive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(in a set with *prohibition,* immediate prohibition, *permanent prohibition,  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prolegomenon/prolegomena</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a preliminary essay/essays that introduces a large, complex work by laying out
the framework of discussion, presuppositions involved, and fundamental concepts
involved in the main treatment</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prolepsis/proleptic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a reference to something or some condition that has not yet been mentioned or
has not yet come about: WB <i>They drained it <u>dry</u>. </i>using a pronoun
before its noun has been entered in the presentation. In debate, disproving an
argument before the opponent has brought it into the discussion: *poisoning the
well.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with proleptic pronoun)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proleptic pronoun: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a
pronoun that refers to a noun not yet said</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prolix</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: wordy, using
more words than are necessary. Wordiness comes from repetition, including
*redundancy, making an overly detailed presentation for the purposes at hand,
including unnecessary accompanying information (rabbit tracks), and from
using wordy constructions like *relative clauses instead of *adjectives or
*participles.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prolog(ue)</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an introductory chapter that sets the stage for the rest of the book, novel, or
play by giving the historical conditions present at the time assumed by the
main writing. Prologue and epilogue deal more with historical circumstances
than with conceptual frameworks and ideologies as such; preface and
introduction have a broader scope.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *epilogue, *preface, *introduction)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prolusion</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pronominal suffix</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Hebrew has suffixes it can put on its verbs instead of having to use
direct-object forms of pronouns</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pronoun</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a word that
stands in the place of a noun. Pronouns have no specific meaning so that <i>it</i>,
for example, can refer to a tree, an act, a rock, an abstraction, <i>etc.</i> They
eliminate what would otherwise be repetitious use of nouns and so create
greater variety of expression. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *demonstrative pronouns, *indefinite
pronoun, *indefinite relative pronoun, *intensive pronoun, *interrogative
pronoun, *personal pronoun, *proleptic pronoun, *reciprocal pronoun, *reflexive
pronoun, *relative pronoun) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Indefinite pronouns: somebody/someone/something/anyone/anybody/anything;
a person, they-ambiguous,: They want to build a crematorium near the high
school! you advisedly: Later <u>you</u> add three teaspoons of butter to
the mix. Gr Lat Heb examples</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> indefinite relative pronouns:  who<u>ever</u>;
also the archaic who<u>soever</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>Greek combines the relative <i>hos</i> + the
indefinite <i>tis/ti</i> to form <i>ostis/o ti</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Interrogative pronouns: <i>who/whose/whom?
which? what?</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Personal pronouns: I, we; you; he, she,
it, they</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Reciprocal pronouns: one another (Gr <i>alleloon</i>) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Relative pronouns get case from their
function within their own clause; they get number and gender from the
antecedent.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin, there is a conjunctive use of
relative pronouns Wh 308 306 qui = et hic</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *proleptic pronoun: a pronoun that refers
to an as-yet unmentioned noun. <i>She</i> is a great woman, my mother.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pronunciation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/<b>pronounce</b>:
<i>Pronunciation</i> emphasizes making the sound of the word while <i>saying</i>
can include the words meaning. With its emphasis on sound, <i>pronounce</i>
can contrast with spelling as in all cases of *silent letters: <i>often</i>
with its silent <i>t</i>, <i>etc.</i> It is spelled <i>o-f-t-e-n, </i>but it
is pronounced<i> offen,</i> spelled <i>soften</i> but pronounced soffen.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> general notation: two of the same
consonants are themselves pronounced the same as if there were only one. The
difference is often that the preceding vowel is not long before a doubled
consonant. The spelling practice was characteristic of Latin (and Greek?)
words; so words derived from those languages retain that spelling and its
corresponding pronunciation. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>te</i> is always the pronunciation of
verbs (and their related <i>tion</i> nouns): <i>amputate/amputation,
calibrate/calibration, correlate/correlation, eliminate/elimination,
estimate/estimation, expectorate/expectoration, illuminate/illumination,
illustrate, iterate, obfuscate/obfucation, obviate/obviation,
orchestrate/orchestration, ruminate/rumination, truncate,</i> <b>[in sert panel]</b>
(in a set with *homograph)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -te/-te: With adjectives and nouns that
do not have a related *homograph *verb, the <i>ate</i> is word-specific as to
whether te or te: <i>magnte</i> (n), <i>potentte</i>, <i>triumvirte</i>,
<b>[insert panel]</b> (in a set with *homograph)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>c-</i> followed by <i>e, i,</i> or <i>y</i>
has an <i>s</i> sound; followed by <i>a, o,</i> or <i>u</i>, and most
consonants, it has a <i>k</i> sound: <i>coccus</i> but <i>cocci</i>, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>cc</i>- words usually follow the rule above
that <i>c</i> before <i>e, i, y = s,</i> while before most consonants and
before the vowels <i>a, o, u</i> it equals <i>k</i>. So, double <i>cc-</i>
words have a <i>k</i> sound to end one syllable followed by an <i>s</i> sound
to start the next, hence, -<i>ks</i>-: <b>[insert panel] </b><i>accent, access,
accidence, accidents, cocci, coccyx/coccygeal, vaccine, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Ch</i> can have (1) a <i>k </i>sound<i>,
</i>(2)<i> </i>a *plosive sound<i>, </i>(3) a<i> sh </i>sound, and (4) no sound
(rarely)<i>. </i>In medical terminology, <i>ch</i> is always <i>k</i> because
the <i>ch</i> comes from the Greek <i>chi</i>, a *fricative that becomes a *stop<i><u>k</u></i>in
English derivatives: <i>achromophilic, chiropractor chromophilic, chromophobic,
chromosome, </i>. (<b>insert panel</b>). The same is true of scientific
terminology generally: xanthochoid, <b>[insert panel] </b>All biblical names in
<i>ch</i> are pronounced <i>k</i> except <i>Rachel</i>. These names have the
Hebrew <i>heth</i>, which has no equivalent sound or letter in Greek, Latin, or
English. <b>[insert panel]</b> Other words, chiefly those of Greek descent,
have <i>ch</i> as a <i>k</i> sound: <i>conch, monarch/y</i>, orchestra, <b>[insert
panel]</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In initial, *medial, or *terminal position,
<i>ch</i> usually has a *plosive sound, as it may elsewhere: [<b>insert panel] </b><i>arch,
approach, attach</i>, <i>bachelor</i>, <i>belch, besmirch, birch, bunch</i>, <i>cha-cha</i>,
<i>chafe, chaff, chain, chair, chalk, challenge, chamber, champion, chance,
chancel, chancellor, chapel, chaplain, chapter, char, charcoal, chariot, charge</i>,
<i>chaity</i>, <i>channel, chant, charm</i>, <i>chart, chase, chaste, chat, chatter,
cheap, check, cheek, cheer, cheese, cheetah, cherry, chert, cherub, chess,
chest, chew</i>, <i>chick/chicken</i>, <i>chickory</i>, <i>chief</i>, <i>child,
chime, chimney, chimpanzee, chink, chip, chirp, chisel</i>, <i>chive, chock,
choice/choose/chose/chosen,</i> <i>choke, chomp, chop</i>, <i>chore</i>, <i>chortle</i>,
<i>chow, chubby, chuck</i>, <i>chug, chum, church, churl, churn, churr, coach, crunch,
drench, hunch, lunch, lurch, march, mooch, much, munch, niche, orchard,
ostrich, parch, paunch, ponch, punch, ranch, raunchy, reach, rich, roach, scorch,
search, smirch,squinch, staunch, such, tench, torch, touch, trench, wench,
winch, zilch</i>. Such words usually come from Alglo-Saxon heritage. This same
sound is often spelled <i>tch</i>; see under spelling <b>[insert panel]</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Ch</i> can have a <i>sh</i> sound
occasionally, as in <i>chauffeur</i>, <i>chagrin, chalet, champagne, chamois,
chandelier, charade, charlatan, chauffeur, chauvinist, chef, chivalry, chute,
crochet, echelon</i>. This value appears largely in words descending from or
through French.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Ch</i> is silent in <i>chthonic</i>
because the initial double *fricative natural in Greek is not allowed in
English.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>cq-</i> equals plain <i>qu</i> because
c ahead of consonants is <i>k</i>; so just like <i>qu</i>: <i>acquaint,
acquiesce, acquire, acquit</i>,. </span><b><span lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>also put under spelling</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>en</i>: more frequently
pronounced like <i>in</i>, but often pronouced <i>ahn</i> in words and phrases
from French influence: <i>en bloc, en brochette, en prise, en rapport, en
suite, enceint, enclave, encore, ennui, ensemble, entre, entourage, <u>en</u>t<u>en</u>te,
entracte, entrechat, entrecte, entremets, entrept, entrepeneur, envelope<sup>1</sup>,
envoy</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span lang=FR style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>-ic adjectives
receive accent on the next-to-last syllable.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -iac for one who does ___ carry accent on
the third syllable back: <i>brainiac, demoniac, hemophiliac, maniac, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> -g </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>followed
by <i>a, o,</i> <i>u,</i> most<i> </i>consonants<i>, </i>and at the end of the
word, has a guh sound: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gab, garb; goon, got; gun, gut</span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>g-</i> followed by <i>e,</i> <i>i</i>,
<i>y </i>usually has a j sound (but see <i>ge</i> below): <b>[insert panel]</b>:
<i>coccygal</i>, <i>meningitis</i> (but <i>meningocele</i>); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>but
some other exceptions can be noted: <i>gib, gibbon, gid, giddy, gift, gig,
giggle, gilbert, gild, gill, gilt, gimbal, gimlet, gimmal, gimmick, gimp, gingham,
gird, girl, girn, girth, gittern, give. </i>Another set of words with <i>g</i>
as <i>guh</i> is linger, longer, monger, stronger, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The <i>j</i> sound for <i>g</i> applies
also to words that end in those letters (except some <i>ge</i> words given below
under -<i>ge</i>): <i>age/agent, binge, cage/cager, carnage, charge, cringe, dirge,
expunge, flange, gauge, hinge, huge, image/imager, large/larger, lunge, manage/manager,
massage<sup>1</sup>, plunge/plunger, rage, range/ranger, sage, singe, stage, tinge,
tonnage,urge, verge, visage, wage, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> To avoid the <i>j</i> sound, <i>-u-</i> is
added after the <i>g</i>: <i>guest, guide,</i> <i>marguerite</i>, <b>[insert
panel]</b> <i>catalog(ue<sup>1</sup>), demagogue/demagoguery, monologue,
morgue, rogue, prologue, tongue, synagogue, vague, vogue,</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>g</i>- can have a <i>zh</i> sound
(like the <i>s</i> in <i>measure</i>) in a few words under French influence: <b>[insert
panel]</b> <i>gite, lingerie, menagerie<sup>1</sup>, regime</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> -ge </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>at
the end of a word can have a <i>zh</i> as in<i> beige, collage, deluge<sup>1</sup>,
entourage, garage<sup>1</sup>, luge, massage<sup>1</sup>, mirage, rouge, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>gh</i> can be silent, or carry the <i>f</i>
sound: <i>cough, enough, laugh, rough, slough, tough,</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>gh is </i>Silent in <i>aught, blight,
bough, bought, bright, brought, caught, delight, dough, drouight, fight, flight,
fraught, haughty, high, height, light, might, night, nought, ought, plight, right,
sigh, sight, sleigh, slight, sought, th(o)rough, though, thought, tight, through,
tight, weigh/t, wright, wrought, </i><b>[insert panel]</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Gn</i>- on the front of words does not
pronounce the <i>g</i>: <i>gnar, bnarly, gnash, gnat, gnathic, gnathite, gnaw,
gnocchi, gnome, gnomic, gnomon, gnosis, gnu.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> H- </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>usually
represents a *fricative in English (as in <i>hat, hot,</i> <i>etc.</i>), but in
a few words it equals the Hebrew <i>aleph</i> and the Greek smooth breathing
(), a *glottal stop: <i>haute, heir, herb/al, herbage, honest/y, honor/able,</i>
<i>hour.</i> British cockney typically substitutes glottal stop for *glottal
fricative: <i>orse</i> for <i>horse</i>, <i>etc.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Kn</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>-
on the front of words does not pronounce the <i>k: knack, knap, knar, knave,
knavery, knawel, knead, knee, kneel, knell, knickers, knife, knight, knish,
knit, knob, knock, knoll, knop, knot, knout, know, knuckle, knur, knurl.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> N</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
has (a) its regular <i>n</i> sound everywhere except before *gutturals/*palatals/*velars.
See <i>ng</i> below. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>N</i> has (b) an <i>ng </i>sound when it
is followed by <i>c </i>(if = k), <i>k,</i> <i>g </i>(if = guh), <i>ch</i> (if
= <i>k</i>): <b>[insert panel]</b> <i>an/ankle, ban/bank, can/canker,
con/conch, Congo, dan/dank, gunk, kung fu, lawn/long/lung, man/mangle, ran/rank,
rink, sin/sink/sinker, stink/stank/stunk, sun/sunk, tin/tinker, uncle, wrinkle,
fungus</i> (but fun + gi, pl., because <i>g</i> before <i>e, i,</i> or <i>y</i>
has a <i>j</i> sound; so the  sound becomes plain <i>n</i>), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>N</i> has (c) <i>ny</i> sound with a
tilde over it (words of Spanish origin): seor, seorita, seora.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>N</i> + <i>c</i> (if = <i>k</i>), <i>g,
k, ch</i> (if = <i>k</i>) [that is *velars] has an <i>ng</i> sound: <i>rank</i>
(<i>rangk vs.</i> <i>ran</i>), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ng</i> at the end of a word has its
typical sound as a *digraph (two letters for one sound; ). When such words
have added suffixes, the same sound usually remains: <b>[insert panel]</b> <i>bang/banged/banging,
cling/clinged/clinger/clinging, hang/hanger, ring/ringer/ringing, sing/singer/singing,
sting/stinger, thing/thingie, wring/wringer, </i>But note <i>long/longer</i>, <i>strong/stronger</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> -ng</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
names of German descent can be unclear. Is <i>Hettinger</i> pronounced <i>Hettier</i>
or <i>Hettinjer</i>? Each family or person determines whether it has be
anglicized.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Rh</i>- and <i>rrh</i> words = <i>r: rhabdom,
rhabdomancy, rhabdomyoma, rhapsody, rhatany, rhea, rhenium, rheology,
rheometer, rheostat, rheotaxis, rhesus, rhetor, rheum, rheumatic, rheumatism,
rhinal, rhinencephalon, rhinoceros, rhinology, <u>rh</u>ino<u>rrh</u>ea, rhizanthous,
rhizobium, rhizocephalan, rhizogenic, rhizoid, rhizomer, rhizopod, rhizopus,
rhodium, rhodochrosite, rhododendron, rhodolite, rhodopsin, rhodora,
rhombencephalon, rhombic, rhombohedron, rhomboid, rhombus, rhonchus, rhubard,
rhumb, rhyme, rhyolite, rhythm</i>;<i> -rrhea, -rrhagia, -rrhexis, -rrhaphy</i>;<i>
catarrh, cirrhosis. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Initial <i>bd-, gn-, kn- kt-, pn-, ps-, pt-,</i>
<i>tl-,, </i>have the first consonant dropped in pronunciation because English
speakers perceive the combination to be unnatural. The same goes for the
*digraphs <i>ph</i> before <i>th</i> (<i>phthistic</i>) and <i>ch</i> before <i>th</i>
(<i>chthonic</i>)..</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>S</i> = <i>s, z, sh,</i> or <i>zh</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>-</b><i>S</i> <i>vs.</i> -<i>z</i> for
plural sound, but always written <i>s</i>. The influence of a preceding voiced
consonant (or a preceding vowel sound) carries on through the sibilant <i>s</i>
to make a <i>z</i> sound: <i>spas, jobs, raids, bees, gags, blahs, skis, balls,
rims, fins, twos, bars, revs</i>; also in plurals that add a syllable to the
singular by adding a voiced <i>e</i> + <i>s </i>( <i>es</i>): <i>bosses, bushes,
prefixes,</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The pattern holds for third-person
singular present-tense endings: <i>bids, chords, dubs, earns, fares, gores,
has, lies, moos, nabs, pads, raids, sags, tabs, wads.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The
<i>s/z </i>variable marks the difference between noun and verb in words like <i>abuse,
grease, house, lose(loose/loss), refuse, re-use, use</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> S </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>as<i>
sh </i>appears in<i> scena</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> S </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ahead
of <i>u</i> can be<i> sh </i>in some words: <i>assure, censure, insure, sugar,
sure,</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>S</i> ahead of <i>u</i> can have a <i>zh</i>
sound: <i>measure</i>,</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>sc</i>- ahead of <i>e</i> is plain <i>s:
acquiesce, scenario, scend, scene, scenery, scenic, scenography, scent,scepter,
septic,</i> <i>etc.</i> This is so because <i>c</i> ahead of <i>e</i>, <i>i</i>,
or <i>y</i> has an <i>s</i> sound; so, two <i>s</i>s in a row equal plain <i>s</i>
(see below un <i>ss</i>).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>sc</i>- ahead of <i>i</i> is plain <i>s</i>:
<i>sciaenoid, sciatic, sciatica, science</i>, <i>scientiall, scientific,
scientism, scientist, sci-fi, scilicet, scimitar, scincold, scintigram,
scintigraph, scintilla, scintillate, scintillation, scintillator, scintiscan,
sciolism, scion, scirrhus, scissile, scission, scissor, scissure, Scituate, </i>sciurid;
<i>etc.</i> This is so because <i>c</i> ahead of <i>e</i>, <i>i</i>, or <i>y</i>
has an <i>s</i> sound; so, two <i>s</i>s in a row equal plain <i>s</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> sc- ahead of y is plain s: <i>Scylla</i>
(and Charybdis), <i>scyphistoma, scyphozoan, scythe, Scythia, Scythian. </i>But
<i>Scyros </i>(<i>sk</i>-) as an alternate spelling of<i> Skiros.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Sch</i> has an <i>sk</i> sound on the
front of most words<i>: schedule, schema, schematic, schematism, schematize,
scheme, scherzando, scherzo, schizocarp, schizogenesis, schizogony, schizoid,
schizont, schizophrene, schizophrenia, schizophrenic, schizothymia, schizy,
scholar, scholarly, scholarship, scholastic, scholastic, scholasticism,
scholiast, scholium; school, etc.; schooner, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Sch</i> has the <i>sh</i> sound in
words with the <i>schisto</i>- prefix in <i>schistocyte, schistoglossia,
schistorrchachis, shistothorax</i>, as well as in <b>[insert panel]</b> <i>scheelite,
schefflera, schiller, schilling, schist, schistosome, schlemiel, schlep,
schlieren, schlimazel, schlock, schmaltz, schmal;tzy, schmo, schmooze, schmuck,
schnapper, schnitzel, schnopok, schnorrer, schnoz, schottische, schuss. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Sch</i> is plain <i>s</i> in <i>schism,
schismatic, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The <i>sh</i> sound can be covered also by
<i>ce</i>- (ocean), <i>ci</i>, -<i>si</i>, -<i>ti </i>(patience, vitiate); -s
(sugar), -<i>ss</i>- (mission, passion), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>-sia/-tia/-cia</i> = shuh </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>si</i>- can be <i>zh</i>: <i>allusion</i>,
<i>fusion</i>, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -ss is usually plain <i>s</i> (the
two-consonant rule), especially on the ends of words: as in <i>access</i>, <i>across,
actress, albatross, ass, assess, bass, bliss, boss, class, confess, crass,
cross, cuss, dress, dross, ess, glass, gross, hiss, kiss, less, loss, mess,
miss, mistriss, moss, toss, </i>and all words with the feminine agent ending <i>ess</i>
(<i>hostess, tigress,</i> <i>etc.</i>, see under <b>suffix</b>) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ss-</i> can be <i>sh: confession, mission</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ss-</i> can be <i>zh</i>: <i>fission</i>,
<i>scissure</i>,  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -ss- can be <i>z</i>: <i>scissors</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The <i>th</i> may be (a) a dental
voiceless fricative: <i>both, catheter, doth, ether, loath, myth, panther, thin,
thing, thingie, thither, thug, thong, thought, thumb, with.</i> All the words
that derive from Greek <i>theta</i> have this same sound because theta was a
voiceless sound: <i>anthropoid, arthropathy, atheroma, catheter, catholic,
euthanize, orthodontist, therapeutic,</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Th</i> may be (b) a dental voiced
fricative (often spelled phonetically as <i>dh</i>): <i>another, bathe, bother,
brother, dither, either, father, farther, farthing, further, gather, hither, lather,
lithe, loathe, mother, mouth, neither, other, rather, seethe, smooth, southern,
swathe, teethe, than, that, the, thee, then, thence, there, these, thine, this,
those, thou, threw, thrice, thrift, thrill, throw, thud, thunder, together, tooth,
thi<u>th</u>er, weather, whether, wither, writhe. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Adding
an <i>e</i> after a final <i>th</i> may changes <i>th</i> to <i>dh: bath/bathe,
lath/lathe, loath/loathe, teeth/teethe, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The
<i>th/dh</i> sound variant can mark the difference between noun and verb: <i>bath/bathe,
mouth<sup>2</sup>,</i> or just between words: <i>lath/lathe, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Th</i> may have (c) a silent <i>h</i> as
in <i>thyme.</i> More correctly, the <i>th</i> is a *digraph that represents a
stop (plain<i> t</i>) rather than a fricative (<i>th</i>) in this case.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>x</i>: Words beginning with <i>x</i>
are pronounced <i>z</i> because <i>ks </i>(<i>= x</i>) is not an acceptable
combination of initial consonants in English; so the <i>k </i>part is dropped
and the <i>s</i> is *voiced to a <i>z</i>. The least number of English words
have <i>x</i> as their first letter: <b>[insert panel] </b><i>xanthan gum, xanthate,
xanthene, xanthochoid, xanthoma, xanthophyll, xanthous, xebec, xenia, xenolith,
xenoblast, xenocryst, xenogenesis, xenon, xenophobe, xeroderma, xerography, xerosis,
xerophtahlmia, xerosis, xerothermic, xi<sup>1</sup>, xiphocostal, xiphoid,
xylan, xylem, xylene, xylidinie, xylophagus, xylograph, xylophone, xylose.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Unaccented vowels in English tend to drift
toward *<i>shevah/schwa</i> (), a light vowel sound as in the word b<u>e</u>cause,
as examples show: <i>calendar</i>, <i>miner</i>, <i>fakir</i>, <i>minor</i>, <i>augur</i>,
<i>satyr</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Long <i>e</i> appears in words derived
from Greek that have followed the <i>ai-, -ae-, e</i> development: <i>palography</i>
(<i>pal<u>ai</u>os</i>), <i>pdiatrician</i> (<i>p<u>ai</u>dion</i>), archology
(<i>arch<u>ai</u>os</i>), <i>encyclopdia</i> (<i>p<u>ai</u>dion</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Two vowels letters written together are often
*diphthongs, that is, two letters for one sound (*monophthong) or a *vowel
glide from one letter to the another, but not two syllables: <i>fail, fault, flay;
feat, feign, feud/deuce, trey; mien; foal, foil, fount, boy; sue, s<u>ui</u>t/q<u>ui</u>t,
quote; buy</i>. Diphthongs can be two of the same letter: <i>feet</i> (), <i>fool</i>
(ooh), <i>foot</i>. There are cases, however, where two same vowel letters are
not a diphthong, but represent two syllables with two sounds, which will be
different: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ii</i>- in <i>card<u>ii</u>ts, fasc<u>ii</u>tis,
ang<u>ii</u>tis</i> (  + ); <i>coiinine </i>a poison, oi + i); <i>skiing,
taxiing</i> (<i></i> + <i></i>); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> c<u>oo</u>perate, <u>oo</u>phorectomy ( +
, not the <i>oo</i> in <i>fool</i>).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>uu</i>- in continuum, vacuum ( + ); </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>Double <i>ee</i> is always a diphthong (*monophthong)
in . Some vowel combinations are rare or do not occur in English as diphthongs:
-aa-, -ao- (but <i>gaol</i>, British for <i>jail</i>), -iy-, -<i>ue</i>- (a
German spelling for rounded <i>u</i>), -<i>uo</i>-,</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ae</i> occurs in limited
circumstances: (1) on plurals of Latin singulars in <i>a</i> (<i>amoeba</i>/<i>ae</i>),
or (2) derivatives from Greek words in <i>ai</i><b>-</b>, which over time
become <i>ae/--</i> (<i>encyclopdia</i>) then <b>- </b>(arch<u>e</u>ology,
p<u>e</u>diatrician), as illustrated in <i>/aeon/eon</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> When vowel sequences appear that could be
diphthongs, but are not, spelling sometimesbut not always (<i>doable</i>)uses
a *hyphen between them or a *dieresis over the second vowel: co-operate, nave.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Some possible vowel sequences either do
not occur or are two syllables rather than diphthongs: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ia</i>- (<i>vial</i>), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>io</i>- (<i>lion</i>), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>iu</i>- (<b>???</b>) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>eo</i>- is a mixed bag: <i>l<u>eo</u>pard</i>
(diphthong, ); but <i>l<u>eo</u>tard</i> (2 syl)<i>, leonine </i>(and other
words built on Latin<i> leo/leonis</i>), <i>geode, paleography, phraseology</i>;
<i>arch<u>eo</u>logy</i> has the sequence by virtue of <i>ai</i> becoming <i>ae-</i>
becoming -<i>e</i>-. There is one syllable in the names <i>George</i> (German <i>Georg</i>,
2 syl) and <i>Leonard</i> (<i>Leonardo</i>, 2 syl)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>oe</i>- does occur in (1)
derivatives of some Greek words in oi-, which over time went from <i>oi</i> to
<i>oe</i> (as <i></i>) to <i></i>: poinee &gt; (poenology) &gt; pnology. Since
German uses <i>e</i> after vowels to show *rounding, some names and other words
can crop up in English with the <i>oe</i>- sequence: <b>???</b> . By chance, -<i>oe</i>-
can fall in separate syllables: <i>orthoepy</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ua</i>- (<i>dual</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ue</i>- (<i>duel, suet</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -ui- is a also mixed bag. There
are two syllables in <i>ruin</i>, but a diphthong in <i>quit</i>, <i>suit</i>,
as noted above. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A rule for pronouncing some vowel
combinations has limited value: When two vowels go walking, the first takes
the lead; that is, the first, pronounced long, is the sound of both. The pattern
usually applies only for <i>ai</i>- (<i>gait</i>), -<i>ea</i>- (<i>leaf</i>),
(-<i>ee</i>-, <i>leek</i>), and <i>oa-</i> (<i>boat</i>). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Derivatives with odd consonant
combinations on the front typically lose the first of those sounds<i>: bd</i>-
(), <i>chth</i> (), <i>gn</i>- (<i>gnostic</i>), <i>kt</i>- (), <i>ll</i>- (<i>llama</i>),
<i>mn</i>- (<i>mnemonic</i>), <i>pt</i>- (<i>ptyalism</i>), <i>wr</i>- (<i>wrong</i>).
Other adjustments are also made: <i>x</i> becomes <i>z</i>; <i>rh-</i> and <i>rrh/rrh-/-rrh-
</i>become <i>r</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Finally, some words are simply pronounced
according to convention without adhering closely to what the spellingoften informed
by derivational transliterationwould call for. <i>Ste<u>ph</u>en</i>, for
example, is almost always pronounced <i>Ste<u>v</u>en.</i> Examples of extreme
conventional pronunciation include <i>coxen</i> (for <i>coxswain</i>), <i>kernel</i>
(for <i>colonel</i>), <i>fxil </i>(for <i>forecastle</i>), <i>gunnel</i> (for
<i>gunwhale</i>), Wooster (for Worchester). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>British pronunciation differs
noticeably from American pronunciation</b>. (1) Some words get different
accenting or vowel length: labratory, vtamin,</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) Vowel sounds are significantly
adjusted. The <i>a</i> as in <i>at </i>more often has an <i>ah</i> sound. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) Final <i>t</i>s are often replaced
with a *glottal stoplike the <i>h</i> in <i>honor.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(4)
Glottal stop and glottal fricative are reversed in certain speakers: orse for
horse.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *accent, *enunciation, *epenthesis,
*pronunciation, *diction, *elocution, *orthoepy, *sandhi, *spelling))</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pronunciation guide</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proofreader</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
one who checks through the print copies of a forthcoming publication to catch
any *typos that may have crept into the copy during typesetting and the like. (in
a set with *galley proof, *galley sheets)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proper adjective</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proper diphthong</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a diphthong in Greek that does not involve a long vowel followed by iota. When
an iota comes into play after a long vowel, it ceases to affect pronunciation
and is written under the other vowel. If the long vowel happens to get
capitalized, the iota comes back up onto the line after the long vowel.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proper names</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
nouns used for identification more than description. Names typically originate
from words that have meaning.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proper noun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a noun whose usage is not to indicate meaning, but identity. A proper name
designates an individual within a class or group of individuals. English,
Greek, and Latin convention calls for capitalizing such words while using *lower
case on *common nouns. <u>John</u> is my brother (proper noun, identity); John
is my <u>brother</u> (common noun, meaning). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew did not have capital <i>vs.</i>
lower-case letters so as to distinguish common nouns from proper nouns in
writing. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew names in the Bible sometimes have
derivations given with them. Moses was so named because he was drawn from the
water (Ex <b>2</b>:10). The predecessor of the Messiah was to be named <i>John</i>,
from the Greek <i>Iooannees</i>, from the Hebrew <i>Jonah</i>, presumably
because John would be given the sign of the dove for identifying the Messiah
(Jn<b> 1</b>:32-34). <i></i>Jacob became Israel because in his wrestling
with the angel that night he <i>strived with God</i> (Gen <b>32</b>:24-29). In
the same incident, Jacob named the place of the encounter Peniel/Penuel
because there he saw the <i>face of God</i> (Gen <b>32</b>:30). Hannah named
her son <i>Samuel</i> because she was heard of God (1 Sam <b>1</b>:20). Abram
was re-named <i>Abraham (); </i>Sarai was re-named Sarah (). The name <i>Joshua</i>
came into a Greek corrupted spelling as <i>Ieesouys</i>, and then into the
Latin and English name <i>Jesus</i>, who was so named because he would <i>save</i>
his people from their sins (Mt <b>1</b>:21, 25; Lk <b>1</b>:31; <b>2</b>:21;
cp. Jn <b>1</b>:29). The Messiah was to be called Immanuel/Emmanuel, <i>God </i>(is)
<i>with-us</i> (Is <b>7</b>:14; Mt <b>1</b>:23). <i>Messiah</i> itself means
anointed one (Dan <b>9</b>:25; Ps<b> 2</b>:2), whose Greek equivalent meaning
is <i>Christos, </i>to Latin <i>Christus</i>, and then to English <i>Christ </i>(Jn<b>
1</b>:41; <b>4</b>:25). The Aramaic <i>Cephas</i> translated into the Greek <i>Petros</i>
(Jn <b>1</b>:42). <i>Rabbi </i>is <i>Teacher</i> (Jn<b> 1</b>:38). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Nicknames, or *surnames, likewise have
accompanying explanations as to why Joseph, for example, was called <i>Barnabas</i>
(Son of consolation/exhortation). Even in these cases, once the origination
of the name has taken place, the subsequent usages are not so much for
description as for identitywho, more than what.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The older, more original Greek *uncial
manuscripts of the New Testament were written in all capitals letters, which
made capitalization a difference that could not be used to indicate proper <i>vs.</i>
common nouns. This feature of the Greek text and its history of transmission raised
questions for later copyists and for scholars who try to re-create a corrected
New Testament text. That presents a question about the possible meanings of
Phil <b>4</b>:3, Yes, I beseech you, true <i>yokefellow</i>, help these
women. Is this a reference to Clement in<b> 4</b>:3, or is this term another
mans name: <i>Syzygos</i>? </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *common noun, *lower-case
noun; *capitals, *small letters; *minuscules, *majuscules) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proper pronoun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a capitalized pronoun as in reference to deity. In English usage, capitalized
pronouns in reference to deity should be limited to personal pronouns and not extended
to reflexive, intensive, relative, indefinite pronouns, <i>etc.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prophet</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a spokesman for
God to man in contrast to *priest, who intercedes for man to God. A prophets
speaking for God includes the full range of what can comprise divine revelation,
not just predictive prophecy. (in a set with *priest, *intercessor)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prophetic literature/prophecy</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prophetic history</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Old Testament historical literature is prophetic history inasmuch as it makes evaluative
comments on whether the king or other leader whose life is being chronicled kept
*covenant.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proposition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) a proposed idea; as a verb to proposition is (2) to seek sexual favors </span></p>
