<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proscribe/proscription</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to denounce or condemn</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prose</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) a
presentation in regular written form in contrast to poetry; its intention is
more to inform and persuade than to beautify or extol. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) In a context where translation is
involved, <i>prose</i> can be used to mean translating from a persons native
language into the one being studied, in contrast to translation from the
foreign to the native language.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *poetry, *free verse)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prose poem</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a writing that by passes the rhyme scheme and meter found in traditional poetry
and incorporates vivid imagery and concentrated expression WB</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prosody</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the study of
metrical structure of verse WB</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>protasis</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the if-clause of
a *conditional sentence. Also called the *antecedent in logic. The protasis
without a *consequent clause is used in Hebrews as a kind of *aposiopoesis for
strong prohibition ( ). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *apodosis) [&lt;Gr. <u>pro</u>,
before + <u>teinein</u>, to stretch]. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prothesis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the addition of a meaningless phoneme or syllable to the front of a word as
with the Spanish <i>e </i>on <i>espaol</i>. WB The opposite of *apheis, the
loss of a sound on the front of a word with out changing its meaning. They
went <i>a-</i>caroling; the cattle were <i>a-</i>lowingan example???</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proto-</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a prefix
denoting the earlier form of somethinga language, letter form, and the like. <b>proto-Masoretic</b>:
a form of the Hebrew text earlier than the standardized text produced by the
Masoretes.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proto-semetic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>prototype</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the qal stem in Hebrew is regarded as the prototype of the other stems in the
verb system. It is the basic form.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>protraction</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the irregular lengthening of a short vowel</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proverb</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (in a set with
*adage, *maxim, *apothegm) (1)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pro-verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>;
the use of only part of a phrase verb. Are you going to cut the grass.  I
should. Did you get your homework done? I did. I dont want <u>to</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>provincialism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a term or expression used in a limited geographical area, particularly an area
off the main path of the political, governmental, or social order. Similar to
*regionalism. (in a set with *archaism, *buzz word, *catch phrase, *colloquialism,
*curse word, *formal term, *informal term, *oath, *obsolete term, *regionalism,
*regionalism, *slang, *technical term, *vulgarism)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proviso clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a dependent clause connected to the main clause with the idea as along as,
provided that. Latin uses a special construction for the concept: <u>dummodo</u>
+ subjunctive.  Wheelock p 223)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>proxy word</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a term that replaces another that is not not acceptable in polite speach. These
words are often *corruptions of vulgarisms like freakin for __, son of a
gun for __; of curse words like dadgum for __, darn for __, (in a set with
*perversion, *corruption)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>PS</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: abbreviation for <i>post
scriptum</i>, post script, an added notation </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>psalm</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the words of a
song, especially the words of the Psalms in the Old Testament. (in a set with
*hymn, *ode)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>psi</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: twenty-third letter of
the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pseudepigrapha</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
by *word picture, false writings, *spurious writings. A group of writings
that falsely claim to be written by Old Testament prophets <b>finish</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *apocrypha, *canonical
books)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pseudonym/pseudonymous</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a pen name, or alias, used for purposes of *anonymity, particularly to pass
something off as by a famous persons writing. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *aka, *alias, allonym, *pen
name) [by word picture false name]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>psycholinguistics</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of psychological influences on the use and interpretation of human
language</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>publication</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
broad term for what is put out for public use: *periodical, a *weekly, a *daily,
a *monthly, an *annual, an *ephemeral paper, a *book.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pun</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a *paronomasia; a *word
play on different senses of the same word or on different words with similar
sound. <b>examples</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>punch line</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a final comment that brings the preceding ones to sudden clarification; used
mostly in presenting something humorous. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>punctuation/punctuation marks</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Indicators beyond vocabulary that help
reproduce oral language in written form. In general, punctuation marks deal
with relationship between words in contrast to *diacritical marks, which deal
with marks within a word. Punctuation marks often correspond to oral (1) pauses,
(2) pitch patterns, or (3) emphases. At other times they indicate </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (4) logical relationships not particularly
marked in the spoken language. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (5) They show the relationship between
words. The English *apostrophe <i>s</i>, <i>s</i> apostrophe, and plain <i>s</i>
distinguish respectively singular possessor, plural possessor, and plain
plural. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In many of these instances commas (6) simply
help the eye of a reader. That is the reason a comma can be omitted between short
co-ordinate clauses: He hit the ball and John caught it. That is also the
reason introductory prepositional phrases do not always need to be separated
from the main sentence: In the morning Ill mow the grass <b>but In Greek,
commas look like they do in English.???</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Period: end of sentences, end of
abbreviations, as a decimal point</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Comma: separates (one comma before or
after) or sets off (comma before and after)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Dieresis: a double horizontal dot above a second
vowel to show that it does not form a diphthong with an immediately preceding
vowel. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Semi-colon: used between independent
clauses that are thought of as related though not joined by a coordinating
conjunction: <i>and</i>, <i>but</i>, <i>or</i>, <i>nor</i>. It is used to
separate two word groups that have a comma separation within one or both of
them.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Colon is used after an independent clause to
indicate a brief explanatory notation. It has the force of that is, heres an
example, to put in a clearer way. Colon is also used between chapter and
verse in biblical citations. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hyphen joins words into one word (<i>pick-up</i>)
or into word parts that, taken, together modify the following term (a
bigger-than-life hero). Hyphens break long words into syllables in order to
divide them up into what will fit on a line of writing. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> a dash separates words groups that
intrude into the general flow of the main sentence.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>An opening dash marks the beginning of the insertion;
a closing dash marks the end of the insertion. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Ditto: a double vertical straight mark
above the line of writing to indicate repetition of the item directly above it
in a list. On typewriters the ditto was the same key as double quotation marks,
which in turn were the same before and after the quotation; consequently, in
typed material (but not necessarily in handwriting) dittos and double quote
marks had the same form. With the advent of computer and smart quotes, the
ditto can be supplied from a specialty list.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Em dash</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> En dash</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Exclamation mark: indicates the presence
of a significant degree of emotional  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A quotation mark may be a single quotation
mark or double quotation mark. Single quotation marks ( and ) are used for a quotation
within a quotation. Smart quotes ( and ;  and ) are shaped in opposite
curvatures at the front and the end of quotations. By convention, quotation
marks follow periods and commas, precede colons and semi-colons; and follow or
precede exclamation marks and question marks depending on whether the writer is
quoting the question (after) or questioning the quote (before), quoting the
exclamation (after) or exclaiming the quote (before).  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Slash (diagonal) goes between switch-out
words: and/or. A double slash isolates an infrequent usage like a phoneme<i>: f,
ph, gh</i> are variant English spellings for the phoneme <i>/f/</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Backslash</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Brackets are used for insertions inside of
quoted material.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Angle brackets ( &lt; &gt;) are used
around e-mail addresses. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Parenthesis/parentheses</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Apostrophe</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> asterisk</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Matilda</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> With the advent of computers and their
better range of available symbols, previous rules for some punctuation marks in
typing can now be specialized. *Italics can now be used for word used as a
word; *underlining, for emphasis; *bold face, for titles and headings (rather
than underling), and *quotation marks for peculiar uses of words. (Italics and
angle brackets were not generally available before except in type-set.)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> See *apostrophe, *asterisk, *backslash, *bold
(face), *brackets, *colon, *comma, *dash, *ditto, *ellipsis marks, *exclamation
mark/point, *hyphen, *italics, *parentheses, *period, *question mark, quotation
marks (single quotation marks, double quotation marks), *semi-colon, *slash,
smart quotes, *underlining. Diacritical marks include *cidella, *dieresis,
*tilde, *acute accent, grave accent, circumflex accent). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Some of these are diacritical marks</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In New Testament Greek punctuation, there
are periods and commas as in English. A raised period serves as the equivalent
of colon or semi-colon. The question mark looks like an English semi-colon.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew punctuation: soph-pasook</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The *uncial Greek manuscripts of the New
Testament do not have spaces between words, no distinction by capitalization distinctions
between *proper nouns and *common nouns, and no punctuation. Occasionally this
latter feature of the uncial texts poses a question about sentence division. Should
Jn <b>1</b>:3 read, Without him nothing was made that has been made. In him
was life? (United Bible Society text) or Nothing was made without him. What
has been made in him was life? (Westcott &amp; Hort text).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>purist</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: someone who
retains strict rules of word usage and grammatical rules no longer observed by
the general populace or rules reserved for formal writing. Splitting
infinitives, <i>e.g.</i>, may be a no-no; and certain sentence structures may
be followed: To whom do you want me to go? <i>vs.</i> Who do you want me to
go to?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>purpose</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the reason for
doing something to bring about an effect. English can use infinitives to
express purpose if the actor in the infinitive is the same as the subject of
the leading: He did it to impress his girlfriend. After leading verbs ,
English can introduce a clause with that, so, so that, in order that: He
worked two jobs that/in-order-that/so-that/so he could get married sooner. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin ways of expressing purpose: acc. supine
wh 331)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Gr purpose constructions: <i>hina/hoos/hopoos</i>
+ subj; infinitive (plain, with genitive article, with <i>hoos</i>, with
hooste, with prepositions like <i>eis</i> and <i>pros</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *purpose clauses,
*infinitives) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>purpose clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a subordinate clause that indicates the purpose for which the action in the main
clause is done.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>qere</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: what is to be
read from the text of the Hebrew Old Testament in contrast to what is
actually written. (in a set with *kethibh) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>qoph</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the nineteenth
letter of the Hebrew alphabet. Also <u>koph</u>: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL
style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>QR code</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a square design
that can be shot with a smart phone camera and can convey information visually
in something of the same fashion as a bar code can indicate information in the
field of marketing.(in a set with *bar code, *code, *language, *semaphore)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>quadriliteral</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having three letters</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>quadriliteral verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a few Hebrew verbs have four-letter roots instead of three-letter ones. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *triliteral root, *weak
verbs, *doubly weak verbs) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>quantitative verse</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>quantity</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the length or
duration of time that it takes to pronounce a vowel; vowel length. Strictly
speaking, what at first had to do with duration has bled off into systematic
shifts between what are called long and short vowels even though their duration
is not appreciably different. The shift from short <i>a</i> () to long <i>a</i>
(), short <i>e </i>()<i> to long </i>e (), short <i>o</i> () to long <i>o</i>
() are shifts between paired, or switch-out, sounds more than anything else.  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> To a lesser extent, the same goes for long
and short <i>a, i,</i> and <i>u </i>in Greek and epsilon/eta and omicron/omega,
although here duration is a more likely aspect of the difference. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>question: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a
wording that asks for information. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English asks questions (1) about
progressive action by <u>reversing the auxiliary verb and the subject</u>: Are
you working at home today? <i>vs.</i> You are working at home today.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Questions (2) about characteristic action
use the <i><u>do</u></i><u> auxiliary</u> plus putting the subject after the
auxiliary. <i>Do</i> <u>you </u>work at home often? In past tense, <i>did</i>
has a *punctiliar value: Did you work at home today?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Questions can be asked by (3) <u>intonation</u>raising
pitch pattern at the end of the sentence without changing the word order from
statement form: You are working at home today? This format is also used if
the questioner is expressing amazement, but the intonation is more exaggerated at
the end.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Questions can be asked (4) using *<u>interrogative
words</u>: (a) pronouns, <u>Who</u> is working at home today? (b) adverbs, <u>When</u>
do you working at home? <u>How</u> do you get any work done at home? Where
do you work at home? (c) adjectives, <u>Which</u> day do you work at home?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Hellenistic Greek, <i>ou(k)</i> + indicative
implies that the speaker expects a positive response from the hearer, while <i>mee</i>
+ indicative implies he anticipates a negative response.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin uses for anticipated negative response
and for anticipated positive response. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *rhetorical question;
*direct question, *indirect question; *informational question; *interrogative
sentence)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>question anticipating negative response</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
You arent working at home today, are you? <i>vs.</i> question anticipating
positive response: You are working at home today, arent you?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek uses <i>mee</i> plus indicative: Jn <b>4</b>:4</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin uses </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with question; *question anticipating
positive response; *informational question; *rhetorical question)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>question anticipating positive response</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
You are working at home today, arent you? <i>vs.</i> question anticipating
negative response: You arent working at home today, are you?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek uses <i>ou</i> plus indicative for positive
response: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin uses </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *question anticipating
negative response; *informational question; *question)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>question mark</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the symbol (?) at the end of English sentences to indicate a *direct question. Spanish
puts an upside-down question on the front of the sentence as well ( . . . ?). Greek
uses a mark that resembles a semi-colon (;). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>questionnaire</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a form piece used for gathering information as when taking a survey. Sometimes
used in preliminary research for doctorate degrees in certain fields like
education. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>quiescent letters</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Hebrew letters that lose their consonantal value under special circumstances: aleph,
he, heth, yod</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>quip</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short
*comment, often with a humorous or sarcastic tone (in a set with *comment,
*commentary)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>quotation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a repeating of the words of another text in contrast to simply referring to its
location or its idea (in a set with *citation, *reference, *paraphrase,
verbatim) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>radical</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: one of the most
basic sounds in root. Hebrew, for example, has verbs with three radicals,
meaning three root consonants on which all the forms of the word are based.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rambling</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: not maintain a
set train of thought on the same subject</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rant</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a *diatribe</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>read response theory</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an approach to interpretation that blurs the distinction between the readers
impressions, inferences, and applications, on the one hand, and the authors
intended meaning, on the other.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>reading</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) a public
reading of usually another persons writing; (2) the wording of a particular
manuscript or family of manuscripts that differ from others at a given point. (in
a set with *oration, *declamation, *speech)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rebus</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a representation
of words in the form of a picture or non-alphabetic symbols; can be used as a
kind of puzzle</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>recension</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a critical edition of a text in order to restore the most likely reading, given
the sources available.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>recessive accent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an accent pattern where the accent moves back from the end of the word as far
as rules of accenting allow. In Greek, recessive accent goes as far back as the
length of the *ultima allows. It is an acute accent that goes back only to the
penult if the ultima is long but back to the antepenult if the ultima is short,<i>
</i>i.e., if it has a short vowel. Finite verbs generally have recessive accent
as do infinitives and participles in the present tense and future active and
middle voices. Elsewhere accents on infinitives and participles are not
recessive. The <i>ma</i> nouns of the third declension have recessive accent.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *accent; *persistent
accent) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>reciprocal pronoun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
English words and phrases for include <i>each other</i>, <i>one another, one to
another.</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek has <i>alleeloon</i>; it also can
use number-article-number for this value: <i>heis ton heis </i>(1 Th <b>5</b>:11).
<i>Heautoon</i>, originally a third-person *reflexive pronoun, can be used
reciprocally: Mk <b>1</b>:27; <b>9</b>:10; Lk <b>17</b>:3; 1 Cor <b>6</b>:7;
Eph<b> 4</b>:32; <b>5</b>:19; Heb <b>3</b>:13; 1 Pet <b>4</b>:8; Jude 20? Mt <b>11</b>:16
may use <i>heteros</i> reciprocally. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> NOTE: <i>alleeloon</i> can be simply
relational without being also reciprocal; that is, one to another rather than
to one another : (). In the relational sense, the action may be one
directional rather than both directions. The distinction comes into play in
discussing Pauls household directives for a husband-wife, parent-child,
master-slave relationships (Eph <b>5</b>:21).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in in a set with *pronouns; *differential
pronouns, *indefinite pronouns, indefinite relative pronouns, *personal
pronouns, *intensive pronouns, *interrogative pronouns, *reflexive pronouns,
*relative pronouns.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>recital</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a detailed
account of certain events. <i>Recital </i>usually refers to music presentations
while <i>recitation</i> refers to verbal presentations</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>recite</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to *say a piece
as with children at a Christmas Eve service. To take part in an academic class
where the teacher/professor directs question to members of the class.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>recitation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the delivery of a memorized piece. A type of class, particularly at the
collegiate level where the professor and the students interact as in
question-answer give and take in contrast to a lecture, practicum, colloquium,
reading course, seminar.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>recursive </span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>red-letter *edition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a *version of the New Testament that puts the words of Jesus in red letters,
usually a King James Version</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>redactor</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an editor, reviser,
one who prepares material for publication. In the study of ancient writings,
the redactor is sometimes postulated as extending himself into the adjusting of
content beyond adjusting the form of it. Such a process might involve
conflating various sources of material, say, on the life of Christ.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>redundant</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
widow woman</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>redundancy</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
unnecessarily saying the same thing twice:  . . . <u>but</u> its a team game,
<u>though</u>; <u>ir</u>regardless; variety of <u>different</u> __; closely
scrutinize. A set of expressions where one element does not contribute
anything beyond what would be said without it. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In the past, grammarians have considered refer
back as redundant; but the back element is not any longer consciously
associated with <i>re</i> as a words subunit; a person can refer to
something on the next page. So, it is not such a mistake any moreexcept
perhaps in formal writing.  Sometimes an expression that, strictly
speaking, is redundant may be used for emphasis. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Redundancy can be used for *emphasis
(pronoun plus person-and-number verb ending). (in a set with *double signal,
*emphasis) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>reduplication</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In <u>Greek</u> verbs, reduplication was a prefix to the root of verbs in the
perfect tenses as part of the sign for those tenses. <u>Roots beginning with a single
consonant</u> reduplicated by doubling the consonant with an epsilon between. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>For roots beginning with vowels/diphthongs</u>,
reduplication equaled augmentwhether before smooth or rough breathing. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Initial fricatives</u> were
reduplicated by adding the corresponding voiceless stop + epsilon. That pattern
obtained because the language would not allow successive syllables to start
with fricatives (except in rare cases were the successive fricatives appeared
from back to front of the mouth). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:.5in'><u><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>Initial double consonants</span></u><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(<i>xs,
ps</i>) were reduplicated by prefixing an <i>e</i>like syllabic augment. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Some verbs that began with <u>vowel +
consonant</u> reduplicated by doubling the set: ollumi &lt;olooleka. <u>Initial
<i>rho</i></u> was reduplicated the same way as augment; the rho was doubled
with <i>e</i> prefixed: <i>riptoo</i> &gt; <i>erripha</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In <u>Latin</u>, reduplication is just one
of several possible additions?alterations to verb roots to create perfect
tenses. The vowel between the repeated initial root consonant may be an e or
some other vowel. A root vowel may be lengthened (sometimes as compensation for
the loss of a root letter): fugio/fgi, venio/v</span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Comic Sans MS"'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ni,
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *augment, *tense formative,
*tense sign)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>reference</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(in a set with a *verse, *chapter, *paragraph, *book, *volume). In biblical references
there are two levelschapter and verse except for the short New Testament books
that do not have chapter divisions. In longer ancient works, there may be three
levels: , book, and paragraph.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>reference book/reference work</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a book not intended to be read straight through. It is consulted topically for
a readers specific interest or need at the time. It is organized
alphabetically by key words or perhaps organized around some outline that gives
efficient access to the matter a hand.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>referent</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the reality a
term or expression refers to (<i> vs.</i> *antecedent)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>reflexive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
what later in the sentence makes reference to the subject of the clause</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>reflexive pronoun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
A pronoun that refers to the subject of the same clause; consequently, in
inflected languages reflexive pronouns have no *nominative case forms. To
create reflexive pronouns, English uses the <i>self</i>/<i>-selves </i>suffix
on <i>my-, our-, your-, him-, her-, it-, them<b>-</b></i> (but not on <i>I/me,
we/us, you, he/his/she/it,</i> or <i>they/their</i>). It is understandable that
<i>self</i> does not combine with nominative forms of pronouns because
reflexives refer to the subject from elsewhere in the sentence. More
complicated is the fact that in first and second persons, the <i>self</i>/-<i>selves
</i>suffix is added to the possessive pronoun form, but in the third person -<i>self</i>
is added to the objective/accusative form of the pronoun rather than the
possessive. As a result, it is considered ungrammatical to say <i>meself</i>, or
<i>hisself</i>, <i>theirselves</i>, and <i>itself</i> is not spelled <i>it<u>s</u>self</i>,
which would be a possessive form attached to <i>self</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  <u>singular</u> <u>plural
</u></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> 1 myself ourselves</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> 2 yourself yourselves</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> 3 himself/herself/itself themselves</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Older English did not distinguish between
reflexive and personal pronouns: Now I lay <u>me</u> down to sleep; the
wickedness of the wicked shall be on <u>him</u> [that is, upon himself] (Ezek <b>18</b>:20,
KJV). Not to be confused with *intensive pronouns, which rename the noun and
so exist in all cases in inflected languages.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Sometimes English speakers slip into using
reflective pronouns in the place of personal pronouns: He brought it to <u>myself</u>.
The mistake possibly comes from the speakers desire to avoid making himself
sound egotistical.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek used <i>heautou</i> for third-person
reflexives, <i>seautou</i> for second-person reflexives, and <i>emautou</i> for
first-person reflexives. In the New Testament the third-person reflexive was
sometimes used as a *reciprocal pronoun as well (). Finally, the third-person
reflexives took on the value of a second-person reflexive (Acts <b>5</b>:35).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>reflexive pronominal adjectives</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Modern English does not distinguish in form between reflexive pronominal
adjectives and plain pronominal adjectives (my/mine, our/ours, your/yours, his,
her, its, their/theirs) unless confusion of reference might occur. In that
case, <i>own</i> can be added after the basic form, but doing so adds an
emphasis not otherwise present: examples</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin does not distinguish reflexive and
personal pronouns of the first and second persons. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek uses emautou, seautou, heautou. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>reflexive verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Latin, a verb that has the subject acting on itself: <u>Utor</u> Close to
the Greek *middle voice and a regular Latin verb plus *reflexive pronoun.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>reflexive-possessive adjective</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
adjectives may indicate either a reflexive or possessive idea: Ceasar ate <u>his</u>
lunch [that is, his own lunch], in contrast to Ceasar ate <u>his</u> lunch
[that is, Ciceros lunch]. English often does not differentiate possessive
from possessive-reflexive unless confusion would result. It can add <u>own</u>,
as in <u>his own</u>, <u>their own</u>, <u>our own</u>, <u>my own</u>, <i>etc.</i>,
to avoid misunderstanding, if need be. Adding <u>own</u>, however, brings
emphasis into the picture, which alters the meaning somewhat.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>regionalism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a usage distinctive to one area within a languages domain </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *archaism, *buzz word,
*catch phrase, *colloquialism, *curse word, *formal term, *informal term, *oath,
*obsolete term, *provincialism, *slang, *technical term, *vulgarism) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>regular</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: following the
expected pattern for making a plurals, for moving through its inflectional
forms (nouns, adjectives, and verbs), for creating principal parts (verbs), for
moving through the degrees of an adjective or adverb. Contrasts with *irregular.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Irregular comparison of adjectives</u>
and <u>irregular comparison of adverbs</u> mean that the roots of the three
degrees of the adjective or adverb do not come from the same root; they are
like the English good, better, best.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Irregular verbs</u> do not have principal
parts that are predictable given the first onelike the English <i>go, went,
gone</i>. (in a set with *defective verbs, *deponent verbs, *impersonal verbs,
*suppletive verbs)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Irregular</u> <u>nouns</u>, like <u>contract
nouns</u>, and <u>irregular adjectives</u>, like <u>contract adjectives</u> or
contract adjectives, also behave in some unusual way relative to regular noun
and adjective forms. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *indeclinable, *irregular
comparison of adjectives, *irregular comparison of adverbs, *irregular verbs) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>regular verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
verbs whose remaining principal parts are predictable from the first principal
part. In English there is <i>work, worked, worked</i>. In Latin there is <i>amo,
amare, amavi, amatus.</i> In Greek there is <i>luoo, lusoo, elusa, leluka,
lelumai, elutheen</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *irregular verb; *composite
verb, *defective verb, *deponent verb, *suppletive verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>reification</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the tendency to read off of a word a finite reality for the referent of the
word. Akin to supposing that the number of words equals the number of things; thus
<i>body, soul, </i>and <i>spirit</i> in 1 Th <b>5</b>:23 does not necessarily
indicate a tripartite nature for humankind. Just because we speak of a <u>will</u>,
a <u>mind</u>, a conscience, and the like, we do not necessarily commit
ourselves to the idea that there is a substance or otherwise-constituted part/thing
in us that is a will, a mind, a conscience. Instead, the experience of choosing,
feeling guilt, thinking, <i>etc</i>., are actions whose causes we do not know. They
are simply nouns for actions, not necessarily nouns for things. Reification is
the tendency to confuse reality and the language for reality.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *hendiadys)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rejoin</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to reply</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rejoinder</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a reply; a response in formal or public argumentation </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *surrejoinder)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>relate</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: give a account
of something that has happened (in a set with *narrate)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>related words</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another term for *cognates, those words that share a common *base/*root/*stem
within the same language: <i>create, creation, creative, creativity, creature, critter,
procreate, procreation, recreation</i>), across related languages that have
descended from the same earlier language (<i>amicus &gt;amigo </i>[Sp]<i>, ami </i>[Fr],<i>
amicable </i>[Eng], or a derivative and a word in some *parent language (<i>creo
</i>[Lat] <i>&gt; create, </i>etc.). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *cognates, *derivatives;
*infixes,*prefixes, *suffixes; *word building).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>relative clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a clause type that has a relative pronoun or relative adjective (who,
which, that, whose). A relative clause usually has an adjective value, but
in older English and in Greek it could have a nominal value: <u>Whom the gods
love</u> dies young.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>relative clause of characteristic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a relative clause type in Latin that has a general reference for the pronoun rather
than a specific person or thing. The relative-clause verb is subjunctive
instead of indicative, as it is with regular relative clauses.   </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>relative clause of purpose</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
wh 313#113</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>relative pronouns</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Relative pronouns relate a noun in the main clause to some piece of added
information expressed in a separate clause that has an adjective value. Depending
on how they are considered, English may be said to have three relative
pronouns: <u>who</u>/whose/whom, <u>which</u>/whose, and <u>that</u>/whose. <u>Who</u>
applies to persons, <u>which</u> applies to things, and <u>that</u> is for
either one. <u>Which</u> is used on the front of *non-restrictive relative
clauses; <u>that</u> is used on the front of *restrictive ones. <u>That</u> is
not used as an object of prepositions (except postpositive ones); <u>which</u>
or <u>whom</u> replaces <u>that</u> in such a situation unless the construction
is rephrased to put <u>that</u> at the end. Relative pronouns are often
omitted in English: Hes the man [that] I love; The man [that] I gave my
book to. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English prefers <u>what</u> to <u>that
which</u>. In common speaking, <u>who</u> replaces <u>whom</u> as the
accusative for direct objects and objects of postpositive prepositions
(expressed or implied). Usually with postpositive prepositions, speakers
substitute <i>that</i> for <i>who/m</i> in the latter circumstance.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In practice, a relative pronoun does not
necessarily have the nearest previous noun as its antecedent. If the intended
antecedent is obvious from context or the nature of the case, the speaker need
not worry about putting the earlier noun closest to the relative. The
antecedent may be the phrase head rather than, say, the object of the adjectival
prepositional phrase attached to it: She has a <i>heart</i> for people <u>that</u>
shows itself in her concern for the poor. Since Latin and Greek have
declinable relative pronouns, the problem of ambiguous antecedents is virtually
always eliminated because position replaces case form.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Unlike English, Greek has one relative
pronoun in three genders: <i>hos, hee, ho</i>. Likewise, Latin has one relative
pronoun in three genders: <i>qui, quae, quod</i>. A relative pronoun gets
number and gender from its *antecedent, but case from its function within its
own clause.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin and Greek never omit relative
pronouns as English does. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> With relative pronouns in Greek, there is
the possibility of *attraction of case and *attraction of gender. Attraction of
case means that the relative pronoun can take the case of the antecedent rather
than the case called for within its own clause. It does so especially if the
antecedent is *ablative (in Latin).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Attraction of gender comes up when the
gender of the subject relative pronoun adopts the gender of the predicate
nominative.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrews all-purpose relative pronoun <i>asher</i>
is used in a redundant manner: The man <i>that</i> I gave the book <i>to him</i>.
Consequently, it is used in a looser way than relative pronouns in English,
Latin, and Greek. It simply links an element in the leading clause with a
dependent adjectival clause. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>relative time:</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A relative-time situation comes up in
Greek *indirect statement and *indirect question, where the subordinate verb-time
is relative to the main verb in contrast to a construction that puts both the dependent
verb <u>and</u> the main verb in relation to the speakers viewpoint in time. Another
way to put the matter is to say, Never change a tense in indirect discourse
[from what it would have been in the direct discourse form]. Relative time
occurs in Greek and Latin with indirect statement, which uses infinitive for
the verb idea. Indirect question in Latin uses a subjunctive clause and
sequential tense. (also in Housa?) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Relative time contrasts with *sequence of
tenses, or *absolute time, where all the verbs are figured from the speakers
viewpoint. Lat &amp; Gr) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *sequence of tense,
*absolute time)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>release</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: one way of
handling consonants on the end of a word. Italian tends to release the
consonant lightly after forming the sound (hence, the manner of mocking
English speakers might do with Italian). English goes to the sound and stops,
creating quite subtle differences that English speakers have learned to
distinguish (hi<u>p</u>, bi<u>t</u>, bi<u>c</u>; bi<u>b</u>, ba<u>d</u>, ba<u>g</u>;
mi<u>ff</u>, my<u>th</u>, Ba<u>ch</u>). French tends to omit such consonants
altogether unless the following word starts with a vowel it can be joined to.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>render/rendering</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another term for *translate/translation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>resh</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the twentieth
letter of the Hebrew alphabet: </span><b><span lang=HE dir=RTL
style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>reesonance</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
intensification of sounds while speaking</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>responsive reading</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a reading where the leader reads one verse of a text and the congregational
reads the next antiphonally (*antiphonal, *lining out)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>restrictive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in contrast to *non-restrictive; also called essential. Restrictive elements set
contrasts with other alternatives; non-restrictive elements characterize the
whole class in the manner described without having other specifics in view. Restrictive
identifies; non-restrictive describes. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In modern English, non-restrictive clauses
are set off with commas: Young people ought to pay attention to adults, who
know what young people are up against. The implication is that as a rule
adults know what young people are up against. Restrictive clauses are not set
off in commas: young people should pay attention to adults who know what young
people are up against, the implication being that young people need to listen
to that portion (restricted) of adults who do understand young peoples
