situation. Omitting a restrictive element changes the intended point of the
writer; omitting a non-restrictive element merely reduces the amount of
information given. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Which</u> rather than <u>that</u>
introduces English non-restrictive relative clauses (except to achieve variety
in sentences that would otherwise produce too many thats. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Non-restrictive prepositional phrases are
not set off by commas in English: xxxxxx. Non-restrictive adjectives also
exist.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Restrictive <i>vs.</i> non-restrictive is
a distinction that cannot be expressed in ancient written Greek, Latin, or Hebrew.
The idea has to be handled by a *circumlocution, and the interpretation of
modifying elements in these languages has to be figured out on the basis of the
nature of the situation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *non-restrictive) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>result clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a subordinate clause that indicates the consequence of action in the main
sentence.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>Classical Greek could distinguish between *actual
result, which came from <u>hoste</u> + an indicative-mood verb, and *tendential
result, which came from <u>hoste</u> + infinitive. The difference could be
expressed in English by in order that/so that/so for the former and so as to
for the latter.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin formula</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rsum</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a write-up of a
personal information provided in an application to a prospective employer. It
typically includes previous experience in the target area, educational
background, achievements, statements of interests, family status.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>retained object</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the accusative/objective form left over when an active-voice sentence is *transformed
into a passive-voice sentence with the former indirect object as the new
subject: She gave the poor dog <u>a bone</u>; the poor dog was given <u>a
bone</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>retort</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a sharp response
intended to negate another persons comment or express strong disagreement with
it</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>retroflexed</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
with the tongue bent upward and backward as in the Hebrew letters <i>samech</i>
and <i>tet</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>revise/revision</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to prepared a new edition of a text, which may consist of clarification,
addition, deletion, rearrangement, and the like.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rhetoric</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: in the ancients
rhetoric covered both oral and written effective speaking</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rhetorician</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a specialist in effective oral or written communication</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rhetorical question</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a question in form but not in meaning. Rhetorical questions do not call for an
answer; they are meant to fix attention on the point at issue: Are you
serious?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Biblical examples: A man cannot enter
into his mothers womb a second time and be born again, can he? (Jn <b>3</b>:4)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *informational question;
*question anticipating negative response, *question anticipating positive
response)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rho</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: seventeenth letter of
the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> /</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rhyme</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (or <i>rime</i>):
patterned like sounds. Rhyming can be classified in descending order of
likeness in sounding: *identical rhyme, *exact rhyme, *imperfect rhyme/*near
rhyme, *suspended rhyme, *rime riche, *eye rhyme. (in a set with *feminine
rhyme)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rhyme scheme</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
abab, abba, <i>etc</i>., where the terminal sound of the last word matches the
terminal sound of one of the subsequent lines in a patterned way. (in a set
with *meter; *poetry)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>riddle</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short,
enigmatic saying intended to challenge the hearer to figure out its meaning, a
meaning that may be associated with a subsequent course of action. Biblical
examples are Samsons riddle in Judges 14:14 and the Lords riddle in Ezek <b>17</b>.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *enigma)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rime riche</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the rhyming of homonyms: to, too, two (get other examples)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Roman numerals</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a system of numbering in which <b>I = 1</b> (II + 2, III = 3, IV = 4), <b>V = 5</b>
(VI = 6, VII = 7, VIII = 8, IX = 9), <b>X = 10,</b> (XV = 15, XIX = 19), <b>XX
= 20,</b> (XL = 40, VL =45), <b>L = 50, C = 100, D = 500, M = 1,000</b>. (in a
set with *arabic numbers)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Romance language</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
any one of the languages with a Latin heritage: Spanish, French, Portugese,
Romanian, Italian. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>root</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the essential
part of a word onto which *morphemes are added to adjust for more specific
meanings. Often used for the common background behind several languages that
have descended from a common source, as with Latin behind the *Romance
languages. More broadly <u>root</u> can carry back to the Sanskrit behind
Latin, Greek, and other related languages. (in a set with *stem, *base). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>root aorist</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek, some verbs add the personal endings directly to the root without
first attaching a *tense sign: bainoo &gt; ebeen; chairoo &gt; echareen;
gi[g]nooskoo &gt; egnoon; as well as the short forms of some mi verbs like didoomi
&gt; dos, <i>etc.</i>; titheemi &gt; thes, <i>etc.</i>; histeemi &gt; esteen, <i>etc.</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>round number</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an *approximate number that is close enough for the purposes of a given communication
(in a set with *numbers)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rounded</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>vowel</b>: a
vowel sound adjusted by rounding the lips slightly during *pronunciation. It
is indicated in writing by the German *unlaut, a horizontal double dot that
looks like a *dier</span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sis
(). German also has indicated rounding by putting an <i>e</i> after the vowel.
<b>Check </b>A letter with a slash through it is also a way of writing a
rounded letter (in Dutch?): , . </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Royal Law, The</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the title James uses for the second great commandment (<b>2</b>:8): Love your
neighbor as yourself. (in a set with The *First Great Commandment, The *Second
Great Commandment, The *Royal Law)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>run-on sentence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
two independent clauses that are not properly joined by a conjunction or
appropriate punctuation; also a *fused sentence</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rune</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sade/sadhe/tsade</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the eighteenth letter of the Hebrew alphabet</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Sapphic stanza</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
type of poetic meter (wh 337)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>salutation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(a) spoken: words said when people meet: Hello; How are you? How are you
doing? Hows it going? Its good to see you, John. Greetings, everyone. Good
morning. Hey, man. Such words of recognition are often accompanied by *gestures
(*kinesics) like a handshake or a wave of the hand during the approach. These
latter expressions differ, of course, from culture to culture and even within
the larger culture (type of handshake, <i>etc.</i>).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> It is interesting to see what people do
when they meet for the second, third, or fourth time in a short space of time. Eye
contact and a smile may be about it. When two people meet for the first time
and when names are exchanged in the process, virtually always they will shake
hands.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (b) written: the hello near the
beginning of a personal letter. New Testament examples: Acts ; Since most New
Testament writings from Romans through Revelation are in letter form, they
begin with a salutation (except for Galatians). Paul likes to include <i>chapein
&gt;chapis </i>(<i>grace</i>), a play on the normal salutation in Greek letters
(<i>chapein</i>).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *greeting, *complementary
close, *inside address, *pleasantries, *postscript, *PS, *signature)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>samek/samekh</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the fifteenth letter of the Hebrew alphabet: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sampi</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: same as *san,
Greek symbol for nine hundred.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>san</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: same as *sampi, Greek
symbol for nine hundred.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sandhi</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: sound
modification in a word depending on its connections with surrounding sounds: the
difference between <i>dont</i> in <i>dont you</i> and <i>dont we</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sarcasm</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a comment
intended to ridicule: What else is new?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sass</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: *backtalk, *lip;
disrespectful talk, especially by a young person to an adult, a parent,
teacher, policeman.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>satire/satirist</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>saturation language learning</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a method of teaching a language that reproduces as much as possible the way
someone learns a first language. (in a set with *analytical language learning)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>say</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: broad enough to include
expressing the meaning of a word, <i>etc.</i> <i>vs.</i> pronounce, which is
limited to the sounding of the word; can be a synonym for recite.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a saying</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an *adage, *apothegm,
*proverb, *maxim; a traditional, memorable expression for some notable idea: Dont
put off till tomorrow what you can do today.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>scan</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to analyze the
metrical pattern in poetry</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>scene</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a division of an
act in a play</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>schema</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the label for
the text containing the first Great Commandment (Deut <b>6</b>:4). It is a
second-person, singular, masculine command-form meaning hear. The accent is
on the last syllable with the <i>e</i> receiving only light pronunciation
(since its a <i>sheva</i>); it is erroneously pronounced (Anglicized) <i>shema</i>
in popular English usage.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>scholium</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an explanatory
note in the margin especially of an ancient text.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>scorn</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to disdain,
ridicule</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>scrawl</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to write by hand
in a hurried, hard-to-read, drawn-out fashion </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *scribble)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>scribal error</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
means a copying mistake in a manuscript in contrast to an error by the author. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>scribble: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>to
write in a sloppy, illegible fashion. (in a set with *writing, *printing, block
lettering): </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>scribe</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: one who wrote by
hand what someone else writes, including the copying of manuscripts and taking
dictation for various kinds of *missives. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *amanuensis, *notary, *stenographer,
*scrivener) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>script</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a kind of
writing, letter formation, alphabet. (in a set with *italics, *font)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>scriptorium</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a room set aside for copying manuscripts</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>scripture</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
what is written [&lt; Lat. scribere, to write] Scripture is the normative
literature of a religion, especially so used in Jewish and Christian contexts. It
differs from a *creed, *deutero-[Pauline], *commentaries, or *devotional
literature by being the foundational literature, whereas a creed is an
authoritative summary of scriptural teaching on central issues.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>scripture portions</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Several identifiable scripture portions have come to have names. Among the more
familiar are the following:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The Annunciation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The Benedictus</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The Cry of Dereliction</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The Golden Rule</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The Good Confession</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The Great Commission</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

"Times New Roman",serif'> The Song of Deborah</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The Ten Commandments</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The Tersanctus (same as The Trishagion)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The Three Witnesses Passage</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The Trishagion (same as The Tersanctus)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>scriptures</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
<u>the</u> scriptures identifies the whole set of foundational literature for
the Christian faith.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>scrivener</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a scribe, a professional copyist; a notary (in a set with *scribe, notary,
*stenographer, *amanuensis, ) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>scroll</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a writing that
is rolled up instead of having leaves. (in a set with *codex, *book)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>second aorist</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek, second aorists were verbs that did not use the sigma-alpha sign
(*first aorists) for the aorist active and middle voice. Instead, they used
endings like those of the imperfect. (in a set with *first aorist)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>second aorist passive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek, second aorist passives were verbs that lacked the theta part of the
theta-eta sign of the aorist passive/future passive stemsixth principal part
(egrapheen, for example, &lt; graphoo). (in a set with *first aorist passive)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>second deponent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a Greek verb that lacks both an active and middle voiceat least in some of the
principal parts. A full second deponent will have no second or third principal
part since those forms provide the bases for active and middle voice. (in a set
with *deponent, *first deponent, *semi-deponent)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>second perfect</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a Greek verb that lacks the kappa part of its more usual kappa-alpha sign (in a
set with *first perfect)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>second attributive position</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a feature of Greek grammar that puts an *attributive adjective after a nouns
repeated article after the noun, creating an article-noun article-adjective sequence.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In the New Testament this format seems to
appear more frequently than in classical Greek perhaps under the influence of
the writers native Hebrew. An adjective-noun combination in Hebrew had an
article (ha-) prefixed to both the noun and its modifier: the man the great (<u>ha</u>adam
<u>hag</u>gadol). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Second attributive position seems to give
more emphasis on the adjective than first attributive position does (article
adjective noun): Jn <b>18</b>:32. Heb <b>11</b>:12 and Mt <b>25</b>:41 have
double repeated articles. Jn <b>14</b>:27 has noun article adjective. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Second attributive position can be
occupied by a preposition phrase that appears after the repeated article, just
as such a phrase can appear after the article of noun in first attributive
position: 2 Cor<b> 9</b>:1, 3.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *first attributive
position, *attributive adjective, *predicate adjective)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>second deponent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek, a verb that lacks the *middle voice as well as the *active. Such
verbs may have no second, third, or fourth principal parts because the second
and third provide the base for only the active and middle voices. (in as set
with *deponent, *first deponent, *semi-deponent))</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Second Great Commandment, The</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the commandment found in Lev <b>19</b>:18 (Mt<b> 22</b>:39; <b>19</b>:19): love
your neighbor as yourself. (in a set with The *Golden Rule, The *First Great
Commandment, The *Royal Law)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>second perfect</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek, second perfects were verbs that lacked the kappa part of the k(a) perfect
active tense sign.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>second person</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the one/ones spoken to, in contrast to the one/ones speaking or the one/ones
spoken about </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *first person, *third
person)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>secondary accent: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>on
longer English words there is a second lighter stress, as in ad<u>min</u>istration.
(in a set with *primary accent)<b>: </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>secondary endings: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>endings
used to indicate person in Greek *secondary tenses and the *optative mood. (in
a set with *primary endings) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>secondary tense</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the imperfect, aorist, and pluperfect tenses, so called in Greek because they
shared augment and the same set of personal endings. The imperfect and
pluperfect tenses in Latin.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>self-referencing</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a statement that includes its own content. The Great Commission is said to be
self-referencing in that teaching them everything I have commanded you
includes the directives in the Commission itself: going into all the world, teaching,
baptizing, and teaching.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>semaphore</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a system of signaling with flags in each hand to represent letters of the
alphabet and certain other messages. (in a set with *signaling)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>semateme</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an irreducible
unit of meaning WB</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>semantic</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: having to do
with *meaning as distinguished from *form (in a set with *meaning)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>semantics</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of meaning that distinguishes between variation in wording and
variation in meaning</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>semi-colon</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a punctuation mark that has the value of replacing a co-ordinating *conjunction
between independent clauses. It can be used group parts within a set or series
that has further internal subdivisions marked off by commas. Thus, it lies
between the disjunctive value of a *period and that of a *comma. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>semi-deponent</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Latin and Greek, a *deponent verb may not be deponent everywhere. Latin has
some verbs that are active in the present (non-perfect) system; but are
deponent in the perfect: audeo, audre, <u>ausus sum</u>; gaudeo, gaudre, <u>gravisus
sum</u>, soleo, solre, solitus sum. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek shows verbs that are deponent in
some tenses (principal parts), but not in others: <i>hamartanoo, <u>hamarteesomai</u>,
heemarton, heemarteeka, heemarteemai, heemarteetheen; </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>bainoo, <u>beesomai</u>, ebalon, bebleeka,
bebamai, ebatheen;</span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span lang=DE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ginomai, gneesomai, egenomeen, <u>gegona</u>,
egeneetheen; </span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span lang=DE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>gi[g]ooskoo, <u>gnoosomai</u>, egnoon,
egnooka, egnoosmai, egnoostheen; </span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span lang=DE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>dunamai, <u>duneesomai</u>, deduneemai,
eduneetheen;</span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span lang=DE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>erchomai, eleusomai, <u>eelthon</u>, <u>eleelutha</u>;
</span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span lang=DE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>esthioo, phagomai, ephagon;</span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span lang=DE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>thaumadzoo, thaumasomai, ethaumasa; </span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span lang=DE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>lambanoo, leepsomai, elabon, eileepha,
eileemmai, eleephtheen; </span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span lang=DE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>manthanoo, <u>matheesomai</u>, emathon,
mematheeka; </span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span lang=DE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>-vidzoo, -<u>nipsomai</u>, -enipsa,
-nenimmai;</span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span lang=DE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>horaoo, <u>opsomai</u>, eidon, heoraka,
eoofamai, oophtheen; </span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>pinoo, <u>piomai</u>, epion, pepooka,
-pepomai, -etotheen; </span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>piptoo, <u>pesoumai</u>, epeson, peptooka;
</span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>phthanoo, <u>phtheesomai</u>, ephtheezsa; </span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *deponent, *first deponent,
*second deponent)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>semiology</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the study of sign language and communication made by signaling.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>semiotic</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: having to do with
semantics</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sentence: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>an
expression deemed sufficient to express a thought that can stand by itself. (in
a set with *phrase, *clause) (in a set with *complex sentence, *compound
sentence, *compound-complex sentence, *elliptical sentence, *sentence fragment)
(in a set with declarative sentence, exclamatory sentence, interrogative
sentence) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sentence fragment</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a part of a sentence considered insufficient to express a thought adequately,
or to stand on its own.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>separable suffix</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a suffix that may also serve as a free-standing word<b>. </b>Latin <u>cum</u>
could stand alone meaning with, but with personal pronouns it was attached as
a suffix: nobis<u>cum</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Septuagint</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the standard Greek translation of the Hebrew Old Testament in use at the time
of Christ. Its name comes from the tradition that seventy translators in
Alexandria, Egypt, were involved in the effort (Gr. <i>septuagintos</i>,
seventy; note <u>The Letter of Aristeas</u>). It dates from about 180 B. C.
???? Its renderings lie behind most New Testament quotations of the Old
Testament instead of their being direct translations of the Hebrew. Often
abbreviated LXX.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sequel</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: another writing,
movie, or television show that piggybacks on a story already published or
aired. A procedure often followed when an original piece achieves unexpected
success.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *episode, *prequel)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sequence of tenses</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a tensing sequence that relates to the speakers viewpoint both the tense of the
dependent and the independent verb forms of a sentence. In English indirect
discourse, for example, the verb in the indirect discourse part is also past if
the main verb is past unless the dependent element expresses a timeless truth. Both
verb are figured from the time standpoint of the speaker. <b>Examples</b> Greek
and Latin, however, make indirect discourse verbs relative to the main verb
rather than relative to the speaker of the whole sentence. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *relative tense Wh 204,
*absolute time)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sequential dative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the dative case instead of the accusative after Latin and Greek verbs that
imply relationship: Latin had <i>credo</i> (trust), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek had <i>hepomai</i> (to follow),</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sequential infinitive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the standard infinitive that by convention follows a certain construction.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Persuade to do</i> is supposedly
preferrable to <i>convince </i>(<i>__</i>) <i>to do</i>; there is <i>angry at,
angry about, angry with</i>; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *complementary infinitive)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sequential preposition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the standard preposition used after a certain term. We say, allergic <i>to</i>
hay, not allergic <i>with</i> hay. <i>Enamored <u>of</u></i> sounds stilted;
most people today say <i>enamored <u>with</u></i>. Is it <i>sign <u>of</u></i>
or <i>sign <u>for</u></i>? Is it <i>convince someone <u>of</u></i> (with preposition)
or <i>convince them to __</i> (infinitive)? </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>serial comma</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a comma between the last two nouns of a series, a set that has three or more
entries. Publishers differ as to whether their editors put a comma between the
next-to-last and last noun in a series of three or more. An advantage of using
the serial comma is that a distinction can then be made if the last items are
thought of as a pair like ham and eggs. In such a case the comma would be
omitted </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Commas are used in a sequence of
adjectives intended to be parallel rather than in series before a noun. The
arrangement has the effect of connecting each adjective directly to the noun
instead of piggy-backing each one on the rest as a set. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> For this reason, commas are used when
adjectives are not sequenced in the linguistically conventional pattern of the language.
An English convention in serial modifiers is *determiner, size, color: that
big red barn; but if the convention is departed from, a comma is required: that
red, big barn. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Another application of commas in series is
found when more than one long or hyphenated adjective ties to one noun: my
ever-ready, happy-go-lucky brother. The comma helps the readers eye see how
the relationship of words. Besides, the spoken equivalent requires a pause
after the first hyphenation so the hearer can separate the first set and the
second set as, in fact, two sets further tied to the *phrase head. The written
comma represents the oral pause.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In a related situation, commas are used to
avoid ambiguity: the advertisement goes real, comfortable jeans rather than
real comfortable jeans. The latter format sounds like an every-day expression
for really comfortable jeans. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>serial modifiers</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a series of adjective or adverbs connected with the same phrase head. If
thought of as each one directly modifying the phrase head, commas are
interposed. If thought of as each one tied to the remaining words as a group,
no commas appear.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>seriatim</span></i></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in various places; used in citations to note that the point of interest shows
up in several places throughout the work being cited.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>serif</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short, thin,
line optionally added to the ends of a stroke in forming letters like <i>A, E,
F, G, H, I, K, L, M, N, P, R, S, T, V, W, Z.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sermon</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a presentation
appropriate to a religious setting. In New Testament literature, it has been
customary to call sermon The Sermon on the Mount (Mt <b>5-7</b>), The Sermon
on the Plain (Lk <b>6</b>:17-49 ), Peters sermon at Pentecost (Acts <b>2</b>:14-40)
and at the household of Cornelius (Acts <b>10</b>:34-43) as well as Pauls
sermon on Mars Hill (the Areopagus, Acts <b>17</b>:22-31). There is some overlap
in custom of usage with *speech (<i>q.v.)</i> as types of *discourse.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *speech; *discourse)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sermon, outreach</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
intended primarily for those not already members of the body of Christ</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sermon series</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a set of sermons delivered over several meeting times, usually related to one
another in some way</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sermonize</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to prepare sermons; with a pejorative turn, to carry on orally about some
matter</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sestet</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a set of six
lines of poetry; the last six lines of a Petrarchan *sonnet.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sesquipedalian</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a long word; given to the use of long words; ponderous because polysyllabic</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>set</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a group of volumes that
form the whole of perhaps an authors complete works or several authors books
that belong together; The Ante-Nicene Fathers, <i>e.g.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>set expression</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a monolithic phrase, thought of as an <u>indivisible unit</u>as with titles: I
wanted to see the new version of <i>The King and I </i>[not The King and <i>Me</i>].
<i>Set expression</i> can apply to phrase <u>idioms<i> </i></u>that could be regarded
as <u>hyphenatable expressions</u>: By tomorrow, Ill be <i>good and </i>ready
[adj]. He was <i>the man of the hour</i> [noun]. She went <i>over and above
</i>the call of duty [phrase preposition]. <i>By and </i>large, we have
avoided that problem [adv]. Well, <i>shut the front door </i>[interjection]!</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Biblical examples of set phraseology
include (1) God/___ do more to me/___ and more also (Ruth <b>1</b>:17; 1
Sam <b>3</b>:17; <b>20</b>:13; <b>25</b>:22; 2 Sam <b>3</b>:35);</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) What have I/___ to do with you/___
(Jud <b>11</b>:12; 2 Sam <b>16</b>:10; <b>19</b>:22; 1 Kg <b>17</b>:18; 2 Kg <b>3</b>:13;
2 Ch <b>35</b>:21, Jn <b>2</b>:4; Mk<b> 1</b>:24 = Lk <b>4</b>:34; Mt <b>8</b>:29
= Mk <b>5</b>:7 = Lk<b> 8</b>:28)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sheva/shewa/schwa</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a lightly expressed vowel like the <i>e</i> in <i>b<u>e</u>cause</i>. It is a
recurring phenomenon in Hebrew with unaccented syllables. Commonly written as
an upside-down, lower-case <i>e</i> []. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>shift</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a systematic
phonetic change such as the American replacement of <i>ah</i> with <i></i> as
in <i>hat</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *itization???)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>shin</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the twenty-first
letter of the Hebrew alphabet. Also <i>sin</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>shoot the wad</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to use up ones material way before the time allotted for the presentation,
much earlier than anticipated</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>short</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the first part
of a longer word used orally to save time or effort; in written form they are
not normally followed by a period: <i>amp (amplifier), meds (medications), reps
(repetitions in an exercise event), tat (tattoo), trig, uke (ukelele), ref
(referee) , ump (umpire) </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *abbreviation, *acronym,
*acrostic)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>shorthand</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a system of notation that enables a *stenographer to keep up with the pace of
normal oral delivery and dictation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sibilant</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a hissing sound:
<i>s, z, sh, zh</i> (voiced <i>sh</i>), <i>tz, dz,</i> retroflexed <i>s</i> (as
in the Hebrew <i>samech</i> <i>vs.</i> <i>sin</i> or <i>shin</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sibilate</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to make a
hissing sound</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sic</span></i></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a bracketed
entry inside a quotation which indicates that the quotation is exact despite
some error of content or form. A Latin word meaning <i>thus</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sidebar</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: in a written
presentation, supplementary or explanatory material that lies outside the
general flow of the presentation, especially in computer-assisted deliveries </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *endnote, *footnote,
*marginal note, *marginalia, *side note)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sidenote</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a comment
written in the margin of a text to given clarification to something in the
text; also an aside in oral presentation </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *endnote, *footnote,
*marginal note, *marginalia, *sidebar)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sigla</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.5in'><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sigma</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
eighteenth letter of the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>with
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
as its lower-case terminal form and C in the uncial manuscripts</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sigmoid</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: shaped like the
letter <i>s</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sign language</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a system of *gestures/signals with the fingers, hands, and arms used for
communicating among the deaf. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *alphabet, *dactylology,
*manual alphabet, *signing)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sign manual</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a handwritten signature by a king at the top of a royal decree</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>signalment</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a detailed description of a persons appearance</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>signage</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the labels
placed on a business or public building that identifies it or its function.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>signal word</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a term that appears, say, in the main clause of Latin sentences that helps distinguish
a subsequent result clause (sic, qualis, quantum, talis, tantum) from a
concessive clause (tamen)(wh ch 31, p 197), adversative clause, and the like.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>signaling</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
communicating through visual, sound, electronic (including radar) means as with
smoke signal, pyrotechnics (fire words in various colors), flag hoists (colored
flags hung on a ships mast), radio, television, telephone, teletype. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>signature</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the author//buyers handwritten name at the end of a letter or on an official
document, used for guaranteeing authenticity. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *inside address, *salutation,
*complementary close, *postscript)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>signing</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: using a system
of *gestures/signals with the fingers, hands, and arms to communicate with the
deaf.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *alphabet, *dactylology,
*manual alphabet, *signing)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sign-off</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a stylized
manner of closing a radio or television program</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>silent letter</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a written letter that does not represent a sound spoken. In Greek, Latin, and
Hebrew, there were no silent letters. English has more silent letters than most
modern languages do. Several reasons contribute to this phenomenon: (1) a
letter that retains an unused or unpronounceable derivational element. When the
n/g/c endings on old Latin and Greek nouns were dropped, the word remaining
letters sometimes created unpronounceable combinations: <i>paradigm-os</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>gh</i> in many words this *digraph is
silent: <i>aught, bough, bought</i>, <i>blight</i>, <i>bright, brought, caught,
delight, dough, drought, fight, flight, fraught, haughty, height, high/higher, light,
might/mighty, naughty, nigh, night, nought, ought,</i> <i>plight</i>, <i>right,
sigh/sighing, slaughter, sleigh, slight, sought, th(o)rough, tight,</i> <i>weigh/weight,</i>
<i>wright, wrought</i>, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  ((-<i>gh</i> can also be be <i>f</i>:
<i>enough, rough, slough, tough,</i> )) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>-<i>gm</i>
at the end of a word has the <i>g</i> silent: <i>diaphragm</i> (but <i>diaphragmatic</i>),
<i>paradigm</i> (but paradigmatic), <i>phlegm </i>(flem), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>gn</i> at the end of words has the <i>g</i>
silent: <b>[insert panel]</b> <i>align, assign, benign, deign, design </i>but <i>designation</i>)<i>,
feign, foreign, malign (but malignant), reign, resign </i>(but <i>resignation</i>)<i>,
sign </i>(but <i>signature</i>), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> gn- </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>at
the beginning of words keeps the <i>g</i> silent: <i>gnarl, gnash, gnat,
gnathic, gnathite, gnaw, gneiss, gnocchi, gnome, gnomon, gnosis, gnu.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>h</i> in <i>wh</i> is often not
pronounced by many American English speakers: <i>which</i> (= witch). But <i>whale,
what, when. </i>Sometimes it is the <i>w </i>of <i>wh</i> that is dropped: <i>who,
whom, whose</i>; <i>whole.</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>kn- </i>does not pronounce the <i>k</i>
on the front of words:<i> knack, knap, knave, knee, kneel, knell, knife,
knight, knit, knob, knock, knoll, knop, knot, know, knuckle, knur, knurl. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> -pn </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>in<i>
pneumonia</i>, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
