text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ps</i> in <i><u>p</u>sycho</i>-, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>pt</i> in <i><u>pt</u>yalism, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> -rh-</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
is pronounced as if it were simply <i>r</i>: <i>rhabdon, rhabdomancy,
rhabdomyoma, rhabdovirus, Rhadamanthine, rhapsodic, rhapsodist, rhapsodize,
rhapsody, rhatany, rhea, rhenium, rheology, rheometer, rheostt, rheotaxis,
rhesus, rhetor, rhetoric, rhetorical, rhetorician, rheum, rheumatic,
rheumatism, rheumatoid, rhinal, rhinencephalon, rhinestone, rhinoceros</i>, <i>rhinology,
rhinopharyngitis, rhinoplasty, rhinoscopy, rhinovirus, rhizanthous, rhizobium,
rhizocephalan, rhizogenic, rhizoid, rhizome, rhizopod, rhizopus, rhizosphere,
rhirhizotomy, rho, rhodium, rhodochrosite, rhododendron, rhodolite, rhodorite,
rhodopsin, rhodora, rhombencephalon, rhombic, rhombohedron, rhombold, rhombus, rhonchus,
rhubarb, rhumb, rhyme, rhyolite, rhythm, rhythmic, rhythmist, </i>(The <i>rh </i>combination
descends from Greek. The <i>rho </i>on the front of Greek words was
aspiratedaccompanied by an <i>h </i>sound.)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>-<i>rrh</i>-
is pronounced as if it were simply <i>r</i>: suffixes in <i>r<u>rh</u>agia, r<u>rh</u>aphy,-r<u>rh</u>ea,
</i>-<i>r<u>rh</u>exis</i> ; <i>cirrhosis</i>,  (The -<i>rrh </i>combination
descends from Greek. The <i>rho </i>on the front of Greek words was
aspiratedaccompanied by an <i>h </i>sound. If an <i></i> was prefixed to it
for *augment purposes, the <i>rho </i>was first doubled. Derivatives into
English have maintained that general pattern by doubling the <i>r </i>whenever
anything is put ahead of <i>rh</i>. Consequently, English words have <i>rrh </i>in
the middle and at the end of all words derived from Greek)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>w-</i> is silent on the beginning of <i>wr-</i>
words: <b>[insert panel] </b><i>wrach, wraith, wrangle, wrapper, wrasse,
wrath/e, wreak, wrech,wreck </i>(<i>etc.</i>), <i>wren, wrest, wrestle, wretch,
wriggle, wright, wring/wrang/wrung, wrinkle, wrist,
writ/write/wrote/writing/written</i>, <i>wrong, wroth, wrought, wry.</i> It is
silent also on the beginning of <i>who, whom, whose, whole.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> -w</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> is
silent on the end of words like <i>bellow, blow, barrow, borrow, bow<sup>1</sup>,
crow, farrow, flow, glow, grow, harrow, hollow, know, low, marrow, mellow,
morrow, mow<sup>1</sup>, narrow, pillow, row<sup>1</sup>, sallow, sew, sorrow,
sow<sup>1</sup>, sparrow, tallow, tomorrow, tow; caw, claw, craw, draw, flaw,
gnaw, heehaw, in-law, jaw, law, maw, outlaw, slaw, straw, yaw; </i>But there is
a <i>wuh</i> sound on the end of other words: <i>allow, bow<sup>1</sup>, brow,
cow, how, mow<sup>1</sup>, now, ow!, plow, pow, prow, sow<sup>1</sup>, vow, wow.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The acceptable sound combinations of
modern English do not correspond with the pronunciation habits of ancient our Greek,
Latin, and Anglo-Saxon heritage. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) a letter that is simply not pronounced
in some forms of the root: <i>answer, bristle, condemn but </i>condemnation), <i>debt,
deign, design </i>(but <i>designation</i>)<i>, dythyramb, ensign, exhume, hustle,
of<u>t</u>en, mistletoe, mus<u>c</u>le </i>(but <i>muscular), reign </i>(but <i>regnal),
resign </i>(but <i>resignation</i>)<i>, sa<u>l</u>ve </i>(but <i>salvation</i>)<i>,
sign </i>(but <i>signature</i>)<i>, sof<u>t</u>en </i>(but <i>softer</i>). <i>su<u>b</u>tle</i>
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Words with terminal <i>ld</i> sound
sometimes lose the <i>l</i>: <i>could, should, would</i> (but <i>billed, bold,
cold, culled, dulled, foaled, fold, fooled, guild, hold,hulled, knelled,
lulled, mold, mould, mulled, polled, rolled, sold, told, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Words with terminal -<i>mb</i> lose the <i>b</i>,
especially if they are in the same syllable: <i>bomb, bomber </i>(but <i>bombastic</i>)<i>,
climb, climber, comb </i>(but <i>combine</i>)<i>, crumb, crumbier </i>(but<i>
crumble</i>)<i>, dumb, dumber, dumbest, iamb </i>(but <i>iambic</i>),<i> jamb </i>(<i>jamboree</i>)<i>,
lamb, limb </i>(but <i>limber</i>)<i>, numb/number<sup>1</sup></i>(but number<sup>1</sup>),<i>
plumb, plumber, rhumb, thumb, tomb, womb. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Words with -<i>lf</i>, -<i>lk, -lv- </i>often
drop the <i>l </i>if they are in the same syllable and are preceded by <i>a </i>or
<i>o</i>: <i>balk/balks, calf, calve/calves, caulk/caulks, caulker, folk/folks,
half, halve/halves, polk/polks, salve/salves </i>(but salvation)<i>, talk/talks,
talkathon, walk/walks, walkathon, yolk/yolks. </i>Most of these are <i>al </i>and<i>
ol </i>words<i>. </i>With <i>e, i,</i> and <i>u</i>, however, the <i>l</i> is
pronounced: <i>elk </i>(but <i>welkin, </i>)<i>; bilk, ilk, milk, silk</i>; or <i>bulk,
hulk, sulk. </i>That is because <i>e, i, </i>and<i> u </i>are vowels with the
tongue in high position, which is close to the position of the <i>l</i>; so, it
is easier to get into the <i>lk</i> sequence. The <i>a</i> and <i>o </i>have
the tongue lower; so it takes more movement to get to the <i>l</i> position. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Many words with a medial <i>st</i> sequence
do not sound the <i>t: bustle, castle, christen, fasten, glisten, hasten, hustle,
jostle, listen, mistletoe, moisten, nestle, rustle, whistle, wrestle,</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Many
words with <i>sce/sci</i> sequence change the <i>c</i> to <i>s</i> before <i>e,
i, </i>or<i> y </i>(by standard rule)<i> </i>and so lose the separate <i>k</i>
sound: <i>ascent, discipline, scent, science, visceral, viscid, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) a letter that has some other function
in a word: the terminal <i>e</i> after a single consonant (or *digraph like ba<u>th</u>e)
lengthens the preceding vowel<i>: mat/mat<u>e</u>; met/met<u>e</u>; mit/mit<u>e</u>;
mot/mot<u>e</u>; mut/mut<u>e</u></i> <b>[insert panel</b>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (4) Custom simply generates a different sound
in speaking while the spelling is retained: <i>colonel</i> as <i>kernel</i>; <i>coxswain
</i>as <i>soxn; forecastle </i>as <i>foxl</i>;<i> gunwhale</i> as gunnal;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (4) Silent letters near the front or end
of a word may come into play when pronounceable combinations are created by
additions at, before, or after. The <i><u>pn</u>eo-</i> terms bring the <i>p</i>
into play with <i>apnea, eupnea. </i>The silent <i><u>g</u></i> in <i>diaphragm</i>
becomes pronounced in <i>diaphragmatic</i>. The silent <i>n</i> in <i>damn</i>
is pronounced in <i>damnation</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *pronunciation, *spelling)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in'><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>simile</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a figure of speech that uses the words<b> </b><i>like</i> or <i>as</i>: Hes
as slow as a sloth. Hes like a horse. Removing <i>like </i>creates a
*metaphor: Hes a horse.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *figure of speech;
*metaphor, *metonymy, *anthropomorphism, *anthropopathic, *hendiadys, *irony)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>similitude</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
*archaism for *allegory or *simile</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>simple sentence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a sentence that does not have a dependent clause combined with a main clause. It
expresses one complete thought. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *complex sentence,
*compound sentence, *compound-complex sentence)<i> </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>simplex</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a word without
*affixes and is not part of a *compound word: <i>care vs.</i> <i>uncaring, caregiver.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sin</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the twenty-first letter
of the Hebrew alphabet. Also <u>shin</u>:</span><span lang=HE dir=RTL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
dir=LTR></span><span lang=HE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span dir=LTR></span> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
lang=HE dir=RTL></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>single-space</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) not having an empty line between lines of type; having type on every single
line. (2) Within a line of typing, <i>single-space</i> means that only one blank
space lies between one word and the next. A single space is used after a comma,
semi-colon, quotation mark, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *space, *double space,
*triple space, *space-and-a-half)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>singular</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: one rather than
more than one. In Greek, Latin, and English, a *word used as a word has a
singular verb and a singular modifier: <i>This <u>foolish ones</u> </i>describe<i>s</i>
the monkeys. *Hendiadys also takes a singular verb: The God and Father of our
Lord Jesus Christ <i>is</i> (1 Th <b>1</b>:3).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sirvente</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a satirical form
of lyric verse of the Provenal troubadours. WB</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>skit</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short, comic
play designed to entertain</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>skywriting</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the process of making cursive lettering in the sky by using an airplane to
release a trail of visible vapor.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>slam</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a comment
intended to criticize or hurt a persons feelings, a cut, an *insult, a
*slur. Slam differs from *innuendo and *insinuation by being overt and direct
to the person instead of implied and thus inferred. A slam is in your face.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>slander</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to tell
something that is not true in order to hurt a persons reputation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>slang</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a made-up word
used in light, every-day circumstances. Slang words may be made up completely
from scratch, or they are based inor perversions ofother words already
within the language. Seldom do they derive from earlier languages since they
come into the language from the general public.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *archaism, *buzz word,
*catch phrase, *colloquialism, *curse word, *formal term, *informal term, *oath,
*obsolete term, *provincialism, *regionalism, *technical term, *vulgarism) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>slash</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a line rising to
the right (/) used between entries for <u>different</u> parallel realities: I/We
must take care of the problem. Similar in value to <i>and/or</i>. The idea
contrasts from appositional <i>or</i>, which gives alternate names for the <u>same</u>
thing, another way of saying, to put it another way. Same as *diagonal.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> example </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(in
a set with *backslash) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>slogan</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a principle or
ideal prized by the entity that uses it; a *motto. <i>Ad astra per aspera</i>
(To the stars Through Difficulties), motto for the state of Kansas; <i>to phoos
tou kosmou</i> (The Light of the World), motto for Cincinnati Christian
University. <i>Slogar</i> may connote a less formal situation as with a group
of people; <i>motto</i> has a more formal ring to it.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>slur</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: v. to speak
indistinctly as when drunk or as a result of injury or disability. The
indistinctness mainly comes from not pronouncing the consonants clearly.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> n. a derogative comment aimed at a person; what
is done when one casts aspersions on someone or, perhaps, something. (in a
set with *enunciate, *pronounce)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>small letters</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another expression for *lower case, the smaller forms of letters in the
alphabet; not capitals </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *higher case, *capitals;
see also *common noun,*proper noun; *all caps; *majuscules, minuscules)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>small talk</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
talk about relatively unimportant matters that takes place as a way to pass the
time than to inform the person</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>smart quotes</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
quotation marks that are curled opposite waystoward the writing quotedon the
front and end of a citation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>snide remark</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>social media</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the use of unofficial computer systems of communication electronically in
contrast to public communication systemsthe media. Examples include Facebook
(formerly Myspace), e-mail, blog, twitter, flicker, pinterest.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Socratic method</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an instructional pattern using a question-answer format in such a way as to
draw ideas out of the student in contrast to telling the student those ideas. Associated
with Socrates, It was built on the idea of anamnesis, which postulated that
knowledge is inborn; consequently, the teaching task was to bring that
knowledge to conscious mind. (in a set with *lecture, *memorization, *rote
learning)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>solecism: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>the
literal translation of an idiom or structure in one language into another where
it does not convey the same ideaor convey any sensible idea at all. An example
is a combination of the Hebrew infinitive absolute plus cognate finite verb
used to express intensity: I have really wanted to eat this supper with you. Luke
22:15 says, <i>Epithumia epethumeesa</i>, dative noun plus cognate finite
verb. In normal Greek such a construction does not appear, but Jewish authors
writing in Greek sometimes used a dative-case noun plus a cognate finite verb to
convey it, as Luke does in this quotation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Another Greek option was to use a participle
plus cognate finite verb for this idiom: Peter says to Ananias, Remaining, it
remained under you authority (<i>menon emenon</i>, Acts <b>5</b>:4). (cp.
*idiom). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Acts, Luke quotes the Septuagint
rendering of Is <b>6</b>:9-10, which handles the idiom with both dative noun
and cognate participle in <b>28</b>:26. Mt <b>13</b>:14-15 cites the same
passage (= Mk<b> 4</b>:12; Lk <b>8</b>:10). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The Latin New Testament handles the Isaiah
quotation with a supine plus cognate and a participle plus cognate verb in Mt <b>13</b>:14a.
In Mk <b>4</b>:12 and Lk <b>8</b>:10, however, participles appear in reference
to both the seeing and the hearing. Acts <b>28</b>:26 says, <i>aure audietis .
. . videntes videbitis</i>, With-the-ear you-will-hear . . . seeing you will
see. Thus, it is a dative-noun-plus-verb construction, but the abstract
hearing reference (<i>akoee</i>) is replaced with a noun for the hearing organ.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>solid</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: said of a
two-part word that does not have a space or hyphen between the parts: stockbroker</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>soliloquy: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>in
drama a character speaking his thoughts when he is presumably alone [Lat.
solus, alone]. A kind of thinking out loud while alone and spoken to no one in
particular. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *monologue, *dialogue)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Solomons Prayer of Dedication</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
The prayer Solomon delivered before the people in Jerusalem at the dedication
of First Temple (1 Kg <b>8</b>:23-53).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Song of Deborah</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the example of ancient Hebrew poetry preserved in Jud <b>15</b>:2-321a,
identified with Deborah, a judge of Israel during the period of the judges before
the monarchy. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Song of Solomon</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another name for Canticles, Canticle of Canticles, or Song of Songs in the Old
Testament scriptures.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Song of Songs</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another name for Song of Solomon, or Canticles, or Canticle of Canticles.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sonnet: </span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a fourteen-line
verse using various rhyme schemes </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>space</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: one stroke of a
typewriter or computer <u>on</u> a line of type; a space <u>between</u> lines
of type (in a set with *double-space, *single-space, *triple-space,
*space-and-a-half)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>space-and-a-half</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having one and a half line empty between each line of type, a feature that was
available on some typewriters and one normally available on computers now. (in
a set with *space, *double-space, *triple-space, *space-and-a-half)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>spam</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: unwanted
e-mails, in the form of advertisement, dangerous or risky messages with
attachments that contains viruses, unimportant newsy items, and the like.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>speaking in tongues</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a phenomenon that came in consequence of the descent of the Spirit on the day
of Pentecost (Acts <b>2</b>) and at the house of Cornelius later (Acts<b> 10</b>).
Paul talks to the Corinthians about appropriate use of speaking in tongues
during public worship services (1 Cor <b>12-14</b>). (a set with *xenoglossia, *glossolalia,
*ecstatic utterance, *tongue speaking)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>special pleading</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
endeavoring to change another persons mind or avoid unwanted personal
consequences by appealing to less-than-satisfactory reasons.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>speech</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) oral
communication as a kind of *discourse; (2) a particular oral presentation. In
Acts, Luke weaves several *discourses into his narrative. They include
Stephens defense before the Sanhedrin (<b>7</b>:2-53) as well as Pauls
defense before Ananias, the high priest (<b>23</b>:1-6), his defense before the
Jerusalem mob (<b>22</b>:1-21), his defense before Felix, the governor (<b>24</b>:10-21),
and his defense before Festus and Herod Agrippa, the king (<b>26</b>:2-29). Inasmuch
as these discourses were not delivered in a purely religious setting, they are
listed here as speeches more than *sermons (<b>q.v</b>.).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *reading; *oration,
*declamation; *sermon, *discourse)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>spelling</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: how the letters
used in a language are arranged to represent its words; *orthography. Spelling
becomes an issue because (1) language drifts over time; so a spelling that made
sense before may no longer correlates closely with the way people say the word;
yet the spelling remains for historic purposes and so there is no problem
reading earlier writings: <b>[insert panel] </b>the <i>gh</i> on <i>cou<u>gh</u>,
enou<u>gh</u>, lau<u>gh</u>, rough, rou<u>gh</u>age, tough, </i>is<i> </i>pronounced
<i>f</i>.<i> </i>However,<i> <u>gh</u> </i>becomes silent in<i> aught, blight, bought,
bri<u>gh</u>t, brought, cau<u>gh</u>t, delight, dou<u>gh</u>, drou<u>gh</u>t, fight,
fli<u>gh</u>t, fraught, haughty, hei<u>gh</u>t, li<u>gh</u>t, mi<u>gh</u>t/mighty,
naught, nigh, ni<u>gh</u>t, nought, ought, pli<u>gh</u>t, ri<u>gh</u>t, sigh, si<u>gh</u>t,
sleigh, slight, sought, th(o)rough, ti<u>gh</u>t, wei<u>gh/</u>t, wri<u>gh</u>t,
wrought</i>. So, the English spelling system is not as good a fit as it is in many
languages. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> For another thing, (2) English vocabulary
contains significantly more terms than most languages doperhaps half again as
many in normal use as are used in even modern, developed nations. The more
examples there are, the harder it is to maintain uniformity. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Furthermore, (3) English is a melting-pot
language, being supplied with words derived not only from the classical
languages of Latin and Greek, but also from the Anglo-Saxon/Germanic background.
The language spelling system has retained the lettering of the feeder
languages; so it remains static while the spoken form keeps drifting. This
phenomenon creates a host of *silent letters in English spelling. There is
silent <u>g</u> in sign, <i>paradigm</i>. <i>Pneumonia</i> does not pronounce
the<i> p</i>. See *silent letters for further examples. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Diphthong</i> says <i>diphthong,
ophthalmologist </i>says <i>opthalmologist,</i> and <i>d<u>ip</u>htheria</i>
says <i>diptheria</i>. English wants to create a *stop-*fricative set from a
fricative-fricative combination whereas Greek wants to create a
fricative-fricative set from a stop-fricative set. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Initial spelled <i>w</i> does not affect
pronunciation in <i>wrap</i>, <i>wreck, wring,</i> <i>wretched</i>, <i>wrung</i>,
<i>wrong</i>, <i>write, wrote, wrought</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Final spelled <i>w</i> does not affect
pronunciation of words like <i>blow/blew</i>, <i>flew</i>, <i>flow</i> , <i>grow</i>,
<i>grown</i>, <i>know</i>, <i>low</i>, <i>mow<sup>1</sup></i>, <i>row</i><sup>1</sup>,
<i>slow</i>, <i>sow<sup>1</sup></i>, <i>tow</i>, The final <i>w</i> does affect
pronunciation on <i>bow<sup>1</sup></i>, <i>brown</i>, <i>cow</i>, <i>down</i>,
<i>frown</i>, <i>how</i>, <i>now</i>, <i>mow</i><sup>1</sup>, row<sup>1</sup>, <i>sow<sup>1</sup></i>,
<i>wow</i>. Sometimes particular words come down through French and other
European languages, which further adjust the Latin originals. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> As a result, (1) <u>letters and
combinations of letters do not always have the same value</u>, as says the
famous jingle about <i>i</i> before <i>e</i> except after <i>c</i> or sounding
like <i></i> in <i>n<u>ei</u>ghbor</i> or <i>w<u>ei</u>gh</i>. But note the <i><u>ee</u></i>
sound for <i><u>ei</u></i> in <i>caff<u>ei</u>ne</i>, <i><u>ei</u>ther/n<u>ei</u>ther/l<u>ei</u>sure,
prot<u>ei</u>n, s<u>ei</u>ze</i>; or the ear sound in <i>w<u>ei</u>rd</i> or
the <i>i</i> sound in <i>aparth<u>ei</u>d, ch<u>ei</u>lostomatoplasty, f<u>ei</u>sty,
h<u>ei</u>ght, l<u>ei</u>tmotif</i>; or the short <u>i</u> in <i>for<u>ei</u>gn</i>,
<i>forf<u>ei</u>t, forfeiture, surfeit</i>. Sometimes the two vowels belong to
different syllables: <i>alb<u>ei</u>t, acqu<u>ie</u>sce, cl<u>ie</u>nt, </i>(fiery),
spontan<u>ei</u>ty<i>, var<u>ie</u>ty</i>; also note <i>seize</i> but <i>siege</i>!
As a Facebook comment said, Use <i>i</i> before <i>e</i> except when you run
a feisty heist in a weird beige foreign neighborhood. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>C</i> before <i>e, i, </i>or <i>y</i>
has an <i>s</i> sound; before <i>a, o, </i>or <i>u</i> it has a <i>k </i>sound.
That feature of pronunciation has a spelling implication in certain
circumstances: picnic is spelled <i>picni<u>ck</u>ing</i> to keep the final <i>c</i>
from becoming an <i>s</i> sound. The same holds for the words <i>panic/panicking,
</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Ch</i> is <i>k</i> in <i><u>ch</u>olangiopancreatography
</i><b>[insert panel]</b>, an explosive sound in <i><u>ch</u>unk </i><b>[insert
panel]</b>, an <i>sh</i> in <i><u>ch</u>ute, douche </i><b>[insert panel]</b>,
and no sound at all in <i><u>ch</u>thonic,schism</i>. <b>[insert panel] </b>(See
under *spelling) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>G</i> can be <i>guh</i>, <i>j</i>, or <i>zh</i>
(<i>barrage<sup>1</sup>, beige, corsage<sup>1</sup>, garage<sup>1</sup>, mirage<sup>1</sup>,
triage</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>S</i> can be voiceless: <i>base, case, douse,
gas, goose, loose, mouse, moose, noose, pastor, sat, tonsil, us, vase<sup>1</sup>,
</i>Initial single <i>s</i> is always an <i>s</i> sound.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>S</i> can be voiced into a <i>z</i>
sound: <i>basil, cosy, does, ease, fuse,</i> <i>laser, miser, pose, toes, woes,</i>
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>ss: </i>Double <i>ss</i> (almost)
always guarantees an <i>s</i> sound: <i>abyss, bass<sup>1</sup>, bass<sup>1</sup>,
boss, class, crass, cuss, dross, fuss, gross, hiss, hoss, kiss, loss, miss, pass,
toss, </i>(But <i>fissure</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>S</i> can have a <i>sh</i> sound: <i>insure,
sugar</i>, reassure, sure, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> S</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
can have a <i>zh</i> sound: <i>fusion, visual</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> -ss- </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>can
have a sh sound:<i> mission</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>-ss<i>-
can have a </i>zh<i> sound: fission</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Th</i> can be voiceless: <u>mouth</u>
(n.), <i>south</i>, <i>thud, with, zither.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Th</i> can be voiced (<i>dh</i>): <i>another,
bother, brother, druther, either, father, farther, further, gather, hither, mother,
mouth </i>(v.), <i>neither,</i> <i>rather, soothe, southern, that, the, thee,
then, these, thine, thither, those, thou, though, thy, whither, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) Furthermore, <u>the same sound can be
covered in several ways</u>. Such a list includes all the *homophones in the
English language, of which there are an amazing number!  See under *homophones.
Other words create related forms spelled with <i>t</i> or <i>d</i>, but both
spellings are pronounced voiceless: <i>feel/felt, give/gift, keep/kept, kneel/knelt,
leave/left</i>, <i>rive/rift, sleep/slept, weep/wept</i> but <i>limp/limped</i>,
<i>nipped, ripped, sipped</i>, <i>stepped, stressed, work/worked</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The *plosive sound <i>ch </i>can be found<i>
</i>in (a) <i>attach, blanch,</i> <i><u>ch</u>unk, church, gaucho, much, munch,
pinch,</i> <i>rachet, rich, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Ch </i>can also be spelled (b) <i>tch</i>
in the medial and terminal position: <i>batch, bitch, botch, butcher, catch, clutch,
ditch, fetch, glitch, hatch, hitch, hatch, itch, kvetch, latch, match, natch, notch,
patch, scotch, scutch, stitch, stretch, satchel, switch, thatch, twitch, vetch,
vetchling, watch, witch, wretch</i>, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>That
same sound can occur with (c) <i>t</i> before <i>u</i>: <b>[insert panel]</b> <i>actual,
adventure, amateur, aperture, armature, cariacature, creature, culture, denture/s,
departure, expenditure, firfeiture, fixture, forfeiture, fracture, functual, future,
gesture/maturation, indentured, instinctual, intellectual, investiture, lecture,
legislature, ligature, literature, mature, miniature, mixture, moisture, nature,
nomenclature, nurture, overture, pasture, pasteurize, picture, posture, pasturage,
picture, punctual, puncture, rapture, ritual, sculpture, stricture, tablature, tincture,
venture, vesture, victuals, vulture, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Portuguese
uses (d) <i>ti </i>for the <i>ch</i> sound: <i>Tolentino</i> is <i>Tolenchino</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The
<i>j </i>sound can be covered by (a) <i>j</i>, of course, but it can also be
covered by (b) <i>g</i> before <i>e, i, or y</i>. Thirdly, it can be covered by
(c) <i>dg</i>, as in words like <i>hedge</i>, <i>judge</i>, <i>judgment</i>, <i>ledge</i>,
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) <u>The same spelling can have the same
sound but different meaning</u> (*homonym). Several verbs have two tenses
spelled the same way and pronounced the same way: <b>[insert panel] </b><i>beat</i>,
<i>bid</i>, <i>burst</i>, <i>clad</i>, <i>cost</i>, <i>cut</i>, <i>hit</i>, <i>hurt</i>,
<i>knit</i>, <i>let</i>, <i>live???</i>, <i>quit</i>, <i>rid</i>, <i>shed</i>, [shit],
<i>spit</i>, <i>split</i>, <i>spread</i>, <i>wet.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Same spelling and sound can cover both singular
and plural: <i>bison</i>, <i>craft</i>, <i>deer</i>, <i>fish</i>, <i>fry</i>, <i>sen,
sheep</i>, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Thats why there are spelling bees in
English! </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>English spelling, however, does follow
certain general patterns.</b> <u>The letter <i>g</i> has a <i>j</i> sound if
followed by <i>e, i,</i> or <i>y</i>; and a <i>guh</i> sound (hard <i>g</i>)
if followed by <i>a, o,</i> or <i>u</i></u>. Exceptions are <i>get</i>, <i>gig</i>.
Even double <i>gg</i> can sometimes be <i>j</i>: <i>exaggerate</i>. A final <i>e</i>
after final <i>g</i> makes the <i>g</i> have the <i>j</i> sound<i>: age, beige,
cage, dirge, gauge, huge, lung/lunge, merge, page, rag/rage, rang/range,
sag/sage, ting/tinge, urge, verge, wag/wage. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The same pattern <i>g</i> + vowels applies
to the two values for the letter <i>c</i>: <u>before <i>e, i,</i> or <i>y</i>,
the <i>c </i>has an <i>s</i> sound; before <i>a, o</i>, or <i>u</i>, it has a <i>k</i>
sound</u><i>: coalesce, excrescence, exscind, obscene, obsolesce, oscine,
oscillate, ecalescence??, piscine, prescience, pubescence, pubescent,
quiescent, rescind, rubescent, scent, scepter, sciatic, science, scintillate,
scion, scission, scissor, scissure, susceptible, tabescent, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In keeping with the pattern for <i>c</i>, the
final <i>e </i>that is normally dropped before suffixes beginning with a vowel.is
kept after <i>g</i> without adding a syllable to keep the g spriant in words
like <i>chang<u>e</u>able</i>, <i>displaceable, manag<u>e</u>able, noticeable,
peaceable, practiceable, replaceable, traceable</i>. Similarly <i>i- </i>keeps
<i>g</i> as a <i>j </i>sound: <i>allegiance</i>. A <i>k</i> may be added to <i>arc</i>
to make <i>arcking</i> so the <i>k</i> sound is for sure kept before <i>ing</i>.
Likewise, a <i>u</i> comes after <i>g</i> in <i>g<u>u</u>ide</i> to help show
that the <i>g</i> is not pronounced <i><u>j</u> </i>before the <i>e</i>, <i>i, </i>or
<i>y</i>. Such words are not to be pronounced <i>gw</i>: <i>guenon, guerilla,
guess, guest, guide</i>, <i>guideon</i>, <i>guild</i>, <i>guilder</i>, <i>guile,</i>
<i>guillemont, guilloche, guillotine, guilt</i>, <i>guimpe</i>, <i>guinea,
guipure, guise</i>, <i>guy</i>, <i>guitar</i>, <i>morg<u>u</u>e</i>, <i>roug<u>u</u>e</i>,
<i>tongue</i>, <i>vaguely</i>. (But note <i>guard</i>, <i>etc.</i>). Some
double <i>cc</i>s are followed by <i>e, i,</i> or <i>y</i>, so that the first
gets a <i>k</i> sound and the second gets an <i>s</i> sound: c<i>occi, coccyx,
succeed, succession, succinct, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) English frequently follows the Latin
practice of <u>doubling a consonant to indicate a short vowel before it</u>: <b>[inset
panel]</b> <i>biter/bitter, inflame/inflammation, miler/miller, miter/admitted,
rifle/riffle; ripe/ripple, stared/starred.</i> That gives rise to the rule that
a word ending in a vowel-consonant doubles the consonant before adding a vowel suffix.
In most cases, not doubling the consonant first would make the preceding vowel
long: <i>begin/beginning; bit/bitten, cap/capped, clap/clapping, dim/dimmed,
emit/emitted, fat/fatten, hit/hitting, hot/hotter; knotted, man/manning, omit/omitting,
pan/panning, rip/ripped, sap/sapped, tan/tanned, win/winning, write/written,. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A patterned exception to the doubling rule
arises in *polysyllables with accents on the *antepenult (the third syllable
from the end). Since English pronunciation tends to weaken unaccented vowels to
sheva, an antepenult accent weakens an ultima vowel. As a result, doubling the
final consonant is not necessary for keeping the preceding vowel short: <b>[insert
panel] </b><i>benefited</i> (rather than <i>benefitted</i>), <i>bracketed,
buffeted, canceled, reveled, riveted,</i> <i>signaled, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (3<u>) A final <i>e</i> after a single consonant
(including *digraphs) makes the preceding vowel long</u>: <i>mat/mate, met/mete,
mit/mite, mot/mote, mut/mute.</i> Even with two consonants , the <i>e</i>
lengthens the preceding vowel in some cases: bathe/bath, <i>haste</i> (but <i>hast</i>),
<i>lathe/lath, lithe,</i> <i>waste</i> (but <i>wast</i>, OE); yet <i>caste</i>
and <i>cast</i> are *homophones, and <i>mouth</i> is a homograph pronounced <i>th</i>
for noun and <i>dh</i> for verb<i>. </i>Exceptions are <i>above, dove, glove,
have, live </i>(v)<i>, love, move, relive, shove, sieve, </i><b>[insert panel]<i>
</i></b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (4) <u>On vowel-consonant-<i>e </i>words
where the accent is three syllables back, the vowel may be short</u> (unless a
secondary accent falls on the last syllable), but the spelling is the same: Here
belong the -<i>te</i> wordswhich are not verbs: <i>passionate</i> <b>[insert
panel] </b> Words ending in <i>ive</i>, regardless of part of speech, have
short <i>i</i> unless accented on the *ultima: <b>[insert panel] </b><i>abrasive</i>,
<i>associative</i>, <i>collective, contemplative, copulative, directive,
durative, elative, exclusive, expansive, expensive, factitive, festive, illative,
laxative, locomotive, massive, missive, native, olive, pensive, provocative, quantitative,
regulative, relative, responsive, restive, restrictive,</i> <i>restorative,
sensitive, stative, transitive, unitive, </i>(no <i>ives</i> under <i>w</i>). Long
because accented on the last syllable are words like <i>contrive</i>, <i>dive</i>,
<i>five, hive, knives, live </i>(adj),<i> lives </i>(n),<i> strive, wives,</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (5) <u>There is an affinity between
related consonants like lip sounds, (labials: <i>p, b f, ph, v</i>), tooth
sounds (dentals: <i>t, d, th<sup>1</sup>, th<sup>2</sup></i>), sibilants (c<sup>1</sup>,
s<sup>1</sup>, s<sup>2</sup>, s<sup>3</sup>, sh, sch, z<sup>1</sup>, z<sup>2</sup>),
velars/palatals (c<sup>2</sup>, k, g<sup>1</sup>, g<sup>2</sup>). </u>Related
words (*cognates) and different forms of the same word commonly shift between
these consonants. Lip-letter shifts include <i>f/v</i> changes: <i>grief/grieve,
knife/knives, half/halves, life/lives<sup>1</sup>, safe/save, wife/wives, wolf/wolves,</i>
Not all singular-plural shifts go <i>f/v</i>; sometimes there is no shift: <i>caf/cafes,
clef/clefs, safe/safes,</i> <i>etc.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> There is an <i>s/t</i> affinity between
cognates because the <i>s</i> sound and <i>t</i> sound are pronounced near the
same place in the mouth. As a result, -<i>sis</i> nouns have a corresponding
adjective (and/or noun) in <i><u>t</u>ic</i>: <i>diagnosis/diagnostic,
prosthesis/prosthetic/prosthetist</i>; ence/-ance nouns have corresponding
adjectives in <i>t</i>: <i>eminence/eminent, imminence/imminent,
sequence/sequential, dominance/dominant, romance/romantic, </i>The <i>s/t</i>
affinity shows up in Greek in the shift from <i>tt-</i> to <i>ss-</i> (<i>thalatta/thalassa</i>,
sea) in its classical to Hellenistic stages.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Vowel shifts may be from short to long,
but there is less pattern to vowel alterations in English. (6) Dictionary forms
in <i>en</i> and other vowel-consonant terminations often follow their Latin
ancentors and alter that vowel ahead of additions: <i>abdomen &gt; abdominal,
nomen &gt; nominal, semen &gt; seminal; femur/femoral, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (7) <u>Consonant + <i>y</i> terminations
usually change the <i>y</i> to <i>i</i> before additions are madeunless successive
<i>i</i>s<i> </i>would result</u>: happy &gt; happier, but rally &gt; rallying
<b>[insert panel]</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (8) <i><u>q</u></i><u> is always followed
by <i>u</i></u>: quack,<i> etc</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Since
custom drives usage, words that were formerly hyphenated may now considered one
word for writing purposes. Hyphenation, for example, may no longer be
considered necessary: <i>cooperate</i>, formerly <i>co-operate</i> or <i>coperate</i>.
Writing conventions lag behind spoken realities. For instance, <i>rain check</i>
has the same accent and pitch pattern as <i>homework, rainbow, railroad, etc</i>.,
but dictionaries still list it as two words. About all a writer can do is
consult a dictionary to see how far convention has carried this particular word
in the opinion of those charged with tracking such matters.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin derivatives with <i>ex</i> + roots
beginning in <i>s</i> drop the <i>s</i> in English; the <i>x</i> (ks) is
allowed to carry the <i>s </i>sound; that is, <i>ex</i> absorbs the initial <i>s</i>
of root: <i>execrate</i> (&lt; <i>ex</i> + <i>sacrare</i>); <i>execute</i>
(&lt; <i>ex</i> + <i>sequi</i>); <i>exile</i> (&lt; <i>ex</i> + <i>silium</i>);
<i>expatiate</i> (&lt; <i>ex</i> + <i>spatiari</i>); <i>expect</i> (&lt; <i>ex</i>
+ <i>spectare</i>); <i>expire</i> (&lt; <i>ex</i> + <i>spiro</i>); <i>extant</i>
(&lt; <i>ex</i> + <i>stare</i>); <i>extinct</i> (&lt; <i>ex</i> + <i>stinguere</i>);
<i>extirpate</i> (&lt; <i>ex</i> + <i>stirps</i>); <i>exude</i> (&lt; <i>ex</i>
+ <i>sudare</i>). In Latin, most of the time the <i>s</i> was separately
written in compounds with <i>ex</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>British spelling differs from American
spelling at certain points.</b> (a) When <i>er </i>does not refer to agent
(work<u>er</u>) or comparative degree (strong<u>er</u>), British spelling sometimes
uses <i>re</i>: centre, litre, metre, theatre where the <i>er </i>is not an
agent or comparative ending; (but not in <i>cancer, liver, pilfer, river, roster;
brother, father, mother, sister,</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (b) Some words are changed somewhat: alumin<u>i</u>um</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *homograph, homonym,
*homophone, *phonetic spelling) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (See also *epenthesis, *pronunciation, *orthography,
*silent letters, *transliteration)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>spelling bee</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a contest based on the ability to spell English words</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sphenogram</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a cuneiform character with its distinctive wedge-shaped form</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>spiel</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: German for ; a
somewhat ridiculing way of referring toa sales *pitch, for example.<br>
<b>spin</b>: a particular way of presenting something so as to take away some
negative<b> </b>way of looking at it. (in a set with *line)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>spiritualize</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to give a figurative meaning to a literal text, one not particularly intended
to have that meaning</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>splice</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: what serves to
connect material already presented and the next item of interest in presentation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>split infinitive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in English grammar, an infinitive construction with an adverb inserted between
the sign of the infinitive (to) and the infinitive itself: to quickly go. The
practice is becoming increasingly acceptable and used more naturally than putting
the adverb ahead of the <i>to</i>. To the modern ear, a split infinitive has
much the same sound as splitting the parts of a progressive verb: We are <i>quickly</i>
running out of gas. In the nature of things, there is no reason not to use the
split format since English considers the infinitive sign a separate particle
from the infinitive itself. In Latin or Greek the infinitive sign was always
suffixed directly to the verb as part of the same word; so it could not so
easily be pushed apart to make room for an insertion.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>spontaneous delivery</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a form of public speaking in which the speaker structures the wording as he
goes in contrast to *manuscript delivery.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>spoof</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a light
imitation intended for good-natured fun rather than ridicule</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>spriant letter</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a letter that stands for a fricative sound: <i>phi, theta, chi</i> (Gr); the <i>bgdkpt</i>
Hebrew letters without <i>dagesh lene</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>spurious</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: in ancient
manuscripts, a passage not part of the authors writing, an *interpolation by a
later hand. <i>Spurious</i> has to do with authenticity of authorahip, not
particularly with correctness of content.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>spurious writing</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a writing not produced by the one who claims to have written it. Same as
*pseudepigrapha. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>square script</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the modern Hebrew characters, which have a generally square shape, in contrast
to the ancient form of the letters found in most inscriptions. Also called Aramaic
square script.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>squinting modifier</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a kind of *double meaning, a modifier that can reasonably connect with a
preceding or succeeding word: We made the trip <u>long</u> before we knew how
expensive it would be. We do business right here at home. NT ex.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stand for</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an expression used for *abbreviations, especially *acronyms </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *abbreviation, *acronym,
*acrostic)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>standard English</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the agreed-upon form of English that is used among educated speakers and
writers especially in public and formal situations. It applies to structure and
written conventions.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>standardized text</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a text like the Hebrew Old Testament that became deliberately fixed despite
variant *readings that previously existed. (in a set with *Masoretic text)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stanza</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (= verse)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>star</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: same as
*asterisk; used more recently with cell phones, <i>etc.</i>, for *economy of
expression.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>statement of faith</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a summary of important convictions held by a religious group but not considered
authoritative for <i>fellowship purposes</i>; it may be required for <i>leadership
purposes</i> within the group or, if held in greater importance, for <i>membership
purposes</i>. The last <i>purposes</i> assumes the validity of
denominationalism. A statement of faith is distinguished from a creed in that a
creed is authoritative for fellowship, leadership, and membership purposes.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *creed, *scripture,
*by-laws)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>state-of-being verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb that indicates being rather than action; another term for *copulative
verb, *equative verb, *linking verb, *stative verb, *to be verb; cp. *fientive
verb. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *active verb, *middle-voice
verb, *passive verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stative perfect</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a value of the perfect tense that stresses the resulting condition of the
completed action: I have it done (<i> vs.</i> I have done it); I had it done (<i>
vs.</i> I had done it); I will have it done (<i> vs.</i> I will have done it). (in
a set with *perfect tense)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stative verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) a verb that indicates a condition rather than an action; another term sometimes
used for *copulative verb, *equative verb, *linking verb, *state-of-being verb,
*to be verb; cp. *fientive verb. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) a verb construction that indicates the
condition that results from a completed action; a possible value of perfect tenses
in Greek, Latin, and even English: it <i>stands </i>confirmed; I have it done (<i>
vs.</i> I have done it). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The difference between stative and plain
passive can be illustrated as follows: They <u>were married</u> last Friday;
so they <u>were married</u> when they got here Tuesday. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *active verb, *middle-voice
verb, *passive verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stem</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the constant
part of a word when ending are added to indicate tense, number, gender, and the
like. (in a set with *combining form, *root, *base) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stemma</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a scroll that
preserves an important record, as list of manuscripts of an ancient literary
piece or of a genealogy, or family tree, especially of an ancient Roman family.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stenographer</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a person who takes *dictation, one of the roles fulfilled by a secretary </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *amanuensis, *scribe)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stenography</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the art or process of doing a stenographers work</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stet</span></i></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: do not delete;
an editors note in contrast to *dele, remove. [&lt;Latin: let it stand]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stich</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a line of
writing; same as <i>stichos</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stichoi</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the lines of an
ancient text; also <i>stiches</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stichometry</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the division of a prose text into lines of standard length and reflecting the
syntactical layout of the writing, a device used prior to the development of
punctuation. The counting of lines was able to identify the Epistle of Barnabas
as in fact a title for the Book of Hebrews in the New Testament. See Westcott
and Hort appendix to the commentary on the Book of Hebrews</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stichomythia</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Alteration between speakers of lines of verse in drama WB</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stigma</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: same as
*digamma, a Greek symbol for six.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stilted</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: overly formal in
speech</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tongue twister</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stop</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a sound made by
stopping the air flow through the oral cavity at one of the *pronunciation
points. The sound may be voiceless (<i>p, t, k, h</i>[onor]) or voiced (<i>b,
d, g</i>). The unvoiced stop is also called a *tenuis.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *fricative, *nasal,
*plosive, *trill)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>story</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an account, but
also a made-up series of events that is similar to real life as in an anecdote;
a lie, as in to tell a story.</span></p>
