<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>streamlining causal distinctions</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In this manner of speaking, what is allowed by a person that person is said to
do. What is done indirectly is worded the same way as if it were done directly.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>street talk</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
usually a way of speaking that implies coarse expression, the use of
vulgarisms, swearing, cursing. The type of language used in impolite company.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stress</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the accent put
on a syllable within a word or on a word with in a set of words accomplished by
increased volume, raised pitch, pausing, or a combination of these ways of
drawing attention to the point of emphasis. Whereas <u>accent</u> is a term
mostly applied to syllables within a word, <u>stress</u> applies to words or
phrases within a sentence. Stress, or emphasis, many times sets up a contrast
with parallel alternatives to the term stressed. (in a set with *accent,
*emphasis)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>structural meaning</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
consists of elaborations of basic meaning by *formal changes/additions,
relationship connections (*distribution/word order/position), and oral nuancing
(*intonation). Contrasts with *lexical meaning</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stutter</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a speech
impediment somewhat more common in men than in women. In it is a tendency to
say repeatedly the beginnings of words and/or to lock up so that the word
does not come out.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>stylized expression</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
similar to *formulaic; an expression that always takes the same form</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>subject</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: The grammatical <u>subject</u>
of a clause is the noun/pronoun that does the action of an *active verb or the
noun/pronoun the receives the action of a *passive verb. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Linking, or equative or state-of-being,
verbs also have subjects that are readily identifiable most of the time. In
Greek, where word order is not as crucial, linking verb sentences with a
*predicate noun raise the question as to which noun is subject. The basic idea
is that, regardless of word order, the subject is the more narrow reference; it
is the particular while the predicate noun is the class: The Word was God (Jn
<b>1</b>:1). <i>The Word</i> is the subject while <i>God</i> is the
classdeity. The issue is not so much which noun appears firsteven in English:
An extreme form of escape is suicide means the same as An extreme form of
escape suicide is or Suicide is an extreme form of escape. Which is said
first may be for emphasis or may be because it links up more easily with the
preceding context to put the predicate nominative earlier rather than later in
the sentence. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The principle of narrower reference
underlies other rules for identifying subject <i>vs.</i> predicate nominative:
a proper noun is subject over a common noun; an articular noun (identity) is
subject <i>vs.</i> an anarthrous one (quality); a pronoun is subject <i>vs.</i>
a noun.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>subject complement</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in English, Greek, and Latin, a complementing modifieradjective or participleplaced
after the verb and harking back to the subject: He was released from jail <u>free</u>
from all charges. This man does not cease <u>speaking</u> words against this
holy place and the law (Acts<b> 6</b>:13). (in a set with *objective
complement; *complementary infinitive)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>subjective genitive: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>In
Greek and Latin, subjective genitive involves a noun tied to an action noun by
the genitive case. The genitive-case noun is the subject of the action in the
other noun: the love of God, meaning the love by God, that is, the love
that God has for me. Subjective genitive contrasts with *objective genitive,
where the genitive-case noun receives the action: the love <i>for</i> God, as
in the love that I have for God. English can use an of construction for
both ideas. Note the situation in Rom <b>8</b>:35, (37), 39. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *objective genitive)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>subjunctive mood</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb mood/mode that is used when the action is somehow uncertain or contingent
on another action. It supposes action. Because of its contingency element,
most usages of the subjunctive mood are in dependent constructions: purpose
clauses, future conditional clauses, <i>etc.</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *indicative, * imperative,
*optative (Gr), *infinitive mood)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>subordinate clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Also called *dependent clause in contrast to *insubordinate clause/*dependent
clause. A subordinate clause does not stand alone because it does not express a
complete thought by itself.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>subscribe/subscription</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a commitment to purchase a periodical for a given length of time.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>subscript</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a symbol placed beneath the line of writing. In Hellenistic Greek, the iota was
written as a subscript with a long *vowel to form an *improper diphthong. (in a
set with *superscript, *exponent) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>substantive</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
A form that can fill a noun slot: *nouns, *pronouns, substantive *adjectives, *gerunds,
*infinitives. Any *word used as a word is a substantive regardless of its
normal usage as verb, preposition, <i>etc.</i> As replacements for nouns, substantives
appear as *subjects of the sentence, *direct objects, *indirect objects,
objects of *prepositions, *vocative nouns in *direct address.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (In a set with *substantive adjective,
*word used as a word; *gerund, *infinitive, *noun, *pronoun,)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>substantive adjective</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word that is normally used as an *adjective but in a given instance has no
accompanying *noun and fills a noun slot. English substantive adjectives do not
use pluralizing *morphemes (even when plural in meaning), can take a plural
verb, have <i>the </i>ahead of them, and can require plural subsequent pronouns:
<i>the halt, the happy, the ignorant, the lonely, the maim, the meek, the poor </i>[in
spirit]<i>, the pure </i>[in heart]<i>, the sad, the strong, the weak</i>, <i>etc.</i>;
also <i>in the singular, in the plural,</i> <i>etc.</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin and Greek also have substantive
adjectives both in the singular and the plural. In translation, it is often useful
to add <i>one/ones, thing/things,</i> <i>people, men.</i> Occasionally English
may have a noun that can cover the original substantive: <i>foolish-ones</i>
becomes <i>fools</i>. A word like the Latin <i>amicus</i> (friend) may be
separately listed in a lexicon as an adjective (friendly). It is a matter of
judgment whether a word is predominantly an adjective used here in a noun slot,
or whether it is so frequently used both ways that, regardless of original
usage, it is now considered either part of speech depending on the case.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *declension, *noun)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>substory </span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>subtext</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the underlying
personality of a character in a drama as implied by the text</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>subtitle</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a secondary
title that appears with the basic title and adds clarifying information to the
main title.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>subvocal</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: not audible as
perhaps in lips movements </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>suffix</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a word ending
that usually is not also a free-standing form; also called a *postfix. Suffixes
create new words by adding another element of meaning to an already existing
base, for creating related words of a different part of speech. Suffixes are
forms that appear only at the ends of words even though related forms with the
same meaning may occur elsewhere in words: -<i>stomy</i> is a suffix for mouth
or opening, and -<i>stomato</i>- can be a prefix or combining form that appears
earlier in words.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> As with ful words, suffixes (and prefixes)
can be compounds. For example, -ectomy is a compound of ec-, out, -tom-, cut,
and y, a nominalizing termination. Together they make a suffix for excision,
which can be added onto a host of roots for body parts that can be removed: <i>gastrectomy,
nephrectomy,</i> splenectomy, <i>etc.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> As with *prefixes, there is a question
about drawing the line between suffixes and the final forms of morphemes in
compound words. Terminal elements like <i>algia, -odynia, -emia, -logy,
-pathy, -cele, -scope</i> occur frequently, and so have been included here but
in italics to distinguish them from endings that manipulate the internal
meanings of roots (in contrast to adding meanings that are not the outgrowths
of the preceding roots). ???Likewise missing from this list are those
inflectional terminations that change tense, person, and voice on verbs as well
as number on nouns. Included, then, are additions that change the *part of speech
and otherwise manipulate the meaning of words. <b>further examples</b>  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> List of English suffixes: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -ability: the noun form of able/ible/uble
words</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -able/-ible/-uble: able to do, able to be
made into what the root indicates</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -able can form a few nouns: constable??</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ad</i>: in the direction of. <i>Caudad</i>
is in the direction of the tail </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ac</i> (n. demoniac; see -<i>iac</i>),
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ac</i> (adj. cardiac), (see also <i>iac</i>)
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ade</i> (action, process), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>-</b><i>age</i>: nominalizing suffix
for condition from nouns<i> </i><b>[insert panel] </b><i>baggage, bandage, blockage,
bondage, carnage, coinage, coverage, homage, leverage, lineage, manage, mileage,
overage, parentage, pasturage, patronage, poundage, roughage, seepage, slippage,
stoppage, stumpage, suffrage, surplusage, tankage, tonnage, vagabonage, vassalage,
verbiage, vestage, vicarage, villeinage, vintage, visage, wordage, wrechage, </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> -agogue/-agog</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a substance that stimulates the flow of something: emmenagogue WB<i> </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>al/-lia</i>, -<i>alis</i> (pertaining
to), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>-algia </i>(painful condition);
anything capable of experience pain has a word for it ending in <i>algia</i>
or -<i>odynia</i> or both: <i></i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>-<i>an</i>
(pertaining to), -<i>ance/-ence</i> (state of), -<i>ancy/-ency</i> (state of),
-<i>ane</i>, -<i>ant/-ent </i>(pertaining to), -<i>ar</i> (pertaining to), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>arian</i> (adj., pertaining to a
person; n., a person), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>aris</i> (pertaining to),<b> -</b><i>ary</i>
(pertaining to), -<i>ase</i> (enzyme), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ate</i>: as a verb ending it is always
te; -te may be adjective or noun; -te may be noun or adjective except if
there is a cognate verb in -te: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -<i>ated</i> (pertaining to a condition
composed of), </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:

"Times New Roman",serif'> List of Greek suffixes: -<i>akis</i>
(multiplicity), -<i>aridion</i> (a diminutive of the root to which it is attached),
-<i>(a)rion</i> (diminutive perhaps with endearment), -<i>eia</i> (&lt; -euoo<i>
</i>v. &gt; abstract n.), -<i>eion </i>(place), <i>-es-</i>[1<sup>st</sup>
decl] (act ptc fem), -<i>eus</i> (agent), -<i>then</i> (directional toward the
speaker), -<i>ia</i> (quality n. &lt; adj), -<i>ianos</i> (n. a *patronymic for
one who is a follower of, or related in some way to, the proper name to which
the suffix is attached), -<i>ikos </i>(adj &lt; n. -<i>inos</i> (adj &lt; n.<i>-ion</i>
(diminutive), -<i>ios</i> (adj. &lt; n), -<i>idzoo </i>(verb), -<i>is</i>
(multiplicity), <i>-ma</i> (result), -<i>mos</i> (name of an action from -dzoo
verbs), <i>-menos</i> (mid/pas ptc), -<i>monee </i>(&gt; n. = -ness), <i>-nt</i>[3<sup>rd</sup>
decl] (act ptc mas/neut), -<i>ou</i> (adverb of clace), <i>-s-(</i>fut), <i>-sis</i>
(abstract action; n &lt; v.), -<i>sunee</i> (qualaity n. &lt; adj), <i>-tatos</i>
(superlative degree with adj/adv), <i>-teros</i> (comparative degree on adj/adv),
-<i>teer</i> (agent), <i>-teerion</i> (place of), <i>-tees</i> (agent &lt;
-idzoo v.), -<i>tees </i>(quality n. &lt; adj), -<i>toor</i> (agent), -<i>t(e)os</i>
(usually passive adj &gt; v. implying capability, possibility, necessity), -<i>oo</i>
(adverb of location relative to another point), -<i>oov</i> (place), -<i>oos </i>(&lt;adj
&gt; adv.; gen neut pl with <u>nu</u> to sigma),</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> List of Latin suffixes: <i>alis/aris/anus/icus</i>

proper name), -<i>ia</i> (n., quality), -<i>ium</i> (n., action or result of

informational question; -<i>osus</i> (adj., full of), -<i>or</i> (n., action or
result of action), -<i>que</i>, meaning and; -<i>tas</i> (ta[ts], n.,
quality), -<i>tia</i> (quality), -<i>tio</i>[ns]/<i>sio</i>[ns] (n., action or
result of action), <i>-tor/-sor/-trix</i> (n., agent), -<i>tudo</i>[ns] (n.,
quality), -<i>ve</i> (or;) </span></p>

text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a type of

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *voiceless, *voiced)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>surname</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) the last name,
the *given name, the family name that identifies the persons as immediate relatives;
(2) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *given name, *maiden name,

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *rejoinder)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>survey</span></b><span style='font-size:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>swear</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (n a set with
*curse/cuss, *oath)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sweet talk</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to talk nicely and encouragingly to get someone to like you and get them to do
something, used especially of a man to a woman or a young person to a
grandmotherly type.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>syllable</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a unit of
pronunciation within a word consisting of a vowel sound (a-/-au), or a vowel
sound (vowel or diphthong) and a consonant (or consonant cluster: <i>as/oil/ask/ails</i>),
or a consonant (or consonant cluster) and a vowel (or diphthong) and a
consonant (or consonant cluster (<i>sap/gait/gaits/shaft</i>). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Greek, syllables were considered long
or short depending on whether they had a long or short vowel in them. In Latin,
a long syllable is one with a long vowel or a syllable with more than one
consonant after the vowel.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span lang=FR style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(in a set with
*syllabification; *monosyllable, *disyllable, *trisyllable, *multisyllabic;
*parisyllable)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>syllabism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the use of characters to represent syllable rather than individual sounds in
writing</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>syllabic augment</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
On the front of Greek verbs beginning with consonants, syllabic augment helped
mark the *secondary tenses of the *indicative mood by adding an epsilon. See
also *temporal augment. (in a set with *augment, *temporal augment). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>syllabification</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
dividing a written word into its pronounceable units so as to know where to
break it at the end of a written line, for example. Greek and Latin syllables
consist of a consonant or pronounceable consonant cluster followed by the
vowels that appear before the next consonant. A series of vowels that do not
form diphthongs are separate syllables. Two same consonants are divided, and
identifiable prefixes and suffixes are disjoined from the root. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Beyond a few basic patterns, English
syllabification is rather complex so as to necessitate looking up the word in a
dictionary. As in Greek and Latin, English words are divided between two same
consonants, after certain identifiable prefixes and before standard suffixes.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>syllabus</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a document in a
college class that gives information about the class: purpose, assignments,
grading scheme, dates of meeting, outline of the materials, <i>etc</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>syllepsis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a construction in which a word governs two or more words but agrees with only
one in number, gender, and case or has a different meaning with one than with
the other: (Webster) Over Thanksgiving he went to Arrow Head Stadium and caught
a game and a cold. Can be applied to situations in inflected languages where
one adjective modifies two nouns of different gender: <i>multi </i>[m] <i>viri</i>
[m] <i>et feminae</i> [f], many men and women (Latin).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>symbol</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a character that
represent and idea or sound</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>syncopate</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to shorten a word by dropping out an element in the middle; a kind of
*contraction</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>syncopated nouns</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
nouns that have a vowel in the nominative singular ultima and lose it
elsewhere: <i>meet<u>ee</u>r/meetros, pat<u>ee</u>r/patros, thugat<u>ee</u>r/thugatros</i>,
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>syncope</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the dropping out
of a middle part of a word: <i>bosn </i>(boatswain), <i>gunwale</i>
(pronounced <i>gunnel</i>), <i>noreaster</i>, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>synonym</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a word that has
approximately the same meaning as another. Strictly speaking, no two words in a
language are absolute synonyms. They may differ in their connotationstheir
feelor in the subject matter where they are used. (in a set with *antonym) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>synopsis</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a summary. In
instructional grammars, the synopsis of a verb is a representative formlike
third person singular or first pluralfrom each place it occurs in the verb
system. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *conspectus, *model)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>synoptic gospels</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the first three gospels in contrast to Johns gospel. So-called because the
three see the subject matter together. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>syntax</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the connection
between parts of a sentence , parts of an expression (cp. *grammar)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>synthesis</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/<b>synthetic</b>:
the use of inflectional affixes to indicate syntactical relationships in
contrst to using *distribution (placement in the sentence) for that purpose, as
in English.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *thesis and *antithesis;
*distribution)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>syntax</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the relationship
between words in a sentence. That relationship may be indicated by word order,
as in English, by inflection of individual words, or by a combination of these
possibilities. An example of the predominance of word order in English is the possibility
of changing a words normal part of speech by changing its placement in the
sentence. Savvy employees <u>position</u> themselves for advancement in the
company (A -<i>tion</i> word, originating as a noun, is here used as a verb). Those
biology dissections <i>weird</i> me out (adjective shift to verb).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>syn</span></b><b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>topi</span></b><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>con</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a scholarly reference work, alphabetically arranged by topic through key words,
that traces a concept through many authors over time. References into the
original works give access to crucial passages in the discussion. Note <i>The
Great Ideas: A Syntopicon of Great Books of the Western World, </i>2 vols.
Encyclopdia Britannica, Inc., 1952. As a work that deals with ideas, a
syntopicon differs from a dictionary or lexicon, which deal with the meaning of
<u>words</u>; and from an encyclopedia by being limited to <u>concepts</u>, ideas,
beliefs in contrast to <u>geography</u> and <u>history</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *dictionary, *lexicon;
*encyclopedia)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>syzygy</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the combining of
two *feet into one metrical foot in classical prosody WB</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>table of contents</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an entry near the front of a longer work that shows in sequence the chapters or
parts of the contents that follow.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tag line</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a *punch line, a
final line in a piece that drives home the point of the piece; a slogan for a
product or company that serves that same purpose: and thats the cold truth
(Alka Seltzer); Lets build something together (Lowes).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tagmeme: </span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>take-off</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: Beginning with
some already-known wording or idea, a new author elaborates or adapts it his
own purposes </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tale</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> a story not to be
taken too seriously; perhaps even a lie, as in he is telling a tale.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>talk</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: loose, general
word for communicate, verbalize. <i>Talk</i> can be used in a *pejorative way
to refer to words spoken as disconnected from internal conviction: Thats just
talk.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>talkathon</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a playful take-off on <i>marathon</i> applied to talking, hence, a long,
drawn-out discussion or presentation, but not necessarily as a delay tactic (in
a set with *filibuster)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>talking point</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
items on a subject that are made part of a presentation or discussion. The
implication can be that an over-all impression, or spin, can be created by the
choice of elements included or omitted.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Talmud</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: Hebrew word for
instruction technically applied to the collection of rabbinic writings so
named and consisting of the Gemara () and Mishnah (), which then serves as the
basis for much of traditional Jewish law.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>targum</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: Hebrew word for translated;
hence, a translation. It is applied to the Aramaic *translations/*paraphrases
(and quasi-commentaries) of the Hebrew Old Testament text. They arose in the
time when the masses (the <i>hoi polloi</i> [the many], the <i>am haaretz</i>,
[the people of the land]) did not readily understand classical Hebrew.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tattle</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: to tell on
someone who has done something not otherwise known to the one/s responsible for
the situation; implies relatively minor things that go on between young kids</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tattle tail</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
one who tattles</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tau</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: nineteenth letter of
the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>taunt</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> to jeer someone
especially in order to get a response out of him </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tautology</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
saying the same thing twice with different words: widow woman () [Gr ta + auta
= tauta]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tautonym</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the same name
twice, a terminology in zoology where the genus and species name is the same</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tav</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the twenty-second
letter of the Hebrew alphabet. Also <u>taw</u>: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>taw</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the twenty-second
letter of the Hebrew alphabet. Also <u>Tilgath-pilneser</u>: </span><span
lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
dir=LTR></span><span lang=HE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span dir=LTR></span> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>taxeme</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a grammatical
feature that does not carry meaning by itself; its contextual placement is what
WB check out</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>taxonomy</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a system of
naming items in a group as exemplified in the scientific system of two-word
designation for flora and fauna (plants and animals; living things).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>teach</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (<i> vs.</i>
preach)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>technical term</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a term that is more limited in its application, given its derivational meaning,
than it is in general usage. <u>Rain check</u> is an expression that originated
from outdoor settingslike baseballwhere the ticket was not able to be used
because of inclement weather. It is now applied to a wide range of situations
where something is not able to be used or done, as in a rain check for some
sale item the store has run out of. <u>Organ crawl</u> was first used for
crawling around the pipes of a pipe organ to see how they were assembled, <i>etc.</i>
Now it is used for organ inspections where no crawling needs to be involved. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *archaism, *buzz word,
*catch phrase, *colloquialism, *curse word, *formal term, *informal term,
*oath, *obsolete, *provincialism, *regionalism, *slang, *vulgarism)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>telecommunication</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
communication at a distance made possible by electronic devicesradio,
television, computers, telegraph, telephone</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>teleconference</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a conference between people separated from each other but united by electronic
device in order to carry on business</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>telegram</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a brief note sent
by telegraph to inform someone </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>telegraph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a device for sending and receiving messages by electronic impulses</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>telegraphy</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the process of using telegraph communication</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>telephone</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an electronic device for sending sound messages by impulses through land lines
instead of radio waves</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>temporal augment</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
The front of Greek verbs were augmented to help mark secondary tenses of the
indicative mood. On verbs beginning with vowels, temporal augment basically
lengthened the vowel, following standard patterns of lengthening: alpha to eta,
omicron to omega, iota to long iota, and upsilon to long upsilon. Naturally,
initial eta and omega words could not be lengthened further. Epsilon was
lengthened either by going to eta or to an epsilon-iota diphthong. See also
*syllabic augment. (in a set with *augment, *syllabic augment)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>temporal clause</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a type of dependent adverbial clause used to mean when, while, after, before,
and the like. Latin formula: <u>cum</u> + indicative; Gr = <u>hote</u> <i>etc.</i>,</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Ten Commandments, The</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the listing of Gods commandment given through Moses as found in Ex <b>20</b>:1-17
and Deut <b>5</b>:1-21.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tendential imperfect</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Among the uses of the imperfect tense in Greek is the tendency for an action to
occur. That may be the point of the imperfect in Acts 5:13, But of the rest,
no one tended-to-be-bold enough to-join them. The next verse talks about a
multitude of believersmen and womenbeing added to the Lord.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tendential result: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>the
result in Greek grammar that tended to come as a result of action in the main
verb. (in a set with *actual result). In distinction from *actual result, it
may be translated so as to rather than so that. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tense:</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *person,
*number, *mood, *voice, and *aspect as possible features of verb forms)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tense: </span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Tenses may not be
identified in one language <i>vs.</i> another one even though the same ideas
can be expressed in either. Tenses are traditionally identified by <u>form</u>.
Latin and Greek do not ordinarily identify progressive present (as English can)
because there is no distinctive wording or verbal morpheme corresponding to
that idea (Greek can construct a periphrastic present past and future by using
a finite form of to be plus a participles). With the extensive use of *circumlocution
and *auxiliary verbs, English can nuance progression (are/are/was/were +
__ing), emphasis (do/does/did + __), ingression (began-to-). Other languages often
depend on context or the hearers independent understanding of the subject to
*infer these kinds of distinctions.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>  Present perfect</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Pluperfect (past perfect)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Future perfect</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Futuristic present: In English, the
present tense can be used in place of the future, especially in certain
if-clauses:  If you <u>go</u> downtown tomorrow, please pay the mortgage.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (See *primary tense, *secondary tenses;
*present tense, *imperfect tense, *past tense, *aorist tense, *preterite,
*present perfect tense, *pluperfect ( = *past perfect tense), *future perfect
tense, *future tense; *progressive present tense, * progressive future tense,
*progressive past tense, *emphatic present tense, *emphatic future tense,
*emphatic past tense, *vivid narration.)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tense formative</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:<b>
</b>See *tense sign.<b> </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tense sign</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
some element that indicates present, past, future, <i>etc.</i>, times for the
action on verbs. Also called *tense formative. English uses an auxiliary word
prior to the verb itself: <u>will</u> (and <u>shall</u>) work. In Greek and
Latin the tense signs appear between root and personal endings: <i>b</i> for
future in Latin, <i>s</i> for future in Greek; -<i>ba</i>- for the imperfect in
Latin; -(<i>k</i>)<i>a</i>- as the tense sign for perfect active in Greek. Greekand
Latin less uniformlyalso uses *reduplication on the front of the word as part
of the sign for the perfect active tense. Greek has (theta)-eta as the main
tense sign for aorist passive and (theta)-eta-sigma for future passive. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin, the sign of the perfect is often
reduplication and/or vowel changes within the root as well as additions to the
end of the root just before a distinct personal ending set. *Tense formatives
for the perfect active include v/i for most verbs in <i>are</i>, -u/i, -s/i,
loss of a root nasal(?)</span></p>

text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> -avi</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In English, several verbs use infixes to
change the tense: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *tense, *tense formant, *present
tense, <i>etc.</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tenuis</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a voiceless,
unaspirated stop (<i>p, t, k</i>), especially of interest in ancient Greek</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *aspirated; *voiced; *stop,
fricative, *nasal, *plosive *trill)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>term</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a word</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>termination</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an ending within the word that provides various alterations to the root ,
depending on the part of speech: number, gender, case (n. &amp; adj.); person,
number, tense, voice, mood (v.); part of speech (adv.). More limited in reference
than *suffix, which is not just adjustments within the root itself, but also
includes the addition of parallel ideas: -ology, -ostomy, <i>etc.</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *suffix, *infix, *prefix,
*affix)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>terminal form</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the shape a letter takes at the end of a word in contrast to its form
elsewhere: Greek uses a different form of <i>sigma</i> at the end of a word;
Hebrew does the same thing with five of its letters: . A similar thing happens
with English words that end in <i>y</i> when vowel suffixes are added. The <i>y</i>
is often changed to <i>i </i>before the additions are made even though there is
no change in sound: vary &gt; varied.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>terminology</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the words chosen to express an idea, particularly for a given subject. Often
the terminology for a subject has been lifted out of the general vocabulary and
specialized to the needs of explanation for the subject at hand. Though things
can be explained in a number of ways, people who deal with specific subjects tend
to settle on a collection of terms to convey the matters involved. (in a set
with *jargon)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Tersanctus</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
The Latin equivalent of *Trishagion (Greek), the three holys that appear in
Is <b>6</b>:3 and Rev<b> 4</b>:8 in address to God.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>terse</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: short and to the
point, perhaps with a connotation of rudeness</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>testament</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) a written document that serves as tangible proof of ownership, a will for
the disquisition of property, and the like. (2) a set of beliefs; (3) either of
the main divisions of the Biblethe Old Testament and the New Testament. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>testify</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) to give
witness in a court of law;<b> </b>(2) in biblical usage outside a legal
setting, to give witness, bear testimony, to declare openly and confidently as
when John the Baptist identified Jesus as the Lamb of God that takes away the
sin of the world (Jn <b>1</b>:29). (3) in modern Christian setting, an
expression for *witnessing to non-Christians about the articles of Christian
belief and practice. (in a set with *witnessing)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>testimonial</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a favorable statement about someones character or accomplishments; a
recommendation, a *tribute</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>testimony</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the content given when a person testifies</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tet/teth</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the ninth letter
of the Hebrew alphabet: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:14.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span dir=LTR></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span> retroflexed <i>t</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tetragrammeton</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the four-consonant personal name of the Hebrew God, probably vocalized
Yahveh/Yahweh. [&lt;Lat tetra + Gr grapho, 4 + written] </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *Jehovah, *Yahveh, *Yahweh)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tetralogy</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a set of four related wordsplays, (in a set with *trilogy) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tetrameter</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>a

12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a diacritical

over the Spanish <i>n</i> to indicate the <i>ny </i>sound as in <i>seor</i> or

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>timbre</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the quality of

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>time</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: time references
can be (1) time when, references to time as a fact. It can be diagrammed as a
point &lt; . &gt; : She slept <i>that night</i>. (2) *Time during, or time
within which, indicates the time frame during which some act or event occurred.
It can be diagrammed as ( . . . ): She slept <i>during the day</i>. (3) *Extent
of time indicates how long some act or event lasted. It can be diagrammed as as
an arrow </span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
Wingdings'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>: She slept (for) one night.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Time words are the singular and plural of
words like <i>second, minute, hour, day, week, fortnight, month, year, decade,
score, century, millennium; </i>dates like<i> ides</i>; <i>Monday</i>, <i>etc.</i>;
<i>January</i>, <i>etc.</i>; general words like <i>time</i> (for a long time). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Time may be indicated by nouns, nouns in
prepositional phrases, or adverbs (<i>later, right away, sometime, soon, today,
tonight, tomorrow, yesterday</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *time during/time within
which, *time when, *extent of time)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>time during</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek, time during is covered by the genitive case on the time word without
the need of a preposition. <i>Dia</i> + G is also used: Acts<b> 5</b>:19. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin time during is covered by the
ablative case: he worked <i>during the night</i>. Same as *time within which.
Latin does not formally distinguish *time when from *time during, covering both
by the ablative case on the time word. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *time, *time when, *extent
of time)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>time when</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In Greek, time when is covered by the dative case on the time word. In Latin,
it is covered by the ablative case: He works <i>at night</i>. English can use
<i>in, on,</i> or <i>at</i> ahead of the time indicator, but often there is no
preceding preposition. With dates and times, <i>in, on, </i>or <i>at</i>
normally occurs: He came back from Georgia <i>on</i> Mo</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>day/<i>on</i>
the twelfth/<i>in</i> September. He went to word <i>at</i> noon. But there
is no preposition necessarily in he came home (<i>on</i>) Monday afternoon.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *time, *time during/*time
within which, *extent of time)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>time within which</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
same as time during</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tip</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an every-day term for
an addition either before or after the *root of a word; a *prefix or *suffix.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>title: </span></b><span style='font-size:

text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tittle</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a little horn (<i>kepaia</i>;
diminutive of <i>keras</i>) used originally to indicate small, perhaps variable
or optional, part of a letter like the horns (flourishes, *serifs) on Hebrew
letters (Mt <b>5</b>:18 = Lk <b>16</b>:17). Broadened somewhat to include
diacritical marks in the spelling of some words such as accent marks, or to
indicate vowel marks, or to refer to the dot on an <i>i.</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *jot; *serif)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Tom Swifty</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a humorous *word play that takes advantage of the multiple meanings of words: She

up all the shades while you have the hang of it. A type of groaner. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *double meaning, *multiple

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tome</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a large book (in

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tone language</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tone marks</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
what are called accents in Greek are actually tone marks for rise tones (acute),
fall tones (grave), or rise-fall tones (circumflex). In tonal languages, such
tones can distinguish meanings as these Greek example show: </span></p>

</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tongue</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: another word for
