<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tongue in cheek</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
something said that is obviously not meant in a straightforward way, an ironic
or facetious utterance, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tongue speaking</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
same as *speaking in tongues (in a set with *ecstatic utterance, *glossolalia, *speaking
in tongues, *xenoglossia)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tongue twister</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>topic sentence</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
usually the lead sentence in a paragraph that sets the subject matter for the rest
of the paragraph.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>toponym</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Torah</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the Hebrew term
for law, used as a name for the five books of Moses, Genesis through
Deuteronomy. (in a set with *Chetuvim and *Neviim)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tract</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:<b> </b>a small,
short piece designed for quick acquaintance with an important issue </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *book, *reference book, *pamphlet)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tractate</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a s</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ll
*tract</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>trade language</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a more universal language used in widespread commerce that reaches beyond the
scope of local languages (in a set with *pigeon language)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>trademark</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a symbol or *logo that a company puts on its product for identification
purposes. It may be marked with a small,  or circled  to show that it is
claimed for exclusive use; it is a trademark, a registered, copyrighted symbol.
The stylized picture of Willie the Wildcat is the logo that appears one items
associated with Kansas State University. To put that symbol on its product,
another company may have to pay a fee.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tradition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) a custom that has arisen over time and is maintained to reinforce the
identity of the group or to help fix attention on something considered
important: the standardized I do at weddings, to put up decorations at
Christmas. (2) A story of some event or person that is not recorded in written
form but passed down orally through generations. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *legend, *lore)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tragedy</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a play or
literary piece whose main character suffers great loss because of what happens
to him or because of some character flaw that brings tragedy on himself. A
story with an unhappy ending. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *comedy)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>transcribe/transcription</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a copying into clearer form, reproducible form, fuller form as from a
physicians notations, from short-hand to full text, from one place to another
as from an artifact or monument.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>transcript</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the academic record of a student in high school or college.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;

mechanisms. It can happen </span></p>

into an equivalent passive-voice format:</span></p>

an equivalent attributive participle construction:</span></p>

"Times New Roman",serif'> When transforming a statement into a

"Times New Roman",serif'> When transforming an adverbial clause into
an equivalent participial construction or an *absolute construction:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>transformational generative grammar</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an analysis of grammar that highlights the patterns by which one grammatical
structure can be changed into another as with statement into question, participial
phrase into a *relative clause, *direct discourse into *indirect discourse,
*direct question into *indirect question,</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>transitional form/expression</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an expression set off in commas that connects what has been said with what will
be said. Transitional forms differ from conjunctions in that they make
conceptual connection more than grammatical connection: <i>accordingly, as a
result, consequently, hence</i>; </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>otherwise, so, then, therefore, thus;
additionally, also, besides, furthermore, in addition, moreover, too, what is
more; </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> after all, all in all, all
things considered, briefly, by and large, in any case, in any event, in brief,
in conclusion, in short, in summary, in the final analysis, in the long run, on
balance, on the whole, to sum up; </span></i></p>

font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> as a rule, as usual, for the
most part, generally, generally speaking, in general, ordinarily, usually;  by

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;

font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> by the by, by the way,
incidentally; </span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> for example, for instance, for
one thing; </span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> in essence, in other words,
namely, that it, that is to say;  </span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Another term for <u>adverbial conjunction</u>
or <u>adverbial connective</u>. Gregg31-32</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>transition</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
passing from one topic to another, from one part of presentation to another
(*splice)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>transitive verb</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a verb that has a direct object in contrast to one that does not. While some
words may always be used transitively, transitiveness has to be figured on a
case-by-case basis. <i>Work </i>is typically in*intransitive: He worked
yesterday; but it can be transitive: The point guard worked <u>the clock</u>
so the team would get the last shot of the half. Consequently, a dictionary
can give only a general verdict on whether a verb is transitive or
intransitive.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Some words may change meaning when used
one way or the other. He dranks <u>the water</u>; but his wife does not know
that he drinks on business trips. As an intransitive verb, <i>drink </i>means
drink alcohol.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *intransitive verbs; *linking
verbs/*equative verb/*to be verb/*copulative verb, *fientive verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>translatable</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
ideally, able to be expressed in another language without loss or addition of
*meaning/*nuance/*connotation; a feature of one language that must be figured
on a per-language basis with each other language since something might be
translatable into one language but not into another.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *untranslatable)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>translation</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
<i>Translation</i> means transferring the <u>ideas</u> from one language to
another. Render is another word for <i>translate.</i> A translation can refer
to the whole body of a work while <i>rendering</i> looks at specific texts,
passages, <i>etc.</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Since
languages differ so much in how they operate, it is frequently difficult to get
everything in the one transferred over into the other. An African language, for
example, has a tag on its verbs that indicates whether an action is legitimate.
Imagine the difficulty that factor presents if the other language has no
information on that point. Consequently, things are said to be lost in
translation. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Language is a matter of <u>forms</u> (words,
word parts, and word combinations) used to convey <u>meanings</u> (*referents).
Since meaning and form are conventional (not inherently necessary) and since
forms and referents are usually not one-to-one, no two languages are likely to
choose the same forms for exactly the same meanings. The translators must
match up as well as possible the overlapping circles that exist across the two
languages between words and expressions that are closest to each other.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> There is a two-step device that helps keep
the meaning close to the original and yet allows it to be idiomatic. Step 1
parallels the wording of the new language as closely as possible to the
original one. Step 2 rewords it in a way a speaker would say it. Ideally the
shift from step 1 to step 2 does not add lose contenta task more difficult
than it might seem. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Distinctions relevant to translation
include the difference between <u>translation and transliteration</u>. <i>Translation</i>
deals with ideas; <i>transliteration</i> deals with symbols. Transliteration
writes the sounds of one language in the alphabet designed of another. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A distinction needs to be drawn between <u>translation
and truth</u>. So to speak, translation deals not with truth but with
translation; it simply represents in another language the original writers
intended ideas. The translator does not have to believe what he is translating;
he simply has to translate it. In a similar vein, it is not the translators
prerogative to make the text say what he thinks is true or what he would have
said. This fundamental character of the translators work has been seriously
breached by inclusive-language translations of the Bible. In the interests of
getting the Bible to say what feminist theoreticians want it to say, the text
is not allowed, for instance, to say <i>He</i> in reference to God because that
is not considered true. It is not the role of the biblical translator to correct
the content to his own understanding. If in commentary, preaching, or teaching
a spokesperson wants to make explanatory notations to the effect that
male/female is not a variable applicable to God, that is another thing; but the
text itself needs to be left alone.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> There is also a consideration of <u>translation
and interpretation</u>. Good translation depends on proper understanding of the
authors intended meaning. Indeed, the Greek word for <i>interpret</i> and <i>translate</i>
is the same: (<i>di/meth</i>)<i>ermeeneuoo</i>. If, for some reason, the
meaning is ambiguous or unknowable, re-expressing that meaning in the new
language is unavoidably inadequate. About all a translator can do is to make a
word-for-word parallel accompanied by an *asterisk and marginal note that explain
the difficulty and the options. In translating ancient texts, scholars can be
hampered by vocabulary not known from elsewhere (*<i>hapax legomena</i>) or by words
used in technical or otherwise unique ways that cannot be deciphered with
confidence. At a higher level, the ideas expressed by words may not be
retrievable because they address items, customs, or beliefs lost in antiquity. Indeed,
the original writer may say something that would have been unclear even to a
fellow native speaker or something capable of more than one interpretation. In
all these circumstances, the resultant translation should be as precise or unclear
as the original itself.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Finally, a difference can be maintained
between <u>translation and *paraphrase</u>. A paraphrase approaches the enterprise
in a way that reflects how the translator would have worded the matter from
scratch. Of course, there are degrees of looseness. The danger is that the
farther the translator moves from conveying the ideas in the authors original
terms, the easier it is to bend the ideashowever unconsciouslyin the
direction of his own thinking. Correctness, however, is not achieved by
maintaining word-for-word parallel with the original. *Connotation particularly
is lost or gained in moving from formal equivalence to paraphrase. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>A</i> translation is also called a
*version.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *pony, *transliteration,
*translation types, *version)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>translation types </span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> word-for-word</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> wooden </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> formal equivalence</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> literal</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> paraphrastic</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *pony</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> loose</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> functional equivalent</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>transliteration</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
means transferring the <u>symbols/letters</u> for one language into the letters
of anotherusing the letters of one *alphabet to represent the sounds of a
different alphabet. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek transliteration into English. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> There is some difference between the way
Greek letters are spelled phonetically in English letters and the way English
*derivatives from Greek words are spelled. That is evident with <i>upsilon, </i>which
has derivatives spelled with <i>y</i> instead of <i>u</i>: <i>psychee</i>,
rather than <i>psuchee.</i> Derivatives often use <i>c</i> for <i>kappa</i>
instead of <i>k</i>: <i>cacophony</i> (bad sound) from <i>kakos</i> + <i>phonee</i>.
But note <i>leu<u>k</u>o-</i> for <i>leukos</i> (white). The diphthong <i>ai</i>
has undergone a pattern of <i>ai</i> &lt; <i>ae</i> &lt; <i>e. </i>Some of
todays words represent one stage of that development: <i>arch<u>ae</u>ology</i>
(<i>archaios</i>, old); others represent a further stage: <i>encyclop<u>e</u>dia</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A similar pattern is observed with <i>oi</i>
&lt; <i>oe</i> &lt; <i>e</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew transliteration</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew transliteration into Greek. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The transliteration problem shows itself
in the Bible where Hebrew names have been transliterated into Greek and then
transliterated from Greek into English. All three alphabets lack the ability to
represent adequately the range of sounds in the other two languages. In the
older translations like the King James, Hebrew names were standardized within
the Old Testament, but in the New Testament those same names were
transliterated into English as based on their Greek spellings instead of being
matched up consistently with the original ones. For instance, Greek had no <i>h</i>
sound except in initial position, hence: <i>Barachias </i>(<i>Berechiah</i>), <i>Elias
(Elijah), Isaias</i> (<i>Isaiah</i>), <i>Jeremias</i> (<i>Jeremiah</i>), <i>Jonas</i>
(<i>Jonah</i>), <i>Zacharias </i>(Zechariah), <i>etc.</i> Then there were <i>Osee
</i>(<i>Hosea</i>)<i>, </i>Newer translations have been avoiding this
unnecessary difference between Old Testament and New Testament spellings of the
same name.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *translation)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>transpose</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
reverse the sequence of items or letters (*metathesis). In Hebrews hithpael
stem, if the root begins with a sibilant after the <i>hith-</i> prefix, <i>tav</i>
and sibilant reverse, or transpose, to avoid a perceived difficult combination
of sounds. Akin to besgetti in a childs mispronunciation of <i>spaghetti</i>.
The dental-sibilant sequence causes problems in Greek and Latin as well. In a
set with eliding the dental, dropping the sibilant, throwing away both the
dental and sibilant, interfixing a vowel.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>treatise</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a writing that
treats some subject, a serious written study </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>treaty</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an agreement
between political entities</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tribute</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a favorable
public statement about a persons character, achievements</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>trigraph</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: three letters
that form one sound like <i>sch</i> in <i>schist, schnookl, schuss, </i>the
German <i>schule, </i>or Hebrew <i>schwa</i>. (in a set with *digraph)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>trilingual</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in three languages or able to speak three languages. The *superscription on
Jesus cross was trilingual (Jn <b>19</b>:20), reflecting the fact that Latin,
Hebrew/Aramaic, and Greek were currently used in the land. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *bilingual, *monolingual)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>triliteral root</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
three-letter *root, a designation for the three-consonant form of most Hebrew
verbs and many of its other words. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *quadriliteral root, *weak
verbs)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>trill</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a series of fast
contacts between the tongue and a pronunciation pointglottal, velar, dental,
labial</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>trilled <i>r</i></span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(in a set with *flapped <i>r</i>)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>trilogy</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a set of three
related works (in a set with *tetralogy)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>trimeter</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a line of verse
containing three metrical feet </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *tetrameter, *pentameter,
*hexameter)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>triolet</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an eight-line
stanza with rhyme scheme <i>abaaabab, </i>in which the last two lines duplicate
the first two<i> </i>lines</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>triple-space</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
having two blank lines between lines of type; typed on every third line</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>triplet</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *couplet)
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>triplicate</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in three copies, an expression that was used when typewriters were in general use
and the typist made two carbon copies at the same time as the original </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *duplicate)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Trishagion</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Greek form; same meaning as the *Tersanctus (Latin), the three holys that
appear in Isaiah 6:3 and repeated again in Rev <b>4</b>:8 in address to God.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>trisyllable/trisyllabic</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word having three syllable</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>trochee</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a metrical foot
with a long-short, stressed-unstressed sequence of syllables </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *anapest)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>trope</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a figure of
speech </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *allegory, *euphemism,
*hendiadys. *irony, *metaphor, *metonymy, *simile, *zeugma)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>trove</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a collection of
valuable items in a certain category, as in a trove of epigraphic texts </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>truism</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: something
patently true, obviously true; something anybody would know. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tsade</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the eighteenth
letter of the Hebrew alphabet: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
dir=LTR></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span> with </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span dir=LTR></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span> as its terminal form: Also </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>sade/sadhe</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tutor</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: an assistant that
helps a student that is having difficulty in a specific course.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>tutorial</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a medium by
which individualized instruction is given on some topic</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>typo</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: short for
typographical error, a mistake made at a keyboard or type-set machine.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>typology</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the study of
comparisons between figures of different times in history. In scriptural study,
it is wise to identify entities as types of later figures only if scripture
makes that comparison. Otherwise, there is no boundary for using something
earlier as a kind of prediction of something later. (in a set with
*interpretation; predictive prophecy)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>unaccented</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
not having attention drawn to it by increased volume, raised pitch, or pausing</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>unaccented vowels</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
unaccented vowels in English tend toward shevalike the <u>e </u>in b<u>e</u>cause,
a phenomenon illustrated by the words calend<u>a</u>r, min<u>e</u>r, fak<u>i</u>r,
min<u>o</u>r, murm<u>u</u>r, mart<u>y</u>r.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>umlaut</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a horizontal
double dot over a German vowel to indicate *rounded pronunciation; equal to an <i>e</i>
written after a vowel. An umlaut looks like a *dieresis, another kind of
*diacritical mark. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>unattainable wish</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a wish that refers to present or past time. Since the situation is already past
or already in existence, it cannot be attained. In classical Greek the idea was
covered by <u>ei gar</u> or <u>either</u> plus the imperfect or aorist
indicative or by <u>ophelon</u> plus present or aorist infinitive for present
or past unattainable wishes respectively.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>uncials: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>inch-high
letters (in a set with *minuscules: cp. *capitals): </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>underlining</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
putting a line under words to emphasize them or in using words as words. (in a
set with *bold face print and *italics)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>underlining, continuous</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
underlining that continues under the spaces between words and under punctuation
that may be present </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>understatement</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
saying something at a lesser level than the situation really is. A teacher
might say to someone who has a 99% average in the class, I think you will pass
okay. Understatement is a manner of speaking sometimes associated with British
custom; a device that can be used for humorous purposes. (in a set with *over
statement, *exaggeration)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ungrammatical</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
understandable but not following the conventional rules of grammar: A great deal
of money <u>dont</u> lead men to wisdom; him and me are best friends;
between you and I; he be my help at work. now looking at the weather,
there is a cold front coming in.(in a set with *usage)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>uninflected</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
not having more than one form to indicate variation in meaning and syntax. Some
*parts of speech are not inflected in any language: adverbs, expletives,
interjections, prepositions. Even in highly inflected languages there may be a
few *indeclinable nouns like Latin <i>nihil, satis</i>, <i>etc.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>universal language</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
same as lingua franca, language used over a wide area where several more local
languages are used</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>unpointed text: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>the
Hebrew consonantal text without the *vowel points added later to facilitate
pronunciation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *pointed text)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>unreadable</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) illegible, unreadable because of the sloppiness of the writing; (2)
unreadable because it is written in an unknown *cipher</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>untranslatable</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
not able to be translated very precisely or efficiently into another language. Sometimes
*circumlocution can clarify the idea by departing from the strict correlation
of wording between the two languages. In some cases, it may take an explanatory
addition outside the flow of the text to make the idea cleara footnote,
endnote, sidenote, marginal note, bracketed noe within the text. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *translatable)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>unwritten</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
not written, a nevertheless known rule of operation, one that may not publicly
be acknowledged or so customary that it need not be said: it goes without
saying.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>upper case</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
another term for *capital letters (of the alphabet) or higher case <i>vs.</i> *lower
case (in a set with *lower case, *small letters; see also *common noun, *proper
noun; *minuscules, *majuscules; )</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>upsilon</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: twentieth letter
of the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>uptalk</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the habit saying
everything with the intonation of a question. According to <u>RD</u>, May,
2010, p. 131, <i>uptalk</i> was coined in 1993 by a professor at New York
University.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>utterance</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
vocal expression, statement</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>vade mecum</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a handbook, guidebook, something continuously useful.; built on the word
picture of something that goes everywhere with a person: Latin, <i>go with me</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>value</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the sound
quality of a letter of set of letters</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>valley talk</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>variant reading</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
After the advent of the printing press and modern copying machines, duplication
can be precise. In ancient manuscripts, which were copied by hand, however,
there were many more opportunities for mistakes to enter into the reproduction
process. Consequently, in New Testament and Old Testament as well as in copies
of other ancient writings, certain places in the texts vary in the way they
read from manuscript to manuscript. This fact gives rise to a discipline called
*textual criticism, which endeavors to retrieve the original, correct reading
wherever variants occur. It works out that no variant reading in the Bible
introduces a difference in doctrinal content.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Differences arise (a) because the original
different wordings of the same account in the *synoptic gospels have been
regularized. Perhaps the scribe, in an effort to be more efficient, relied on
memory too much and ended up confusing the different wordings of the two
accounts. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (b) Sometimes word order is changed.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (c) <b>put under textual criticism</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>[[list of major manuscript variants]]</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *textual criticism,
*dittography, *haplography, *homoioteleuton, *metathesis)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>vav</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the sixth letter of the
Hebrew alphabet.<b> </b>Also <u>waw</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>veiled</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: not quite clear
referenceveiled reference; implied, not straightforward, as in a veiled
threat.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>velar: a </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>sound
made with the tongue against the soft-palate in the back of the mouth; previously
called *<u>palatal</u> or even *guttural. (in a set with *labials, *dentals, *liquids,
*glottals)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>verbatim</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a word-for-word
restatement of someones comment. Same as <i>ad verbum</i>, Lat) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>verb</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a word with
certain inflection features and distribution placements in a sentence that
indicates what the subject is or is doing. Popularly defined as a word that
expresses action or state of being.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> An action verb refers to action, movement,
process in contrast to linking verbs, <i>etc.</i>, which indicate mere
existence</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Copulative verbs (= linking verbs,
equative verbs, state-of-being verbs)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Equative verbs (= linking verbs,
copulative verbs, state-of-being verbs)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Linking verbs (= copulative verbs,
equative verbs, state-of-being verbs)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> State-of-being verbs (= copulative verbs,
equative verbs linking verbs) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Fientive verbs: verbs that equal an
English linking verbs plus predicate adjective: is-strong</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Finite verbs, which indicate person</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Infinite verbals, which do not indicate
person; i. e., infinitives, participles, and gerunds</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Main verbs appear in independent clauses.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Dependent verbs appear in dependent
clauses.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Primary verb</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Auxiliary verb: English uses forms of the
verbs to be (is, are, was, were), do (do, does), have (has, have); may/might,
will/would, shall/should, can/could, tried to.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Regular verbs</u> are those whose other
principal parts are predictable by standard patterns starting with the first
principal part.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Irregular verbs</u> do not have
predictable principal parts.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Suppletive verbs</u> are irregular
verbs whose principal parts come from completely different roots: cp. English
go, went, gone; Gr phero, oiso, enenka; in NT lego; Lat fero, ferre, tuli,
latus and its cognates adfero, aufero, confero, offero, refero. (= *hybrid verb
wh 212)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Defective verbs</u> are those that do
not have all the normal principal parts.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Deponent verbs</u> are those that lack
one or more of possible voices in one or more of their principal parts. In
Greek there are first deponents, which lack the active voice only; as well as
second deponents, which lack both the active and middle voices. In the case of
second deponents, there is no third principal part because that principal part
supplies the base for active and middle voice in the aorist and future tenses;
consequently, those types of verbs have only a sixth principal part for
covering the aorist tense. (The third principal part provides the base for
active- and middle-voice forms.)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Transitive verbs have *direct objects
that complete the meaning: He cried a river.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Intransitive verbs do not have an object:
He cried.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Impersonal verb exists only in the third
person singular and technically has a in (phrase) as its subject: Latin <i>licet</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> A *merged verb (English) closely combines
a basic verb and an adverb in that order, either immediately or after
separation: She probably wears out the poor man/She probably wears the poor
man out. Please <u>look up</u> the number/Please <u>look</u> the number <u>up</u>.
Also called a *fused verb although the latter is technically limited to phrases
that cannot also be separated. The structure is similar to the Greek and Latin
practice of prefixing prepositions to verbs to nuance or stress their meanings.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>verbal</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a form derived
from a *finite verb: *infinitive, *participle, and *gerund. In addition, Latin
has *gerundive (future passive participle specifically) and *supine. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Classical Greek had verbals that derived
from the sixth principal part of the verb (-t[e]os, -t[e]a, -t[e]on) and were used
to express necessity.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>verbal adjunct</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
anything that connects with a verb*direct object, *indirect object, *adverb,
*prepositional phrase. This feature of grammar applies as well to
*verbals*participles, *gerunds, *infinitives, *gerundives, *supines. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>verbal inspiration</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a view of inspiration that attempts to avoid the ambiguity in use of <i>inspiration</i>
by itself as a description of scripture. Verbal means that its accuracy is not
a general conceptual matter, but lies at the level of the words of revelation
through Gods prophets.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *dictation theory of
inspiration, *dynamic inspiration, *infallibility, *plenary inspiration;
*inerrancy) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>verbal noun</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a noun derived from a verb, a *gerund, an *infinitive used in a noun slot.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>verbalism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an expression in words</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>verbalize</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to put a concept into words; to express it in words.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>verbiage</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the way
something is expressed in words; also wordiness, *verbosity</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>verify</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a possibility in
English that comes from its relatively sparse inflectional endings: to use a
noun in a verb slot, to  verb your nouns. Many English words like <i>work</i>
and <i>hammer</i> have been serving a dual role for a long time in the language
already. Verbing a noun in effect, then, means doing it to nouns that have
not yet been entered into that usage. to transition into a new role; to <i>position</i>
yourself for advancement in the company; <b>example</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>verbose</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: wordy, full of
words, using many words to say something or talking for a long time about it;
lacking economy of expression (in a set with *prolix)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>verbosity</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
wordiness [Latin: <i>verb</i>-, word, -<i>ose</i>, full of, -<i>ity</i>,
condition]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>verisimilitude</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
writing in a way appropriate to the setting of what is written about. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> An example in the New Testament may be
Acts <b>1-12</b> <i>vs.</i> Acts <b>13-28</b>. More distinctively Greek idioms
like *litotes appear in the last section, where the account chronicles the
Gentile mission, while *Hebraisms are more prevalent in the first part, where
the events take place in Palestine. Samuel Clemens [Mark Twain] draws attention
to that feature of his writing in <i>Tom Sawyer</i>. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>vernacular</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the standard, every-day, local language of the common person. In more recent
times, the Roman Catholic Church has adopted the practice of conducting
services in the vernacular in contrast to using universal ecclesiastical Latin
for that purpose, a practice in place for several hundred years.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>verse</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the shortest division
of a biblical text, which occurs within a chapter (except, of course, with the
four short New Testament books that do not have chapter divisions: Philemon, 1
John, 2 John, Jude)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In music lyrics, the verse is the
introductory section that leads to the chorus, which may repeat after each new
verse.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In poetry, a verse equals a set of lines. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *chapter, *book, *part,
*volume) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>version</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a *translation,
especially a translation of the same text in comparison with other translations
of the same writing. Outside a translation context, <i>version</i> can refer to
a particular form of a writing or account among several forms of the item </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>videlicet</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a marker for introducing a list [Latin: *crasis of <i>videre licet</i>, to see
is permitted]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>viewpoint</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the one through whose eyes a story is told Agatha Christies *mystery that
tells the story through the eyes of the guilty character. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *anthropocentric viewpoint,
*geocentric viewpoint, *omniscient viewpoint)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>vignette</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a short literary
sketch; a scene excerpted from a movie</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>visible speech</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a system used in teaching the deaf or hard-of-hearing to read lips, more
exactly to see all the factors that go into oral expression</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>vitriol</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: bitter, caustic,
hurtful criticism of someone</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>vivid narration</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the use of the *historic present instead of the past tense (perfect in Latin or
aorist in Greek) when giving an account of an occurrence in past time: Yesterday,
I am going downtown to pay my mortgage, and this guy stops me on the sidewalk
and . . . </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>vocabulary</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
(1) the words a language uses. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> *Cognate words are those that share the
same or similar base: work (noun), work (verb), workable/unworkable, workman,
working (man), (public) works, workbrittle, workhorse, workflow, worker,
workaholic, workout, workmanship, a work-up, and a number of other words.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> The speaking vocabulary, listening
vocabulary, and reading vocabulary are in ascending order of size according to
a native speakers use of the language.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) the distinctive words associated with
a particular discipline or field of study.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *inflection, *syntax)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>vocative case</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
case of direct address: John, come here, please.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In English, a vocative noun may be
preceded by the particle <i>O</i>, a practice that has largely fallen out of
usage. English has no distinctive case form, the usage being signaled by pause,
*distribution, or pitch pattern to keep it separate from the nominative. Written
English sets off the vocative with commas, reflecting the associated pitch
pattern and slight pause in oral expression.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin and Greek the case form for
vocative is always the same as the nominative in the plural. In the singular,
Greek <i>os</i> nouns use <i>e</i>, and in Latin the corresponding <i>us</i>
declension likewise uses <i>e</i> to indicate vocative. Virtually everywhere
else the nominative and vocative singular have the same form. Latin <i>ius</i>
nouns use <i>i</i> for vocative singular; for <i>meus</i> the vocative is <i>mi</i>;
and for <i>deus</i> the vocative plural is <i>di</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *nominative, *genitive,
*dative, *accusative, *ablative, *locative)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>vociferate</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
to speak loudly, vehemently, especially as in protest</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>voice</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: Depending on the
language, voice may be *active voice, *passive voice, *middle voice, or simply
*stative or *linking. Active voice has the subject acting in the verb. Passive
voice has the subject acted on by the verb. Middle voice has the subject acting
on itself or on a direct object so as to affect itself. A *linking verb does
not show action in the verb; it simply connects the subject with another noun
or *descriptor. A *stative verb is one that emphasizes the resulting condition
of the action: I have it done, one possible translation of the Greek and
Latin perfect tense.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *person, *number, *tense, *mood,
*aspect)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>voiced</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: having the vocal
cords vibrating in the making of the sound (in a set with *voiceless) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>voiceless</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
pertaining to a sound that does not have the vocal cords vibrating, as in a
whisper or with consonants that do not require the use of the vocal cords. (in
a set with *voiced; *surd) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>volume</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) degree of
loudness. (2) a subdivision of a large work that has more than one book form,
or codex, to contain the material. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *verse, *chapter,
*paragraph, *part, *book, *set, *reference)<b> </b></span></p>
