<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>word play</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
word usage that takes advantage of the multiple meanings of words; *paronomasia</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *groaner, *Tom Swifty)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>vowel</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *consonant, *liquid, *click,
*rounded vowel)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>vowel points</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
markings developed in the ??? century by the Masoretes?? for indicating the
vowel sounds that went with the consonants in the original Hebrew Old
Testament.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>vowel glide:</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> a
slide from one vowel to another; a kind of *diphthong. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *monophthong, *diphthong)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>vowelize</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: another
expression for adding vowel points as in Hebrew, whose basic alphabet is
consonantal.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>vulgarism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a term or expression with extremely negative connotation, meant in complete
disrespect and not welcome in polite company. (in a set with *archaism, *buzz word,
*catch phrase, *coarse talk, *curse word, *colloquialism, *formal term,
*informal term, *oath, *obsolete term, *provincialisms, *regionalism, *slang,
*technical term) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Vulgate</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the standard
Latin translation of the Bible used even today. It was finished by Jerome at
the end of the 300s A. D. and lies behind modern vernacular Roman Catholic
translations including the Confraternity Edition Bible in English. The Vulgate
replaced the Old Latin translation of the Bible, being better suited to use by
the masses. The term <i>vulgate</i> originally meant the language of the common
people, a usage related to the word <i>vulgar</i>, which has picked up a
negative connotation in modern English. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>waw</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the sixth letter of the
Hebrew alphabet. Also <i>vav</i>.: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>weak verb:</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> A
Hebrew verb that has a guttural as one of its root letters is called weak
verbs. Also pe-nun verbs, verbs that have nun in their initial root position </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *triliteral root, *quadr</span><span
lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>literal
root, *doubly weak verb)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>weasel word</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word used in such a way that it is intentionally misleading so as to avoid
taking a position or making a commitment<b> </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>western text</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(in a set with *majority text, *Byzantine text, *neutral text)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>will</span></i></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: (1) the main
auxiliary verb for expressing the future with English verbs; (2) as a
development off of futurity, <i>will</i> can indicate a persons intentions;
(3) a *testament by which one indicates his intentions for passing on property
after death</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>wisdom literature</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
Old Testament examples are Job and Proverbs; in the New Testament, The Sermon
on the Mount/Plain, James, and Jude are examples. Wisdom literature makes
observations and gives advice more exactly on the basis of the <u>nature of
things</u>what works or does not work. Thus, it is *advice more than
*commandment, which is based in the <u>authority of the essential author</u>. Wisdom
literature speaks about significant generalities, whereas law and commandment
speak in absolutes</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>witnessing</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
in modern religious usage, speaking to non-Christians about Christian belief
and practice; testifying, evangelizing<b> </b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>witticism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a cute, clever, light statement; *<i>bon mot</i> wh 217</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>word</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a free-standing
unit of communication that is understood by fellow speakers. Saying that
something is not a word is not strictly a cogent statement if it is meant by a
speaker and understood by hearers. What the expression is not a word means is
that it is not considered a proper word in educated society. Consequently,
the followingamong many othersare words: <i>aint, dark complected, hisself, irregardless,
theirselves</i>; all words for animal sounds: cluck, <i>meow, peep, quack, </i>[see
under *onomapoeia] </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>word building</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the creation of *vocabulary in a language by combining *roots, *suffixes,*
prefixes, *infixes (*morphemes). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Sequence of roots. In compound words with
more than one root, all the parts usually come from the same language. If Latin
or Greek is involved, all the parts of the word are likely to come from Greek
or from Latin. So the word is <i>n<u>y</u>ctalopia</i>, not <i>n<u>oc</u>talopia</i>
because the latter morpheme for <i>night </i>comes from Latin while the <i>al- </i>(blind)
and <i>opia</i> come from Greek.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In long compound words such as those
frequently found in medical terminology, the order of the roots follows the
sequence of the process. In the digestive process, the esophagus precedes the
stomach, which precedes the duodenum, <i>etc.</i> Consequently, the words will
be <i>esophagogastric</i> and <i>gastroduodenoscopy</i>. If the <i>esophagogastric</i>
addresses an acid reflux problem, however, it may be written <i>gastroesophageal</i>.
In medical terminology the body part comes first, followed by the condition or
procedure suffixed to the end.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Words ending in <i>ma</i> add<i> t</i>
before connecting vowel and any further additional elements. That happens
because the Greek words from which <i>ma</i> words come had a <i>t</i> that
ended the root everywhere except in the nominative singular. The *zero ending
in that place for third-declension neuter nouns meant that the dictionary form
would have ended in t. Greek words could not end in <i>t</i>, however; so the
letter <i>tau </i>was dropped unless inflection added a sound. Then it appeared
as part of the word. That same pattern applies to English derivatives of all -<i>ma
</i>words to yield forms like <b>[insert panel] </b><i>atheroma/atheromatai</i>;<i>
derma, dermatitis, dermatology</i>; <i>lipoma/lipomata</i>; <i>sarcoma/sarcomata</i>;<i>
soma/psychosomatic</i>; <i>stigma, stigmata, stigmatize</i>; <i>trauma/traumatology</i>;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>word of mouth</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the spread of information informally individual to individual without
deliberate intent to *advertise and without the use of *mass media. Similar to
social media in contrast to dispersal by official publication.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>word order</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> In Latin the basic word order is subject,
indirect object, direct object, adverbs, and verb; but the considerable
deviation from this sequence provides variety and emphasis. Languages like
Latin and Greek that have case endings do not need to maintain a particular sequence
of sentence parts. In *poetry the sequence is even more radical that in *prose.
If a word appears up front that by standard order more likely would to appear
later in the sentence, the author probably intends to emphasize it. Breaks from
standard order are noticeable and therefore stressed. *Interrogative words
typically appear at the front of their clause, whether they are subjects or
not.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> English has set formats because there are
no case indicators except with pronouns; so placement/distributionword
orderindicates the role a word has in the sentence. Flexibility in sequence is
greatly reduced from what it can be in the classical languages. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Latin has a basic sentence format
consisting of subject, indirect object, direct object, adverb, and verb. The
standard position for an adjective is after the noun it modifies: <i>femina
bona</i>. Demonstratives and numbers, however, usually precede the noun. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Some words do not appear first in their
clause, words said to be postpositive. English used to observe the custom of
not putting <i>however</i> at the front of a sentence. Latin has <i>autem</i>, <i>igitur</i>,
<i>inquit</i>, Greek has <i>de, gar, te</i>, </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> There are *bound constructions even in
highly inflected languages that do not have to depend on word order for
*syntax. Latin and Greek prepositional phrases have a noun-object sequence
(with the exception of one postpositive preposition in Greek, where its object
appears before the preposition: ). Latin departs from this uniformity when <i>cum</i>
has an object modified by an adjective; in that case the adjective precedes the
preposition (<i>magna cum laude</i>). When <i>cum</i> has a personal pronoun as
its object, it becomes a *postpositive attached to the end of the pronoun: <i>mecum</i>.
Some other Latin bound constructions have <i>causa </i>preceded by its genitive
(<i>remissionis causa</i>, for-the-sake of-forgiveness).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek always has its articles before its
nouns. With articular nouns, adjective always appear between article and noun
(first attributive position) or after the repeated article (*second attributive
position), or on the other side of a linking verb. Demonstratives, however,
always appear in *predicate position, that is before the article or after the
noun.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebrew typically puts the verb first
followed by the subject and direct object.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> German tends to puts its verb last.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (akin to *distribution, *postpositive)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>word parts</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
same as *morpheme; the smallest unit of meaning in a word. Thus word parts
include, *roots/*bases/*stems, *combining forms, *prefixes, *infixes, *suffixes
(in a set with *affix)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>word picture</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the imagery in a word because of its origin by derivation or coinage; probably
a better concept than the oft-used literal. The word picture is usually less
than its applied meaning. <i>Homosexual</i>, for example, by word picture means
same sex; but its applied meaning adds the element attracted to (the same
sex). The word for <i>resurrection </i>in Greek is <i>anastasis</i>, which is
comprised of <i>ana</i>, again, and <i>sta</i>-, to stand; its word
picture, then, is a standing again, but it is particularized into standing
again after being prone because of death.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> Sometimes the word picture does not even
involve the most crucial aspect of the *referent. <i>Epistaxis</i> is a word
for nosebleed, but nothing in it says nose. <i>Atelectasis</i> is a word
for collapsed lung, but nothing in it refers to lung. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>word play</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
*pun, *paronomasia. An expression that takes advantage of a words variant
meanings. The Golden Rule has been humorously restated to mean they that have
the gold have the rule; <u>golden</u> can mean very good or made of gold and <u>rule</u>
can mean principle of control.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>word square</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>word used as a word</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a word not used so much for its meaning or its role in the sentence, but for
its own identity. Such a word is always put in the <u>nominative case</u> in
Latin, Greek, and English: She said <i>he</i> four times in one sentence. A
word so used has singular number, taking a singular verb and singular
modifiers: <i>This <u>foolish one</u></i><u>s</u><i> </i>describe<i>s</i> the
monkeys.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>wordal/wordle</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
a collage of words related to a common theme and put on a page or sheet without
regard for order, symmetry, or maintaining horizontal direction.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>work</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a scholarly writing
in some important field of study; it may refer to a multi-volume set and
usually the result of one author. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *monograph, *book,
dictionary, *encyclopedia, *synopticon, *writing) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>workbook</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a book that
accompanies a *textbook and provides exercises that reinforce the materials
presented in the text.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>writ</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: a legal document
(in a set with *deed, *title) (in a set with *deed, *title)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>writer</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: another term for
author, even if that person dictated the text to a stenographer. The person who
writes the <u>words</u> of a song in contrast to <u>composer</u>, who writer
the music.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *author, *lyric, *lyrics,
*lyricist, *libretto)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>writing</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: putting
something down on paper in contrast to oral expression; *cursive in contrast to
printing. Originally applied to handwritten works, but retained after the
printing press as a designation for an authors work however produced.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *prose, *poetry; *block
lettering, *scrawl, *scribble)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>writings</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the compositions
by which an author has formally expressed himself on subjects of interest to
him; implies a scholarly product </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>xenoglossia: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>speaking
in an actual contemporary foreign language, especially by the enablement of the
Holy Spirit in contrast to a foreign language learned by normal means</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (in a set with *glossolalia, *ecstatic
utterance, *speaking in tongues. *tongue speaking)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>xi</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: fourteenth letter of
the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>xylograph</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
an engraving on wood</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Yahveh/Yahweh</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
the approximate vocalization of the *tetragrammeton, the ineffable name of the
Hebrew God</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>yellow journalism</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
uninhibited, careless journalism usually negative or defamatory</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>yod/yodh</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the tenth letter
of the Hebrew alphabet: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span dir=LTR></span><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span dir=LTR></span>you
advised</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>: the use of <i>you</i> as an *indefinite pronoun in
place of <i>one, a person, someone</i>: When <i>you</i> throw a curve ball, <i>you</i>
put <i>your</i> fingers on the seams this way.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>zayin</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the seventh
letter of the Hebrew alphabet</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: <span lang=HE dir=RTL></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>zed</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the letter <i>z</i> in
British *parlance.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>zero ending</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
In an inflection set, the absence of an ending parallel to the others endings
becomes significant. +Latin examples. It occurs in the neuter nominative
singular of third-declension Latin nouns and in the nominative masculine
singulars of er nouns and adjectives in the second declension. Ex. Latin, 2<sup>nd</sup>
sg imperative active (da, give); nom mas sg of er nouns and adjectives from
the second declension (puer, pulcher). Zero endings also appear in second
singular imperatives of third-declension active verbs (dic, duc, fer, fac (or
are their vowels lengthened in these examples?) </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> +English examples:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><sup><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> +</span></sup><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Greek
examples: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><sup><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> +</span></sup><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Hebrew
examples: third sg mas perf verbs</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>zeta</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the sixth letter
of the Greek alphabet: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>/</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-top:0in;
text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>zeugma</span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>: the use of a
word to mean two things at once. WH 289</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:10.0pt;text-align:
justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (in
a set with *paronomasia, *play on words)</span></p>
